Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large New Interest in Zebu Cattle Emerging


LENGTH: 534 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 1, 1995

DAKAR, Senegal - The International Livestock Research Institute says it is making efforts to make the tropical Bos Indicus cattle or Zebu more efficient in producing food from available feeds as it is biologically possible.

The institute, which has centers in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia and Nairobi, Kenya said in a recent publication that "investigations are in the process to determine how energy on the back (of Zebu) can profitably be converted into more meat or milk without compromising their adaptive strategies."

Since no cow has yet been designed to produce milk without a calf, the institute said, the challenge for researchers was "to improve nutrient utilization by Zebus in a way that would enable them to have calves more frequently and also milk per lactation." 

Currently, the institute provides national cross-breeding programmes with information on the productive and adaptive traits of indeginous breeds to enable them select those which need to be conserved in more efficient production systems or sperm banks.

"Once researchers understand the exact nature of the trade-off between adaptation and productivity in tropical Zebus, they will be able to select for those individuals that are genetically predisposed to increase their outputs of meat and milk," the institute said in an article published in October.

The new interest in the Zebu follows the disappointing performance of high-producing exotic Taurine breeds in the tropics.

Exposed to high disease challenge and insufficient feed, the institute said, the productivity of exotic breeds "decreases markedly, and many eventually succumb to environmental stress."

Exotic cattle crossbred with Bos Indicus are hadier than the pure ones "thanks to specific adaptive traits inherited from their local parents. But they require substantial feed and veterinary inputs to survive and to maintain reasonable high productivity in tropical environments."

Crossbred cattle are liked by farmers in the cool East African highlands, particularly Kenya where they are used for traction and milk production.

Ethiopia recently imported 100 crossbred cows from Kenya for on-farm testing of their performance as traction and milk-producing animals, the institute said in the article published by the Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Renewed Fight Against River Blindness


LENGTH: 1094 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 1, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Millions of Africans are expected to be saved from river blindness under a joint international medical programme launched Tuesday in Washington at a conference hosted by the World Bank.

River blindness, which is caused by a black fly that thrives in fast-flowing rivers, is a debilitating disease that also causes severe itching.

A World Bank statement obtained Tuesday by PANA in Lusaka said that the African Programme for Onchocerciasis control (APOC), will implement community-based drug treatment programmes in 16 African countries.

The programme will be jointly carried out by governments, non-governmental development organizations, bilateral donors, and international agencies, including the World Bank. 

A drug called 'Mectizan' is to be donated by its discoverer, Merck and Compnay of the United States to use in the anti river blindness campaign which is modelled on the highly successful Onchocerciasis Control Programme (OCP), established in 1974 to eliminate river blindness in 11 countries in West Africa.

The goal is the elimination of onchocerciasis as a major public health problem and impediment to socio-economic development throughout Africa.

According to World Health Organization (WHO) estimates, nearly 100 million people are at risk of the disease and 15 million are infected in the 16 countries to be covered by the new programme.

"Over the next generation, apoc will add 10 million years of productive labour to the 16 African countries covered by the programme and, by way of OCP, we know that the tools exist and the international collaboration can be garnered to fully control the disease and achieve results," World Bank President James Wolfensohn is quoted as saying at the launch of the programme Tuesday.

The African Programme for Onchocerciasis Control has been made possible by donor nations, sponsoring international organizations and a coalition of 11 non-governmental organisations to eradicate the disease from the rest of the continent.

The programme will be implemented in a broad swath containing parts of 16 countries and running from Cameroon to Ethiopia in the east and then south to Angola and Malawi.

It is based on the OCP which is on the verge of eliminating river blindness in 11 West African countries with a population of 32 million people.

The world bank was instrumental in the creation of the OCP and continues to play a major role as a leading sponsor and its second-largest donor.

The OCP, in addition to controlling the carrier of the disease (the blackfly) using a method called "vector control," uses a drug called 'Mectizan' (generically known as Ivermectin), donated by Merck and Co., Inc.

Merck announced in 1987 that it would give the drug free to approved river blindness programmes "for as long as needed to as many as need it." Currently some 13 million people are being treated with donated supplies of Mectizan, a number which will vastly increase with the new programme.

The non-profit Carter Center in Atlanta, Georgia, houses the Mectizan expert committee, which approves supply of the drug for major programmes.

The Mectizan donation programme, which oversees the drug's distribution, is also located at the Carter Center. Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter personally supports, and has been active in promoting the APOC.

In particular, he and the carter center support the model of global partnership for disease control throughout Africa represented by this new programme.

Like the OCP, the APOC will be co-sponsored by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), Food and Agriculture Organization, World bank and the World Health Organization and will be headquartered in Africa.

"If we move expeditiously and begin sustained mass treatment programmes now, there is a good possibility of eventually breaking the chain of transmission and elimnating the disease as a major public health problem throughout those major parts of Africa where the disease remains endemic," said Bruce Benston, head of the world bank's onchocerciasis unit.

River blindness, as it is commonly referred to or onchocerciasis is an ancient scourge spread by the bite of the tiny but aggressive blackfly. After the bite, parasites laid under the skin mature from larvae into thread-like adult male and female worms that live in nodules, ugly bumps under the skin.

The adult worms mate, giving birth to millions of immature worms that migrate to all part of the body. They may either die after living up to 30 months or be ingested by a female blackfly when she needs a meal of blood and then, after evolving into another stage, be transmitted to another human when the blackfly needs another meal. And the cycle begins all over again.

The immature worms cause havoc in the human body. Their presence and death cause rashes and unbearable itching. Over the years the skin becomes swollen and thickened, and there is often depigmentation leaving white patches.

With repeated infections, the disease becomes more severe. The immature worms also get into the eyes where they cause inflammation and scars which, over time, lead to permanent blindness.

Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria City Dwellers Run High Pollution Risk


LENGTH: 627 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 1, 1995
by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - Are you a resident of Lagos? If you are, then rush to your physician to check the level of carbon monoxide in your blood system.

Two separate medical studies here have revealed that city dwellers in Nigeria carry abnormally high levels of that gas in their blood stream due to air pollution.

According to medical experts, exceptionally high levels of carbon monoxide in the blood stream pose health hazards associated with shortness of breath, headache, fatigue, respiratory failure, unconsciousness and in some cases can lead to death. 

The acceptable international standard of the gas is 1.5 per cent, but the studies at the Nigerian Institute of Medical Research (NIMIR), Lagos, and the engineering department of the University of Lagos, revealed a high level of between seven and 10 per cent in the system of people they studied.

Dr. Gabriel Uko of the NIMIR said his three-member team arrived at their conclusion after a study involving 60 adults. The motive was originally to establish that cigarette smoking increased the level of carbon monoxide in the blood stream.

But the researchers discovered that smokers and non-smokers alike used in the study, manifested higher-than-normal concentrations of between seven and 10 per cent of the gas.

Also Dr. Olufunso Akindele of the engineering department of the the Lagos University said their own research had focused on pollution from engines of automobiles, especially second-hand vehicles imported from Europe, popularly known as "Tokunbos" in Nigeria.

He said the study showed that vehicles with faulty or worn-out engines, for which Lagos, Nigeria's economic capital is notorious, are a major source of carbon monoxide emission.

The research also found out that vehicles with poor cooling systems operate at high temperatures resulting in the formation of exhaust pollution. This problem is worse during traffic jams, for which Lagos, with a population of about six million people, is also famous.

Sources of the harmful gas in the blood stream, include emissions from exhaust system of automobiles, refuse burns, cigarette smoke and related pollutants.

Medical experts warn that while 10 per cent level of carbon monoxide could still be considered "mild", long-term exposure to air pollution is potentially dangerous. The risk could be extended through blood transfusion.

As a solution, Akindele of the University of Lagos suggests that second-hand vehicles be made to carry an exhaust re-cycling device to reduce temperature generated within the engine.

Other sources of pollution, including smoking, he added should also be checked to improve health and life expectancy, currently put at 48 years for men and 50 for women in Nigeria.

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Researchers Isolate Immune System Chemicals That Fight Aids


LENGTH: 867 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 1, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Researchers have identified natural substances in human cells that appear to slow the progression of Aids and that may open new avenues for treating the deadly disease, the latest issue of the Washington Line newsletter has reported.

According to the United States State Department publication, the researchers report that they have isolated several molecules secreted by a class of infection-fighting cells known as CD8s. These immune-system cells are thought to play a critical role in controlling the Aids-causing human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) during early stages of infection.

The findings will be published in the 15 December issue of the journal 'Science.' 

"We identified this family (of molecules) and found that they are very powerful," said Dr Robert Gallo, the director of the New Institute of Human Virology at the University of Maryland in Washington.

"There is something happening here," said Anthony Fauci, Director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. "There is no question that this is door-opening time."

The latest discovery was made by a team headed by Gallo and Paolo Lusso of the San Raffaele Scientific Institute in Milan, Italy. The research was conducted at the National Cancer Institute Laboratory in Bethesda, Maryland.

Aids researchers around the world have been trying to identify the natural HIV-fighting chemicals since 1989 when researchers at the University of California at San Francisco found that the body's CD8 immune system cells produced molecules that appeared to suppress the ability of HIV to copy itself.

Gallo and his team isolated three such molecules -- called rantes, MIP1-alpha and MIP1-beta -- that they believe work in concert to suppress HIV replication. The researchers found during testing that the molecules shut down several different strains of HIV reproduction as well reproduction of the Simian immunodefiiciency virus, a virus that causes Aids in monkeys.

All three molecules are known as chemokines secreted proteins involved in the body's wound-healing process.

Immunologist Sergio Romagnani of the University of Florence called the findings very convincing. "It provides direct evidence that the CD8 suppression of HIV is mediated by these chemokines," he said.

In another study published in the British journal Nature', a team at the Paul Ehrlick Institute in Langen, Germany, led by Reinhard Durth, reported the discovery of a different and apparently less powerful HIV-suppressing factor.

Fauci, after reviewing both studies, said he found the Gallo group's results especially convincing because "Gallo is getting really impressive suppression at low concentrations (of chemokines), and in the Kurth paper the concentrations are much higher."

Gallo said that while scientists do not yet know exactly how chemokines suppress HIV, they may still learn how HIV causes disease by studying their mechanism of action.

Gallo said that if the chemokines prove to be non-toxic in animal tests now underway, then they could possibly be used to control HIV for long periods of time in infected patients. The ultimate goal is to begin human clinical trials at Gallo's New Institute and at the San Rafaele Institute in Milan.

One cautionary note is that prior research with CD8 cells found that their level of HIV-suppressing activity appeared to decline as HIV-infected patients progressed to full-blown AIDS. Gallo said, however, that it may be possible to boost the body's production of HIV-suppressing chemicals.

Marc Girard of the Pasteur Institute in Paris, a leader of the French Aids vaccine effort, said that while it is too early to tell whether the chemokines will have practical applications, he is optimistic.

"You open a new window in the wall, and then you have to look through the window to see what you see," he said. "There's a whole new landscape out there."


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Weekly Press Review


LENGTH: 614 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 1, 1995
by Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal - The recent refugee summit in Cairo and the verbal war between the president of South Africa and the Nigerian military government are the top stories in Africa this week.

The Cairo meeting of four African leaders and former U.S. President Jimmy Carter made headlines in the Times of Zambia.

The state-owned newspaper said that the conference, which aimed to find a solution to years of ethnic fighting in Burundi and Rwanda was "without doubt a step in the right direction." 

However, the Bujumbura weekly, L'Independant, said Burundian politicians should have stayed away from the summit because it was engineered by parties that were not impartial.

The face-off between South African President Nelson Mandela and Nigerian military leader Sani Abacha also received attention from the The Guardian, a private Lagos daily.

Pointing to the execution of the nine Ogoni activists in Nigeria, the paper said that although there was nothing strange about the soured diplomatic relations between the two leaders, it is "worrisome" that Abacha and Mandela resorted to name-calling.

Because South Africans and Nigerians have shed blood for democracy and basic human rights, the paper said "It is quite in order that a threat to these essential values, this time in Nigeria, should be the subject of engaging disputation between the two countries." It added that the destiny and values of the black people are at issue here.

The paper said that no matter what Nigeria's relations are now with South Africa, Mandela, with his heroic glow, "illuminates the perception of every person and nation about Africa and black people everywhere."

Africans, it said, were eager to see both nations working together to emancipate the continent and raise its reckoning in the global scheme of things.

"For this reason, the two leaders can ill-afford the furor bordering on name-calling," it said.

Another political squabble surfacing in African editorials this week was the quarrel that Libya picked up with Mauritania for establishing diplomatic relations with Israel.

Libya attacked this development through its official press and the official Mauritanian News Agency, AMI, responded Thursday.

"Kadafi is badly placed to speak in the name of the Palestinain cause, and even less so claim to be their defender, since his has expelled thousands of Palestinians from Libya," AMI said.

It added that Kadafi condemned the rapprochement with Israel while asking the Turkish prime prime minister "to intercede on Libya's behalf with Tel Aviv".

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Southern Africa In New Anti-Malaria Drive


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 1, 1995
by Tawona Tavengwa, PANA Correspondent

KADOMA, Zimbabwe - Southern Africa is forging a unified strategy to fight malaria.

During a recent workshop in Kadoma, Zimbabwe, the World Health Organization in Africa announced a combat plan to malaria experts from the Southern African Development Community. 

The organization said that past failure to sustain control strategies cannot be repeated. It has designed training materials for district health teams that attend to 70-80 percent of all malaria cases in Africa.

The training will last from the year 1996 to 2000 and will reduce the incidence of malaria by at least 20 percent in 1977, the organization said.

Ei Hadi Benzerough, the organization's malaria expert said that malaria produces a considerable impact on the health of African children, mostly during the first five years of life.

"This increases the susceptibility to other infections," he said.

Although a curable disease malaria continues to kill between 1.5 and 2.7 million Africans every year and causes debilitating clinical illnesses to 300-500 million other people in Africa.

In some countries such as Malawi many malaria victims are resistant to the most effective anti-malaria drug, chloroquinem.

Zimbabwe Health Minister Timothy Stamps said about four million Zimbabweans are exposed to malaria each year.

Participants at the workshop said that the prevailing drought in southern Africa, although temporary, is helping to reduce the spread of malaria because mosquitos, the vectors for the disease, need water to lay their eggs.

Since the early 1990s malaria epidemics have been reported in Angola, Botswana, Mozambique, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zimbabwe and Zambia.

December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Francophone Leaders Arrive For Summit


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 1, 1995

COTONOU, Benin - French President Jacques Chirac was expected in Benin Friday to join 29 other leaders attending the twice-yearly meeting which groups France and 46 other French-speaking countries.

Chirac will inaugurate Friday a news conference centre which is the venue of the summit which begins Saturday. The centre cost 4.8 billion CFA francs (about 9.6 million dollars), of which France contributed 3 billion CFA Francs.

Meanwhile, Francophone foreign ministers ended their pre-summit meetings Thursday after the adoption of a number of resolutions to be submitted to the heads of state.

Benin foreign minister and chairman of the conference, Edgar-Yves Monnou, said the forum discussed the situation in Rwanda and Nigeria.

Nigeria is said to be seeking to become a member of the 'Francophone commonwealth' after it was suspended from the British-led Commonwealth because of its abuse of human rights.

Francophone countries cannot go beyond what the international community has already done, Monnou said.

He was referring to the suspension and other sanctions slapped on Nigeria in the wake of the recent hanging of nine Ogoni minority rights leaders including author Ken Saro-Wiwa by the military regime in Nigeria.

The ministers conference approved Wednesday a proposal to appoint a secretary general to oversee the actitivies of the organization.

The secretary-general, who would also be the Francophone official spokesperson, will be elected at the seventh summit in 1997.

Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria Britain Says Oil Embargo is Possible


LENGTH: 240 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 1, 1995

LONDON - Britain has not ruled out oil sanctions to force the Nigerian military government on a course to democratic rule.

British foreign minister Malcolm Rifkind told Zimbabwean journalists in London on Friday that if sanctions already imposed on Nigeria by the Commonwealth and the European Union did not yield speedy results, then oil sanctions could be applied. 

"We did not rule out oil sanctions. We think it is something that still needs to be considered," said Rifkind after his 30-minute meeting with Mugabe at his hotel in London.

He said there was already a total arms embargo on Nigeria in addition to restrictions on visas for functionaries of the military government and a suspension of non-humanitarian aid.

Reacting to Rifkind's pronouncement, Zimbabwe's foreign minister Stan Mudenge said "That is a major statement. It has never been said anywhere by the British."

9 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Burund Moderate Hutus Assassinated In Northern Burundi


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 1, 1995
by Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Eight moderate Hutus were killed in Ngozi, northern Burundi, this week in an unending political feud, the official news agency, ABP, reported Friday.

The agency blamed the assassinations on the Party for the Liberation of the Hutu People, a violent underground movement that targets the Tutsi minority in the country. 

Unknown persons have circulated leaflets warning Hutu moderates to stop collaborating with Burundi's Tutsi-dominated army and with the local authorities.

The Hutu, who comprise 85 percent of the country's 6.02 million people, dominate the government.

The army has been making continuous purges to rid the country of anti-government militias, termed officially here as bandits.

In a related incident, six Tutsi schoolchidren and five displaced Hutus were shot dead Thursday in two separate attacks at the Bubanza Technical Training School, in northwest Burundi, and in a nearby camp hosting displaced persons, the army said.

Fighting between the army and unidentified militias took place Wednesday in Bujumbura. Independent estimates say 100 militiamen and one soldier were killed.

However, state-run Radio Burundi reported Thursday that 20 attackers were killed and several others wounded.

The attacks come in the wake of a recent four-nation summit in Cairo to end the ethnic carnage in Burundi and neighboring Rwanda, brokered by former U.S. President Jimmy Carter.

Fighting between militias and the Burundi army has now escalated to include militia sabotage of state-owned infrastructure such as hydro-electric dams.

As a result, Bujumbura, has been without electricity for a month. This has seriously affected the economic sector, which Hutu extremists claim has been dominated by the Tutsi for decades.

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large ECA to Revitalise Itself


LENGTH: 334 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 3, 1995
by Felix Njoku and Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondents

DAKAR, Senegal - The United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) has taken measures to revitalize the institution, its executive secretary, Dr. K.Y. Amoaku said Sunday.

In an interview Amoako, who is in the Senegalese capital to attend a donors' conference of the U.N. African Institute for Economic Development and Planning, said he was emphasizing three key areas -- strategic focus, cost effectiveness and more effective partnerships. 

"Africa's problems are very many and the commission has very limited resources. We need to target our efforts and energy toward few clear, well-defined areas.

"We must have clearly defined indicators so as to be able to assess the impact of our work," he said.

Amoako said he has begun consultations with some African leaders on how best to make the commission's work more cost effective in areas where it can make a measurable impact.

It will also try to forge closer links with its partners, non-governmental organizations and other U.N. agencies, to enable the commission its play role in Africa's development.

The ECA, based in the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa, was established by the United Nations on April 29, 1958 to promote economic and social development in Africa.

December, 1995


Mauritania- Union of Arab Chemists Expells Country


LENGTH: 187 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 3, 1995

TRIPOLI, Libya - Mauritania has been expelled from the high council of the Union of Arab Chemists for having established diplomatic relations with Israel. 

Reports reaching PANA in Tripoli said the council made the decision after a two-day meeting in Damas, Syria.

Libya is currently the only Arab country to have officially condemned Mauritania for reopening diplomatic ties with Israel.

Tripoli has recalled its ambassador to Mauritania, cut off its economic aid and expelled all Mauritanian workers on its territory.

Mauritania has meanwhile closed down the Libyan cultural center in its capital, Nouakchott.

December, 1995


Sudan Women Reluctant To Use Contraceptives


LENGTH: 160 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 3, 1995

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Although contraceptives are available to 70 percent of Sudanese women only 10 percent are ready to use it, the country's Family Planning Association has said. 

The association said in a statement Saturday the use of contraception in Sudan remained low despite hazards posed by successive and early births .

A major cause of the reluctance to use contraceptives is fear of side effects, it said.

Other factors limiting the use of contraceptives is the high cost and male ignorance of the benefits of contraceptives.

Africa-at-Large Francophone Summit To Play Greater Role


LENGTH: 227 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 3, 1995

COTONOU, Benin - French-speaking countries meeting in Cotonou were Sunday expected to restate their determination to play a greater role in international affairs.

Sources at the sixth Francophonie summit said the countries were also expected to emphasize respect for minority rights. 

"Democracy, development, security and peace are necessarily related and inter-dependent," a draft declaration said.

The declaration would also commit its signatories to "redressing imbalances noted in economic and cultural exchanges in order to promote fair partnership and genuine solidarity."

Meanwhile, Sao Tome and Principe, a former Portuguese colony, and Moldavia, a former Soviet state neighboring Romania, were Saturday given associate membership by the grouping. This raises the number of members in the community to 49.

Africa News


December, 1995


Ghana Cedi Makes Big Gains At Open Exchange Counters


LENGTH: 334 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 5, 1995

ACCRA, Ghana - The Ghanaian cedi remained relatively stable in the official interbank market Tuesday, but continued to make big gains against the major currencies in the open bureaux de change in Accra.

The cedi has been appreciating steeply at forex bureaux over the past one week in what operators say was caused by a slump in demand for hard currency. 

"The traders (importers) have finished buying their goods for Christmas and demand is very weak.

"We have so much here that we can't even sell," operators told the Ghana News Agency in Accra Tuesday.

The currency hit an all time low in the past weeks selling at 1,540 to one U.S. dollar on average at Ehe Bureau de Change.

This compares with the exchange rate of 1,234.29 (buying and (1,403.57) cedis selling at the official interbank rate.

The pound sterling is now being bought at between 2,000 and 2,050 cedis.

The Deutsche mark, which hit its highest level of 1,075 cedis for buying and 1,100 for selling is now being bought at 900 cedis and sold at 1,000 cedis in the open market.

This compares with the official interbank average exchange rate of 984.29 cedis for one DM (buying) and 1,002.43 (selling).

Bureaux operators say the rates will continue to be low until after Christmas when traders resume imports.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria Naira Comes Under Pressure


LENGTH: 254 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 5, 1995

LAGOS, Nigeria - The parallel market exchange rate of Nigeria's local currency, the naira, has dropped to an all-time low in two weeks as threats of sanctions against the West African country continued to mount, forex dealers said Tuesday in Lagos.

In the wake of the Nov. 10 hanging for murder of nine Ogoni minority rights leaders, including author Ken Saro-Wiwa, the naira took a knock exceeding the 90-to-one-dollar mark in the black market. 

The Central Bank of Nigeria intervened in the second week of November injecting some 100 million dollars into the autonomous market at the rate of 85 naira to the greenback, the highest rate in 1995.

Meanwhile, the official rate of 22 naira to the dollar approved by the 1995 budget is being maintained strictly for government transactions.

Industrialists, including members of the Manufacturers Association of Nigeria, have called on the military government to abolish the dual exchange rate regime and introduce a unified system with the 1996 budget due to be announced in January 1996.

South Africa European Union Funds Projects


LENGTH: 146 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 5, 1995

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - The European Union has agreed to finance a number of projects in South Africa costing some 160 million U.S. dollars.

The head of the EU delegation in South Africa, Erwan Fouere, said the projects included provision of water and sanitation in rural areas, a land reform pilot program, a human rights program and a micro-projects program for small community-based development initiatives.

The EU has proposed that an amount of about 170 million dollars a year be provided to finance South African projects until 1999.

LANGUAGE: English

17 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Trade With Germany Stagnates


LENGTH: 494 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 5, 1995
by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - Africa is lagging behind in its trade with Germany while other developing countries in Asia and Latin America are recording double-digit growth in their trade with the European economic giant.

"Africa was the only region whose trade with Germany stagnated in 1994... or in some cases even declined slightly," according to the latest edition of the German information service Inter Nationes Bonn.

Quoting a study by the Hamburg-based Institute for Economic Research, the report said African accounted for about 11 per cent of Germany's trade with the developing world. 

It said Germany imported goods worth some 11,800 million deutschmarks from African countries in 1994, and exported goods worth 9,700 million (about 6,930 million U.S. dollars)

Although this represents a trade surplus of some 2,100 million deutschmarks in Africa's favour, the report noted that Asia and Latin America were doing better.

Texiles and clothing dominated German imports from the developing countries, accounting for 50 per cent while minerals, agricultural products and leather items were the other major imports.

However at the country level Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, recorded a trade surplus with Germany of 636 million deutschmarks in 1994, more than double the 1993 figure.

The report said the country's impressive trade figures with Germany were partly due to oil exports and positive results from the bilateral technical assistance projects between both countries.

Nigeria exported goods worth 1,440 million deutschmarks in 1994, nearly the same level in the previous year, while its German imports dropped by about 30 percent to 805.3 million deutschmarks.

Germany is regarded as one of the world's largest importer of goods from developing countries, with a total import of some 76,000 million deutschmarks in 1993.

Some 27 countries including 11 from Africa took part in the Import Fair'95 organized by the German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development in its efforts to promote exports.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


18 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Rwanda U.S. Wants to Extend U.N. Mission


LENGTH: 454 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 5, 1995
by Segun Adeyemi, PANA Correspondent

UNITED NATIONS - American, British and German diplomats at the United Nations have started negotiations to extend the stay of the multinational U.N. Assistance Mission in Rwanda (UNAMIR). The mission's current mandate ends Friday.

U.N. Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali announced Monday plans for the withdrawal of the 2,190-member force starting Friday. His report said the Rwandan government was opposed to the extension of the mission's mandate. 

But diplomats from the United States and the two European countries were reported to be consulting with Rwanda's permanent representative to the United Nations, Manzi Bakuramutsa, in an effort to persuade the his government to change its stand.

Sources close to the meeting said Tuesday the ambassador had asked for time to consult his government on the issue.

As part of the 'Save-Rwanda' effort, interested countries are also said to have started drafting a resolution that will modify the mission's mandate to focus on assisting the central African country in its reconstruction and rehabilitation, as well as in the repatriation of refugees.

The Rwandan government insisted it will allow the mission to continue its operations only on those grounds, rather than its present involvement in providing security and facilitating reconciliation.

Boutros-Ghali said in his report a continued presence could help to build confidence among the 1.6 million Rwandan refugees in Zaire and other countries and encourage them to return home.

"It is in this context that a large part of the international community believes that a further six-month extension of the current mandate of UNAMIR is desirable," he said.

UNAMIR, which comprises troops from 27 nations, was deployed last year after the massacre of an estimated 500,000 to one million people, mostly Tutsis and moderate Hutus, by elements of the former Rwandan government forces and militias. The government was dominated by Hutus.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

December, 1995


South Africa U.S. Vice President in South Africa


LENGTH: 294 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 5, 1995
by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG - The question of further sanctions against Nigeria ranks high on the agenda when South African President Nelson Mandela meets American Vice President Al Gore Tuesday. Mandela said Monday he will push for further sanctions against the Nigerian military accused of human rights abuses. The 54-member Commonwealth, the 15-nation European Union, and the United States already have imposed limited sanctions on Nigeria that include the recall of envoys from Lagos and arms embargoes.

Sources in Johannesburg said Gore and Mandela also will discuss relations with other countries with poor human rights records, like Iraq.)

Meanwhile, Gore and South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki will sign agreements involving business development, environmental protection, sustainable energy development, human resource development, and science and technology.

Further agreements on a national youth development commission to provide skills and training for South African youth, and on an American Peace Corps program for South Africa will also be signed.

In addition, an agreement on South African agricultural exports to the United States will be signed.

20 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Hooliganism Seaps into Soccer


LENGTH: 747 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 8, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondet

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian soccer has become dangerous. Coach John Shinde of Power Dynamos, the 1994 Premier League champions, would be the first to admit this.

Shinde, whose team is based in Kitwe, the soccer-crazy northern copper-mining town, was Friday reported to have "gone into hiding for fear of his life." 

Last Saturday Dynamos lost 0-1 to Nchanga Rangers from neigboring Chingola mining town. An agitated fan could not stomach the defeat. He followed the coach and threatened him with a revolver.
Shinde told reporters at his home in Kitwe that since the incident he has felt as if he has been placed "under house arrrest."

"He accosted me just outside the changing rooms as I was about to leave. He pulled out the revolver and pointed it at me. I was scared stiff," he told journalists.

A day after Dynamos lost the match, four other supporters went to Shinde's house and beat up his cousin.

"It is okay when they call you names and harass you in other ways but going to the extent of showing you a revolver is just too much, I could not believe my eyes when it happened," a frightened Shinde narrated Thursday, before going underground.

Shinde is a victim of what appears to be Zambian soccer fans' new "strategy" to get their teams to win matches.

Last week the Football Association of Zambia (FAZ) closed Nchanga Rangers' stadium because of "unruly behavior" by the home team supporters who are notorious for harassing visiting teams, and sometimes their own players.

The closure followed an earlier incident of assault on Power Dynamos players.

In another recent incident of soccer hooliganism, Kabwe Warriors fans in the midlands town of Kabwe invaded the pitch in which their players were training. The fans threatened to stone the players if they lost the upcoming matches.

Earlier this year Nkana supporters were blamed for "going a bit too far" when they threatened to paralyze operations at the local copper mine to protest the team's persistent defeats.

Members of the team's supporters club, most of whom are miners, later forced Nkana mine's general manager Earnest Pilula to explain the company's plans to reverse the team's dwindling fortunes.

This led to the sacking of team coach Ben Bamfuchile. His replacement is a veteran former national soccer team defender "Gentil" Kapambwe Mulenga, one of Nkana's own original products.

Before that, on two occassions, the irate Nkana fans had ambushed and stoned their own players and a visiting team to show their disgust over match losses.

Now it appears the new strategy has paid dividends.

Nchanga Rangers have managed to avert relegation to a lower division next year after a rather shaky start this season.

Nkana has also jumped into the top eight bracket on the elite league and so has Kabwe Warriors which is lying 4th from the top with 46 points from 28 games so far played. They still have two games for the season.
Wanderers and Dynamos are fighting to represent Zambia in the 1996 Africa Club Champions Cup and hopefully Shinde could "come out of hiding" by then if he manages to get his team retain the league title.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


21 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Weekly Press Review


LENGTH: 1014 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 8, 1995
by Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal - Anybody wondering why African leaders needed to attend the sixth Francophone summit could find the answer in the editorial pages of local newspapers.

The summit that closed in Benin on Monday is perceived as France's attempt to get Rwanda to accept orders as a condition for French recognition, and a lot of space was devoted to the the ironies of the Nigeria-South Africa conflict. Even the politics of a gas pipeline project in Nigeria were loudly addressed.

The thrice-weekly Kinshasa paper in Zaire, La Tempete Des Tropiques, the city's Le Potentiel, and the Cotonou newspapers in Benin, La Nation and Le Matin, all commented on the Francophone conference that closed in Benin Monday. 

La Tempete Des Tropiques asked if African leaders attending the conference realized that their presence actually encouraged French domination of the French-speaking world.

"Why are Africans not ridding themselves of this?" it said.

Besides continuing to support dictatorships in Africa, the paper said the genocide in Rwanda is a clear example of what French presence has done.

The Ugandan press criticized the tough conditions France set to normalize relations with Rwanda.

According to Rwandan President Pasteur Bizimungu, the conditions include a blanket amnesty for all but 10 perpetrators of the genocide in the country, a reforming of the army to include half of soldiers under the ruling power and half from the ousted government army, as well as the rotation of the army command.

France also said that if Rwanda stops criticizing its government, lets refugees return to their former host countries, accepts French as the official language, France would arrest some perpetrators of the genocide and promote a regional conference that would give proper recognition to Rwanda.

"The whole business sounds incredibly far-fetched but as the saying goes, truth is stranger than fiction," said the state-owned New Vision. " It is now up to the French government to confirm or deny..."

The Rwandan government, it continued, was grappling with "huge problems" and France should know that "a solution cannot be imposed from outside by a foreign government."

However, Le Potentiel said that the summit did achieve its major goal, which was to guarantee French as a linguistic and cultural diversity in Francophone countries.

Another gain was the collective desire to see Francophone grow into a worldwide political force. But this objective, it said, had its own limitations.

The arguement Le Potential did pose, joined by the privately-owned Benin newspaper Le Matin, was that the political force of Francophone influence goes back to the legacy of French culture and has its own limitations.

Le Matin noted that a resolution at the summit asked that the movement be more involved in conflict prevention.

"Suppose other linguistic groups adopt specific ways of settling their conflicts, what would become of the OAU and the UN?" it said.

The pro-government Cotonou daily, La Nation, said that the moderation of political resolutions adopted, especially on Nigeria and Rwanda, "clearly shows how difficult it is to get consensus on major delicate issues."

The state-owned Zambia Daily Mail, published in Lusaka, said sanctions against Nigeria for the hanging of nine minority rights activists is ironic in that South Africa is now leading that campaign.

"From the see-saw verbal battles now raging it might be possible to state that African countries stand to eventually lose for isolating one of their kind over a matter which the Nigerians erroneously view as 'internal'," it said.

The political and economic pressure on Nigeria, it continued, "must be a strong pointer to the fact that Africa will no longer tolerate" the violation of human rights under the guise of dealing with law breakers.

For its part, the privately-owned Nigerian paper Vanguard picked up attempts by Britain and South Africa to get the Shell Petroleum company to pull out of the country's liquefied natural gas project. This is part of the campaign to punish the country for the executions.

"We believe that the LNG project, which has already suffered much delay, is a laudable project which is both for the benefit of the oil producing areas and the nation in general," it said.

The project, it said, would mean significant reduced gas flaring -- a major cause of pollution in the producing areas -- and environmental degradation. It would also increase Nigeria's foreign exchange earnings.
TMP002

South Africa Multi-Million-Dollar Pact Signed With Taiwan


LENGTH: 214 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 8, 1995
by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent

PRETORIA, South Africa - South Africa and Taiwan signed a $40 million cooperation pact to set up a vocational training center for the South African National Defense Force. 

President Nelson Mandela and Taiwanese Ambassador I-cheng loh agreed Thursday that the center will train retired or redundant soldiers in various trade skills.

The center will focus on specific trades demanded by South Africa's Reconstruction and Development Program.

The agreement covers overall planning, design and reconstruction of workshops, including the supply and installation of equipment.

Up to 1,500 people will be able to recieve training, which will be provided in 31 different fields.

December, 1995


South Africa Stock Exchange Hits New High


LENGTH: 294 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 8, 1995
by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - The Johannesburg Stock Exchange has hit a new all-time high in trade as South Africa moves toward what is expected to be its best year of economic growth in a decade.

As shares continued their record-breaking, the exchange here listed market capitalization of companies that topped one trillion rand (about 275 billion dollars) for the first time. 

In terms of market capitalization and, this increase of almost 30 billion dollars since the start of the year reinforces the status of the JSE as the 10th biggest stock market in the world.

"It has been a very successful year for the JSE," said its Executive President Roy Anderson.

Anderson said that "Not only has there been a resurgence in new listings, we have also fulfilled our primary role of raising new capital."

During the 11 month period of January to November this year, some five billion dollars was raised in equity capital, compared to 2.5 billion dollars in 1994.

After lagging behind key global markets this year, blue chip industrials have led the JSE index into record territory.

24 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria Nigerian Crisis Weakens African Unity


LENGTH: 840 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 9, 1995
by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - The recent executions of nine Ogoni minority rights campaigners has excerbated the internal political crisis in Nigeria and further alienated the country's military government from the international community.

The hue-and-cry generated by the recent hangings also threatens the fragile unity in the marginalized African continent, according to political analysts in Lagos.

Of particular worry to pan-Africanists is the deepening diplomatic row between Nigeria and South africa over the hangings. The two are the continent's potential great nations. 

The political row threatens to overshadow Nigeria's moral and material contributions to world peace and, perhaps most importantly, the decolonization of Africa and the anti-apartheid struggle in particular.

The crisis follows the dismal democratizing and human rights records of successive military governments that have ruled the populous West African country for 25 of its 35 years of nationhood.

Many would not disagree with Nigerian Information Minister Walter Ofonagoro that "nobody can ignore a country with 100 million people."

But independent observers also insist that Nigeria must get its act together to remain relevant as a strong force among the comity of nations.

Nigeria's international rating took a steep dive in the aftermath of the decision by the previous military regime of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida to cancel the June 1993 presidential election, widely believed to hasve been won by millionaire-politician Moshood Abiola and which international observers judged to be free and fair.

Two years on, the measures imposed on Nigeria by some Western nations after the poll cancellation have continued to haunt the current military regime of Gen. Sani Abacha, who took power on Nov. 17, 1993.

Abiola, who defied the Abacha regime by declaring himself president in June 1994, is in detention awaiting trial for treason. Abacha insists his trial must go ahead despite appeals to release him.

Also, Nigeria's former military ruler Olusegun Obasanjo and his former deputy Maj.Gen. Musa Shehu Yar'adua are among 40 people in jail after they were convicted last March for plotting to overthrow the Abacha regime.

The sentences passed on the 40, ranging from life to death, were however commuted after a flood of clemency pleas from within and outside Nigeria.

The Abacha regime apparently feeling it would lose authority succumbing to another bout of appeals for clemency, ratified the death sentences passed on the nine minority rights leaders, among them writer Ken Saro-Wiwa.

Sanctions and threats of more punitive measures have poured from across the globe following the execution Nov. 10 of the nine minority rights leaders.

But what has surprised Nigerian officials has been the strong stance adopted by South African President Nelson Mandela, who has personally undertaken to lead the international campaign for Nigeria's isolation.

At one stage the diplomatic row degenerated into name-calling between Mandela and Abacha.

The situation has remained tense with the Nigerian government accusing Mandela of being "used" and a threat to African unity.

But apart from South Africa and Zimbabwe, which are leading the anti-Nigeria campaigns, other African countries have been restrained in their comments.

There is a growing fear the diplomatic wranglings between Pretoria and Abuja could creep into sports, which has been a unifying tool for a continent wracked by civil strifes.

Following South Africa's November decision to withdraw an invitation to Nigeria for an African four-nation soccer tournament, and the perceived fear of insecurity for Nigerian players, it is unclear if Nigeria will defend the Africa Cup of Nations, for which they are champions, to be held in January in South Africa.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


25 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Guinea Islamic Ministerial Conference Opens in Conakry


LENGTH: 307 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 9, 1995

CONAKRY, Guinea - Foreign Ministers from the Organization of the Islamic Conference (OIC) Saturday started their 23rd session in Conakry, Guinea, with the Middle East, Bosnia, Afghanistan and Somalia high on the agenda.

The meeting, chaired by Guinea's President Gen. Lansana Conte, has attracted at least 900 delegates. 

The conference is taking place amid serious disagreements among certain Arab states over the handling of the Middle East peace process.

One of them, Libya, expelled Palestinians to show its disgust over the peace agreement signed by Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) for limited autonomy in parts of the West Bank.

Tripoli has also been angered by Mauritania's decision to forge closer ties with Israel.

The conference is also taking place at a time when Islamic fundamentalists are causing havoc in several Arab countries, particularly Algeria and Egypt.

The ministers will examine the Islamic world's economic and cultural problems and examine a report on ways to improve the world-wide image of Islam.

The document was prepared by a select group during the last OIC conference held in Morocco in 1994.

Africa News


December, 1995


South Africa Political Killings Drop Sharply


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 9, 1995
by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South Africa experienced less politically-motivated violence in 1995 compared with 1994, according to a local human rights group.

South Africa's Human Rights Committee revealed Friday that the number of people killed in political violence in the country this year has plummeted to less than half the number for 1994. 

The committee, an independent watchdog body, announced that an average of 97 politically-related killings occured every month in 1995, compared with 223 monthly the previous year.

The main hot-spot remains the troubled Kwazulu-Natal province, in which two-thirds of the country's political deaths occurred this year. Nevertheless, the monthly death-toll in Kwazulu-Natal has also dropped by a half.

The national death-toll in political violence in November was 54 -- significantly below the monthly average for 1995.

"The continued presence of the police and the army in trouble spots," said the committee, "is an important factor which, taken together with with the political will of the Inkatha Freedom Party to demonstrate the province is governable, helps to provide and explanation".

But the committee pointed out that while deaths in Kwazulu-Natal had dropped, political intolerance remained as high as ever.

"The difference is that large-scale indiscriminate attacks have given way to more well-organized targeted attacks against specific individuals."


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Ruling Party Postpones Convention


LENGTH: 494 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 9, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's ruling party, the Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) has postponed its third national convention for two days.

The crucial meeting in which party officials will be elected will now be held Dec. 19-21.

MMD national secretary, retired Brig. Gen. Godfrey Miyanda announced in Lusaka late Friday that the convention was postponed because of logistical problems. 

Sources close to the ruling party said the party was still looking for money to hire transport to ferry delegates from across the country for the meeting.

More than 1,000 party members are expected to attend the convention and MMD publicity chairman Sikota Wina has said the party needed about 600,000 U.S. dollars to transport, accommodate and feed the delegates.

The convention's business includes election of a new national executive committee and making ammendments to the party's manifesto.

Senior MMD officials said recently the meeting, scheduled for 1996, had to be held this year "to give time for the wounds to heal" for leaders who would lose the party elections, so as to enable them to assist the party win the general elections next year.

Former Vice President Levy Mwanawasa is campaigning to challenge President Frederick Chiluba for the party's presidency.

Mwanawasa, who resigned from Chiluba's cabinet, has accused the president of derailing the party's original ideals to eliminate poverty and restore confidence in the government.

President Chiluba is currently embroiled in a dispute over his citizenship following press claims that he was a Zairean alien.

The MMD has recommended in a draft constitution for the country that only second-generation Zambians should in future qualify to hold the office of president.

Political observers believe the MMD convention might decide to drop the clause to avoid possible lawsuits from injured parties should President Chiluba be retained as party president and presidential candidate for the 1996 elections.

South Africa New Pact Signed With Cuba


LENGTH: 254 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 9, 1995
by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South Africa and Cuba have signed a bilateral investments protection agreement.

The pact ensures protection for South African companies investing in Cuba and vice versa. 

The agreement was signed by South Africa Trade and Industry Minister Trevor Manuel and Cuban Foreign Investment and Economic Cooperation Vice-Minister Noemi Benitez de Mendoza.

Last month the two countries signed another agreement under which several hundred Cuban doctors will be coming to South Africa from next year to assist with rural primary health care. The first batch of Cuban doctors is expected in February 1996.

Earlier this week South Africa and Taiwan signed a 40-million U.S. dollar co-operation pact under which Taiwan will set up a vocational training centre for retiring or retrenched members of the South African National Defense Force.

29 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Scientists Converge in Kampala for Aids Conference


LENGTH: 547 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 9, 1995
by Moses Draku, PANA Correspondent

KAMPALA, Uganda - Some 2,600 scientists and researchers are gathering in the Ugandan capital, Kampala, for the 9th African International Conference on Aids and Sexually Transmitted Diseases which opens on Sunday.

The meeting on the theme " Hopes and Challenges" will address the serious threat AIDS poses to mankind and seek solutions to the HIV/AIDS pandemic.

Conference chairman Sam Okware said the participants will try to find answers to the questions: What's the future like? Where have we gone wrong? Why have we failed so far? What are the challenges? 

The conference will be the first opportunity for scientists to examine the qualities of an anti-AIDS drug discovered by a hitherto unnamed Ugandan scientist.

Delegates will also here speeches and statements from the international steering committee, national organizing committee and top bureaucrats in the United Nations agencies involved in the battle against HIV/AIDS.

More than 800 abstracts are to be presented during plenary sessions and as posters.

Among well-known scientists expected here is Dr. Luc Montagnier who headed the French team that first isolated the HIV type 1 virus and Prof. Souleymane M'boup of Senegal who discovered the HIV type 2 virus.

African traditional healers will also take part in plenary and poster sessions to show what they have to offer in the campaign against the killer-disease.

Conference organizers said four plenary sessions will be held daily at the conference centre with poster sessions and satellite meetings in conference rooms of hotels around the Ugandan capital.

The conference will be the second of its kind to be held in Africa. The first was held in Marrakech, Morocco, in 1993.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO) HIV/AIDS has hit sub-Saharan Africa more than any other region in the world.

Presently the estimated total of HIV infections exceeed 10 million with slightly more women than men infected.

WHO estimated HIV prevalence among adults world-wide was over 13 million in 1994.

Some 6,000 people are infected each day. By the year 2000, the cummulative total of HIV infection world-wide could reach 30 to 40 million, with 10 million developing AIDS by then.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


30 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zimbabwe Investors Await Positive Signals From Government


LENGTH: 454 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Foreign and domestic investors on Zimbabwe's stock market are keenly awaiting positive signals from the government on its commitment to the second phase of market reforms launched five years ago, a major stock broking firm said on Tuesday.

Sagit Stockbrokers, said the market was also looking ahead to the appointment of a new finance minister, to replace the late Ariston Chambati, who died in October, barely five months after he took office.

In addition, progress on privatisation of loss-making public enterprises and moves to trim the government were also keenly awaited, Sagit said. 

"We are currently on an IMF (International Monetary Fund) shadow programme which is demanding the above and seems to be having some effect," it said.

"We will probably be accepted back onto a full programme as they (IMF) have a lot of credibility invested in us. But if we aren't, that will give a very negative signal," Sagit said.

The IMF, a major backer of Zimbabwe's market reforms officially launched in 1991, in September this year suspended disbursement of crucial balance-of-payments assistance to Zimbabwe, saying it was not happy with high government spending and inflation.

The IMF board was expected to meet later this month to review measures taken by Zimbabwe, following which it was expected to recommend that lending should resume early in 1996.

Among other conditions, the IMF is demanding tighter government spending controls and inflation to be cut to 17 percent by mid-1996, down from 24 percent in October 1995.

Sagit said Zimbabwe stood to lose credibility in the international community if it failed to return to an IMF-supported reform programme.

"An example of how we are rated and what we stand to lose is given in the IFC (International Finance Corporation) report on building the private sector in Africa. For their 1995 year, Zimbabwe had the highest direct IFC loan and equity investment out of 33 African countries," Sagit said.

Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria 400 Delegates for All-Politician Summit


LENGTH: 507 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995
by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent

Lagos, Nigeria - Some 400 delegates are to attend the Nigerian All-Politician Summit scheduled for Lagos, Thursday, to draw up strategies for resolving the political and social problems of the country, organisers of the event said Tuesday.

Speaking on the final arrangements for the summit, the joint secretaries of the conveners' committee, Olu Falae and Alhaji Baba told journalists in Lagos that five former top elected leaders from each of Nigeria's 30 states had been invited to the summit.

Various groups and associations have also been invited, according to the joint secretaries who said the necessary steps had also been taken to ensure a trouble-free summit. 

"We will like to see government as our partner in this forum and we don't expect any negative response from any quarter," said Falae, a one-time secretary to Nigeria's federal government and a former presidential aspirant.

Falae said a chairman would be elected from among the politicians at the summit.

The statement was designed to put to rest official suspicion that the proposed summit had a hidden agenda.

The Nigerian government's special duties minister, Wada Nas, on Sunday warned that if the summit is for "any hidden agenda or motive", it would be rejected outright.

Government had reportedly invited a cross-section of politicians to discuss Tuesday its concern about the forthcoming summit but had to postpone the meeting for the second time until after Thursday's meeting.

Analysts see this as a tacit approval by the military administration of the much-talked-about summit to be held in the wake of international hostility against the country's military regime.

Criticism of the regime led by Gen. Sani Abacha for its lack of progress in returning the country to democratic rule peaked with the execution last month of nine minority rights activists, including the author, Ken Saro-Wiwa.

"There's nothing sinister about the summit as was alleged in some quarters," Baba said.

"Those invited in our opinion represent some of the credible and knowledgeable leaders in the country," he added.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


32 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria Soccer: FIFA Dumps Nigeria Again, Selects Malaysia for 1997


LENGTH: 587 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995
by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - Assurances given last month in Lagos by Joao Havelange, president of the International Federation of Association Football (FIFA), to make a case for Nigeria to host the Under-20 World Soccer Cup in 1997 have landed on the rocks with the endorsement of Malaysia to host the event.

Havelange, who was in Nigeria to inspect facilities for the tournament, failed in Paris Monday night to tilt the scale in favour of the West African country as promised eager government officials during his four-day visit in November.

With an 11-9 vote, FIFA's executive committee agreed that the championship should be held in Malaysia as provisionally decided in 1993. 

The special vote, according Nigerian Football Association sources, became necessary after a confident Havelange failed to convince the Asian country to step down for Nigeria.

The Asians, reportedly backed by the Europeans, held to their guns to edge Africa out of the soccer extravaganza.

Sport pundits in Lagos believe this was to be expected because the FIFA meeting came exactly one week after the European Union countries slammed limited sports sanctions on Nigeria for its poor human rights record, especially the recent execution of nine minority rights activists including the author, Ken Saro-Wiwa.

They pointed out the European Union's firm resolve not to allow Nigeria to host the event.

For Nigerians, Monday's decision was a new addition to three previous attempts to host the championship.

Nigeria was first considered for the 1989 tournament but failed to qualify after FIFA found it was simply not ready.

A provisional award for the 1991 edition to Nigeria was withdrawn after a two year-ban later clamped on the country because of discrepancies in the ages of players who represented it in previous championshps.

Portugal was later granted the right to host the competition.

In 1993, FIFA considered Nigeria for the 1995 edition but withdraw the offer after an outbreak of meningitis near one of the four venues of the tournament. Qatar staged the event earlier this year.

The immediate reaction of Nigeria's sports minister Jim Nwobodo was to urge Nigerians to take the outcome calmly.

"The closeness of the result indicated Nigeria still has many friends in the world," he told journalists.

Nwobodo was howver full of appreciation to Havelange and Issa Hayatou, president of the Confederation of African Football (CAF), for standing by Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


33 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Niger Niamey Resumes Relations IMF And World Bank


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995

NIAMEY, Niger - The West Afrian state of Niger has signed a memorandum of understanding with the World bank After breaking ranks with the Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for eight years.

Under the document signed by prime minister Hama Amadou and the director of the World Bank department for West and Central Africa, Olivier Lafourcade in Niamey on Sunday, Niger will resume structural adjustment of its economy with support from the Bank and the Fund. 

Officials said the country will immediately receive some eight billion CFA Francs (about 16 million US dollars, and 51 billion CFA, francs (about 102 million dollars) later under the bank's Enhanced Structural Adjusment Facility (ESAF).

The delay in reaching an agreement with the Bretton Woods institutions had hampered the implementation of several projects and discouraged donors from providing direly needed funds.

ESAF will run for three year (1996-1998) during which the country is expected to achieve four percent economic growth rate.

Investment rate is projected to increase from 10.5 percent of GNP in 1994 to 14 percent of GNP in 1998, or 261 billion cfa francs.

Investment in the social sectors -- education, health and water -- will absorb 39 percent of the resources officials said.

ESAF is expected to increase revenue from taxes to 11 percent of GDP and rationalise public spending.

Investment will focus on loans to to productive private sectors while public companies will be restructured.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


34 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Kwacha Maintains Stability


LENGTH: 240 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995
by Musenga Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - The kwacha continued to be stable against the currencies of Zambia's three major trading partners -- the United States dollar, the South African Rand and the British Pound sterling -- this week.

Currency dealers said the average kwacha exchange rate against the pound remained stable at 1495.88, while the average selling rate of the kwacha against the dollar stabilised at 962. 

The local currency was also stable against the South African rand, exchanging at an average of 263 per rand.

Finance analysts on Tuesday attributed the stability of the local currency to recent agreements reached with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank.

The IMF last week granted Zambia 1.3 billion dollars loan. It is also seeking a further 800 million dollars from the Fund for balance of payments and other support.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Less Food Imports Needed, Says SADC


LENGTH: 280 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia needs to import some 557,000 tonnnes of famine relief maize this year as against the original estimate of 798,000 tonnes, according to a Southern African Development Community (SADC) report published Tuesday.

Zambia, along with other neighbouring southern African states, has suffered drought over several past rain seasons. 

The southern African sub-region will, meanwhile, need to import a collective total of 3.9 million tonnes of maize instead of the 7.1 million tonnes forecast earlier, according SADC says.

Zambia needs about USD 120 million to bring in the staple. Some donor countries have already contributed toward this.

The country is currently importing the maize from South Africa and Tanzania, using mainly private importers.

The new SADC estimates follow a revision of South Africa's own maize stocks. SADC had originally thought South Africa needed to import some 3 million tonnes but later discovered the country needs only 532,000 tonnes to bridge its shortfall.

December, 1995


Zaire Government Orders Closure of Brothels


LENGTH: 187 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995

KINSHASA, Zaire - Zaire's justice minister, Joseph N'Singa Udjuu, has ordered the closure of all brothels in the country. 

In a circular from his office, Udjuu said the brothels had become a public nuisance in especially Kinshasa, the capital.

He told the authorities to ensure that all violators of the order were prosecuted.

Some observers in Kinshasa however said the order would have little effect because prostitution was a big business tolerated by the local authorities who levy a daily tax on each room used by those in the trade.

Seen as playing an important role in the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases, brothels have stirred much controversy in Zaire.

December, 1995


Nambia and Zambia Conference Warns of Possible Strife


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995

WINDHOEK, Nambia - The second conference of "sister" parties in Southern Africa, ended in the Namibian capital Tuesday with a communique urging more respect for former heads of state and other political leaders.

The call was prompted by reports from the United National Independence Party of former Zambian president Kenneth Kaunda to the conference hosted by Namibia's ruling SWAPO. 

The UNIP delegation said Zambia's Movement for Multiparty Democracy government was persecuting Kaunda and had created a level of political tension that could plunge Zambia into political chaos.

In a report titled "The Political Situation in Zambia Since the Last Presidential and General Elections in 1991", UNIP Secretary General Sebastian Zulu charged Zambia was likely to face political instability whose effects could spill over its borders, if the MMD government continued its persecution of Kaunda.

Zulu said labelling Kaunda a Malawian and threatening him with deportation did not augur well for peace in the country.

He said civil strife in Zambia could affect the entire southern African region.

UNIP was the only opposition party invited to the three-day conference. The conference agenda included political cooperation among countries in the region, unemployment and demobilisation of combatants of the liberation wars, and cultural and economic cooperation among political parties in southern Africa.

The parties represented at the conference included the 'Chama Chamapinduzi' of Tanzania, the MPLA of Angola, the BDP of Botswana, the BCP of Lesotho and Malawi's UDF.

Cameroon Tobacco Processing Plant Opens


LENGTH: 187 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995

YAOUNDE, Cameroon - The Industrial Tobacco Company of Cameroon (SITABAC) has opened a plant for the production of cigarettes at Bokito, some 140 kilometres from Yaounde, estimated to have cost 14 billion CFA Franc (about 28 million US dollars). 

Officials said on Tuesday the plant has the capacity to process up to to four tonnes of tobacco per hour. Its main activity is to process tobacco leaves into cigarettes.

The premises which covers an area of 3,895 square meters includes several warehouses and some 30 other buildings currently under construction.

Deputy prime minister in charge of local government, Gilbert Andze Tsoungui, presided at the inauguration of the plant on Saturday.
