39 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Press Association Checks Press Reports on Chiluba Nationality


LENGTH: 480 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Press Association of Zambia (PAZA) has described as "serious" reports by the controversial Post newspaper that President Frederick Chiluba was born in Zaire while recent investigations carried out by a group of Zambian journalists revealed that he was born in Kitwe's Wusakile township.

"The issue is serious. PAZA will meet soon to make its stand known over the matter and a statement will be issued soon after the executive meets," said PAZA vice president Mike Daka. 

The Post recently reported Chiluba had been born at Chibambo mission in Zaire of Zairean parents and that claims that he had been born in Kitwe on the Zambian Copperbelt were false. The Post published a copy of what it said was Chiluba's birth certificate. The document showed he had been born at Chibambo mission in Zaire of Zairean parents.

The issue is of importance as Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy has proposed constitutional reforms that would bar first generation nationals from contesting Zambia's presidential elections. The proposal had been widely seen as an attempt to bar former president Kennneth Kaunda, whose parents came from Malawi, from standing in the elections.

A group of Zambian journalists last week visited Chibambo mission hospital in Zaire where the authorities refuted Post newspaper reports that Chiluba had been born there.

The Zairean authorities said Chiluba could not have been born at the mission hospital because it had been built in 1944 while the president was born in 1943.

They named a Lusato Bondo as the person who had forged the birth certificate used by the Post.

The same group of journalists visited Musangu village in Zambia northern Luapula province where a senior headman gave an account of Chiluba's life. He said the Zambian president was born in Wusakile in Kitwe but grew up in the village before going back to the Copperbelt to find work.

The press assistant to the president, Richard Sakala, said the Post story was a fabrication designed by members of the opposition to discredit Chiluba.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


40 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large People With HIV Can Survive 20 Years


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995
by Moses Draku, PANA Staff Correspondent

KAMPALA, Uganda - People with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV-2) can survive with it for 20 years without developing AIDS, researches say.

A study conducted on prostitutes in the Senegalese capital, Dakar, showed that only one of the infected women developed the disease after nine years (1985-95), AIDS expert Phyllis Kanki said. 

Kanki, of the Harvard Aids Institute in Boston, United States, participated in the study. She was addressing the Ninth International Conference on AIDS and Sexually Transmitted Diseases in Africa, taking place in Kampala, Uganda.

She said that HIV-2 provided natural protection against HIV-1. The latter is commonly found in east and Southern Africa countries. Scientists say it is 50 per cent different from HIV-2 mainly found in West Africa.

Commenting on the study, the World Health Organisation Regional Director for Africa, Dr. Ebrahim Samba said: "If one can survive with the virus for 20 years without developing AIDS, this will give us enough time to find a vaccine."

He said, as the AIDS epidemic progressed, many people with the virus would recover.

"This is the trend and history of epidemics. They rarely wipe out a generation," he said.

Kanki, told PANA that some studies showed that people with HIV-2 survived for an average of between six and seven before developing AIDS.

Another descovery in HIV-2 infected persons is that the possibility of mothers passing the virus to their babies during birth is minimal. In most cases, there is no transmission to the new born.

However, Kanki said that the ratio of infection by mothers who are hIV-1 positive to new born babies is about one in three.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


41 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria More Crude Lifted As Threats Of Embargo Mount


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995
by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - Shrugging off threats of an oil embargo, Nigeria increased crude oil production in November 1995 to 2.02 million barrels per day (MBD), according to data released by the National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC).

Supplies to the market, however, remained at the 1.865 (MBD) level allocated to the country by the 12-nation Organisation of Petroleum Exporting countries (OPEC).

Statistics from the NNPC which oversees production and marketing of the country's oil, show that output for November was higher than the 1.970 MBD produced in October. 

But petroleum ministry officials say crude oil supply to the international market was still restricted to the OPEC quota despite rising production.

The statistics also show that crude oil production had been on the upward trend in the last five months.

In July, output was 1.820 MBD, rising to 1.900 MBD in August and 1.950 MBD in September.

Officials link the performance to the resolution last August of a cash-call problem between the government and its joint venture partners, especially Shell.

Nigeria, the seventh highest oil-producing nation in the world had been facing threats of an oil embargo due the lack of progress by its current military administration in returning the country to democratic rule.

The situation came to a head with the execution last month of nine minority rights activists, including the author Ken Saro-Wiwa, who in his life time campaigned bitterly against government and oil companies operating in Ogoniland, his native home, for the lack of development and the environmental degradation of the area.

Nigeria like other members of OPEC has contributed to the current rise in the organisation's production.

OPEC production rose to 25.67 MBD last month, more than one million barrels per day over its ceiling of 24.52 MBD.

Given the relatively low oil price on the market and forecasts of higher production by competitors, the vienna-based body agreed last month to maintain its 24.52 MBD ceiling for the first six months of 1996.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

December, 1995


South Africa Hotel Industry Heading For Boom


LENGTH: 307 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995
by Lionel Williams, PANA Staff Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - The South African hotel industry is heading for an all-time record year in 1995.

Figures released Monday by the Central Statistical Service show that hotel bookings for the first nine months of this year exceeded 10-million bed-nights, about one-third above bookings for the first three-quarters of 1994. 

Europe remains the main source of visitors to South Africa with more than 50 percent of the total number of visitors up to the end of September 1995. Africa is the next highest source, with 17 per cent, followed by the Far East with 15 percent.

The Johannesburg Star newspaper reports that it is against this background that the giant Hyatt International group decided to move into South Africa with a 50-million-dollar hotel in the city.

And in neighbouring Sandton, the Hilton International group is busy constructing 60-million-dollar hotel, and Stocks Hotels and Resorts will be opening its 40 million dollars hotel in May 1996.

In addition, multi-million-dollar projects are being planned for more hotels in the cities of Cape Town and Durban, and in the scenic Mpumalanga province.

December, 1995


Ghana and Zimbabwe Ashanti Gold Goes For Cluff PLC


LENGTH: 427 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 12, 1995

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Ghana-based Ashanti Goldfields, has made a formal bid for the Parent company of Cluff Resources Zimbabwe Ltd, based in the United Kingdom.

The bid for Cluff Resources PLC by Ashanti, announced at the end of last week, comes in the wake of increased investor interest in the company, which has lucrative mining interests in Zimbabwe, Ghana and Tanzania.

Reports of the offer lifted Cluff Resources Zimbabwe's share price during trading in minings on the local stock exchange on Friday, which ended the day at 160 cents (18 US cents). 

Cluff announced last month it had received an approach which could lead to an offer being made for the entire issued share capital of the company.

Since the offer was made, the UK company had been consulting with its financial advisors, Samuel Montagu, and had warned shareholders not to expect any further announcement for several weeks.

Market analysts said on Monday the takeover of Cluff Resourcesl PLC would give Ashanti a firm foothold in Zimbabwe, where cluff's subsidiary owns the country's largest underground gold mine near Harare.

Cluff Resources Zimbabwe Ltd recently announced it had entered into a joint-venture with another local mining firm to develop a major gold field some 200 km north-east of Harare.

It was also interested in another joint venture to explore for diamonds with Masasa Mines, the Zimbabwean subsidiary of Australia's Delta Gold NL.

Ashanti, in which the Ghanaian government and the international conglomerate Lonrho PLC are the main shareholders, this year said it wanted to open an office in Zimbabwe and spearhead its exploration programme in southern and eastern Africa.

The company, located some 180 km north-west of Accra, was last year reported to have found gold reserves of over 17 million ounces, making it one of the world's richest mines.

LANGUAGE: English

44 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria Six Million Suffer from Diabetes


LENGTH: 334 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 13, 1995
by Randy Cormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - About six million Nigerians are suffering from diabetes, according to a news release from the Diabetic Association of Nigeria.

The disease currently affects 2.8 percent of the adult population above the age of 15. 

Quoting its findings from a survey conducted by Nigeria's national experts committee on non-communicable diseases, the association said ignorance and poor education about the disease are causing unnecessary suffering and premature death among thousands of Nigerians annually.

"With proper education, as much as 80 percent of diabetic complications can be avoided," the association said.

According to the experts late diagnosis or poor management of the condition after diagnosis can lead to complications including heart and kidney diseases, failed pregnancy, blindness and amputation of limbs.

Diabetes is partially hereditary and partially caught through the adoption of certain lifestyles, especially excessive consumption of carbohydrates and sugar.

About 100 million people (the population of Nigeria) have diabetes in the world.

This figure is expected to double by the year 2010 unless drastic measures are taken to alter the situation.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria Soccer: Are The Eagles Camping In Holland Or Isreal?


LENGTH: 560 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 13, 1995
by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's national soccer team coach Dutchman Bonfrere Jo is having problems obtaining visas for his technical crew of three trainers and four home-based players for a scheduled training tour of Holland.

Jo selected a squad of 26 players -- 22 of them European-based pros -- who have been called to camp this week in Holland to prepare for the Africa Cup of Nations tournament to be held in South Africa in January 1996.

The Super Eagles technical adviser who was to leave for Holland Wednesday tonight has yet to obtain visas the seven players and crew to fly out to Holland. 

The Dutch embassy is reluctant to grant him visas apparently because of the European Union's sports sanctions imposed against Nigeria following last month's execution by the military regime of nine minority rights activists including writer Ken Saro-Wiwa.

The sports sanctions expressly forbid the issuance of visas to Europe-bound Nigerian teams.

Jo told newsmen about an alternative training site should he fail to secure the visas.

"It is somewhere near Tel-Aviv, in Israel," he said.

"Politicizing sports is not good. It's bloody politics but we will go to a nice place", he said in anticipation of the rejection of the Eagles in Holland and the possible shifting of camp to Isreal.

Israel has been critical of the international community for its hostility towards Nigeria.

Israeli ambassador in Nigeria Gadi Golan has been very vocal about his country's position on the matter.

Despite the last-minute hitches being encountered the Nigerian Football Association said wednesday it was continuing with preparations for the Africa Cup of Nations match.

Meanwhile, the government is expected to announce Monday whether or not Nigeria will participate in the tournament.

Youth and Sports Minister Jim Nwobodo cited national pride, diplomatic implications and safety for the players as reasons why the Super Eagles may not go to South Africa to defend the cup they won in Tunisia last year.

"If a 30,000-dollar-fine is all Nigeria would suffer in the event of a pull-out, we can afford it," a ministry official told PANA.

Apart from suspension from subsequent editions of the Africa Cup of Nations, a country that withdraws faces other sanctions to be decided by Caf, Africa's soccer governing body.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December, 1995


Burundi U.N. Summons International Inquiry Commission


LENGTH: 347 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 13, 1995
by Ferdinand Bigumandondera, PANA Correspondent

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The United Nations International Commission of Judicial Inquiry will investigate acts of violence in Burundi that began two years ago.

Although its mandate has not been specified, the commission will investigate the massacre of over 50,000 civilians and other acts of violence that followed the death of Melchior Ndadaye, the first democratically elected president in Burundi. He was assassinated in a coup attempt Oct. 21, 1993.

After talking with the Burundian government, the commision will make recommendations on legal, political or administrative measures.

The commission will also work to bring to trial the perpetrators of the violence in order to promote national reconciliation in the country.

About 70 soldiers suspected of taking part in the coup attempt and 4,500 people suspected of active participation in the 1993 massacres are currently detained at Bujumbura central prison awaiting trial.

However, pointing to recent attacks, a UN spokesperson in Burundi said the commission is operating in a climate that does no facilitate its work.

In the North Mutanga area, where the commission is based, the spokesperson said that armed gangs who belong to the ethnic Hutu majority killed more than 50 people and wounded many others.

The commission, which arrived in Burundi on Oct. 28, said Wednesday that five of its members will soon leave Bujumbura, the capital, to consult with the New York headquarters.

December, 1995


Science, Medicine and Technology WHO to Reinforce Team in the Ivory Coast and Liberia


LENGTH: 267 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 13, 1995

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - Although only one case of the Ebola virus has been confirmed in the Ivory Coast, a team of World Health Organization (WHO) experts will investigate the situation.

Director of Program Management at the WHO office for Africa Dr. Ayite D'Almedia said the situation in the Ivory Coast is far from that experienced in the Zairean town of Kikwit where over 200 people died from the virus in January-May this year. 

D'Almedia added that the victim of Ebola, said to have contracted the virus in Liberia and carried it to the Ivory Coast, will recover.

Because insecurity makes it difficult to have access to the area, the WHO regional office has asked Liberian authorities to provide security for the experts.

D'Almedia said that the WHO will send two epidemiologists, one virologist and one expert in logistics to the Ivory Coast and neighboring Liberia where three other cases are currently under observation.

WHO and local experts are also investigating the outbreak of cholera and yellow fever in the area.

December, 1995


Zimbabwe Mugabe Warns Against Violent Demonstrations


LENGTH: 334 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 13, 1995
HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe will deal ruthlessly with people who cause disorder through violent demonstrations, President Robert Mugabe said Wednesday.

He singled out the Zimbabwe Human Rights Association, popularly known as Zimrights, saying it thrived on division and was bent on creating chaos. 

"When in the name of human rights zimrights becomes zimlooters, blatantly violating our zimlaws, is the zimgovernment expected to view such criminal behaviour with folded hands?" he said.

He termed these groups "gangster organizations" and warned that they would be "descended upon with the full force of the law".

He said, "Let zimrights, so called, therefore know that we have a formidable structure of zimprisons waiting for its zimlooters."

Mugabe made these remarks in reference to recent demonstrations against the accidental fatal shooting by police of two pedestrians.

The demonstrators became violent, burnt cars and looted property worth some two million Zimdollars (about 222,220 U.S. dollars).

He said crime levels in the country had become unacceptable and needed to be immediately addressed as people were now living in constant fear of becoming victims of robbers, tricksters and conmen.

A no-nonsense law and order president, Mugabe was among leading personalities in the recent international campaign to punish the Nigerian military regime for its execution in November of nine human rights activists.

December, 1995


Ghana FAO Boss Arrives


LENGTH: 240 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 18, 1995

ACCRA, Ghana - United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization Director-General Jacques Diouf arrived in Accra Sunday on a four-day official visit.

Diouf said he was in the Ghanaian capital to exchange views with government officials and see how best his organization could support the country's effort in increasing agricultural production. 

As the organization's regional centre for Africa, he said, it was important for him to get first hand knowledge of the operations of the Accra office.

He said the FAO was planning a summit on increasing food production to be held in Rome, Italy, in November 1996. The summit will give guidelines on how the FAO could feed some 800 million people who do not have enough to eat.

Diouf said it was also the priority of his organization to decentralize its offices and change its structure to include a division to cater for women, who produce about 50 percent of food in developing countries.

Africa News


December, 1995


Mozambique U.S. Embassy Accused Of Restricting Press Freedom


LENGTH: 480 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 18, 1995
by Paul Fauvet, PANA Correspondent

MAPUTO, Mozambique - The Media Institute of Southern Africa (MISA) has issued an "action alert" on Mozambique, charging the United States Embassy there of threatening freedom of the press and of information.

The Mozambique news agency, AIM, said Monday Misa usually targets governments in the region.

The institute's latest criticism refers to the embassy's ban on its officials from speaking to United States journalist Joseph Hanlon. 

Once a long-time resident in Mozambique and a prominent writer on the country, Hanlon was refused permission to speak with staff members of the United States Agency for International Development when he visited in October.

AIM reported that when asked, embassy Press Attache Adrienne O'Neal gave no reason for the ban. But Ambassador Dennis Jett confirmed it, the institute said in its alert dated Dec. 15, 1995.

"Hanlon is an unprofessional journalist whose reporting is totally and consistently biased," the institute quoted Jett as saying. "It is a waste of time talking to him."

It said Jett claimed that the embassy ban did not limit press freedom and that the U.S. government would not prevent journalists investigating their findings.

"But if the government doesn't want to talk to you, you can't force it to. It is my choice to take up questions," he said.

But AIM said the U.S. Embassy remained an important source for American journalists on Mozambique's foreign relations.

Hanlon lived in Mozambique in the late 1970s and early 1980s. He was the correspondent for the London-based Guardian newspaper and for the British Broadcasting Corporation, media that are usually associated with high levels of professionalism.

He has written several widely-praised books on Mozambique. A man of the ideological left, Hanlon has made trenchant criticisms of U.S. policy toward southern Africa.

He has American citizenship but is permanently resident in Britain where he says he enjoys greater freedom.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


51 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zimbabwe Foreigners Allowed In Reserved Areas


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 18, 1995

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe - Foreigners in Zimbabwe will be allowed 100 percent ownership of industries in areas reserved for citizens because of lack of local entrepreneurship.

Zimbabwe Investment Centre (ZIC) executive for Bulawayo, Nohlupheko Phiri, said local people have no financial resources or the technology required. 

He was responding to remarks by some industrialists that barring foreigners from 100 percent ownership in areas reserved for locals blocked speedy industrialization.

"We have said where there is high-tech, huge financial responsibilities or special skills that our people do not have, then foreign investors can be allowed to go 100 percent," Phiri told the Zimbabwe Inter Africa News Agency, Ziana.

As part of measures to promote black economic empowerment, the government last year reserved areas for local investors, in which foreign investors may only be allowed to take up to 25 percent of equity.

Some of the areas reserved for domestic investors include manufacture and marketing of amarments, public water provision for domestic and industrial purposes, agriculture, forestry, transportation, retail and wholesale trade.

"These are traditionally areas dominated by our people but there are certain things like investment in luxury coaches which need money. That's where our committee gives special concessions to foreigners," Phiri said.

But he said special concessions could not be extended to manufacturing and marketing of amarments.

Early this year ZIC said it would continuously review conditions concerning investment by foreign companies in the reserved areas so as to speed up foreign investment.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


52 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


South Africa Higher Growth Rate Needed


LENGTH: 320 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 18, 1995
by Lionel Williams, PANA Correspondent

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - South Africa needs to double its economic growth rate in order to achieve its development targets, Prime Minister Thabo Mbeki has said.

South Africa's expected economic growth rate of 3 percent for 1995 was positive but the country needs 6 percent growth in the future, he said over the weekend. 

Speaking at a year-end news briefing here, Mbeki said there were positive signs for the country's economy, which include a drop in inflation to 6.3 percent, the lowest in 23 years, and a reasonably large inflow of foreign investment.

"This is a vote for confidence in the future of the country, a vote by domestic investors and by international investors," he said.

Mbeki emphasized the need for a sustained growth rate of at least six percent to keep economic growth on track. The key to this lay in manufacturing, he said.

He said growth has to be driven by new investment particularly in manufacturing.

Mbeki said a clear policy on the restructuring of state assets should emerge in the new year, and a strategy for medium-term economic growth should be completed during the first quarter of 1996.

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Conflict Management Body Meets Behind Closed Doors


LENGTH: 334 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 18, 1995
by Ghion HAgos, PANA Staff Correspondent

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - African foreign ministers went into closed session Monday at the start of another meeting to end the continent's five areas of war.

After the formal opening in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, and adoption of a seven-point agenda, they met to review progress in ending conflicts in Burundi, Liberia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone and Somalia. 

They will also discuss the report on the Comoros by the secretary-general of the Organization of Africa Unity, following a botched mercenary-led coup in the Indian Ocean Island nation.

However, top on the agenda is the report by Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim on the June assassination attempt in Addis Ababa on Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak.

The ministers and other officials -- the 16 members of the OAU's committee on conflict prevention, management and resolution-- will want to see how incidents such as the plot against Mubarak could be prevented in the future.

Egyptian muslim militants belonging to Al Gama'a Al-Islamia are being blamed for the attempt on Mubarak, who is virtually at war with them in Egypt.

Ethiopia says that three militants fled to neighbouring Sudan immediately after the failed attempt and that Khartoum was harboring the would-be killers. Sudan denies the charge.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


54 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Commission Meets On Human Rights


LENGTH: 347 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 18, 1995

KAMPALA, Uganda- An extra-ordinary meeting of the African Commission for Human and Peoples' Rights opened here Monday to review the human rights situation in Africa with a special focus on Nigeria.

Over 70 delegates from the Organization of African Unity (OAU) member states are attending the two-day meeting. 

Opening the conference, Uganda's Foreign Minister Ruhakana Rugunda said the continent has not performed well in upholding the basic human rights, duties and freedoms enshrined in the OAU charter.

"A number of African countries are in political turmoil because of the absence of good governance and democracy," Rugunda said.

He said while each country should take its own historical, political and economic circumustances and chart its own path, political authority should derive from the freely expressed will of the people.

"The problem of abuses of human rights in Africa is of such serious proportions that it needs to be addressed thoroughly and comprehensively," he said in reference to the recent events in Nigeria which have been condemned by the international community.

Nigeria executed in November nine minority rights activists including author Ken Sara-Wiwa.

"The problem affecting Nigeria needs to be addressed by a speedy democratization process within the shortest possible time," he said.

The African Commission for Human and Peoples Rights was established in 1987 by the OAU.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


55 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Cape Verde Ruling Party Wins An Absolute Majority


LENGTH: 267 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 18, 1995

PRAIA, Cape Verde - The ruling party in Cape Verde has won the country's parliamentary elections.

The Movement for Democracy (MDP) won Sunday's elections with an absolute majority, according to the results published Monday morning by the National Electoral Committee. 

The exact elections results will be announced later in the day but unconfirmed results said MDP won almost 50 out of the 72 parliamentary seats.

The victory of Prime Minister Carlos Veiga's ruling party came as no surprise but observers ruled out the possibility of a landslide victory.

All along his electoral campaign, Veiga kept reminding the voters of the necessity to give him "the absolute majority" he needs to give his party a free hand to continue its programs.

Veiga said the new majority in parliament will enable his party to rule "in stability".

He indicated that all those who hurled "insults" against him during the election campaign will be taken to court.

Five political parties took part in the elections.

Africa News


December, 1995


Niger Rebels Call for Investigation into Death of Tuareg Leader


LENGTH: 414 words


 
Panafrican News Service
December 17, 1995:

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Tuareg rebels in northern Niger are calling for an investigation into the death of Mano Daya, a faction leader who died in a plane crash Friday.

The rebels said during the weekend they suspected Daya, head of the Tuareg 'Armed Resistance Coordination', had been a victim of foul play. 

He died Friday around 1 p.m. local time when the chartered Cessna in which he was travelling exploded in the Tenere desert where his organization is headquartered. Witnesses said, however, the plane was flying in poor weather.

His second in command, the secretary general of the People's Liberation Army of Northen Niger and a French national were also killed in the explosion.

A professional tour operator, Dayak took up arms to fight for the autonomy of northern Niger in 1991.

One of his aides, Rissa As Doula, in April signed a peace agreement with the government of Niger. Dayak refused to accept the truce and continued his armed rebellion.

It is, however, widely believed he had entered into negotiations with the Niger prime minister, Hama Amadou, and French, Burkinabe and Algerian mediators.

The negotiations, well placed sources said, were designed to map out a permanent peace accord.

The government of Niger had by Saturday not reacted to the death.

They were in an airplane belonging to private airline, Niger Air Service. Witnesses said the plane exploded at noon local time (1 p.m. Greenwich Mean Time) soon after taking off from an airstrip in the Tenere desert, 200 kilometers (124 miles) north of Agades.

The cause of the crash is still unknown. Witnesses said weather conditions were poor at the time.

Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria Abacha Warns of 'Re-Balkanisation' of Africa


LENGTH: 640 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 17, 1995:
by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's military ruler Gen.Sani Abacha warned against what he called the "re-balkanisation" of Africa through regional groupings.

In a major foreign policy statement Saturday night in Abuja at the annual patrons dinner of the Nigerian Institute of International Affairs, Abacha said Africa should continue to resolve its problems through consensus and not confrontation. He apparently was referring to the Southern African Development Community's stand against his country. 

He said everything must be done to stop "the use of regional groupings to divide us" because this will not do Africa any good.

SADC member states, led by South African President Nelson Mandela, have been most vocal in their condemnation of Abacha for the execution last month of nine Ogoni minority-rights activists, including the celebrated writer Ken Saro-Wiwa.

The United States and the European Union countries imposed arms and sporting embargoes on Nigeria. The British-led Commonwealth suspended Nigeria, with the support of some African member countries, during the 53-nation body's recent summit in Auckland, New Zealand.

Abacha said Africa will continue to be the centerpiece of his country's foreign policy but stressed that with the apartheid's demise and in the light of the current situation, this policy would be revised, placing Nigeria's interest first.

He said the Commonwealth was unfair in its use of the Harare Declaration on good governence as a pretext to suspend Nigeria for what it claimed was the country's lack of progress in returning to democracy.

"The Harare Declaration did not lay down any timeframe for achieving democracy," Abacha said. Nigeria, he said, would remain faithful to its plan to return the country to civilian rule by 1998 but would not be stampeded into doing so by any country.

Earlier, in his opening speech, NIIA Director General George Obiozor said his institution was satisfied with the government's conciliatory policy and rapproachment with certain sections of the international community.

He appealed to the Nigerian leader to continue with his approach of "charity to all and malice to none" to ensure cordial relations between the country and the international community.

"Nigeria needs the support of the international community in its efforts to achieve the goals of democratization and economic growth, just as the world needs Nigeria as a potential economic and political force in the continent of Africa," Obiozor said.

Founded on Dec. 13, 1961, as a nonprofit organization, the NIIA promotes the scientific study of international politics, economics and jurisprudence.

Its annual year-end patrons dinner has become recognized as an important forum for government to take stock of its international relations and make foreign policy pronouncements.

December, 1995


Senegal Africa Left Behind By Information Highways


LENGTH: 454 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995:
by Aminata Toure, Pana Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - The Executive Secretary of the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA), Kingsley Amoako, fears that because of the continent's archaic telecommunication network, it will not benefit from the emerging information super highways.

"It is sad to note that many African countries still lack the required basic telecommunications facilities", he said recently at symposium organised as part of the second Biennial of Sciences and Technologies (AFRISTECH), held in Dakar from 11 to 16 December 1995. 

Amoako said the communication growth gap between the North and the South is likely to widen when countries in the north intensify the use of "Inforoads".

Africa, according to Amoako, gets into the 21st century with a precarious economic situation. Donors, Intergovermental and non-govermental organisations and the private sector must work together to enable Africa to have access and use the 'Inforoads', he told participants at the symposium.

Meanwhile, Momar Ali Ndiaye, who was chairing the symposium, said the Information Super Highways was "one of the last chances Africa's endogenous development".

He told PANA that Africa should not make the mistake of considering the use of of new information technologies as a luxury. It is rather a "necessity", he stressed.

According to him, 80 percent of the World Economy will be accounted for by information sales. "We have to create networks and organise ourselves so that others do not sell their information here," Ndiaye added.

He said the 'Inforoads' have effects on all development sectors (Trade, Industry, Research...).Africa's chance lies on the adoption of an African Strategic Plan on
that question.

He named Egypt and South Africa as two African countries which were doing well by developing efficient communication systems.

Africa News


December, 1995


Mozambique Anti-Sexually Transmited Disease Drive Praised


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995:

MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambique is among few African countries which have won praise for their drive against sexually transmitted diseases as a way of curbing the spread of HIV.

This was said Tuesday here by the head of the country's Epidemiology department, Avertino Barreto, at a news conference. 

He said Mozambique's experience in treating sexually-transmitted diseases was praised at last week's African conference on AIDS, in the Ugandan capital, Kampala.

Dr. Barreto said the worst AIDS- affected areas are Manica and Tete provinces, in central and northwestern Mozambique, where the number of aids carriers continues to rise as if no campaign was being implemented.

He said that more work is being done to counter this rise. Mozambican health authorities estimate that nearly one million people already carry the Human Immunodeficiency Virus that leads to AIDS. Barreto said out of this number, only 2,000 AIDS patients have been registered by the health ministry.

Barreto said his department will step up its fight against sexually transmitted diseases, and the campaign will include sexual education in schools.

A study conducted recently in neighbouring tanzania says that there can be a 50 percent reduction in the rate of HIV infection if organised programmes of treating sexually-transmitted diseases are implemented.

Barreto lamented that cultural beliefs were making it difficult to change the mentalities of adults towards AIDS. He thus urged youth to raise to the challenge of saving future generations.

Africa News


December, 1995


Zimbabwe Higher Tobacco Exports Expected


LENGTH: 454 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995:

HARARE, Zimbabwe (PANA) - Zimbabwe could soon displace Brazil as a major supplier of flue-cured tobacco to the Far East, Zimbabwe Tobacco Association (ZTA) president Peter Richards said Wednesday.

Richards said on a recent promotional trip to Asia and the Far East ZTA executives were told there was high demand for Zimbabwean flue-cured tobacco mainly because of its quality.

"For the first time, some of the customers stated that they prefer our quality to that of Brazil. That is a promising development because for a long time Brazil has been supplying these countries," Richards said. 

"I believe, therefore, that each and every country we visited will be taking increased quantities of our tobacco in the future."

Zimbabwe is one of the world's top three tobacco producers together with Brazil and the United States.

Richards said because of competition from other suppliers, Zimbabwean growers should cut costs and improve efficiency so as to remain competitive, particularly on prices.

"I believe that if we do that we will have a better product to offer and if the product is not more expensive than our competitors', we have a great future in the region we
visited," he said.

Richards said Zimbabwe's 1995/96 tobacco crop was looking good and nearly all the crop has been planted. Recent widespread rains, he said, had given hope tofarmers that they would have another record season.

"The start has been very favorable and growers' hopes are very high for an excellent crop, enough to satisfy our customers who are already making enquiries," he said.

Flue-cured tobacco production during 1995/96 was expected to rise from some 435 million pounds the previous season to about 462 million kg.

Tobacco, which brings in over Zimdollars 3.5 billion (389 million U.S. dollars) annually, is one of Zimbabwe's single largest foreign currency earners.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


61 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Angola Two Ebola Cases Confirmed a


LENGTH: 360 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995:

LUANDA, Angola (PANA) - The World Health Organization (WHO) has confirmed that the two patients in the Ebanga area, in central Angola, were infected with the deadly Ebola virus.

The discovery of the two patients came barely two weeks after a Liberian refugee in Ivory Coast was confirmed to be infected with the Ebola virus. 

The virus, which causes a severe haemorrhagic fever and bleeding that kills a patient within a week, caused 250 deaths in Zaire's Kikwit area between April and June 1995.

The virus liquefies the patient's internal organs, provoking bleeding in several parts of the body, including the nose, mouth, eyes and skin, and excessive diarrhea.

Reporting the latest outbreak of Ebola in Africa, the Angolan News Agency, Angop, said last Friday that epidemiologists from the UN health agency arrived in Luanda the same day and travelled to Ebanga for further investigations.

Ebola spreads rapidly among people who touch an infected person's fluids, including blood and excreta. A doctor and nurses who operated on the first Ebola victim in Kikwit died of the disease.

Meanwhile, in Ivory Coast, medical experts from the French Medicins Sans Frontiers (Doctors Without Borders) discovered that only one of the four suspected Ebola carriers actually had the virus.

The young Liberian refugee in Ivory Coast said he left behind another person with symptoms like his. This prompted health workers to travel inside the war-ravaged country to track other Ebola cases.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


62 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Uganda AIDS Hits African Youths Hardest, Amid Hopeful Signs


LENGTH: 787 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995:
by Moses Draku PANA Staff Correspondent

KAMPALA, Uganda (PANA) - The incurable acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) disease is taking an increasing toll among youths in Africa, particularly young women, one of the workshops at the recently ended International Conference on AIDS and Sexually Transmitted Diseases in Africa, was told. But the leading experts who participated in the workshop on the "Status and Trends of HIV/AIDS Epidemics in Africa" noted that while the pandemic continues to spread relentlessly on the continent, there is reason for hope.

The workshop brought together 30 experts from a wide range of fields including epidemiology, economics, demography and international development. 

Their conclusion was that different AIDS epidemics move through populations with different speed, taking an increasing toll on young people, especially young women. "The HIV/AIDS epidemics in Africa have become the epidemics of the young," said Dr Daniel Tarantola of the Harvard School of Public Health, who co-chaired the workshop with Dr. Peter Lamptey of Ghana, the Director of AIDSCAP. Lamptey, one of the world's leading experts on HIV/AIDS,said that the apparent stabilization of HIV prevalence in some African countries could have resulted from the saturation of the disease in older age groups and the modification of sexual behaviour among young people due to ongoing prevention education efforts. "The important point is that HIV prevalence is declining in some locations, whether or not we can explain exactly why," said Lamptey.

World Health Organization figures show that by the end of 1994, over 11 million adults were living with HIV in Africa. This represented 65 percent of the total number of infections in
the world.

Although it has been predicted that Asia will overtake Africa in the number of new HIV infections in the coming decade, the major impact of the HIV/AIDS epidemics in Africa are yet to come, the workshop was told.

The experts noted that 19 African countries had more than 100,000 people each currently living with HIV, which causes the incurable disease.

These countries accounted for 90 percent of all HIV infections on the continent.

Demographic surveys in several countries have shown substantial increases in infant and child mortality. Projections from Zambia and Zimbabwe indicate that AIDS will increase child mortality nearly threefold by 2010.

Combined with the increase in adult mortality, these trends will result in significant reductions in life expectancy in countries hardest hit by HIV/AIDS.

What is staggering is the fact that the pandemic is raging at a time when the African continent is also facing severe economic hardships, fewer employment opportunities, open conflicts, low-intensity wars, environmental degradation and natural disasters.

These factors are causing the displacement or migration of millions of Africans from their homes.

Away from their normal social settings, many of these severely stressed people become more likely to practice unsafe sex, thereby increasing the spread of HIV, the experts noted.

Mobility, which facilitates the spread of sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV, calls for enhanced surveillance as well as expanded HIV programs to address the specific needs of mobile populations, the experts said.

Throughout Africa the differences that have been seen between urban and rural HIV infection rates are narrowing, sometimes rapidly. No longer is HIV only mainly a threat to urban sexually active populations.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


63 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Mozambique Government Denies Allegations of Corruption


LENGTH: 547 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995:
...MAPUTO, Mozambique (PANA) - Mozambican labor minister,
Guilherme Mavila, denied accusations in the South African
press claiming his government and corrupt ministry officials stole
millions of South African rands intended to compensate families of
Mozambicans crippled or killed in South African mines.
Mavila described the alleged scandal as a surprise.

The Sunday Times reported that the allegations surfaced
after an investigation into the plight of eight Mozambican
families of victims of a Vaal Reefs mines accident in May. 
 The investigating group including representatives from South
Africa's Rand Mutual Assurance (RMA), National Union of Mine Workers
(NUM), the Mine Labor Organization, Ernst and Young Auditors, and
TEBA, an organization that handles compensation for miners from
Botswana and Lesotho.

Seven months after the accident, the victims' widows have not
seen any of the 60,000 rands (16,700 dollars) in insurance
or life pensions of about 1,000 rands (278 dollars) a month, paid to
families of the 96 victims of a similar accident in July, the
paper said.

The investigation found that Rand Mutual Assurance was
paying 700,000 rands (194,400 dollars) a month through the
Johannesburg office of the Mozambican Department of Labor. Only
about 10 percent of this is being paid out.
NUM and the Chamber of Mines now are calling on the
government to cancel a 1964 agreement with the then Portuguese
colonial authorities that stipulates all Mozambican mine workers'
compensation and death or disability pensions be paid through their
country's labor department.

Investigators charged theft and corruption are the order
of the day among those handling the money and that pensioners,
many of whom are illiterate, are at the mercy of unscrupulous,
unsympathetic officials.

NUM representative James Motlasi and executives from RMJA
and TEBA told the Sunday Times they received a hostile
reception from the Mozambican government in Maputo in November
when they proposed that pension payments be handed over to
TEBA, which administers similar payments for workers from
Botswana and Lesotho.

64 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Chiluba Set to Retain MMD Leadership


LENGTH: 707 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995:
by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia (PANA) - President Frederick Chiluba of Zambia is likely to be re-elected as the president of his ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy (MMD) at the party's third extraordinary national convention in the capital Wednesday.

Chiluba opened the conference Monday with a call to delegates to elect "capable, honest and efficient leaders" and a pledge to weed the party of corrupt leaders, but the party's vice president, Levy Mwanawasa, is challenging him.

Mwanawasa resigned as Chiluba's republican vice in 1994 after accusing Chiluba of lacking the courage to discipline corrupt cabinet ministers. 

Political analysts said Mwanawasa's resignation was likely to "haunt" him in Wednesday's elections. His political opponents accused the veteran lawyer of "lacking courage" himself by resigning from government when he was expected to help Chiluba cleanse government of corruption.

Chiluba launched an indirect anti-Mwanawasa campaign when he opened the convention by suggesting that the MMD could not hope to last long if it elected "megalomaniacs whose love for power far exceeds dedication to the service of the people". This was an apparent reference to Mwanawasa's earlier departure from government.

The MMD national chairman reinforced Chiluba's own bid by advising the 1,300 delegates to be wary about "changing horses in mid-stream unless the other horse is lame."

Chiluba's supporters have insinuated that Mwanawasa is mentally "lame" following a near fatal 1991 car accident while he was republican vice president. His bodyguard died in the mishap. He was treated at a South African hospital where doctors pronounced him physically and mentally able to continue as Zambia's vice president.

Both Chiluba and Mwanawasa were founder-members of the MMD in 1991. The party initially comprised political rebels against former president Kenneth Kaunda's 17 years of one-party rule. They included academics, trade unionists and other groups disillusioned by Kaunda.

The MMD's early insiders, including Chiluba himself, confirmed that he was chosen to lead the party because he was considered the most likely candidate to defeat Kaunda.

He eventually did beat Kaunda in the Oct. 31, 1991, multiparty general elections.

Mwanawasa is himself a professional lawyer and is credited with executing successfully most of the MMD's litigations in the legal campaign to get Kaunda to amend the one-party constitution to allow for multipartyism.

Chiluba Monday sought to clear current doubts about his alleged alien nationality and threatened to ban the independent Post newspaper that he accused of orchestrating a malicious nationality campaign on behalf of Kaunda.

Kaunda has said he will challenge Chiluba in the 1996 presidential elections despite the MMD recommendation in a new republican constitution that only people born in Zambia with Zambian-born parents should contest the top post.

Kaunda had Malawian parents and Chiluba could himself be barred from the elections if charges that he was born in Zaire of Zairean parents were proved true.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

December, 1995


Eritrea Ethiopia Mediates Eritrea-Yemen Dispute


LENGTH: 400 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995:
by Ghion Hagos PANA Staff Correspondent
...ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia (PANA) - A high-level Ethiopian delegation leaves Thursday for the Eritrean and Yemeni capitals in an effort to find a peaceful settlement to a dispute about control of the Greater Hanish Islands at the southern entrance to the Red Sea.

Ethiopian Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin will lead the delegation. 

Fighting broke out between Eritrean and Yemeni forces early Saturday and lasted two days, with Yemen accusing Eritrea of invading the islands with planes and naval ships.

Intermittent fighting continued until Tuesday, despite an announcement Sunday night in Yemen that presidents Issayas Afeworki of Eritrea and Abdella Ali Saleh of Yemen agreed to a ceasefire as of 9 p.m. Greenwich Mean Time Sunday, midnight local time.

According to a statement issued here Wednesday by the Eritrean embassy, elements within Yemeni armed forces have made baseless charges against Eritrea concerning events in the Greater Hanish Islands since Saturday. "This is apparently to instigate more trouble," the statement said. The statement said "the mendacious accusations" that the Yemenis were levelling against Eritrean armed forces are meant to make up for the failure of their military design over the islands belonging to Eritrea.

The Eritrean government said it took more than 180 Yemeni soldiers as prisoners and destroyed one helicopter. The announcement said six Eritrean soldiers were killed and three were injured.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the Organization of African Unity reiterated the comment made Monday by Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim that the row over the Hanish Islands should not be turned into an African-Arab dispute.

This came after the League of Arab States backed Yemen in the dispute.

December, 1995


Zambia Fight-Starved Boxers Ask for Street Fights


LENGTH: 560 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 23, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Two fight-starved professional Zambian boxers decided they could no longer stand what they termed as persistent evasion by local title holders fearing to be dethroaned.

Consequently, on Wednesday, they approached the northern Copperbelt Regional Police Commander, Henry Chisha, for a permit to hold street fights with the elusive champions. Chisha turned the request by Musonda Chinungu, alias The Bull, who seeks to challenge national light middleweight champion Chipundu Chipayeni, and of Masozi Kamanga, itching to snatch the light heavyweight title from Mike Chilambe. 

The two sought police help in Ndola, the copperbelt capital, hoping that these would compel Zambian boxing officials to oblige the champions to stake the titles.

Accompanied by their fans and Chinungu's wife, Joyce Sabrina, the two marched into the police commander's office to ask for licences to fight the champions on the streets.

"I am a boxer and I feed my wife and children through fighting. That is why I and my friend... have come to ask for a permit to allow us to ' sort these guys' out in the streets and for the results of the street fights to count," Chinungu told the police chief at Ndola's Central Police post Wednesday.

But the request did not amuse Chisha in his capacity as the region's principal law and order enforcement officer.

"That is an offense. We (police) do not give permission to commit an offence. How can we allow someone to fight in the streets," said Chisha.

He warned Chinungu the police had "enough empty cells" for trouble-makers.

Undaunted by the warning, Chinungu said he would now approach Zambia's Boxing Board to allow the street fights. He said he cannot stand being evaded by Chipayeni who is allegedly "scared" of him.

After a few further exchanges between the two men, Chinungu's wife took the police advice and persuaded her husband to drop the street fight idea.

The two pugilists left the police station amid "show of power" by their fans.

Zambia boxing fans have complained that professional boxing was almost dead since the departure of Nigerian Promoter Gibson Nwosu who had been instrumental in popularizing the game.

Nwosu, who returned to Nigeria, was credited for grooming Lottie Mwale, Zambia's best known boxer and former Africa light heavyweight champion.

Africa News


December, 1995


Zimbabwe Traditionalists Defend Marijuana Use


LENGTH: 654 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 23, 1995
by Archibald Musonza.

HARARE, Zimbabwe, - He is 80 years old and sitting on a wooden stool he takes a long pull from his pipe.

He closes his eyes and slowly lets out the acrid smoke through his nostrils. 

"This will keep away the evil spirits for another day," says the old man offering me the pipe.

I politely decline and he looks at me with a knowing eye and says, "That is the problem with you children of today, you did not go through the proper channels of being brought up. You are too full of the white man's blood, that is why you are so weak."

"Why the government follows the white man's belief, I do not know. Mbanje (marijuana) is a part of our life. I can spend the whole day telling you how it was productively used in the past. In our days children did not suffer from the silly illnesses haunting you today because we used mbanje as a protective herb," the old man says.

"Our chiefs were wise then because they would clear their minds with the herb. Ask anyone who fought in the (Zimbabwe) liberation struggle how it helped them."

Marijuana, or mbanje as it is known in Zimbabwe in the local Shona vernacular, is readily avaliable throughout southern Africa.

In Zimbabwe, mbanje worth millions of dollars is confiscated by police annually.

Traditional herbalists believe marijuana has healing properties and can cure some cases of cancer, glaucoma, stress and many other illness.

An Australian AIDS researcher, Don Baxter writes that the drug is actually more effective than most recommended drugs.

"It has long been known that marijuana is an effective treatment for some of the symptoms of cancer and glaucoma, the eye disease, and we would like to see the laws outlawing marijuana reformed for medical use," he said.

The herb is said to have an advantage over pills as the smoke is transported all over the body through the lungs.

One traditionalist says controlled legalizing of the drug should be an issue of high priority because it is the right of every African to live the African way.

"It should have long been decriminalized soon after independence because the laws banning cannibis were brought in by the colonialists.

"Before they came to Africa, mbanje was smoked in public by the elderly chiefs and kraal (village) heads but there wasn't any form of violence or aggressiveness," he said.

However, the dangers of the herb are real with many people in Zimbabwe having been admitted to psychiatric homes suffering from mbanje-induced mental illnesses.

"With mbanje, a single pull causes permanent damage to the brain. Therefore legalizing it would be leading people to death because once the brain is damaged, that would be the end of that person," said a Harare doctor.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


68 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


South Africa Dogs To Fight Trafficking


LENGTH: 294 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 23, 1995

NAIROBI, Kenya - South African-trained sniffer dogs will be sent to four east and southern African countries early 1996 in a bid to step up the war against international drug traffickers, a United Nations official said in Nairobi Wednesday.

Bjorn Franzen of the U.N. International Drug Control Program said the sniffer dogs are part of a 250,000-dollar three-year

program designed to bring drug trafficking to an end in the region. 

He said the program includes dog-handling , anti-narcotics training and the supply of vehicles and drug detection equipment.

"We've designed a project which will use South African expertize and know-how to set up a sniffer dog program in Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania and Zambia, Franzen said.

Franzen, a chief technical adviser, said the dogs, either Alsatian or Labrador, were effective in scaring drug traffickers crossing borders.

Drug smuggling is on the increase in Kenya and neighboring Tanzania with dealers using the countries as transit points between Asia, Europe and the United States, police said.
Police in Kenya last week set ablaze 5.7 tons of hashish with an estimated street value of 5.7 million dollars.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


69 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zimbabwe Inflation Soars to 26 Percent


LENGTH: 294 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 23, 1995

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's annual inflation soared to 26.3 percent in November largely due to a spate of food price hikes, the Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe said Thursday.

"The rise in the general level of prices at this time of the year, while reflecting seasonal factors particularly on foodstuff items, was anticipated following increases in fuel prices, rates and electricity charges as well as sales tax and excise duties," the bank said. 

However, it said in a bulletin that indications were that inflation would start to fall during the first half of 1996.

Foodstuff prices went up by 10.8 percentage points to 35.6 percent during November. Items registering major increases in this category were fruit and vegetables, bread, cereals, oils and fats as well as meat.

"Also contributing to the annual rise in inflation in November was a 1.8 percentage point increase to 3.5 percent in prices of beverages and tobacco," it said.

Inflation is expected to end 1995 around the current level but should start to decline in the first half of 1996.

Government and major donors financing market reforms launched five years ago expect inflation to reach 17 percent by mid-1996.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December, 1995


Zimbabwe High HIV Infection Reported


LENGTH: 334 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 23, 1995

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's National AIDS Coordination Programme issued a chilling report Thursday on the spread of the deadly AIDS disease, saying estimates showed up to 25 percent of sexually active adults in the 15-49 age group could be infected with the HIV virus.

The report said about 10 percent of Zimbabwe's population of some 10.4 million people were infected with HIV, while one in three babies who were born to HIV positive women had the virus which causes aids. 

"Almost all those with HIV are expected to develop AIDS in time," it said.

It added that average life expectancy may be shortened by perhaps 20 years, with a shortage of young and middle-aged productive adults and huge numbers of orphans, possibly one in three of all children by the year 2010.

"Sex ratios will change as women die younger than men, and dependency ratios will worsen. Alls sectors of society and of the economy will be affected," it said.

Population growth is expected to slow and may become negative for a time, although it would gradually recover.

By mid-1995 Zimbabwe had a cumulative total of 40,000 AIDS cases reported but it was believed about two thirds of the cases went unreported.

Recently country's health and child welfare minister shocked the nation with a report that up to 300 people were dying of AIDS-related diseases every week.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


71 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria Magazine Sues Nigerian Government Over Alleged Harassment


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 23, 1995
by Paul Ejime PANA Staff Correspondent

LAGOS, Nigeria - A Nigerian weekly magazine, Tell, is claiming $9.54 million in damages for the arrest of its editor-in-chief and for two separate seizures of recent editions. Tell Publications, which owns the magazine, dragged the Nigerian federal attorney-general and the inspector-general of the police force to court Wednesday. 

Tell said some 55,000 copies of its Christmas edition entitled "Abiola's Freedom: The World Waits For Abacha," were seized Dec.17.

The title refers to the detained millionaire-politician Moshood Abiola, who is the acclaimed winner of the annulled 1993 presidential election military regime. He is awaiting trial for treasonable felony after declaring himself President of Nigeria in 1994 in defiance of the present regime under Gen. Sani Abacha.

Tell also claims in the suits, for which no hearing date has been fixed, that another set of 50,000 copies of its publication dated Jan. 1, 1996 and entitled "Abacha Is Adamant: Terrorizes the Opposition" were seized by security agents Dec. 23, the same day editor-in-chief Nosa Igiebor was arrested.

It says that the "forceful seizure and confiscation" of the copies were "unlawful, unconstitutional, null and void."

The magazine is asking the court to order Igiebor's release or to charge him to a court of competent jurisdiction. It claims his arrest and detention are a violation of his fundamental human rights.

The military government, which is under intense international pressure over its human rights record, has not responded to the magazine's claim of harassment.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


72 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Chiluba Blames African Coups On Lack Of Education


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 23, 1995
by Musengwa Kayaya, PANA Staff Correspondent

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba said Thursday undereducated soldiers are partly responsible for the high number of military coups that plague the African continent.

Pointing to the questionable way armies handle issues, Chiluba said that the majority of the military forces in Africa have been "poorly regarded" for many years. 

Chiluba was speaking at the opening of the Defense Services and Staff College, which will train senior defense services and command staff for the 12-member Southern Africa Development Community.

He said Zambia has trained officer cadets locally since independence in 1964 and it has relied on overseas courses to educate senior military personnel.

He said military coups in Africa are partly attributed to the lack of adequate education for the soldier.

Outside influences have added to the mess, he said.

The college, which has both army and air force wings, will admit defense personnel from SADC and offer 12-month courses to prepare officers for senior responsibilities in army command and staff appointments. Senior military delegations from several neighboring states, inluding Indian Deputy Chief of Army Staff Lt. Gen. Kevin D'Souza, witnessed the inauguration ceremony.

Gen. D'Souza said Wednesday that over the next three years India will contribute some $200,000 to the college.

India has trained many senior Zambian military personnel and was one of the leading supporters of the southern Africa liberation movements, including Nelson Mandela's Africa National Congress, that were based in Zambia.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Weekly Press Review


LENGTH: 707 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 23, 1995
by Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent

DAKAR, Senegal - African newspaper editorials seemingly ignored the fighting between Eritrea and Yemen Saturday on the Hanish Islands, and instead gave attention to the just ended AIDS conference, Nigeria and Liberia.

On the AIDS meeting, Kampala newspapers appeared somewhat distressed by the fact that there was no announcement of a possible vaccine in sight against the disease.

"Even more depressing was the news that by the year 2000, as many as 40 million people will be infected with AIDS," the state-owned New Vision said. 

"This paints a grim picture for Sub-Saharan Africa where the socio-economic disruption caused by the disease is beginning to bite hard," it added.

Despite these grim revelations, it went on, the conferene was a success in that it was fully attended thereby emphasizing the "global determination" to combat the scourge.

"The conference also demonstrated the International faith in Uganda's open approach as the only credible way of dealing with the pandemic," it said.

Therefore, the paper appealed to politicians and lawmakers, whose policies on protecting vulnerable groups like women are crucial, to take the lead in emphasising the multisectoral approach as the only way to limit the spread of AIDS.

As the African peacekeeping force fanned out in Liberia Sud Quotidien, a privately-owned Dakar newspaper in Senegal, criticised other West African countries for not contributing more to the effort. The daily also offered reasons for this and the effect of this hands-off policy.

Nigeria, it said, has greater influence in directing a solution in the Liberian crisis by defualt: That is because of the noncommital attitude by most of the 16 nations forming the Economic Community of West African States.

For example, it said, following the decision to beef up ECOMOG, the peacekeeping force, "again only Nigeria made a significant contribution".

Nigeria's dominance in Liberia illustrates the country's "nuisance potential" in the subregion, it said.

This is more so, it went on, because many countries have failed to condemn Nigeria's internal political policies.

West African countries could not openly do so, it added, "because that would expose them to similar criticism for their rule at home."

It noted that Nigeria, now under limited sanctions from the West and form South Africa, could easily use Liberia to "thumb its noze" at the international community: But it has not done so.

In a related issue, Organisation of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim also came under attack from the privately-owned Kampala Tri-weekly, The Star.

The Ugandan paper took issue with Salim because of his statement that Nigeria should not be isolated for hanging Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight others environmental rights activists in November.

"It is not clear what Salim ate, drank, or smoked during this meeting with the blood-drenched Nigerian Dictator-General Abacha in Abuja," It said.

"It is profoundly puzzling why Salim chose to give comfort to a murderous military regime, at a time when popular opinion in Africa and the world over is demanding condemnation and isolation," it concluded.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


74 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Weekly Press Review


LENGTH: 1120 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 29, 1995
by Olu Sarr, PANA Staff Correspondent

Dakar - Newspaper editorials reaching PANA at the end of the year ignored one of the biggest stories recently, the fighting between Eritrea and Yemen over the Greater Hanish island.

However, one paper commented on another important and nagging problem: The fate of the multinational airline Air Afrique and another on the Isreal-Syrian peace talks.

The Niamey-based Le Democrate noted the paltry state of finances in the multinational Air Afrique which, it claims, makes "incessant demands" for money. It said it did so in 1988, 1992 and 1995, each time asking for larger amounts. 

"On each occasion the money was supposed to revamp the company on a long term but instead we are swamped by debt," it said.

"Every two years France and the member states are asked to give more, to artificially maintain the company, which is about to face stiff competition now that there is about to be total deregulation (of the aviation industry) in Europe," it said.

"But its (Air Afrique's) resources are very limited faced with Western megacompanies," it said.

It put the blame for the airline's state on "the blind attitude of those who, at the highest level, are charged with conducting our transport policy."

Dakar's Sud Quotidien commented on the renewed optimism of peace since the resumption of exploratory talks between Israel and Syria.

But the Senegalese paper warned that this was firmly "set against the background of the intransigence" of the radical Arab world and Isreal's overiding security concerns, especially over the Golan Heights.

The peace accord between the Palestine Liberation Organisation and Israel, it noted, started the peace process which has gained momentum with the assassination of Isreali Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.

It said that Syria had re-entered the process, and was ready to make concessions to Isreal, at this time because it felt it had sufficient hold of Lebanon.

But it warned that achieving peace would not be easy for Syria.

"Damascus will be faced with the problem of the terrorist groups it harbours and which are violently opposed to Israeli-Palestinian accords," it said

"If an agreement is reached these groups may become the snakes Syria will have reared in its own territory, just like extremist Israeli settlers who have become the enemies of peace from within," it said.

In Nigeria one Lagos newspaper focused on the effect of the country's 1995 budget. It noted the introduction of measures designed to redirect a troubled economy "anchored on the philosophy of guarded deregulation."

The objectives of the budget, it said, were also supposed "to restore the dignity of the national currency (the naira), arrest spiral inflation, increase the money supply and attract foreign investment."

However, it said, 12 months after it budget "turned out to be only a modest success against the goals set by the government."

For instance, it noted that the "inflationary rate has persisted, with escalating cost of basic necessities of life. The price mechanism has collapsed due to the inability of the government to induce private sector reduction of the cost of raw materials which has affected the cost of production."

The daily claimed "this has led to down-sizing of the industries with attendant high rate of unemployment."

As a result, it went on, "the standard of living in the country has plummeted considerably leaving Nigerians despondent and impoverised."

The situation, it said, was made "more disconcerting" with the deplorable state of infrastructure and other related public utility services, "thus creating a gloomy climate."

Worse still, it said, "the hostile political atmosphere has undermined the laudable policy thrust of the budget by eroding the confidence of key players."

Turning to soccer, the privately owned Lagos newspaper The Punch paid tribute to George Weah, a Liberian, for winning the Golden Ball award of European football.

"Can anything come out of Liberia? Oh yes one good thing, at least has come out of war-torn Liberia. and that 'one good thing' is George 'Opong' Weah who, Monday became the European Footballer of the Year 1995," it said.

Weah's dexterity in scoring goals, his gentlemanly behaviour on and off the field, it said, were "some of the qualities that must have endeared him to the judges" who chose him for the two awards.

"But perhaps more than these are Weah's outstanding contributions to the development of soccer in his war-ravaged homeland. Single-handedly, he has lifted the Liberian national team by the bootstraps, making all the financial contributions that have made it possible for the team to compete in international competitions," it said.

"It warms the heart to note that Weah's sacrifices and contributions, not only to the Liberian national team but also to African football have not gone unnoticed," it said.

"Weah has done himself proud, he has brought hope to the land of his birth and prestige and honour to every black man," it added.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

75 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Leone Stars Ready to Play


LENGTH: 574 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 16, 1995
by , PANA Staff Correspondent

Nouakchott, Mauritania - After their first appearance in the African Cup of Nations, two years ago in Tunisia, the Leone Stars of Sierra Leone are itching for a tougher fight at the tournament to be held January 1996 in South Africa.

The Sierra Leoneans have proved they have sharp claws in the paws by twice winning, successively, the zone two tournament of the Supreme Council for Sports in Africa.

Alternatively known as the Amilcar Cabral Cup, the zone two tournament was held November 17-18 in the Mauritanian capital, Nouakchott. 

This triumph after a home victory in 1993, is evidence of the country's soccer progress. It emerged from this competition as the only nation in the zone to qualify for the African cup finals. Seven-time Cabral Cup winner Senegal was sidelined.

Sierra Leone did not lose a single game in the Cabral'95, winning five of their six matches without most of their professionals.

In Bloemfontein, South Africa, the Leone Stars will face Zambia, runners up in the 1994 Africa cup, Algeria, 1990 champions, and Burkina Faso, all in group B.

Under Swedish Head Coach Roger Pamgren, who took charge of the team in July, and Abdoulaye Garincha Cesseay, the Leone Stars started training in November. They played friendly matches in Accra and Libreville, losing 2-0 against Ghana's Black Stars and 1-0 against Gabon's Azingo National.

The second phase of preparations December, which includes 14 European based professionals, takes on teams in Belgium, Italy, Portugal and Scotland.

Among the more well known professionals are Mohamed Kanu, who plays for the first division Belgian side Alost, Mohamed Sylla of first division Belgian side Lokeren, and Mohamed Kaloum with first division Inter Milan of Italy. Others are Moussa Kaluga who plays in Portugal, Lamine Konte in Germany), John Lama, Abou Kanu and Biche Bangoura who all play in Sweden.

Sierra Leone will meet Ghana and Gabon again but this time in Freetown before spending a week in Gambia where they will play the Scorpions in Banjul.

Friendly matches are also scheduled against Senegal and Mali before a final training camp in Sweden. "The December matches will allow us to spruce up tactical play in the team, which is undergoing some changes," Pamgren said. "I have noticed improvement in defence as well as in attack. Our passing is better now." The task ahead, he said, was to ensure that the mixture of locals and foreign based professionals worked well together.

The team is more mature, our players want to make an impact in South Africa," team Captain Bah Ibrahimah said.

LANGUAGE: English
