Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Nigerians Are Top Dogs In Group C


LENGTH: 707 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995

Dakar - Nigeria's Super Eagles will be the main attraction in Durban, South Africa, where teams in Group C of the 20th African Cup of Nations will battle to reach the finals and capture the trophy.

Nigeria comes with vast experience, having reached the final four times in the last six competitions. The Super Eagles' best performance was in 1994 in Tunisia, where they won the African trophy fielding an array of talented professionals. 

The Nigerian line-up will be a bit different in South Africa '96, especially in defence: long-serving Captain Stephen Keshi has retired. But the best Nigerian forwards -- Daniel Amokachi, Emmanuel Amunike, George Finidi and Austin Okocha -- are still very much on the attack.

The only uncertainty it the participation of goal poacher Rashidi Yekini, who finished top scorer in Senegal '92 and Tunisia 94. He has been benched for several months because of injury.

At any rate, Super Eagles Dutch coach Jo Bonfrere is not too worried. He has a reservoir of quality players from which to draw: his newest asset, forward Nwankwo Kanu.

Barely aged 20 years, Kanu won the European Champions League 1995 with fellow Nigerian Finidi, both playing for Dutch team Ajax of Amsterdam.

Liberia also has a highly rated squad although this will be its first participation in African Cup finals. In wartorn Liberia, football remains one of the few unifying factors.

Geroge Weah, who symbolises that unity in the team, is rated Africa's best player. He and teammates Joe Nagbe, James Debbah, Christopher Wreh or Mass Sarr, all play in Europe. They are aware of the importance of football in their country and worked hard to qualify the Lone Star for South Africa '96.

However, after qualification, Liberia now has to prove its metal in the finals despite the team's inexperience and weak defence.

Gabon, coached by Alain Da Costa, is hoping to better its performance in Tunisia when, under Belgian coach Jean Thissen, it was booted out in the first round.

However, Tunisia proved a worthwhile experience for Azingo National, as the Gabonese team is known. Since November the team with professionals such as Pierre Yaya Aubame and Guy Roger Nzamba have beeen training together.

And there is Zaire, which has called up 13 professionals in an effort to recover its past soccer crown. In South Africa, the Leopards, as the Zairean team is called, will be directed by Turkish coach Mushi Ertugal.

Zaire started its preparation very early and if players like Dinga Mbote and Lembi Lukaku are at their peak for their third consecutive participation, they will be a force to be reckoned with.

Group C teams and their records in the African Cup:

* Gabon: One participation in 1994. Eliminated in round one.

* Liberia: First participation.

* Nigeria: Ten participations. Champions in 1980 and 1994. Runners-up in 1984, 1988 and 1990; Third in 1976, 1978 and 1992. Eliminated in the second round in 1963 and 1982.

* Zaire: Nine participations. Champions in 1968 and 1974. Fourth in 1972. Quarter-finalists in 1992 and 1994. First round elimination in 1965, 1970, 1976 and 1988.

Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Zairean Football Rocked By Crisis


LENGTH: 200 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995

Kinshasa - The First vice-chairman of the Zairean Football Association, Mvumbi Puati, has decided to leave office temporarily for personal reasons, sources said in Kinshasa.

The decision is said to have resulted from differences between FEZAFA members following a long crisis of legitimacy, the sources added. 

It took the intervention of the International Federation of Association Football, FIFA, to restore order in the association.

Meanwhile, UNIBRA, a brewery in the Zairean capital, has offered 11,000 U. S. dollars to the association as part of its operation "Forward With The Leopards". Zaire's national soccer team is called The Leopards. The money will go to paying bonuses to the players in the 20 African Cup of Nations which kicks off January 13 in South Africa.

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: The South African Enigma


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995

Dakar - The South African national football team, Bafana Bafana, remain an enigma in the ratings for the 20th African Cup of Nations which kicks off January 13 in Johannesburg.

Few African sports analysts have been able to watch the Bafana Bafana. This is because South Africa was banned from continental and international competitions for two decades because of its policy of separate development for all races, also called apartheid. 

However, just three years after the sports ban with South Africa was lifted it organised and won the May 25 to June 24 Rugby World Cup.

Now, with less than three weeks before the 20th Africa Cup, the question asked by many observers is whether the South African footballers can equal the feat of the country's rugby players.

South Africa's Orlando Pirates, winners of the 31st African Champions' Cup on December 16 in Abidjan, have given a first hint of things to come.

Orlando's victory is significant since it marks South Africa's first triumph in continental soccer. It is also a warning to other teams facing the Bafana Bafana in the 20th African Cup.

Despite playing away and before a capacity crowd of 50,000 ASEC supporters in Abidjan's Houphouet Boigny stadium, Orlando's Sea Robbers staged a real "hold up" by winning 1-0 against the odds on favourites. Two weeks earlier they held ASEC 2-2 in Johannesburg.

Bafana Bafana are aiming to use this club's triumph as a springboard to continental glory come January. Their opponents in Group 'A' - Cameroon, Egypt and Angola are warned: The South Africans are tough competitors and with home support can be formidable.

The Pirates' victory in Abidjan follows a series of good results by the South African national team, which also won a the four-nation tournament November in Johannesburg against Cameroon, Egypt and Zambia. Following Orlando's African triumph, President Nelson Mandela said the team had given South African football the perfect platform on which to build to ensure victory in the African Cup tourney.

In another encouraging development, South Africa held treble world champions Germany to a goalless draw on December 15.

The bar of competition is set high, but that is unlikely to deter the Bafana Bafana from trying to clear this obstacle, just as the Springboks did in June against all expectations.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


79 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Of Clubs And National Teams


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995

Dakar - DAKAR, Senegal (PANA) - Algeria, South Africa and Tunisia, three countries competing in the 20th African Cup of Nations, have triumphed at the club level by winning the three continental club competitions.

These victories should be a warning to their opponents in groups 'A', 'B' and 'D', since they are a sign of the three countries' potential to perform well in the African Cup which will be held from January 13 to February 3, 1996. 

Football punters will have to take into account the results of the three African club competitions in making bets for the big event. Players who won an African trophy at club level will be morally and physically ready to lead their national teams to glory.

In the players of Orlando Pirates, 1995 African club champions, South Africa have a reservoir of quality footballers capable of winning matches for the 'Bafana Bafana'.

Likewise, Algeria can draw from Jeunesse Sportive Kabilye, winners of the 21st African Cup Winners' Cup, and Tunisia should build their team around Etoile Sportive Sahel, winners of the 4th Confederation of Africa Football Cup.

However, the African Cup of Nations can be a different competition altogether, where nothing can be definitely decided on in advance. Victory in club competitions does not always rub off on the national team.

In fact, countries whose clubs win African trophies do not always perform well in the African Cup. Such is the case of Egypt, whose clubs, especially Al Ahly and Zamalek, dominated African football in the 1980s. They won the African Cup of Nations at home only in 1986, after a long drought. It could take more than club success to win the 1996 African Cup of Nations.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


80 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Fears of Boycott Over, But Trauma Lingers On


LENGTH: 987 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 20, 1995
by Randy Zormelo, PANA Staff Correspondent

Lagos - The diplomatic row between Nigeria and the international community over the execution last month of nine Ogoni minority rights activists, including the writer Ken Saro-Wiwa, brought fears of a boycott by Nigeria of the Africa Cup of Nations tournament to be played in South Africa from January 13 to February 3, 1996.

The execution triggered the suspension of Nigeria from the Commonwealth and calls for sanctions against the West African country.

That South Africa and the European Union (EU) countries fired the first shots did not go down well with the military authorities in Nigeria.

The EU sports boycott of Nigeria, the spear-heading by South African president Nelson Mandela of an international isolation of Nigeria, and the withdrawal by South Africa of Nigeria's invitation to a four-nation friendly international soccer competition were interpreted in Lagos as acts of hostility which should be met squarely by boycotting the nations cup. 

Opinion was, however, divided on this issue.

While some argued that a boycott would damage Nigeria's prestige as a sporting nation in Africa and the world, others believed it would hurt the EU countries and South Africa, who have invested in the event and stand to gain financially from it, more.

Even FIFA's warning later to South Africa that it was opposed to Nigeria being barred, for political reasons, from the four-nation friendly competition it (South Africa) organised ahead of the cup finals failed to cool down tempers in Lagos.

In fact, it did little to quel the controversy as to whether or not the Super Eagles should keep the appointment in South Africa.

Government's muted reaction to the issue, in spite promises of an official statement, heightened fears of a possible boycott.

"If a 30,000 dollar fine is all Nigeria would suffer in the event of a pull out, we can afford it," an irritated youth and sports ministry official told PANA. But he forgot the proviso that apart from suspension from subsequent editions of the African Cup of Nations, a country that withdraws from the competition faces other sanctions from the Confederation of African Football.

A withdrawal 20 days to the start of the competition would earn the defaulting country suspension from two subsequent editions. In an effort to beat this deadline, the go-ahead finally given the Super Eagles by military the government on Friday to defend the cup they won in Tunisia in 1994 came as a relief to many sports lovers.

But the decision by Nigeria to attend the soccer fiesta was loaded with conditions, including the issuance of visas to its players, officials and supporters by the South African embassy in Lagos and a guarantee by the South African Football Association (SAFA) of their safety and security.

Apart from the political problems that nearly marred the competition, security inside South Africa became a factor following recent incidents in which players and supporters of ASEC Mimosa of Cote d'Ivoire were manhandled and a robbery after the shooting dead of a cashier at the venue of a world boxing title fight in Johannesburg.

Safa's quick move to reassure Nigeria that all the conditions would be met soothed the nerves of soccer its lovers. Sports minister Jim Nwobodo in breaking the news of Nigeria's participation after a marathon meeting, said he had received a letter from SAFA secretary general, Donald Norman, that "all would be well with the Super Eagles".

"The Nations Cup is an African affair. We have no choice as Africans but to join our brothers at the championship," said an apparently appeased Nwobodo. But the saga surrounding the participation of Nigeria in the competition continues and could have a traumatic effect on its team, especially since the sporting sanctions imposed on the country have begun to bite.

Its squad of 26 players, of whom 22 are European-based professionals called to camp last week, could not assemble because Dutch coach Bonfrere Jo failed to obtain visas for his technical crew of three and four local-based players to fly out of the country to Holland where the team was to set camp.

Similarly, Jo was denied visas by the Israeli embassy in Lagos to enable him prepare the squad in Tel Aviv, the alternative site selected by the Nigerian soccer officials. With his plans in complete disarray, Jo is now setting his eyes on Morocco, Ethiopia or Kenya as possible camp sites -- about 25 days to the tournament.

The Eagles' state of preparedness will now depend not only on their physical fitness and cohesion but also on their ability to psychologically overcome the trauma of sporting sanctions.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


81 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Ivorian Elephants End Home Training


LENGTH: 627 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 19, 1995

Abidjan From the West African's political capital, the group, of mainly locally-based soccer stars, will travel to either Italy or France where they are expected to blend their tactics with European-based professionals.

ABIDJAN, Cote D'Ivoire (PANA) - The Ivorian national football team, known as the 'Elephants', Monday ended an initial two-week training stint in Yamoussoukro, to prepare for the 20th African Cup of Nations finals in South Africa.

The team's handlers said six professionals are to join the final training phase. These are France-based Tiehi Joel (Martigues) and Moussa Traore (Ales), who have been called up by the national coach, Frenchman Pierre Plemelding. 

But the team will greatly miss hit-man Ahmed Ouattara, another professional who plays for Sporting Lisbon in Portugal. He has been medically declared unfit for four months following a recent injury in a league match.

Cote D'Ivoire, who have been drawn in Group 'D', will play in Port Elizabeth against Ghana, Mozambique and Tunisia.

The 'Elephants' started their training camp on December 6 in Yamoussoukro with a group of local players.

They were Hoba Guy, Traore Zacharie, Hobou Arsene, Genito Kpassagnon, Lue Ruffin, Kone Ibrahima, Kone Adama Clofie, Gouamene Maxime, Die Serge (Africa Sports), Kamara Ibrahim, Tizie Jean-Jacques, Loue Guy Claude, Zeze Tape (Stade d'Abidjan), Tidiane Youssouf, Obou Macaire, Bile Serges (Stella Abidjan), Dadie Hyacinthe, Grobli Mihel, Tiene Aboubacr and Seri Ambroise (SOA).

In one of the team's test matches, the home-based boys won the international peace tournament 'Belier D'Afrique', staged from November 26 to December 2 in Libreville, Gabon, in the memory of the late president Felix Houphouet Boigny of Cote d'Ivoire, who died two years ago.

In that competition's final match, the Ivorians beat Algeria 2-1.The other teams were Cameroon which came third while hosts Gabon held the tail. All the four teams have qualified for the Cup of Nations final in South Africa.

In their second outing, December 9, the 'Elephants' beat visiting Mali 2-1 in the central town of Bouake. In the final residential training in Europe, the Ivorian side will be reinforced with players from African vice-champions, ASEC of Abidjan. The team lost to South Africa's Orlando Pirates on a 3-2 goal aggregate in the final of the 31st African Champions' Cup on December 6. The Ivorians have an impressive participation record in the African Cup of Nations, which is held every two years.

South African '96 will be 12th involvement of the 'Elephants' in the prestigious continental cup's finals (1965, 1968, 1970, 1974, 1980, 1984, 1986, 1988, 1990, 1992, 1994 and 1996). After failing to win the trophy at home in 1984, the Ivorian side finally won the 18th edition in 1992 when it was hosted by Senegal.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


82 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Ivorian Still Tops Scorers' Chart


LENGTH: 334 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 19, 1995

Dakar - Cote d'Ivoire's Laurent Pokou still holds the record for the largest number of goals scored in the African Cup of Nations.

The famous Ivorian striker scored 14 goals in two editions -- six in 1968 in Ethiopia and eight in 1970 in Sudan. 

He is followed by Nigerian Rashidi Yekini with 13 goals. Yekini finished top scorer in the last two editions with four goals in Senegal (1992) and five in Tunisia (1994), where he missed a number of chances which, if converted, would have allowed him to beat Pokou's record.

Yekini had scored once in 1988 and three times in 1990. The Nigerian centre forward, who sustained a serious knee injury and has been sidelined for a long time, could have another opportunity to beat Pokou's goal tally if he is included in the 'Super Eagles'' line up.

The third all-time top scorer in the African Cup is Egyptian Hassan Chazli with 12 goals in three editions -- six in 1963, five in 1970 and one in 1974.

Only one of the leading scorers in the African competition is certain to play in South Africa: Ivorian Abdoulay Traore, alias Ben Badi.

However, the top scorer for a single edition of the African cup is Zaire's Ndaye Mulamba, who netted nine goals in 1974 in Egypt. Egypt's Diab Mohamed El-Attar remains the top goal scorer in one match. He netted all four goals in the final of the first edition which Egypt won 4-0 against Ethiopia. The 20th Africa Cup of Nations championships open in South Africa net month.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


83 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: The Missing Giants Morocco


LENGTH: 427 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 19, 1995

Dakar - Morocco's national football team, the Atlas Lions, will be among the giants missing in the 20th African Cup of Nations which kicks off next January in South Africa.

Morocco's international record shows one African Cup victory in 1976 in Addis Ababa (Ethiopia) and three participations in the World Cup finals -- in 1970 and 1986 (Mexico) and in 1994 (United States). 

However, the Atlas Lions failed to qualify for South Africa '96, losing the qualifying spots of group 7 to Burkina Faso's 'Stallions' and Cote D'Ivoire's 'Elephants'.

Burkina Faso won the group's top slot, against all odds, as the Ivorians and Moroccans were hot favourites to qualify.

With a tally of three points, Morocco finished third, behind Burkina Faso (7 points) and Cote D'Ivoire (4 points).

The Moroccans saw their African dream wrecked by the Stallions, who beat them 2-1 in Burkina Faso and drew against them in Morocco.

Morocco then beat Cote D'Ivoire 1-0 in Casablanca and lost to the same team 0-2 in Abidjan.

Other former African champions who failed to clinch a ticket for South Africa '96 are Ethiopia, 1962 winners in Addis Ababa; Sudan, 1970 winners in Khartoum; and Congo, 1972 winners in Yaounde.

However, it was not a surprise that these three teams failed to make it because they are no longer the football giants they used to be on the continent.

The elimination of Senegal, Guinea and Mali, participants in the 19th edition in Tunisia, was also an upset for some.

The three Zone II countries peformed rather well in the 1994 edition. But Sierra Leone will be the Zone's only representatives in South Africa.

Supporters of Senegal's 'Lions', Mali's 'Eagles', and Guinea's 'Sily' will now have to watch other teams for thrills.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Ivorians Hold Consecutive Record


LENGTH: 387 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 21, 1995
by , PANA Staff Correspondent

Dakar - Twenty-eight African national soccer teams will have played in the African Nations Cup at least once by the time the 20th tournament ends in South Africa February 3, 1996.

Egypt, with 15 appearances, has the highest showing. But the best attendance index goes to Cote d'Ivoire. This is because it has made the most appearances without interruption. From 1984 to 1994, Cote D'Ivoire has participated in 12 straight tournaments.

Cote d'Ivoire's achievement is noteworthy since, unlike Egypt which first took part in the competition in 1957, the Ivorian Elephants appeared in CAN for their first time in 1965.

Beside Egypt and Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana and Nigeria are the next most regular attendants in the cup finals. If their outing in South Africa is figured in, they will have each attended 12 tournaments.

But whereas some 20 countries have yet to make their fist attendance at the soccer festival, 12 others have managed this just once.

This is true for Mauritius which appeared in 1974, Tanzania (1980), Libya (1982), Malawi (1984). In South Africa, Angola and Liberia will be competing in the tournament for the first time. Egypt remains the only country which, so far, has refused to play in the competitions after qualifying. Citing political reasons, the Pharaohs stayed away in Libyan '92.

The best performance-attendance ratio is held by Libya. It is the only team which has reached the final in its only showing.

Mali also gets credit for notable performances. It lost 3-2 to Congo in the 1972 final and reached the 1994 Tunis
semi-final albeit ending in a 4-0 drubbing by Zambia.

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Ivorian 'Elephants' Off to French Camp


LENGTH: 760 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 21, 1995
by Kone Souleymane, PANA Staff Correspondent

Abidjan - The Ivorian national soccer team, the Elephants, left Abidjan Tuesday for France where they will begin their last preparations for the 20th African Cup of Nations.

Coach Pierre Pleimelding of France released the list of 23 players who will train in Mouries, four kilometres outside the southern port city of Marseilles.

Five professionals will be taking part in these preparations. They are defender Cyrille Domoraud of the French Second Division team Red Star and strikers Tiehi Joel of Martigues French Division One, Bakayoko Ibrahima of First Division French club Monpellier, Moussa Traore of Second Division French club Ales and Bassole Michel of the Saudi Arabian First Division club El Ittihad. 

Another professional, Ahmed Ouattara who plays for Sporting Lisbon in Portugal is out of action for four months following a recent knee injury.

The final list of 22 payers picked for South Africa will be released January 3 1996.

Cote D'Ivoire, which is in group B, will play in Port Elizabeth along with Ghana, Tunisia and Mozambique.

The vice chairman of the Ivorian Football Association in charge of the press, Oscar Kossehasse, said the French city was chosen for the last stage of the preparation because the climate was similar to that of Port Elizabeth.

"In Port Elizabeth, Cote D'Ivoire will play in temperatures between 15 and 20 degrees," he said. "In Mouries, or players will be training in temperatures of 16 or 17 degrees."

He said that this training stint was of utmost importance to the team because it would be first by all the players together.

Pleimelding said that the Elephants will play five friendlies in Mouries against a selection of National 1 (the French Premier League) players on December 23, Martigues on December 26, a Monaco team on December 30, a First Division selection on January 3 and the Montpellier team on January 6.

Before leaving for France, the players received 200,000 francs cfa (about 417 U.S. dollars) each as part of their 500,000 franc (1,042 dollar) allowance. The balance will be given to them in Marseille.

The team will return to Abidjan January 8 and board a special flight, the same day, for Johannesburg.

Following are the players shortlisted by the coach Pleimelding for final selection: Their clubs are in brackets:

Goalkeepers: Diarra Seydou, Konate Losseni (ASEC), Obou Macaire (STELLA).

Defenders: Aka Kouame, Akassou Ghislain, Kouassi Jean-Marie, Dao Lassina (ASEC), Cyrille Domoraud (Red Star France), Gneto Kpassagnon and Hobou Arsene (Africa Sports), Kamara Ibrahima (Stade D'Abidjan).

Mid-Field: Sie Donald, Guel Tchiressoa, Aliou Badra Sibi, Serge Maguy Alain (ASEC), Kone Ibrahim and Die Serges (Africa Sports).

Forwards: Tiehi Joel (Martigues-France), Traore Abdoulaye, Sekou Bamba (ASEC), Bassole Michel (El Ittihad-Arabie Saoudite), Bakayoko Ibrahima (Montpellier-France), Moussa Traore (Ales-France).

Reserves: Keeper: Gouamene Alain (Toulouse Division 2 France), Defence: Djedje Darius and N'Guessan Serge (Stella), Forwards: Kone Adama Clofie (Africa).

Technical Staff: Pierre Pleimelding (coach), Wolle Basile (deputy coach), Da Silva Gilbert (goalkeepers coach) and Kablan Sampon (head coach).

Medical Staff: Dr. Sangare Malick (doctor) and Bakayoko (physiotherapist).

Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Eleven Pros Join Zairean Team


LENGTH: 267 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 21, 1995

Kinshasa - Zaire's national football coach, Mushin Ertugal, has called up eleven professionals to join the team currently preparing for the finals of the African Cup of Nations, kicking off in South Africa January 13.

The eleven professionals, including Mukanya (Lomel, Belgium), Essende (Durban, South Africa), Ndinga Mbote (Guimaraes, Portugal), Bunene (Turkey), Lembi (Brugge, Belgium) and Lukaku (Seraing, Belgium), have been asked to join the team in Kinshasa by the end of December. 

However, while the form of players such as Mukanya, Ndinga Mbote, Lembi and Lukaku, who represented Zaire in Tunisia '94 is known, the fitness of several others is doubtful.

Locally-based national team players are undergoing two training sessions per day at Kinshasa's Kamanyola Stadium.

In a test match on December 2, the Leopards were held to a 2-2 draw by Etoile Club of Congo.

The result discouraged Kinshasa soccer fans who had expected foreworks from the team, which had just returned from training stints in Germany and Turkey.

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Abdoulaye Traore, The Enigma


LENGTH: 654 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 21, 1995
by , PANA Staff Correspondent

Dakar - Enigmatic goalscorer Abdoulaye Traore, alias 'Ben Badi', will be among Cote D'Ivoire's major assets in the 20th African Nations Cup which kicks off on 13 January in South Africa.

Aged 29, Traore will play in the African Cup for the 6th time and will be among the most experienced players in South Africa '96.

Ben Badi has a knack for scoring goals, and decisive ones at that. The Ivorian centre forward, who has been a regular of the African Cup since Egypt '86, is currently fourth in the competition's scoring chart with nine goals, behind fellow Ivorian Laurent Pokou (14), Nigerian Rashidi Yekini (13) and Egyptian Hassan Cahzli (12). 

In 1986, he scored the only goal in Cote D'Ivoire's 1-0 win over Senegal, one of the favourites, and opened the door to the semi-finals for the Elephants.

Since then, he has been netting goals in the African Cup with a regularity which does not match the pattern of his footballing career, which could have been far more successful.

Traore, whose build and goal poaching ability are reminiscent of Germany's Gerd Muller, who terrorised defenders in the 1970s, did not have the career observers deemed suitable for his talent.

His critics blame this on a lack of ambition.

But Ben Badi says he was penalised by incompetent coaches and managers.

Whatever the case, Abdoulaye Traore has so far failed to win his place in professional football despite being among Africa's top goalscorers in the last few years.

In 1974, he left Stella Club of Abidjan for ASEC, the most popular team in the Ivorian economic capital.

But this was only the beginning in the Traore saga. When called up for the national team, he deserted a training camp in Yamoussoukro in 1985. This caused an outcry among football fans. He then left for FC Metz in the French first division, when he was only 18.

However, Traore could not adjust to the harsh Lorraine winter. He is good at scoring goals in almost any position, but he does not like to suffer.

This latter side of his character was a liability in professional football, and his short stay in Portugal, after France, was also a failure.

In 1990, he eventually decided to return home to ASEC. The club had then been in the shadow of arch-rivals Africa Sports of Abidjan for 10 years.

But on his return, Ben Badi outclassed opponents to help ASEC to the national title. By so doing, he became the idol of ASEC's management and supporters alike, despite being somewhat inconsistent.

Ivorian football fans are hoping that Traore will have digested the disillusion of losing the African Champions' Cup to South Africa's Orlando Pirates when the 20th African Cup of Nations kicks off. Otherwise, it will be difficult for the Elephants to repeat their triumph of 1992 in Senegal.

However, the African Cup will be the best opportunity for Traore to show that his talent has remained undented and silence his critics.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Burkina Faso's "Stallions" Receive Support


LENGTH: 280 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 29, 1995
by Christophe Nanga, PANA Staff Correspondent

Ouagadougou - Burkina Faso's soccer team, the Stallions, has received a 6,315-U.S.-dollar ticket to the African Nations Cup scheduled mid-January in South Africa.

This will not be enough to pay the air tickets for the entire squad and team officials but it will help. 

The three-million franc cfa cheque came from the country's post office and was handed to the chairman of the Burkina faso Football Association, Didier Ouedraogo, by Communication Minister Claude Somda.

The post office was responding to an appeal by government to support the Stallions for the Nations Cup finals which begin January 13.

In a related development, the post office said it would begin January 4 issuing stamps bearing the logo of South Africa '96. The stamps will also picture the Stallions.

The team left Ouagadougou, the Burkina Faso capital, Wednesday for acclimatization in Botswana.

An Italian sportsware company donated clothes to the team and said it would give it some 37,894 dollars between now and the 1998 World Cup.

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Nigeria Pulls Out


LENGTH: 774 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 30, 1995
by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

Lagos - Defending champions, Nigeria, have pulled out of the 20th Africa Cup of Nations tournament kicking off January 13, 1996 in South Africa, because of security reasons, Sports Minister Jim Nwobodo announced in Lagos Saturday.

"We regret that this decision which has been painfully taken as a last resort after exploring all possible ways to ensure the safety of our players and the prevalence of an atmoshpere of fairplay," he told a news conference.

The minister said reports by Nigerian Foreign Ministry had shown very serious security risks for Nigerian players in South Africa. 

The Nigerian National team known as the Super Eagles was to have left Lagos Friday for Nairobi, Kenya for training ahead of the 16-nation soccer fiesta in South Africa.

Nigeria and South Africa have been involved in a diplomatic row following the November 10 executions of nine Ogoni activists, among them the author Ken Saro-Wiwa.

The execution of the nine, convicted of murdering four of their kinsmen from southeastern Nigeria in 1994, has provoked international condemnations and sanctions against the West African nation.

Pretoria recalled its envoy from Lagos and imposed arms embargo on Nigeria, because of the executions. President Nelson Mandela has vowed to intensify international efforts to isolate Nigeria.

South Africa also withdrew Nigeria's invitation to a recent four-nation soccer tournament, while Miss Nigeria was forced to withdraw from the Miss World Pageant in South Africa's Sun City.

Announcing the withdrawal from the nations cup, Minister Nwobodo said "we know that there are repercussions and even possible sanctions, but far more important is the safety of lives of our players."

He said Nigeria would explain to the African Football Confederation, CAF, the constraints that compelled it to take this course of action.

According to Nwobodo "there is no superior consideration than that of lives of our citizens particularly such great ambassadors as our players, officials and fans."

He said that if a Nigerian player was seriously maimed or killed by violent action "a terrible blemish would have been caused not only to CAF and the cup of nations but a further souring of relations between Nigeria and South Africa would be inescapable."

"These threats do not only concern the acceptable sporting disapproval signals of jeering and whistling but border seriously on life and death."

The minister said Nigeria had requested written assurances from the South African Football Association, SAFA, but there had been no positive response.

The Eagles' Dutch coach, Jo Bonfrere told PANA he was "disppointed" by the withdraw news. "There is confusion all over, but I am still hopeful if we receive the assurance we will travel to South Africa to defend the cup," he added.

The coach said all the 26 invited players, but three, who were to have joined the team in Kenya, were now in Lagos.

The Eagles' Skipper Austin Eguavoen was equally disappointed. He said the players had waited for two days for the minister's address, "only to receive a sad news."

But he said the minister had been "painstaking" in explaining the situation to the players.

" I am going to appeal to the players to take it easy and go back to their various clubs," Eguavoen said.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


90 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Nations Cup: Nigeria Risks World Soccer Limbo


LENGTH: 814 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 31, 1995
by Paul Ejime, PANA Staff Correspondent

Lagos - Going by standing rules, Nigeria risks being barred from international soccer for the rest of the century following its decision Saturday to withdraw from the 20th Africa Nations Cup due to kick-off in South Africa in the next two weeks.

The African champions took the decision citing fear for the safety of their players. This followed a diplomatic row between both countries after the November 10 executions for murder of nine Nigerian minority rights activists, including the writer Ken Saro-Wiwa. 

Article 14 (4) of the African Football Confederation (CAF) rules and regulations frowns at withdrawals from the confederation's competitions.

Among other sanctions, the rule says an offending country could forfeit affiliation fees, pay a hefty fine and risk suspension from subsequent editions of the championships.

Football analysts in Lagos say the implication of such sanctions is that Nigeria could be barred from the 1998 Africa Nations Cup. And if the measures are endorsed by the world's soccer governing body, FIFA, Nigeria could also be excluded from the preliminaries and finals of the 1998 world cup in France.

In reference to the grim scenerio, sports minister Jim Nwobodo, while announcing Nigeria's withdrawl from the Africa Nations Cup, said the country "will dutifully explian to CAF the constraints that have compelled us to take this course of action."

There have still to be official reactions from CAF and F*IFA, which early this year, citing security reasons, withdrew Nigeria's hosting right for the world youth soccer tournament.

Meanwhile, members of Nigeria's national team, the Super Eagles have continued to express disappointment over the country's withdrawal from the nations cup.

Africa's 1993 footballer of the year, Rasidi Yekini said "football is so important to us in the country and our lives are at stake too. But the competition is good for our career," he added.

To prevent the country from missing the World Cup and other international competitions, Rasidi, who now plays in Spain, said Nigeria should contact CAF and FIFA to extract security guarantees for Nigerians from South Africa.

He said the Eagles could travel to South Africa under a 24-hour-notice to defend the trophy they won in 1994 in Tunisia.

Another Eagle, Victor Ikpeba of Liege Monaco, France, said he would "hang around for another three days," to see if Nigeria would change its mind.

Equally disppointed was Celestine Babayaro, who said "it is unfortunate because I am appearing in the competition for the first time."

The Eagles' Dutch coach, Jo Bonfrere remained hopeful. He said he collected the contact addresses of the players, saying that "a phone call or fax can make the difference."

Reports reaching PANA Sunday from Johannesburg said South African soccer officials had expressed shock and disappointment at Nigeria's decision to withdraw from the Cup of Nations.

The official News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) quoted the president of the South African Football Association (SAFA), Solomon Morewa as saying "we are surprised with the decision. We are utterly devastated. We have assured the nigeran officials and the team of security and we mean no harm to them whatsoever."

He said South Africa was well prepared to receive the Eagles, adding "only on Friday last week we received a full list of the Nigerian contingent and we had since started processing visas for them. They should have told us then that they were not coming."

Morewa was quoted as saying his country intended to seek CAF's intervention in the matter.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


91 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Lest Africans Forget


LENGTH: 1374 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 31, 1995
by Felix Njoku, PANA Staff Correspondent

Dakar - By and large, Africa will be the only continent not counting its blessings at the end of this century. And going by the state of most African countries at the end of 1995, one might well ask whether "this blighted continent is under a kind of evil spell".

Otherwise, how does one explain a situation whereby the continent has become an island of want and depravation in a world bristling with wealth and modernity.
The superstitous trace the origin of the black race to the biblical figure Cain, the accursed brother of Abel, both born of Adam and Eve -- the first known couple on earth. 

A section of the Bible says Cain was condemned to perpetual servitude byGod after he killed his brother out of jealousy. The fugitive is said to have migrated to the area now known as Africa. Based on this unauthenticated reasoning, Africans are said to be the direct decendants of the "Murderer"

At least one religious sect, The Dutch Reformed Church used what many now believe to be a fallacy to justify the subjugation of black peoples in South Africa for centuries.

Some revisionists still think there could be some truth in the story. Otherwise, they ask, how can anybody explain a situation where one particular race has had to bear the burden of humanity for so long?

Only some sort of magical spell, they argue, could have made it possible for 20 million offsprings of one race to be shipped like logs thousands of miles across the Atlantic Ocean and enslaved for several centuries, for instance.

Slavery and long years of equally excruciating colonialism have now become history. Sometimes, discussion on their affect of on the black race come up in international fora but merely to support calls for assistance or feeble demands for reparations.

The director-general of the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation, Federico Mayor, Had cause to raise the subject once again at the beginning of the outgoing year. Mayor's point was that the rich West was heavily indebted to Africa in cash and kind. "The modern wealth, power and dynamism of the West are in large measure the result of the forced contribution exacted from Africa.

"This enormous contribution in the form of people, hard labour, sacrifice and also natural resources was exacted first by slavery and then by colonisation.

"The massive and historically unprecedented haemorrhage slowly drained Africa of its very lifeblood, its vital, creative and productive energy, which we must today make heroic efforts to reconstitute, whatever the cost," Mayor said at a forum on development called Audience Africa he hosted February in Paris.

But analysts say while advocacy for Africa is most welcome, the situation in most of the countries today makes it almost impossible for them to put such assistance to good use.

After the lost decade of the 1980s, Africa was supposed to be a net beneficiary of the so-called dividend of the end of cold war and the collapse of the Belin wall. The belief, then, was that since the continent provided the battle ground for the East-West confrontation of the era, peace and prosperity would reign here as the big powers reconciled their differences. This has not been the case. Spurred by the the wind of democracy (some call it "demoncrazy"), internacine instincts nurtured by colonialism and kept in the cooler by totalitarian regimes have begun to surface.

For instance, since 1993 when Hutus and Tutusi in Burundi and Rwanda began to see virtue in drawing blood from one another, ethnic wars have assumed wider dimension on the continent. What the trend portends for a continent, home of one-third of the world's 6,000 major ethnic groups, can only be imagined.

Worse, in some African countries the ethnic card has been raised to the level of state craftsmanship. Recent "democratic" elections in Cote d'Ivoire took place over the corpses of dozens of poor people. Why? Violence was used to supress opposition protest against a constitutional disqualification of one of its own, to wit Alassan Ouattara, a former prime minister of the country in which he is now regarded as a "foreigner".

In Zambia the opposition is currently engaged in a running battle with the ruling party as the later tries to push an article in a draft constitution that would effectively bar some Zambians from contesting presidential elections. One of the people who would be affected by the new law is former President Kenneth Kaunda. He was born in the territory of Malawian parents before Zambia gained independence. The move seems to have backfired as incumbent President Frederick Chiluba and aides are now fighting hard to prove that his parents were not Zaireans.

Though paramount, these are not isolated cases. Divisions either on ethnic, linguistic, religious or racial grounds are mounting in many Africa countries, compromising national unity and development.

Farther afield sub-regional groups, which were supposed to foster integrated development, rather tend to assume the posture of hostile blocs with the potential of wrecking what remains of the African unity the likes of Kwame Nkrumah and Cheikh Anta Diop worked and died for.

The nine-rounds of polling held to select the President of the African Development Bank in Abuja and Abidjan in June and August, and the bad blood it bred between states is a pointer to the damage which such a posture could breed.

Apparently taking a cue from high quarters, it is not unsual now to hear Africans refer to folk from North, South, East and West of the continent in such derogatory terms that one begins to wonder what is happening. Some have fallen in love so much with the foreign languages they speak that stupid reference as "francofools" for Francophones and "Anglophobes" for Anglophones have become part of everday vocabulary. Naturally, this evil ingenuity leaves no room for anybody to discover and popularise the common "Africophone" heritage.

Poor Africans who migrate to neighbouring countries feel the pinch the most. They are tagged "illegal immigrants" and shipped back whence they came.

The irony of this is that it is happening at a time when the concept of the state is shifting from geopolitical considerations to economic viability. More successful states are girding themselves to face the challenges of "ecostates" while Africans, who constitute only one-tenth of the world population, are recoiling into their various ethnic cocoons. Is it not time Africans took a long walk down memory lane?


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


92 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Summary of African Events in 1995


LENGTH: 40574 words


 
Panafrican News Agency
December 31, 1995

Dakar- The following are the highlights of events concerning Africa as reported by the Panafrican News Agency, PANA, in 1995.

Summary of African Events in January 1995

JANUARY 2

LAGOS, Nigeria - Ousted Somali military ruler Mohammed Siad Barre dies early in his exiled home, Nigeria. Barre, believed to be 75 years old, arrived in Nigeria May 17, 1992 with several members of his family.

JANUARY 3

LUSAKA, Zambia - Retail trade in African merchandise including promotional campaigns for "afrocentric goods" earn almost three billion U.S. dollars yearly on the African American market, the World Bank says in a report.

The report, quoted in the Washington Line, a publication of the United States Information Services, says there is growing demand among middle and upper-middle class African Americans for African luxury goods on which they spend large sums of money annually. 

NAIROBI, Kenya - Some 2,000 Kenya Railways Corporation technical staff in Mombasa go on strike demanding a salary increament of between 30 percent and 45 percent.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - A 21-kilometre road linking urban and rural areas of eastern Khartoum, built by Libya, is declared open at a ceremony attended by President Omar El-Bashir and Libyan Prime Minister Abdulateef El Gauod.

JANUARY 4

KHARTOUM, Sudan - A man and his wife who hijacked a Sudenese aircraft on an internal flight surrender to special forces at Port Sudan Airport in the east of the country.

KAMPALA, Uganda - Ugandan traders rush to Rwanda to beat deadline to exchange old franc notes with new ones in the neighbouring country. The rush follows an announcement January 2 on Radio Rwanda by the National Bank of Rwanda Governor, Gerald Niyitegeka, that new notes would be issued January 3-4 to replace 5,000, 1,000 and 500 Rwandan franc notes.

NAIROBI, Kenya - A plane carrying 190 somali refugees leaves the Kenyan Indian Ocean coastal city of Mombasa for Berbera, Somalia, bringing to 1,200 the number of Somali refugees to be voluntarily repatriated since December 23, 1994.

ABUJA, Nigeria - Nigeria's military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha receives Anthony Enahoro, 71, a former minister who was freed December 1994 after four months in detention.

No official details of the surprise closed-door meeting between Abacha and the human rights activist are given. Enahoro became information minister in Nigeria's first post-independence government. He is credited with moving the historic motion calling for the country's independence from Britain 1960.

JANUARY 5

NIAMEY, Niger - Legislative elections scheduled in Niger for January 7 are postponed to January 12. The government says it has taken the measure because the electoral committee is unable to organise the polls by the date set.

TRIPOLI, Libya - At the end of a two-day meeting in Tunis, interior ministers from 21 Arab League States adopt a draft code on ways to combat the spread of fundamentalism in their countries.

JANUARY 9

ACCRA, Ghana - One of Liberian factional leaders, G.V. Kromah fails to arrive in Accra on time, forcing the adjournment of a crucial meeting on Liberia's future politial structure.

Kromah is scheduled to join other Liberian warring leaders in the Ghanaian capital to elect members of Liberia's Council of State which is to rule until elections are held.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's constitutional conference resumes its final plenary as the West African country enters the second week of great expectations in 1995.

ALGIERS, Algeria - Despite threats by Moslim militants, Western European nations say they will keep their embassies open in Algiers, the Algerian capital, state radio reports.

It does not mention any extra security measures taken by the seven countries concerned. The embassies concerned, those of Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Russia, Yugoslavia, worked normally January 8.

JANUARY 10

ACCRA, Ghana - Charles Taylor, leader of the National Patariotic Front of Liberia announces in Accra that he is the choice of his group for the five-member council of state which will rule Liberia until elections are held in the troubled West Africa State.

LAGOS, Nigeria - The international Court of Justice at the Hague is to begin proceedings March 16 in the territorial dispute between Nigeria and neighbouring Cameroon over ownership of the Bakassi Peninsula, Nigerian Justice Minister Michael Agbamuche says.

Briefing journalists in Lagos, on the activities of his ministry, he says the court has given Cameroon until March 16 to file its case. Nigeria will have until December 18 to reply.

PARIS - King Juan Carlos of Spain and former United States President Jimmy Carter are named winners of UNESCO'S 1994 Felix Houphouet-Boigny peace prize.

King Carlos Is honoured for his "role guaranteeing the transition to democracy and his continous role in the protection of minorities in the evolution of democracy and his international role of conciliation."

Carter is honoured for his contribution to "the purusit of peace in many different parts of the world and as a private citizen has managed to contribute even when government at first had not necessarily invited him," the award's organisers say in Paris.

JANUARY 11

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian university lecturers suspend their five-month strike for better pay and adequate funding of higher education, their spokesman tells Radio Nigeria.

The national president of the Academic Staff Union of Universities, Asisi Assobie, is quoted by the radio as saying the teachers decided to call off the strike in response to appeals from various individuals and organisations.

Lecturers in Nigeria's 37 universities launched a strike August 22, 1994 to press various demands, including the establishment of stabilisation funds to run the universities.

DAKAR, Senegal - The summit of the Organisation for the Development of the Senegal River, OMVS, opens under the shadow of a three-billion-franc cfa (5.67 million dollars) debt the four member states owe the body.

The summit's four leaders -- Lansana Conte of Guinea, Alpha Oumar Konare of Mali, Maaouya Ould Sid'Ahmed Taya of Mauritania and Abdou Diouf of Senegal -- discuss ways of improving the management of the body during the two-day meeting.

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso - Representatives from 10 West African countries begin a four-day seminar in Ouagadougou to evaluate the effects on consumers in the sub-region following the devaluation of the cfa franc.

They represent consumers' organisations in Benin, Cameroon, Cote D'Ivoire, Gabon, Ghana, Liberia, Mali, Niger, Nigeria and Senegal.

TUNIS, Tunisia - The chairman of the Organisation of African Unity, Zine Al-Abidine Ben Ali, creates an annual prize, to be given January 11, for people exceptional in safeguarding the rights of children.

NIAMEY, Niger - Niger's worker's unions announce they will suspend their weekly 48-hour strike in view of legislative elections scheduled January 12.

JANUARY 12

NIAMEY, Niger - The National Movement for the Society in Development wins 29 of the 83 available seats in parliamentary elections.

An estimated four million voters in the landlocked West African state went to the polls to elect a new parliament.

Some 774 candidates from 15 parties vied for the seats. The legislature was dissolved by President Mahamane Ousmane after his ruling coalition government was brought down by an opposition vote of no confidence.

DAKAR, Senegal - Presidents from Mali and Mauritania witness as President Abdou Diouf of Senegal officially inaugurates a private radio station which ends the state monopoly in broadcasting in Senegal.

The station, Sud FM, started running trial transmissions six months prior to the ceremony.

JANUARY 13

NIAMEY, Niger - Niger's National Movement for the Developing Society, formerly the only political party in the country, wins seven of the 11 parliamentry seats.

The party, which became the major parliamentary opposition body after Niger's first multiparty elections in 1992, performs well in areas inhabited by minority ethnic groups, especially Tuareg nomads.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Ethiopian paleontologist Yohannes Haile-Selassie claims discovery of the partial skeleton of the world's earliest human ancestor, 4.4 million years old.

At a news conference in Addis Ababa given by a team of international scientists Yohannes says he found the fossils at Uits of Aramis, in the Afar region of the Middle Awash study area of Ethiopia.

The remains are one million years older than the "Lucy" partial skeleton found to the north of Aramis 20 years

JANUARY 16

LIBREVILLE, Gabon - A former military aide to Gabonese President Omar Bongo is arrest on suspicion of being the leader of a gang of armed robbers, police say.

Reporting this, the Gabonese News Agency says that Col. Mamadou Ibrahim, a one-time governor of Libreville Central Prison, has suffered a heart attack under police questioning. He is taken to the Jeanne Ebori Foundation, a medical facility.

MASERU, Lesotho - African universities are told to halt declining adacemic standards and strive to regain their past credibility. This comes from King Letsie III of Lesotho at the meeting of the African Associaiton of Universities.

JANUARY 18

LUSAKA, Zambia - Twenty-four junior doctors at Ndola Central Hospital, in Zambia's Northern Copperbelt Region, continue their strike for the third straight day, protesting alleged poor management at the semi-autonomous institution.

They accuse Executive Director Patrick Nyendwa of squandering money on non-medical purchases. They charge, also, that he has caused artifical shortages of essential drugs and medical equipment.

COTONOU, Benin - Japan and Benin signs an agreement for a Japanese grant of 61.7 billion F CFA (about 116.98 million dollars) to finance a rural water supply project and the improvement of Cotonou's drainage system.

NAIROBI, Kenya - The Central Bank of Kenya puts into circulation the high denomination 1,000 shilling currency note.

JANUARY 19

CONAKRY, Guinea - Guinea's parliamentary elections is stalled due to government's failure to pay 100 millions Guinean francs (124,000 U.S. dollars) to a computer firm compiling data for the polls, the country's Electoral Commission Chairman Ibrahim Fofana says in Conakry.

JANUARY 20

NAIROBI, Kenya - Kenya police anti-narcotics agents recover a multimillion consignment of hard drugs at the centre of a major scandal in an executive bungalow in a Nairobi surburb, the Kenya News Agency reports. It does not say when the seizure was made.

Police estimates the street value of the six tonnes of drug at 480 million Kenya shillings (about 10.8 million U.S. dollars).

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana President Jerry Rawlings holds discussions with the foreign ministers of Burkina Faso and Nigerian on the stalled Liberian peace process. Rawlings, Baba Gana Kingibe of Nigeria and Ablasse Ouedraogo of Burkina Faso agree negotiations must resume urgently.

NEW YORK - Libya, under a United Nations embargo imposed in 1992, condemns the use of sanctions to maintain or restore international peace and security, saying that they are incompatible with development.

Libya is under U.N. sanctions for refusing to surrender to the United States and Britain two of its nationals, accused of involvement in the bombing of a Pan Am Jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Ghana Airways and Egypt Air this week save Nigeria Airways from further embarrassment by clearing its backlog of stranded passengers in Jeddah, Lagos and London.

DAKAR, Senegal - An African regional meeting begins in Dakar to prepare the sixth general assembly of the World Association of Community Radio Broadcasters. The two-day meeting attracts 80 representatives of private radios and national community radios from various African regions.

JANUARY 23

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The Kamenge Military Hospital and the Bujumbura neighbourhoods of North and South Muganga are attacked by 58 people in gendarmerie uniforms, state radio reports.

It says one of the attackers is killed and another wounded. A government military truck is burned and 19 civilian cars damaged.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - African ministers, troubled by deteriorating political, economic and social conditions of the continent, meet to grapple with these woes.

The United Nations Economic Commission for Africa says in a study that preliminary estimates for 1994 show that Africa's economic output has grown by 2.8 per cent. However, these gains were offset by a population increasing at 3.2 per cent per annum.

The 53-member Organisation of African Unity is represented by 32 ministers at this 61st ordinary session. Cape Verde, Gambia, Guinea-Bissau, Mauritania, Seychelles and Somalia fail to send delegations to the opening.

JANUARY 24

KADUNA, Nigeria - African Football Confederation President Issa Hayatou lauds the organisation and standard of soccer during the Ninth Africa Youth Championship taking place in Nigeria since January 24.

JANUARY 25

MASERU, Lesotho - The reinstatement of King Moshoeshoe II as the royal monarch for the 1.6 million people of Lesotho caps the successful efforts of leaders of Botswana, South Africa and Zimbabwe to bring democracy and constitutional order in this tiny mountain kingdom.

The Lesotho task force chaired by Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe took a firm stand against a royal coup d'etat by King Letsie III that ousted the government of Prime Minister Ntsu Mokhehle in August 1994.

MAPUTO, Mozambique - Tanzania's embassy in Maputo asks Mozambique to explain the alleged deaths of 13 Tanzanians in a jail in the central Mozambican port city of Beira.

An embassy spokesman, quoted by Radio Mozambique, says a letter reporting the deaths reached the embassy in December 1994.

LUSAKA, Zambia - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees starts making preparations for the repatriation of some 26,000 Angolan refugees in Zambia, following the cessation of civil war in that country.

UNHCR resident representative in Zambia Abou Moussa says he will meet Angolan and Zambian government officials February in Luanda to discuss the logistics of the operation.

JANUARY 26

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Scottish-born anaesthetist Richard Gladwell Mcgown, convicted on two counts of culpable homicide, starts a six-month prison term in Harare, after his application for bail against both conviction and sentence are refused by the high court. He is also fined 1,250 U.S. dollars.

Mcgown is convicted for causing the death of two patients. He gave Kalpesh Nagindas, 2, and Lavender Kaminwa, 10, lethal doses of morphine for surgery.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - A senior official of the African National Congress, Obed Bapela, says that tens of thousands of Zimbabweans in South Africa will be flushed out in a nationwide operation to rid the country of illegal aliens.

Addressing a news conference in Johannesburg, Bapela, the ANC deputy secretary, says the party supported the government's "clean-up."

NIAMEY, Niger - The Niger Football Federation fires national coach Moumaila Tiemogo, soccer officials say. The sacking follows the poor results of the team while preparing for the 20th African Nation's Cup.

RABAT, Morocco - Morocco orders an enquiry into the finances of the national carrier, Royal Air Maroc, state radio reports. It says Prime Minister Abdellatif Filali ordered the investigation following a 140-million dirham (14.89 million dollars) loss in 1994.

JANUARY 27

WASHINGTON D.C. - Two leading African Americans call a meeting for February 3 in Washington D.C. in an attempt to combat the declared intention by the new republican-led United States Congress to eliminate U.S. assistance to Africa.

The meeting is convened by one-time U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Andy Uoung, and Donald Payne. They orchestrate a massive coalition of organisations to meet on capital hill.

ABUJA, Nigeria - Leaders of Nigeria's main pro-democracy group, NADECO, met in private with military ruler Sani Abacha on the lingering political crisis in the West African Country, the body's officials say.

NADECO says both sides agreed to "be silent, at least for now, on the search for peace."

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - Twelve members of parliament from the Bouenza area of south Congo decide to resign from President Pascal Lissouba's Pan-African Union for Social Democracy, State radio announces.

JANUARY 30

DAKAR, Senegal - Senegal's President Abdou Diouf opens the 20th session of the joint Africa-Caribean-Pacific/European Union assembly in Dakar. The meeting is attended by 140 parliamentarians from 85 northern and southern countries linked by the Lome convention.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Teachers in Nigerian state-owned schools begin a nationwide strike to press for improved pay and work conditions.

KINSHASA, Zaire - Zaire's parliament, the High Council of the Republic, a transitional body, announces the creation of a group for friendship with Arab and Islamic states.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Mali tramples Guinea 3-0 while Nigeria edges Zambia 2-1 to reach the semi-finals of the African Cup of Nations Youth Soccer Championships being staged in Nigeria.

BANJUL, Gambia - Gambian military Head of State Yayha Jammeh appoints a new deputy and an interior minister following the arrest of their predecessors, state radio reports.

The new vice chairman of the five-member Armed Forces Provisional Ruling Council is Capt. Edward Singhateh and the interior minister, Capt. Lamin Bajo. Singhateh maintains his portfolio as defense minister. Bajo was a commissioner in one of the administrative divisions in the country.

ALGIERS, Algeira - A car bomb kills 38 people and wounds 250 others in Algiers. Anti-government Moslim militants are blamed.

JANUARY 31

KADUNA, Nigeria - Cameroon's national youth soccer team defeats Burundi 1-0 in the Ninth African Cup of Nations but the two sides join Mali and Nigeria in the competition's semi-finals to be played February 4 in Lagos and Kaduna.

CONAKRY, Guinea - An estimated 24,000 Sierra Leonean refugees flee into neighbouring Guinea after rebels sweep into the northwestern Sierra Leone town of Kambia in the week of January 23, United Nations officials say.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Burundi's main opposition political party, the National Union for Progress, UPRONA, calls a two-day work stoppage starting February 1 to force Prime Minister Anatole Kanyenkinko to resign.

Summary of African Events for February 1995

FEBRUARY 1

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The strike called January 31 by Burundi's main opposition party, the National Union for Progress, UPRONA, slows down activity in government offices and banks in Bujumbura, the capital.

The action is aimed at forcing Prime Minister Anatole Kanyenkino, a Tutsi, to resign from a government of national unity.

DAKAR, Senegal - French Cooperation Minister Bernard Debre announces in Dakar, Senegal, that France, as chairman of the European Union, would ensure that money in the Eighth European Development Fund is maintained at "a high level" for Africa.

FEBRUARY 2

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Sudanese President Omar El Bashir claims Ugandan troops fought alongside guerrillas of the Sudan People's Liberation Army in an attack on Kapoeta, in south Sudan's East Equatoria region.

Gen. Bashir is quoted by El Sudan El Hadeeth newspaper as telling local media executives February 1 that Sudanese troops were now in full control of the situation.

NIAMEY, Niger - The Supreme Court of Niger throws out a petition filed by President Mahamane Ousmane's party, the Democratic and Social Convention, in an attempt to nullify the election results of eight constituencies.

The court rejects the party's demand that poll results in some "special districts" be cancelled because these constituencies are only valid for the transition period to civilian rule from November 1991 to March 1993.

FEBRUARY 3

LAGOS, Nigeria - The Burundi junior soccer team brushes aside their domestic crisis and mauls highly-rated Mali 3-0 to qualify for the final in Lagos of the Ninth Africa Youth Championship February 5.

Burundi takes on Cameroon, which sidelined host Nigeria 2-1 in the first semi-final in northern Nigeria city of Kaduna.

The outcome does not alter the fact that Burundi, Cameroon and Nigeria are to represent Africa in the 10th World Cup Youth Soccer competition in March.

MAPUTO, Mozambique - Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano lay a wreath at Maputo's Monument of Heroes, on the occasion of the 26th anniversary of the assassination of the founder and first president of Frelimo, Eduardo Mondlane.

Mondlane was killed in Dar es Salaam February 3, 1969 by a parcel bomb sent to his office by agents of the notorious Portuguese Secret Police, the PIDE.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - A high-ranking Sudanese official announces that at least 80,000 guerrillas have defected from the Sudan People's Liberation Army to government ranks.

Lino Rol Deng, who is secretary-general of the Sudanese Higher Council for Peace, tells an Arabic language newspaper in Khartoum that the rebellion in southern Sudan is reduced to "small pockets".

FEBRUARY 6

PARIS - A five-day developmemt forum opens to highlight a host of reasons why the world's rich countries should assist their poverty-stricken African counterparts.

ABUJA, Nigeria - Nigeria's military government disbands the nation's junior soccer team, the Flying Eagles, for failing to click in the Ninth Africa Youth Championship which has just ended.

Coach Fanny Amun is sent on compulsory leave. The measure is taken after Nigeria performs less than expected, coming third in the event.

NIAMEY, Niger - Niger Prime Minister Souley Abdoulaye resigns, so does his cabinet.

Abdoulaye's government, formed October 5 1994, is brought down in a vote of no-confidence by members of parliament from the opposition who dominate the house. But President Ousmane re-appoints Abdoulaye.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Debt-ridden Zambia National Broadcasting Corporation loses five vehicles at a go, seized by Lusaka Court bailiffs on behalf of a British creditor.

COTONOU, Benin - Trade unionists from 11 African countries start their meeting in Cotonou to prepare a two-year educational programme on union affairs.

FEBRUARY 8

NIAMEY, Niger - Former Niger Prime Minister Mahamadou Yssoufou is elected speaker of the national assembly. He beat outgoing speaker Moumouni Adamou with an absolute majority in a single ballot.

LAGOS, Nigeria - International air fares in Nigeria shot up by 130 percent in the local currency, the naira, at the end of tough negotiations between government and foreign airlines in the country.

Foriegn airlines unilaterally hiked their fares by 300 per cent last week following Nigeria's 1995 budget directive requiring private sector operators to obtain funds from the autonomous foreign exchange market.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Angola says it is prepared to contribute 64.7 million dollars out of the estimated 1.3 billion dollars needed to implement the country's peace agreement with the anti-government guerrilla movement, UNITA.

Washington Line, a United States Information Service publication, says this was announced in New York by Angola's foreign minister, Venancio De Moura.

FEBRUARY 9

BAMAKO, Mali - Tourism ministers from Burkina Faso, Cote D'Ivoire and Mali discuss ways of harmonising and boosting the fast-declining sector in their countries.

The ministers, meeting in the Malian capital Bamako, seek to harmonize their national tourism regulations and draw a common tourist guide.

In another development, Ghanaian and South African mining concerns win a bid to extract gold in Mali, officials say in Bamako, the Malian capital.

The companies, Ashanti Goldfields and the Johannesburg Consolidated Investment Company, will operate the Kalana Gold Mines in the centre of the country. They take over from Sogemork, a state-owned gold mining company dissolved in 1994.

LUSAKA, Zambia - In a desperate move to settle debts owed to the Confederation of African Football, CAF, the cash-strapped Football Association of Zambia gives defaulting clubs until February 15 to pay their fines.

Association General-Secretary Hermann Mpashi says in Lusaka that defaulters had incurred about 7.3 million kwacha (10,138 U.S. dollars) in disciplinary charges on the field.

NAIROBI, Kenya - All but one of the 11 aid workers kidnapped last week in southern Sudan arrive in Nairobi to an emotional welcome. Three of them, David Onyango, Violet Gikonyo and Judith Nyakoa, are Kenyans.

The others released are a Briton, two Ethiopians, two Frenchmen, one Swiss and one Australia. They and the Kenyans worked for UNICEF, Save The Children Fund, the Swiss Disaster Relief or Medicines Du Monde.

PARIS - Algerian writer Rachid Mimouni dies of acute hepatitis in a Paris hospital.

Mimouni settled in Tangiers, Morocco, in December 1993, following threats to his life by Moslim militants as well as for the wellbeing of his 13-year-old daughter.

FEBRUARY 13

MASERU, Lesotho - The Lesotho Government makes cabinet changes for the first time since it came to power in 1993, with the swearing-in of two senior ministers by the Basutoland Congress Party-led government of Prime Minister Ntsu Mokhehle.

The minister of education and manpower development, Pakalitha Mosisilim, was sworn in as deputy prime minister. An assistant minister in the prime minister's office, Sephiri Motanyane, was sworn in as minister without portfolio.

ABUJA, Nigeria - Nigeria urges other African countries to support its challenge of FIFA'S decision February 10 cancelling the World Youth Soccer Championship slated for March in the West African country.

Nigerian Head of State Sani Abacha says while receiving the credentials of South Africa's new high commissioner to Nigeria, George Nene, the FIFA decision was "sad and disappointing".

FEBRUARY 14

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Grenade explosions in a Tutsi neighbourhood in Bujumbura marks the beginning of an indefinite nationwide strike called by Burundi's main oppostion party, the National Union for Progress.

ALGIERS, Algeria - Algerian President Liamine Zeroual begins consultations with political leaders to prepare for the presidential election expected before the end of 1995, state radio reports.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Botswana and Namibia decide in Harare, Zimbabwe, to seek international arbitration over a disputed border island after experts appointed to recommend a solution fail to agree on its ownership.

COTONOU, Benin - Forty-four nationals from Niger, who have been expelled from Gabon, arrive in Cotonou from Lome, Togo, where they had landed by plane the previous night.

FEBRUARY 16

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Bujumbura, the Burundi capital, is paralysed for the second day running by a strike called by the main Tutsi-dominated opposition UPRONA party to force the resignation of Prime Minister Anatole Kanyenkiko, himself a Tutsi.

MONROVIA, Liberia - National Patriotic Front of Liberia leader Charles Taylor, who is due in the Liberian capital, cancells his visit, a pro-Taylor weekly newspaper the New Patriot reports.

ZURICH, Switzerland - The world soccer governing body, the International Football Federation, or FIFA, suspends its cancellation of the venue of the 1995 World Youth Soccer Championships describing the earlier ban as "unfortunate."

FEBRUARY 16

ACCRA, Ghana - Bushfires sweep across the West African State of Ghana cause extensive damage to the country's forests and crops, the Ghana News Agency reports.

It says at least 12 people, among them children, have been killed, houses and other property are burned.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon - Gabonese security officers step up identity card checks in Libreville's highly populated areas.

Several "illegal" immigrants are arrested for failing to beat the February 15 deadline given to them to regularise their stay or leave the country.

DAKAR, Senegal - Gambia's foreign minister, Bolong Sonko, says in Dakar, Senegal, that his country's military government will authorise political parties in the next 17 months.

FEBRUARY 20

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's first president, Kenneth Kaunda, appeares before a Lusaka magistrate court charged with unlawful assembly. He denies this.

The state prosecution alleges that Kaunda, 71, committed the alleged offence February 11 at Chongwe, a few kilometres outside the capital, Lusaka. He is alleged to have addressed a political campaign meeting for which he did not have a police permit.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - Congolese civil servants begin a strike organised by the country's Trade Union Confederation. The action follows negotiations which collapsed February 18 between the union and the government over salaries and better working conditions.

The workers' umbrella union is asking the government to pay them at least two-and-a-half months of salary arreas. The union also wants the government to abrogate two recent decrees freezing salary increments and the 50 percent reduction of the allowances for civil servants.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The Tutsi-dominated opposition in Burundi proposes Antoine Nduwayo, an economist, as a successor to Anatole Kanyenkinko who is forced to resign as prime minister.

However, political observers in Bujumbura say it is very likely Nduwayo would face the same difficulties that forced his fellow Tutsi predecessor to step down.

The problems stem from the difficult task of pleasing his party, the Union for National Progress, or UPRONA, and the president who appointed him. In addition there is the seemingly irreconciliable ethnic tension between the majority Hutu and the minority Tutsi.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria, determined to host the 10th World Youth Soccer Championship says it has insured all 16 teams for the postponed FIFA-Coca Cola tournament.

The sole administrator of Nigeria's Sports Commission, Babashola Rhodes, says on state radio that the insurance package, which he does not disclose, is part of the issues raised at a meeting the week beginning February 12 in Zurich between a Nigerian delegation and FIFA officials.

FEBRUARY 21

NIAMEY, Niger - Niger President Mahamane Ousmane appoints Hama Amadou, 45, as the West African Country's new prime minister.

Amadou is the secretary-general of the National Movement for the Society in Development which became Niger's main parliamentary party by winning 29 seats in the January 12 parliamentary elections. There were 83 seats at stake.

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso - Seconday and post high school teachers in the West African state of Burkina Faso walk out of classrooms demanding a pay rise and improved working conditions.

FEBRUARY 22, 1955

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Ethiopian Police seal off Addis Ababa's Markato mosque, scene of the fatal shooting between rival Moslim groups February 21.

They were each claiming the right to run the affairs of the country's Moslim Supreme Council.

Police also seal off other mosques in the capital of the largely Christian country, fearing that violence could spread. So, worshipers sought alternative places of prayer, like football fields. In the clash four people were shot dead and 74 wounded.

UNITED NATIONS, New York - The United Nations officially launches 1995 as the year for tolerance, in line with the General Assembly's proclamation in 1993.

Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and the director-general of UNESCO, Federico Mayor, jointly launch the year at a press conference in New York. UNESCO is the lead organisation for the commemoration.

LONDON - the International Labour Organisation says that the developing world, particularly Sub-Sahara Africa, remains the major challenge in creating employment in the world.

In its annual report World Employment 1995, it says the problem in Africa is excerbated by rapid population growth. This means that there will be an extra six million job seekers every year in the 1990s. Africa's population south of the Sahara is estimated at 600 million people.

NIAMEY, Niger - About 3,000 people march peacefully in Niamey in protest against possible cancellation of the 1994-1995 academic year in the landlocked West African State of Niger.

MASERU, Lesotho - Lesotho Prime Minister Ntsu Mokhehle announces new cabinet changes, the second within a month. He shifts Foreign Minister Qhobela Molapo to the restored works ministry which was previously under transport and communications.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The wreckage of a Burundi Air Force helicopter and its two dead pilots are found in Ruvuvu National Park in the northeastern Muyinga Province.

The helicopter went missing February 16 after taking off from Gitega Air Base in central Burundi on a routine mission, the ministry of defence says.

LUSAKA, Zambia - President Ferederick Chiluba sacks Bank of Zambia Governor Dominic Mulaisho. This comes in the wake of a vast depreciation of the local currency, the kwacha.

Chiluba appoints Senior Economic Adviser to the government Jacob Mwanza to take over as chief executive of the central bank. Chiluba's office says the measure is taken to instill confidence in the foreign exchange market.

The Zambian kwacha has, over the past three months, recorded a dramatic drop against major international currencies. It trades at 845 to one United States dollar and at 1,334 for one British pound sterling.

FEBRUARY 24

LAGOS, Nigeria - the National Drugs Law Enforcement Agency warns against a syndicate which specializes in smuggling Nigerian citizens to South Africa as couriers for the drug trade, the News Agency of Nigeria, NAN, reports.

NAN cites statement issued February 23 in Lagos by a drug agencey official, Abiodun Adesola, as saying the syndicate charges between 50,000 and 100,000 naira (between 2,272 and 4,545 dollars) to smuggle their victims with fake visas through Swaziland into South Africa where they are picked up by drug barons.

ALGIERS, Algeria - Thirty-six hours after Algerian forces put down a mutiny at the Sarkaji Prison in the capital, the government now says 100 people were killed in the operation.

This confirms the figure given February 22 by several independent sources. Algerian television, quoting an official statement, says 96 inmates were killed and of these 80 were Moslim militants. Fifteen were common criminals and wardens.
