OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso - Burkina Faso's supreme court cancels the results in seven districts of municipal elections held February 12.

The court orders the measure after complaints by political parties. Politicians say electoral districts are not clearly defined, voters are intimidated and that there is violence during balloting.

FEBRUARY 27

ACCRA, Ghana - The Ghana Bar Association says it will maintain its boycott of the courts which starts today until newly appointed Chief Justice Isaac Abban resigns.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - An official of the International Red Cross says that many African countries have failed to ratify an International Weapons Convention because they are unaware of it.

In another development, Zimbabwe and the World University service sign an agreement to help set a regional office in Harare.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian public service workers, at loggerheads with government over salary demands, give President Frederick Chiluba until March 2 to make a decent offer or they will go ahead with a planned country-wide strike.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - Germany reschedules Congo's debt of 95 million deutsche marks under a bilateral agreement signed by the two states recently.

OUGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso - Leading film directors begin a forum on the film centenary as part of the 14th Pan African Film Festival, FESPACO.

The biennial Pan-African film festival, held in this Burkinabe capital, could become an annual event by the year 2000 the organisers say.

BAMAKO, Mali - Mali appoints Mamadou Ba, 41, as its new defence minister. Ba, an inspector of economic affairs, replaces Boubacar Sy who died in a car accident February 19.

NAIROBI, Kenya - An earth tremor measuring 5.0 on the Richter scale rock parts of southern Kenya, Nairobi University seismologists say. Earthquakes of this magnitude can cause considerable damage. But there are no reports of any damage or casualties.

LAGOS, Nigeria - European criminal syndicates may be encouraging illicit cannabis cultivation in Africa, the international criminal police organisation INTERPOL says.

In the 1994 report of the United Nations International Narcotics Board, released in Lagos, INTERPOL says the North African nation of Morroco remains the major supplier of cannabis resin for illicit European markets.

FEBRUARY 28

CAPE TOWN, South Africa - Mozambican President Joaquim Chissano and his South African counterpart, Nelson Mandela, sign two accords on security and tourism. The agreements are initialed on the first day of Chissano's official visit to South Africa. Under the security accord, the two states agree to cooperate in combating crime.

Summary of African Events for March 1995

MARCH 1

CAPE TOWN, South Africa - South African and Mozambican police will now be able to cross their borders to investigate crimes, the Mozambican news agency, AIM, reports. This follows a security cooperation agreement signed by both countries Feb. 28.

MARCH 3 HARARE, Zimbabwe - Foreign ministers from 11 southern African countries meet in Harare to discuss ways of implementing the new mandate of the former frontline states to deal with civil conflicts in the region.

COPENHAGEN - United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali opens the World Summit for Social Development in Copenhagen, Denmark. The meeting focuses on the plight of the world's impoverished people.

Some 120 world leaders including presidents, vice-presidents and prime ministers attend the meeting.

The summit, which ends March 12, is one of a series of global forums organized by United Nations agencies since 1990. It dwells on the least developed countries, many of them in Africa.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's defence spokesman, Brig. Gen. Fred Chijuka, concedes that several officers are being questioned for spreading what he calls "rumours" in connection with an alleged plot against Nigeria's military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha.

However, Chijuka says it is premature to say they have planned a coup. He refuses to say how many people are being questioned or where they are being held.

But independent newspapers report that the most prominent among the 150 being questioned is Brig. Gen. Lawan Gwadabe, commander of the 23 Armoured Brigade in Yola, northern Nigeria. He briefly commanded the Gambian army.

NIAMEY, Niger - Niger civil servants suspend their five-month strike after reaching an agreement with government for the payment of a month's salary arrears.

The government tells the Confederation of Niger Workers Union that public servants would be paid latest March 15. Government also agrees to halt punishment of customs officers who went on strike.
MARCH 8

KAMPALA, Uganda - Ugandan Foreign Minister Ruhakana Rugunda tells journalists that Odongo, leader of a anti-Kenya guerrilla movement calling itself the February 18 Popular Resistance Army has been sent to a third country. The move is designed to ease tensions with the government of Kenya.

PARIS - France gives francophone Africa 100 million CAF (200,803 million dollars) to help it prepare for the Sixth All-Africa Games to be held in Zimbabwe Sept. 13-23, the head of the Office of International Relations in the French Ministry of Youth and Sports, Paul Cozigon, says.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Addis Ababa police arrest six Africans, caught forging United States dollars and Ethiopian birr banknotes in their five-star hotel.

MARCH 9

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - Transportation in Brazzaville, Congo of capital, comes to a halt as taxi and bus drivers go on strike in support of a demand by civil servants to be paid salary arrears.

Congolese public workers, on strike since February 20, are pressing for payment of two and a half months' wages. The impact of the protest is being felt most in schools and universities, which have remained closed since the action began.

MONROVIA, Liberia - Life in Monrovia, the Liberian capital, is at a virtual standstill as residents comply with a stay-at-home protest organized by religious leaders.

Nearly all educational institutions, businesses and government offices remain closed in support of the protest or because most workers fail to show up for work.

The protest, staged in spite an appeal from the ruling Council of State to call it off, is in support of a new initiative by Moslim and Christian leaders to pressurize Liberia's faction leaders to advance stalled peace talks.

BONN, Germany - Southern African government ministers, leaders from the opposition and labour movements meet with representatives of the German government and European Union for an international conference in Bonn focusing on southern Africa's transition from confrontation to dialogue and peaceful development.

The two-day conference is organised by Friedrich Ebert Stiftung and officially opened March 8 by German Federal President Roman Herzog. The meeting groups political and trade union leaders from Botswana, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe. It includes the Southern African Development Community, SADC.

MARCH 10

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's Chief of Defence Staff Maj. Gen Abdulsam Abubakar confirms that a group of military officers and civilians planned to overthrow the country's military regime.

NAIROBI, Kenya - Kenyan Vice President George Saitoti is charged with stealing 18 billion shillings (404.49 million U.S. dollars) from the government treasury.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark - African non-governmental organisations at the Global Summit on Social Development call for the closure of all foreign military bases in Africa saying they were a threat to the well-being of the continent.

MARCH 12

COTONOU, Benin - Campaigning in Benin's general elections due March 22 begin with a stinging attack on the opposition by incumbent President Nicephore Soglo.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Some 95 people are killed while several others sustain injuries when two luxury coaches collide on the Benin City-Lagos expressway in Nigeria.

One bus was coming from Onitsha in Eastern Nigeria, the other from Lagos.

MARCH 13

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The Burundi government declares four days of mourning beginning in memory of assassinated Mines Minister Ernest Kabushemeye.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Former Nigerian military ruler Olusegun Obasanjo is arrested by security officers, his assistant Ayo Aderewale tells journalists.

NIAMEY, Niger - Teachers in Niger's state-run schools return to work after an appeal by the Niger National Union of Teachers.

MARCH 14

ACCRA, Ghana - One hundred thirty Guinea-Bissau nationals expelled from Gabon are refused entry into Ghana by immigration officials because they have no entry permits.

MARCH 15

MASERU, Lesotho - Agents of Lesotho's National Security Services kidnap the administrative secretary for the country's southern district of Guthing, state-owned radio reports.

TRIPOLI, Libya - Algerian Interior Minister Abdulrahmane Meziane Cherif says he has been misquoted by a British weekly newspaper which reported him as saying that self-defence militia would be set up to protect local communities. "There will be no legalisation of self-defence militias," he says.

ABIDJAN, Cote D'Ivoire - The first Africa bureau of Interpol, the global crime-busting police network, begins operations with a new 180 million CFA francs (361,445 dollar) budget from an Abidjan suburb.

DAKAR, Senegal - Senegalese President Abdou Diouf makes a major cabinet reshuffle bringing in five opposition ministers and dropping a long-serving minister, Djibo Ka, who was senior minister of the interior.

MARCH 16

LUSAKA, Zambia - A high court in Lusaka fixes April 3-4 to hear the charge of unlawful assembly prefered against former Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The funeral of Ernest Kabushemeye, Burundi's minister for mines who was assassinated March 11, is delayed for 24 hours for unspecified "technical reasons", Junior Minister for Public Security Issa Ngendakumana says.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - The trial of Ethiopia's former military rulers is adjourned to May to enable the prosecution prepare replies to objections raised by the defence.

KINSHASA, Zaire - Medical doctors in Kinshasa go on a two-day strike to protest the killing of Dr Lucien Kasela, the assistant director for the coordination of AIDS control.

ABIDJAN - Cote D'Ivoire Prime Minister Duncan Kablan Daniel officially inaugurates the country's Audiovisual Communication Council, set up to ensure public and private radio and television stations uphold professional standards.

MARCH 19

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Three Belgians are killed in an ambush by an armed gang on National Highway 7 near Bujumbura. Two of the three are businessmen, the third a daughter of one of the men. They were returning to Bujumbura, the capital, after a weekend in the countryside.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Tunisia, the current chairman of the Organisation of African Unity, sends shockwaves across Africa at the weekend when it announces a last minute cancellation of the First Pan-African Youth Conference which is to have opened in Tunis, March 21. Some 30 African ministers, whose portoflios deal with the youth, are already airborne for the Tunisian capital when the cancellation is announced at the OAU headquarters in Addis Ababa. The OAU secretariat staff, translators and equipment are already in Tunis.

MARCH 20

ALGIERS, Algeria - Algerian authorities say that 21 members of the armed wing of the banned Islamic Salvation Front have been arrested in a nation-wide operation. The first arrests were made March 16. Interior Minister Abdulrahmane Meziane Cherif announces an increase in the number of commnunity forces from 10,000 to some 50,000 created six months ago to beef up security.

BAMAKO, Mali - An outbreak of meningitis in Mali leds to 75 deaths, medical authorities say in Bamako. They say that 47 of the 247 people diagnosed die in the first half of March.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Developing countries are told they will have to spend an extra 60 million dollars yearly if the current dependence on conventional energy supply systems continue. UNESCO Director-General Federico Mayor makes this statement in a message he sends to the African Regional Conference called to promote solar energy as an alternative source of power.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Sudan says it will hand over to the government in Addis Ababa five Ethiopians who hijacked an Ethiopian Airlines Boeign 737 jet March 17, a well-informed privately owned Khartoum newspaper reports.

The daily, Akhbar El Youm, quotes sources it describes as "authoritative" in the government of Gen. Omar El Bashir saying that a committee headed by Justice Minister Abdul Aziz Shidou is preaparing the repatriation.

NIAMEY, Niger - The Agency for Cultural and Technical Cooperation begins celebrations to mark its 25th anniversary in Niamey, Niger.

The organisation, headquartered in Paris, was created March 20, 1970 at the initiative of eminent heads of states and learned men including Leopold Sedar Senghor, Habib Bourguiba, Diori Hamani and Andre Malraux.

ABUJA, Nigeria - Nigeria wants former United States President Jimmy Carter to intervene in the diplomatic row between Abuja and Washington. The secretary to Nigeria's military government, Aminu Saleh, tells Carter who is visiting Nigeria that the U.S. government "should realise that in the area of democracy, every country reserved the right to fashion out the type best suited to its environment."

LUSAKA Zambia - Zambian Police Inspector-General Francis Ndhlovu announces that his force is investigating allegations that some opposition parties have sent recruits abroad for training to destabilise 1996 presidential and general elections. Zambia has at least 15 opposition parties but only the United National Independence Party of the country's first president, Kenneth Kaunda, and the National Party are represented in parliament.

MARCH 21

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Low levels of access to all forms of energy have diminished the quality of life in Africa, the Economic Commission for Africa says in a study presented at the Africa Regional Solar Energy Conference in the Zimbabwean capital of Harare. The commission says that average annual per capita access to energy in Africa has since 1975 stagnated at the equivalent of just about three barrels of oil, compared with Europe which has recorded almost double the rate over a similar period.

WINDHOEK, Namibia - Namibian President Sam Nujoma is installed for a second term of office. Nujoma, who won Namibia's presidential elections in December 1994, takes an oath of office at a colourful ceremony attended by several heads of state and government.

LUSAKA, Zambia - A debt-ridden Zambian state-run firm, Contract Haulage, dismisses 207 workers, leaving behind a skeleton staff of 10. An estimated 130,000 workers have lost jobs in Zambia since 1992, either through privatisation of state-run companies or because of companies folding in the face of foreign competition in a liberalized market.

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana's President Jerry Rawlings holds separate meetings with two Liberian leaders and the United Nations secretary-general's special representative on how to push forward the peace process in war-torn Liberia.

ABUJA, Nigeria - Former United States President Jimmy Carter says that 1997 appears to be an acceptable date for Nigeria's military rulers to hand over to civilians. However, speaking to journalists in Abuja he says that the international community's judgement of the military will depend on how it handles two key issues The handover date and the fate of politicial detainees.

MARCH 22

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana's National Security Council decides to deploy additional military units and reinforce police presence in the Northern Region to prevent the escalation of ethnic clashes. Fighting which started again March 12 between the Konkombas and Nanumbas claims at least 36 lives and 34 others injured. Fighting in the area in 1994 over the price of a guinea fowl claimed at least 2,000 lives.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Director-General Federico Mayor praises Africa for making "great strides" towards scientific and technological development over the past two years.

LONDON - Representatives of Algerian opposition parties meet in London.

MARCH 23

KAMPALA, Uganda - Uganda's state-owned daily newspaper,The New Vision, reports that 50 Ugandans undergoing six weeks of industrial training in Kenya have been expelled. The employees who started their course March 5 at Mumias Sugar Factory were deported last week, the daily says.

ALGIERS, Algeria - Algerian opposition parties which in January signed the Rome proposals for the restoration of political order in their country, refuse to participate in talks on the next presidential elections proposed by President Liamine Zeroual. Zeroual invites 11 opposition parties and four civilian organisations on March 21 to discuss the presidential elections scheduled for 1995.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, Nigeria's fourth military ruler after independence in 1960, is granted conditional release from detention by the current head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha. This follows the intervention of former United States President Jimmy Carter. Information Minister Walter Ofonagoro says Obasanjo would be restricted to his Lagos home pending investigations of suspects being held in connection with an alleged coup plot to topple the Abacha government.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Students at Burundi University demonstrate in Bujumbura calling for the "immediate departure" of the Unitd Nations special representative in the country, Amedou Ould Abdallah. They accuse Abdallah of taking sides in the ethnic conflict between Hutu and Tutsi, which has bedevilled the country since 1993.

TUNIS, Tunisia - Democracy comes under intense scrutiny in Tunis as some of Africa's ruling and opposition political parties began a meeting on how politics can be brought to bear on the continent's economic and social problems. The meeting is organised by Tunisia's ruling Democratic Rally led by President Zine Al-Abadine Ben Ali, chairman of the Organisation of African Unity.

MASERU, Lesotho - Commonwealth Secretary-General Emeka Anyaoku arrives in Lesotho for a three-day official visit. He meets with ranking government officials. Anyaoku tells journalists on arrival in Maseru that his mission is to discuss possible ways in which the British-led Commonwealth can help solving the country's outstanding political problems.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Former Nigerian leader Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, freed by presidential pardon after 10 days' detention, returns to his Ota home near Lagos Thursday.

MARCH 24

LUSAKA, Zambia - Namibian opposition figure Hiskia Uanivi, who had disappeared mysteriously in his own country, is being held in a Lusaka prison, immigration authorities in the Zambian capital say.

BAMAKO, Mali - Boubacar Dembele, a former managing director of a Malian state company, is sentenced to death by the court of assizes in Bamako for stealing 1.2 billion CFA francs (about 2.4 millilon dollars).

KAMPALA, Uganda - British opposition Foreign Affairs Spokesman Robin Cook warns in Kampala of an impending breakdown in security in camps hosting Rwandan refugees in Zaire due to dwindling food stocks.

MARCH 28

ACCRA, Ghana - Former United States President Jimmy Carter meets Ghanaian President Jerry Rawlings on Liberia's civil war and the guinea worm eradication programme in Ghana. Carter is on the last leg of an African tour that has also taken him to Kenya, Nigeria and Sudan.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Sudanese strongman Gen. Omer Al Bashir declares a two-month cease-fire with the guerrillas of the Sudan People's Liberation Army. The cease-fire, to take effect midnight, is designed to give impetus to peace initiatives as well help a guinea worm eradication programme being run in southern Sudan by former United States President Jimmy Carter.

TRIPOLI, Libya - Libyan Head of State Moammar Kadhafi threatens to quit the United Nations which he describes as an "instrument in the hands of American, British and Zionist colonialists." Speaking in Tripoli on the 25th anniversary of the evacuation of British forces, Col. Kadhafi says "The Libyan people are obliged to reconsider its membership of the United Nations at the next meetings of popular congresses."

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian security personnel handover an American released by Chadian rebels to United States officials. United States Consul-General in Nigeria Philips Carington receives Anthony Johnson and his Chadian cook from Col. Joseph Okhai, Commander of Nigeria's armoured brigade in the northern state of Borno, near the Chadian border.

MARCH 30

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - The Commission for Eritrean Refugee Affairs reports that some 14,798 Eritrean refugees have left Sudan for home since a repatriation operation began in November 1994.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's main opposition, the United National Independence Party, challenges government to make public the report on the Gabon air disaster in which nearly all of Zambia's national soccer team perished. Party President Kebby Musokotwane accusses the government of Frederick Chiluba of wanting to sweep its findings under the carpet.

COTONOU, Benin - Several political parties allege that parliamentary elections in Benin held Ma Brch 28 were rigged. They condemn unidentified parties for the alleged fraud.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - United Kingdom-based British Steel Consultants Ltd wins a Zimbabwe government tender to manage the Zimbabwe Iron and Steel Company, ZISCO, and restore viability of the ailing state-owned giant.

MARCH 31

DAKAR, Senegal - Some 45,000 Rwandan refugees, most of them Hutus, leave their camps in northern Burundi in search of other countries of asylum, the United Nations reports.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria could have earned about 400 million dollars from tourism if FIFA, the world soccer governing body, had not moved the venue for the Eighth World Youth Soccer Championship to Qatar, a tourism official says in Lagos.

Summary of African Events for April 1995

APRIL 3

KAMPALA, Uganda - Uganda police say Monday they still had no clue of the whereabouts of Health Minister James Makumbi who was first reported missing Friday.He was last seen Friday at around 11.00 p.m. (0900 gmt) at Lutete, 10 kilometers north of Kampala, the capital.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The welfare of disabled persons is is examined by experts from Southern African countries at a five-day meeting which opens Monday in Harare. Of the estimated 500 million disabled persons in the world, 450 million live in developing countries. Of these at least 80 per cent reside in rural areas.

LOME, Togo - Togo's minister of techincal education Stanislas Bamouni-Baba opens an international workshop on housing and urban development in Africa Monday.

COTONOU, Benin - The Secretary-General in the President's office in Benin, Florentin Mito-Baba, resigns, the government daily newspaper 'La Nation' reports Monday.In a letter, he says he left because he had lost the onfidence of President Nicephore Soglo.

APRIL 4

ACCRA, Ghana - An international workshop on unesco's "slave route project " ends late Tuesday with a call for regional efforts in the preservation of what historians considered as "the greatest human tragedy " on the African continent.

BERN, Switzerland - Mozambican opposition leader Afonso Dhlakama is on a tour of six european countries to seek financial support to help the maputo government rehabilitate the country's war-ravaged economy and society.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Police say criminals got away with property worth at least 150 million zimdollars (18 million U.S. dollars) through theft by conversion, housebreaking and armed robberies throughout Zimbabwe's Harare Province during the past year.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon - France gives 515 million Francs CFA (1.07 million U.S. dollars) to the Schweitzer hospital in Lambarene, 245 kilometers southeast of the Gabonese capital libreville.

APRIL 6

TRIPOLI, Libya - Sudan and Uganda pledge to stop supporting each other's rebel groups and to initiate confidence building measures at the end of their talks in Tripoli

ABUJA,Nigeria - South African presidential envoy Archbishop Desmond Tutu says detained Nigerian politician Moshood Abiola has now agreed to his conditional release.

COTONOU, Benin - Benin's Minister of Education Karim Dramane and that of Youth and Sports minister Alassane Tigri get beaten in the country's parliamentary elections.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Hundreds of supporters of Bishop Abel Muzorewa's opposition United Parties demonstrate with posters which likened President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe to ousted Malawian dictator, Dr Kamuzu Banda.

APRIL 7

KIGALI, Rwanda - Rwandan President Gen. Juvenal Habyarimana and his Burundian counterpart Cyprien Ntaryamira are killed in a plane crash April 6 at night, as they return from a sub-regional meeting in Tanzania aimed at curbing ethnic tension in their two countries.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - South African television producer Francis Vincent is shot dead by unknown gunmen late Thursday in Bujumbura while covering Burundi's ethnic violence.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's former Information Minister Prince Tony Momoh is hospitalised for leg gunshot wounds sustained when five armed burst into his home Thursday.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - The government of Gen. Omar Bashir accuses the Sudan People's Liberation Army Friday of violating a cease-fire unilaterally declared by Khartoum March 28.

APRIL 10

NAIROBI, Kenya - Kenyan authorities officially close the Utange refugee camp in Mombasa ity on the Indian Ocean.The camp had hosted several thousands of Somali refugees.

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania - A session of the Mauritania-Tunisia joint cooperation committee opens.

TRIPOLI, Libya - A meeting of the Algeria-Egypt joint cooperation committee opens in Algiers.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - Central African Urban Planning ministers opens with a call on governments in the region to take urgent steps to curb the "terrifying" expansion of cities.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian police confirm that 15 people drowned last Friday in the Luapula river in the north after their boat capsized in a rainstorm.

DAKAR, Senegal - Leading scientists from Africa, the United States and Europe hold a four-days symposium to mark the centenary of the death of Louis Pasteur, the great French chemist and biologist, whose discoveries formed the bedrock to today's vaccination.

APRIL 11

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - The Ethiopian government says it had asked Sudan to hand over five hijackers who seized a passenger plane on a domestic flight in March.

KAMPALA, Sudan - Uganda declares a ranking Sudanese diplomat in Kampala, Award Mohammed Hassan, persona non grata and ordered him to leave the country for allegedly engaging in activities which were detrimental to relations between the two neighbouring states.

KHARTOUM, Sudan- Reciprocating Uganda's expulsion of its Charge d'Affaires, Sudan on Tuesday gives a diplomat from Kampala, Geoffery Kaboshinga two days to leave the country.

MONROVIA, Liberia - Chief of Staff of the United Liberation Movement in Liberia (ULIMO), Armah Youlu, announces moves to prevent a possible confrontation with the African Peacekeeping Force, Ecomog.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) offers to mediate the rift between Sudan and Eritrea that has resulted in the cutting off of diplomatic ties.

APRIL 12

NEW YORK - United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali asks the Security Council to extend the mandate of its observer mission in Liberia.

TRIPOLI, Libya - Morrocan and European Union fishing experts on begin tough negotiations for a new fishing agreement between the two parties.

LUANDA, Angola - A Unita delegation is expected in Luanda to make preparations for an iminent meeting between Angolan President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos and the armed opposition group's leader, Jonas Savimbi.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The head of the Organization of African Unity, Salim Ahmed Salim, holds talks with rival Burundian politicial leaders in a bid to avert an ethnic bloodbath in that Central African country.

MASERU, Lesotho - The government of Lesotho is to cut teachers salaries, erroneously raised by 80 per cent after a recent strike, because they cannot be sustained for long.

APRIL 13

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - The Ethiopian government releases nine Italian tourists they said had entered the country illegally and gave them three days to leave the Eastern African state.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - British Secretary for Defence Malcolm Rifkind meets Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe for talks on several issues, including war-torn Angola.

KAMPALA, Uganda - Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko agrees to release a Ugandan cargo plane impounded six months earlier for flying counterfeit Zairean currency into his country.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Organisation of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim says that everything is being done to stem an escalation of revenge killings between Burundi's majority Hutu and minority Tutsi ethnic groups.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba blames Western countries for the Third World's economic and social problems. He said this during an address to the Centre of Strategic and International Studies.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon - The Gabonese government grants a general amnesty to those accused of plotting to overthrow the country's first President, Leon Mba, who died in 1967.

APRIL 14

BAMAKO, Mali - Mali has decides to partially privatise the national cigarette and match-box company, one of the West African country's largest state enterprises.

TRIPOLI, Libya - Libyan Leader Col.Moammar Kadhafi receives a Morrocan envoy, Abdul Rahmane al Sibai, with a special message from King, Hassan II.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Italy's Foreign Minister Susanna Agnelli thanks the Ethiopian government for helping to end the ordeal of its nine citizens who had entered the Eastern African country illegally.

DAKAR, Senegal - a delegation from algeria's national transition council (Interim Parliament) is expected in Dakar saturday for week-long visit.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - The Inter-Governmental Authority on Drought and Development (IGADD) is to hold a day-long summit in Addis Ababa.

APRIL 18

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Two Burundi army soldiers are killed and eight others wounded in a dawn rifle and grenade attack on a military post in the north-eastern village of Gasorwe near Bujumbura.Five of the 40 assailants are also shot dead.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - As Zimbabwe marks its 15th independence anniversary, President Robert Mugabe appeals to the international community for help to avert a fullscale civil war in Burundi.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - The Congolese government reduces working hours from 40 to 35 per week for all civil servants except those employed in the education sector which is doged by problems.

APRIL 19

TRIPOLI, Libya - A Libyan passenger plane with 147 pilgrims leaves Tripoli for the Saudi city of Jeddah, marking the first violation of a United Nations-imposed air embargo on the North African country.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon - Supporters of Gabonese President Omar Bongo plan a protest March against French media allegations that the Head of State lives with the Human Immunedefiency Virus (HIV) that causes the incurable AIDS disease.

BAMAKO, Mali - Three Malian opposition parties merge to create a new political group known as the "Rally of Patriotic Forces".Its founders say its objective will be to promote genuine reconciliation in the West African country.

DOHA, Qatar - Eight African referees and three linesmen officiate at the 8th junior football world cup which kicked off April 13 in Doha, capital of the Emirate of Qatar.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe's largest merchant bank says this year's drought will hit the country's rural poor hard as they are forced to buy commercially milled maize in spite their reduced disposable incomes.

APRIL 20

DAKAR, Senegal - Locust activity worsens in North-West Africa with more and more swarms appearing in Morocco and Algeria, the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization says.

DOHA, Qatar - FIFA initiates investigations to idenftify persons reported to have fixed matches in the 8th World Cup Junior Soccer tournament in the emirate of Qatar.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - Congo passes a law bringing the police under civilian direction instead of the military.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - A three-day regional meeting on the impact of armed conflict on children urges warring parties in Africa to stop recruiting children to achieve their military objectives.

DAKAR, Senegal - Senegal and Burkina Faso sign a general agreement for economic, science, technical and cultural cooperation.

the agreement provides for the setting up of a joint commission which is to meet regularly to examine the major areas of bilateral cooperation.

APRIL 21

LIBREVILLE, Gabon - Gabon recalls its Ambassador in France and summoned the French envoy here over media allegations from Paris news that President Omar Bongo as infected with the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) that causes the incurable AIDS disease.

DAKAR, Senegal - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees warns there would be "a catastrophe" unless urgent help is given to 100,000 destitute people huddled on a hill in Rwanda.

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania - West African ministers from the nine-nation Inter State Committee for Drought Control in the Sahel begin their 30th ordinary meeting saturday in Nouakchott, a city already engulfed by the Sahara Desert.

KAMPALA, Uganda - Uganda has expels eleven diplomats from the Sudanese embassy in Kampala, four of them ordered to leave within 48 hours effective from Thursday.

APRIL 24

BRAZZAVILLe, Congo - The Congolese police arrest a 42-year-old woman for growing Indian hemp on a farm in her Mabombo village in the country's south.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Angered by the latest massacre in Rwanda, Organization of African Unity (OAU) authorities call for an investigation and punishment against their perpatrators.

NIAMEY, Niger - Representatives of Tuareg rebels and of the government of Niger sign a peace agreement hoping to end four years of conflict over the former's demand to be given autonomy.

APRIL 25

BUJUMBURA, Burundi (PANA) - A Burundi soldier and an assailant are shot dead in clashes between a government army patrol and criminals operating in Kamenge, an all-Hutu suburb in Bujumbura, the capital.

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso (PANA) - Thirty African journalists begin a four-day training workshop to improve their skills on reporting human rights issues.

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso - Burkina Faso authorities close two Sunni mosques after the death of 30 people mand injury of 30 others in clashes between two rival factiobs squabbling over funds for the construction of a new prayer place.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Voter registration for Ethiopia's federal and regional elections in May is extended to Sunday so that those who missed the listing, because of easter holidays, can sign up.

APRIL 26

BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe - The 36th Zimbabwe International Trade Fair opened Wednesday in Bulawayo, the country's largest second city, with a record 37 countries participating.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - relative calm returns to Kamenge suburb in northern Bujumbura after sporadic exchanges of gunfire the previous day between the Tutsi-dominated army and Hutu militia.

TRIPOLI, Libya - A court in Lagiers postpones the trial of 2nd. Lt. Lambarek Boumarafi, who is charged with assassinating Algerian President Mohammad Boudiaf.

APRIL 27

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, George Moose tells a news conference that he was encouraged by by the commitment of Burundian politicians "to seek peace for their country".

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia decontrolls the marketing of maize, the national staple, and plans to set up a food reserve agency to operate and manage a national food security reserve.

ACCRA, Ghana - A West African summit on Liberia will now be held in the Nigerian capital, Abuja, on May 17, Ghana's deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Mohamed ibn Chambas says.

APRIL 27

ACCRA, Ghana - Five people are reported killed and 436 houses burnt in renewed ethnic clashes in Ghana's northern region.

YAOUNDE, Cameroon - Red Cross eperts say that at the current pace of operations, it will take at least 100 years and slightly over 33 billion dollars to clear the 110 million anti-personnel mines buried around the world.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - A catholic priest in Ntega, north of Burundi's capital Bujumbura, Father Zacharie Nduwimana was abducted by unknown persons as he walked past a camp for war displaced persons.

Summary of African Events for May 1995

MAY 2

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - The United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (UNECA) and South Korea sign a memorandum of understanding to establish a Development Fund for Africa.

Officially known as the Korea-ECA Cooperation Fund, its aim is to meet the costs of large scale projects to be mutually agreed on. Seoul places 200,000 U.S dollars into the fund.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian Express Airways suspends all its flights following an order by Transport Minister William Harrington.

He directed that the carrier halt all South Africa- bound flights until it hired former Zambia Airways employees who lost their jobs when state-owned airline was liquidated in December 1994.

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana's peacekeeping expenditure in liberia operations shoot up by more than half over the previous year, the office of the Controller and Accountant-General says.

About 3.4 million dollars was spent on Ghana's contingent in the West African Peackeeping force (ECOMOG) in 1994.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Angolan President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos is expected in Lusaka for an official visit, ahead of Friday's crucial peace meeting with Unita leader Jonas Savimbi.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Sudan says it would welcome Uganda's decision to close the two countries' common border saying this will help end mutual accusations of helping each other's rebels.

DAKAR, Senegal - Ten African Presidents are expected to attend the third African-African-American Summit in Dakar, the meeting's organisers said.

MAY 3

ACCRA, Ghana - The ghana armed forces and a detachment of United States special forces start joint military exercises in ghana's northern region.

DAKAR, Senegal - The chairman of the World Press Freedom Committee, Harold Andersen, says governments purporting to support democratic institutions must end censorship and other restrictions on the media.

DAKAR, Senegal - Washington declares that it will challenge Europe's longstanding grip on the African economy, with the prospects of a boom in sight.

U.S Secretary of Commerce, Ron Brown, says this at the opening session of the Third African African-American Summit in Dakar.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon - Gabonese Information Minister Alexandre Sambat lifts the ban on two opposition weekly newspapers wednesday, on the occasion of the world press freedom day.

MAY 4

DAKAR, Senegal - Organisation of African Unity (OAU) Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim says he wants African-Americans to back the continent's efforts to defuse conflicts and other emergencies.

In an interview, Salim says he believes the powerful african-american constituency could help stop externally-induced causes of Africa's economic crisis.

BAMAKO, Mali - The Malian government starts repaying the second instalment of its internal debts estimated at 41 Billion F CFA as at the end of 1994.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - At least 18 people are killed and others wounded in an ambush in northern Burundi.

ABUJA, Nigeria - Nigeria's military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha says he would return the country to civilian rule, but not in a rush."We must take care ...to avoid rushing into the mistakes of the past".

DAKAR, Senegal - Senegal's Prime Minister Habib Thiam says 1,000 crack troops were dispatched to the Southern Casamance Province for four French tourists feared abducted by separatist guerillas.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian authorities annpunce that the official visit of Angolan President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos had been delayed.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - Congo introduces a national solidarity and reconciliation tax whose preceeds will be used to assist people displaced during the recent ethnic unrest in which at least 2000 people were killed.

MAY 5

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Twenty -three people are injured when unknown assailants hurl a grenade at Bujumbura central market.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - Congolese opposition parties win five of the seven seats in congo's parliamentary by-elections.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - A Zimbabwean opposition party claiming to have won 19 seats in the April parliamentary elections says it will take the government to court if the reverse occurs.

LUSAKA, Zambia - The United Nations announces that the peace summit between Angolan President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos and Unita leader Jonas Savimbi will now take place saturday instead of Friday.

DAKAR, Senegal - The African-African American summit ends in Dakar with a call by the U.S. Commerce Secretary, Ron Brown, on American businessmen to deal with Africa directly.

MAY 8

NAIROBI, Kenya - The Kenya-Zambia joint permanent commission begins discussions on ways of expanding bilateral cooperation.

ACCRA, Ghana - Finance Minister Kwesi Botchwey says the Ghanaian government is prepared to review its Value Added Tax (VAT) introduced two months eralier.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Two watchmen are killed and another wounded when a score of gunmen stormed a soap factory in Bujumbura's industral area Sunday night.

YAOUNDE, Cameroon - Cameroon is to host the 1996 summit of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), the government officially announces here.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - A top Sudanese official Mahdi Ibrahim accuses uganda of trying to drag his country into a border war.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Four Zambian journalists are detained at Johannesburg international airport and threatened with deportation for lack of entry visas. They are part of President Frederick Chiluba's advance delegation to the World Economic Forum opening in johannesburg later in the week.

MASERU, Lesotho - Thousands of peaceful placard-waving teachers calling for a end to deep salary cuts bring traffic to a halt in the Lesotho's capital, Maseru.

MAY 11

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Sudan requests Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe to help end the civil war in its southern part.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Southern African Development Community (SADC) chairman Ketumile Masire of Botswana says in Johannesburg that the sub-region has the necessarcy conditions for an "economic take-off".

He says speaking at the joint SADC-World Economic Forum summit.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe accepts President Bill Clinton's invitation for an official working visit to the Wwhite House May 12.

MAY 12

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The Burundian government expresses concern following the arrival of thousands of new Rwandan refugees in the country, adding to the 200,000 already there since April 1994.

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana's Interior Minister Emmanuel Osei-Owusu announces the death of five people in anti-government demonstrations in the capital, accra. An unknown number of are also injured, says the minister.

MAPUTO, Mozambique - World Food Programme and Mozambican Red Cross officials start searching for the ringleaders behind the theft of 840 tonnes of donated maize worth 160,000 U.S. dollars in Milange district of the central Zambezia Province.

NAIROBI, Kenya - The Inter-Governmental Authority on Drought and Development (IGADD) committee of experts meets in Nairobi to map out strategies to revitalize the organisation and give it a new direction.

IGADD groups Djibouti, Eritrea, Kenya, Somalia, Sudan and Uganda and came into being in 1986. Its main goals are to boost food security , mitigate the impact of drought and destertification, and environmental protection.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - The Administration of Refugees and Returnees Affairs (ARRA) in Ethiopia says that some 6,795 Somali refugees have crossed into Daror in Eastern Ethiopia since fighting broke out in Burao, North-West Somalia.

MAY 15

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's health personnel are put on alert in border areas with Zaire where the deadly viral infection, Ebola, has claimed more than 60 lives.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The Dutch government says it gave zimbabwe 21.25 million U.S dollars for macro-economic support for its structural adjustment programme and for rural development.

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghanaian teachers, civil servants, nurses and judicial staff give the government up to May 31 to increase their salaries or face a strike action.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The body of Burundi's Health Ministry Permanent Secretary, Alexis Hatungimana alias Bucucu is found in Gatumba, one kilometer north of Bujumbura on the border with Zaire.

KINSHASA, Zaire - Six new deaths are reported in Kikwit, 250 kilometers from the Zairean capital, Kinshasa, raising the death toll caused by the deadly 'Ebola' virus to 64.

MAY 16

NAIROBI, Kenya - Twenty people are killed and many others seriously injured in a head-on collission between a bus and a minibus in eastern Kenya monday.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia takes measures to check the possible spread of the 'Ebola' virus from neighbouring Zaire where the disease has killed 77 people in the town of kikwit.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Malnutrition in harare's high density suburbs is reported to have risen three times more than projected levels, a study by the city's health services said. It cited economic hardship as a possible cause of the problem.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - The Abidjan-based African Development Bank has lifted its ban on lending to Sudan, the country's minister of finance Abdalla Hassan Ahmed discloses.

MAY 17

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana's President Jerry Rawlings says that victims of a public demonstration in Accra will be paid compesation.

LONDON - The United States protests to Zimbabwe on the arrest of three Modus Publications executives over a story linking a high court judge and a cabinet minister to an alleged secret wedding between President Robert Mugabe and Grace Marufu, a secretary in his office.

TRIPOLI, Libya - King Hassan II of Moroco says his country's agricultural sector has been hard hit by drought and urges his subjects to prepare for a "national disaster".

DAKAR, Senegal - FAO Director General Jacques Diouf starts a 10-day West African tour of Cape Verde, Gambia, Guinea and Senegal.

DAKAR, Senegal - UNESCO Director-General Federico

MAYor denounces the murders of two university directors, two women and a history teacher in Algeria.

KINSHASA, Zaire - Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko says he will not visit Kikwit, the city 250 kms from the Kinshasa, where 86 people have died in an epidemic of the deadly 'Ebola' virus.

MAY 19

LUSAKA, Zambia - Hundreds of eastern Zambians are reported to be flocking daily to Malawi to drink a traditional concoction believed to prevent and cure most diseases including the incurable AIDS.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Liberians in Addis Ababa say the international community must pressure the country's warring factions to honour the Cotonou agreement to bring lasting peace to the west african nation.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Burundian President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya visits Tanzania to negotiate the release of a ship-load of chinese-made arms and ammunition impounded at Dar es Salaam port a month earlier.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Burundi national radio reports the killing of six people and the injury of a similar number in grenade attacks in Bujumbura, the capital, and its suburbs.

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso - A workshop on the prevention of natural disasters in Africa ends with an appeal on governments to create structures to deal with these problems and a fund to meet the costs involved.

MAY 22

ABUJA, Nigeria - The Board of Governors of the African Development Bank and its affiliate, African Development Fund begin their annual meeting in the Nigerian capital, Abuja.

MASERU, Lesotho - Members of the Lesotho police start a go-slow strike Monday to press for a 15 percent salary increase given to all civil servants and teachers by the government.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The Burundi capital, Bujumbura is deserted after a night of shoot-outs between rival gunmen.

MAY 23

ABUJA, Nigeria - Five senior officials of the African Development Bank have been fired and 15 others sanctioned for varying degrees of impropriety.

TRIPOLI, Libya - The trial of the accused murderer of former Algerian President Mohammad Boudiaf is postponed to next Saturday.

TUNIS, Tunisia - Tunisia's ruling Constitutional Democratic Rally ( Rassemblement Constitutionnel Democratique' party wins 99.86 percent of the ballots in minicipal elections Sunday.

ABUJA, Nigeria - The 31st annual general meeting of the board of governors of the African Development Bank (ADB) opens after an elaborate ceremony presided over by Nigerian military leader Gen. Sani Abacha.

DAKAR, Senegal - Gambia denies allegations that its soldiers had shot dead the sub-prefrect of Sindian in the Southern Senegalese region of Casamance, as reported by a Dakar-published newspaper.

MAPUTO, Mozambique - At least 100,000 people in Mozambique's Southern Inhambane province are reported to be at risk of death from famine following a drought in the area.

LAGOS, Nigeria -A World Bank report says Africa will in the next decade need some 1.5 billion U.S. dollars annually to rehabilitate its roads.

KAMPALA, Uganda - Denmark joins the United States in calling for multi-party democray in Uganda. Danish minister for international co-operation Poul Nielson says donors will not accept President Yoweri Museveni's 'No Party' system in the long run.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia National Commercial Bank minority shareholders threaten to sue their government over the proposed merger of their bank with the troubled local branch of the Meridien-BIAO.

MAY 26

ABUJA, Nigeria - The Board of Governors of the African Development Bank asked the institution's outgoing head, Babacar Ndiaye of Senegal, to stay on until fresh elections are held in August at its headquarters Abdijan, Cote d'Ivoire.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon - Gabon has decides to postpone a scheduled constitutional referendum from June 25 to July 23 to give room for ample preparations.

Summary of African Events for June 1995

JUNE 2

DAKAR, Senegal - Senegalese police find the bodies of Amath Faye, Administrator of the southern Sindian District and of his three aides who had disappeared in the Gambia-Senegal border zone in April.

NAIROBI, Kenya - Kenya writes to all its missions and tourism offices abroad denying unconfirmed reports of an outbreak of the deadly Ebola in the east african country.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia announces that it has contained the African swine fever that broke out two years ago and lifts the ban on importation of pig and pork products from neighbouring Zimbabwe.

LAGOS, Nigeria - One of Liberia's faction leaders Charles Taylor who believes one-on-one dialogue with the Nigerian leadership holds the key to peace in his country is due in the Nigerian capital, Abuja.

MAPUTO, Mozambique - South African investors are expected to launch agricultural and tourist projects in northwestern Mozambique under a bilateral agreement to be signed by the two governments.

LAGOS, Nigeria - World's soccer governing body FIFA decides not to penalise Nigeria for failing to participate in the April under-20 world championship in Qatar.

ACCRA, Ghana - Members of the Ghana Union Traders Association close their shops here to back demands for the suspension of the country's recently introduced Value Added Tax (VAT).

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian police travel to the northern city of Ilorin, where a bomb blast at a state function killed at least three people and left many others injured the previous day.

NAIROBI, Kenya - President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya rules out radical constitutional reforms in the country. His statement in national broadcast comes in the wake of growing criticism of what many see as his "undemocratic" rule.

LUSAKA, Zambia - After breaking off diplomatic relations, Sudan and Uganda agree to the mediation of malawi president bakili muluzi, chairman of the common market for east and southern africa to which they belong.

NDJAMENA, Chad - Chad's security agents ransack the premises of the independent weekly newspaper 'Ndjamena-Hebdo' and detain its Director and Editor-in-Chief.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Visiting Liberian warlord Charles Taylor holds talks in the Nigerian capital, Abuja, with the Nigerian Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi.

JUNE 6

LAGOS, Nigeria - The President of the Nigerian special military tribunal hearing the case of military officers and civilians on trial for an alleged coup plot in March says their verdict will be known by June 30.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Burundi's nurses start a strike for better pay and improved work conditions. They say it was time to change their status, established in 1954.

NIAMEY, Niger - Police release eight of the 12 students remanded in custody after violent demonstrations in the nation's capital, Niamey, the previous week.

DAKAR, Senegal - Despite defiant words Togolese university students here ended two days of protest outside their embassy in the Senegalese capital, Dakar.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Malawian President Bakili Muluzi arrives in Khartoum on a brief state visit to Sudan in an attempt to patch the diplomatic rift between kampala and khartoum.

ALGIERS, Algeria - Algeria's national soccer team coach Rabah Majer is fired because of his team's inability to win matches.

LUSAKA, Zambia - A three-day international conference on industrial minerals of Southern Africa opens in Lusaka.Its objective is to attract local and foreign investment in the industrial mineral development sector in the sub-region.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Indian President Shankar Dayal Sharma, accompanied by his wife Vimala, arrive in Harare for a three-day state visit aimed at strengthening economic, cultural and technical relations with Zimbabwe.

NEW YORK - The United Nations is to scale down its 5,967 personnel in Rwanda, according to a report by the organisation's Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali.

JUNE 8

MAPUTO, Mozambique - Southern African Development Community (SADC) Executive Secretary Kaire Mbuende leaves Maputo after discussing plans for a donors' conference for the reconstruction of war-ravaged Angola and Mozambique.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The Burundi government prepares to introduce a "special type of administration" in Bujumbura's northern suburbs of Kamenge and Kinama, scenes of recent bloody fighting between the Tutsi-dominated army and opposing Hutu militias.

BAMAKO, Mali - A Malian government mission leaves Bamako for Southern Algeria to meet Tuareg refugees as part of a national reconciliation effort. The team is also to visit Burkina Faso and Mauritania.

NAIROBI, Kenya - The United Nations Environment Programme calls for the protection of the world's oceans from abuse by man.The appeal is contained in a message by UNEP Executive Director Elizabeth Dowdswell, to mark "Oceans Day".

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian politician Olusola Saraki declared wanted by police in connection with the bombing at a public function in northern Nigeria turns himself in.

MAPUTO, Mozambique - Mozambican police says it seized 12 firearms and large quantities of arms in a raid on the Manhica Coldstore complex on the outskirts of Maputo.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The Southern African Development Community and the European Union plan a meeting to discuss the latter's experience in promoting regional integration.

JUNE 12

DAKAR, Senegal - Senegalese President Abdou Diouf leaves for Bissau for talks with Guinea-Bissau's President Joao Bernardo Vieira.They are to sign a protocol on the joint use of territorial waters shared by the two countries, based on an accord concluded on September 9, 1993 in Paris.

TRIPOLI, Libya - Baccalaureat exams start in northern Algeria amidst tight security for fear of assassinations by a radical islamic group.

BRUSSELS, Belgium - Experts from the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and the European Union start a week-long seminar to discuss the eu's experience in promoting regional integration.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Fifteen casualties are reported from Sunday's clashes between Hutu and Tutsi students at Bujumbura University.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Business in Nigeria's economic capital, Lagos, picks up gradually amid fears of possible violence on the second anniversary of the June 12, 1993 presidential election annulled by the military. But a sit-at-home call by the 'campaign for democracy' was largely ignored.

JUNE 13

DAKAR, Senegal - Senegalese President Abdou Diouf ends a visit to neighbouring Guinea-Bissau saying that the two countries had agreed to end hostilities and build stronger economic ties.

MUTARE, Zimbabwe - The Mozambican government protests against zimbabwean plans to draw large quantities of irrigation water supplies from the pungwe that flows through the two countries.

BRUSSELS, Belgium - The European Union pledges to help the 11-member Southern African Development Community (SADC) states integrate their widely disparate economies.

JUNE 14

NAIROBI, Kenya - A Kenyan soldier with the United Nations peacekeeping mission shot dead in Croatia sunday is identified as Corporal Stephen Nyogio Chebochok.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Burundi denies Tanzanian claims that its troops have made incursions into parts of tanzanian territory, saying it was amazed by the allegations.

PARIS, France - The European Union and the Southern African Development Community agree take practical steps to promote regional integration in Southern Africa.

TRIPOLI, Libya - An Egyptian court finds Cairo University Prof. Hamid Abouzid guilty of "heresy" for his works on the Holy Koran.

JUNE 15

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana's Foreign Minister Obed Asamoah denies international media reports that his country has been airlifting arms to Rwanda's Hutu militias.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's Deputy Head of State, Lt. Gen. Oladipo Diya, reiterates his government's decision to maintain its candidate for the African Development Bank presidency. Elections held in Abuja, the nigerian capital, a month earlier failed to come up with a clear winner.

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso - The Foreign Ministry in Burkina Faso announces the killing of a Burkinabe officer serving with the OAU Observer mission in Burundi.

JUNE 19

LUSAKA, Zambia - A three-day meeting on the establishment of a data-bank for culture in the Southern African region begins in Lusaka to adopt the findings and recommendations of a feasibility study by a UNESCO consultant.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe says it needs about 732 million zimdollars (91.5 million u.s. dollars) from the international community to buy food, agricultural inputs and improve its water supplies.

JUNE 20

NEW YORK - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees says the number of refugees increased globally by four million between May and June, with the highest increase recorded in Africa.

MAPUTO, Mozambique - The United Nations High Commission for Refugees announces that the "movement phase" in the repatriation of mozambican refugees from the six neighbouring countries is completed.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian police detain the Managing Director of a privately-owned 'Post Newspaper' for criminal libel against President Frederick Chiluba.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian police, facing a rising wave of urban crime, ordered all private firearms depots in the country off limits.

JUNE 21

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - The Hutu Director of Scientific Research at Bujumbura University, Dr Stanny Ruzenza, is killed in his office by an unknown assailant armed with a pistol.

KINSHASA, Zaire - Seventeen people are killed and many injured in a train derailment near Bena-Kadiebwe railway station in the West Kasai Province in Central Zaire.

ADDIS ABABA, Addis Ababa - The 62nd Session of Organization of African Unity's Council of Ministers opens in Addis Ababa ahead of the continental body's Heads of State Summit.

NIAMEY, Niger - Niger's University Students Union gives the government 24 hours to pay nine months of scholarship arrears and improve their living conditions or face a demonstration.

BRAZZAVILLE, Congo - The leader of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, Jonas Savimbi, arrives in Brazzaville for talks with Congolese leaders.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Southern African Development Community experts on culture choose South Africa as the location of the sub-region's culture data bank.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Sudan tightens security along its border with Eritrea to ward off possible threats from its eastern neighbour.

JUNE 23

ACCRA, Ghana -Thousands of people demonstrate in Ghana's sea port of Takoradi, about 230 kilometres West of Accra to protest high costs of living.

ENTEBBE, Uganda - World Bank President James Wolfensohn says he will give priority to alleviation of poverty in Africa. The bank's Vice-President for Africa Edward Jaycox says the Bretton Woods institution will also spend between 7.5 and 8.0 billion us dollars in assistance to Africa during the next three years.

MAPUTO, Mozambique - The World Bank has moderated its stance on Mozambique's cashewnut processing industry and is now prepared to accept a measure of temporary protection for the industry.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian police in the northern copper-mining town of Chingola confiscate a gun allegedly produced during fighting between opposing factions at a meeting of the country's main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP).

TRIPOLI, Libya - Preparations for a self-determination referendum in the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic hit another snag due to manoeuvres by the Polisario front and Morocco which have for years disputed over the ownership of Western Sahara. The latest date set for the ballot was January 1996.

OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso - Malian President Alpha Omar Konare says the end of a 48-hour working visit to Burkina Faso that there was no military solution to his country's Tuareg rebellion in the north.

NIAMEY, Niger - Eleven students are arrested following clashes with police in which three of their colleagues sustaind injuries.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Countries owing the Organization of African Unity arrears of contributions win a 28-day reprieve before sanctions are enforced.Under a decree issued last year, the 53 member states were given until June to settle 58 million U.S dollars in contribution arrears or be barred from voting or speaking at OAU meetings.

JUNE 26

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak narrowly escapes an assassination attempt in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia an hour before the opening of an annual African Heads of State Summit.Two of the six attackers were shot dead by Mubarak's bodyguards.

ACCRA, Ghana - A three-day workshop for 19 chief electoral officers and senior Commonwealth officials takes place in Accra.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - With several internal conflicts in mind, United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali underscored the need for peace in Africa Monday, at the opening of an annual continental summit.

ABIDJAN, Cote d'Ivoire - Laurent Gbagbo, the secretary general of the opposition Ivorian Popular Front (FPI) is chosen candidate in the country's presidential election of October.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Ethiopian president Meles Zenawi was chosen by his African counterparts as the new Chairman of the Organization of African Unity (OAU) at the opening of the continental body's 31st Summit.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - An official of the Organization of African Unity in Burundi says that 13 military officers had arrived in the Bumjumbura to reinforce the body's observation mission in the Central African country.

JUNE 27

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - African leaders, meeting without Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, began their second day of the 31st summit by discussing the continent's political and socio-economic issues.Mubarak flew back to Cairo after an assassination attempt on him.

KHARTOUM - Sudan denies involvement in attempt to kill Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak on his arrival in Addis Ababa for the 31st Summit of the Organization of African Unity.

ADDIS ABABA - Organization of African Unity (OAU) leaders meeting in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, officially condemn Monday's assassination attempt on Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak, describing it as an abominable act which should strengthen the OAU's resolve to stem terrorism on the African continent.

KINSHASA - Uganda and Zaire are to jointly prospect for oil along their common border, sources in Kinshasa have disclose.

JUNE 28

ADDIS ABABA - Ethiopian authorities tighten security in Addis Ababa as African heads of states attending the 31st OAU return home.Local police combed the city for suspects in the attempted assasination of the Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak Monday.

TRIPOLI, Tripoli - Libyan leader Moammar Kadhafi meets with Capt. Ebou Jallow, spokesman for the Gambian military now in power. No further details of the meeting were disclosed.

ADDIS ABABA - Sudan's president Omar El-Bashir accuses Egypt, Eritrea and Uganda of conspiracy to destabilize his country by supporting insurgents trying fighting for autonomy from Khartoum.

JUNE 29

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana says it will host the July summit of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) should Nigeria decline.

LUSAKA, Lusaka - Zambia's former President Kenneth Kaunda is re-elected leader of the country's major opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP). He beat incumbent party president Kebby Musokotwane during elections at the party's congress in Lusaka.

Kaunda received 1,916 votes against Musokotwane's 400 to grab his former post he had relinquished in 1992 when he "retired" from partisan politics.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - The Pan African News Agency, the continent's collective wire service, needs three million U.S. dollars to get up and running and into cyberspace, its Coordinator-General, Babacar Fall, says.

YAOUNDE, Cameroon - Clashes between Bamoun farmers and Bororo shepherds in the Cameroonian village of Nkoumdoum, about twenty kilometres from Foumban in the north, leave seven people dead and about 30 wounded.

NIAMEY, Niger - Riot police brutalise and then arrest seven students who converged at Parliament building in Niamey, the capital.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Sudan bans bus travel to and from neighbouring Eritrea following complaints that Asmara authorities had doubled entry fees to 40,000 Sudanese pounds (some 120 US dollars).

KHARTOUM - Twenty-six football players are reported killed in Central Sudan on Tuesday, when the boat in wich they were travelling capsized in the Blue Nile.

JUNE 30

MAPUTO, Mozambique - The Mozambican post office introduces postal codes for the first time Friday into the country's mail address system.Letters and parcels should now bear a five figure postal code immediately after the town or locality to which they are addressed.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Security is tightened in Nigeria's economic capital, Lagos following running batlles between robbers and policemen in which at least 10 people were reported killed the previous day.The dead included an army captain and three policemen.

NEW YORK - The United Nations High Commissioner says it needs 44 million U.S. dollars over the next two and a half years for the voluntary repatriation of some 300,000 Angolan refugies.

YAOUNDE, Cameroon - Cameroonian president Paul Biya expresses satisfaction at the choice of his country as the venue of the 32nd OAU summit to be held in June 1996.

Summary of Afrian Events in July 1995

JULY 2

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Some 3,000 residents of Kamenge, a Hutu residential area in the Northern part of Bujumbura, were resettled after fleeing an army sweep through their neighbourhood two weeks before. Fearing repression, Kamenge's estimated 40,000 residents fled when the Tutsi-dominated army combed the area for suspected Hutu rebels.

JULY 4

ADDIS ABABA - Ethiopia denied its security forces had been involved in a failed terrorist attempt to assassinate Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak as he arrived in Addis Ababa for an OAU summit a week before.

LUSAKA - After regaining control of the United National Independence Party, former Zambian president Kenneth Kaunda fired the leader of the opposition in parliament, Dingiswayo Banda, from the party. Kaunda also sacked party administrative secretary Gen. Peter Zuze.

JULY 5

DAKAR - The United Nations High Commisioner for Refugees resumed the repatriation of Rwandans from camps in Goma, eastern Zaire.

JULY 6

DAKAR - The United Nations High Commission for Refugees disclosed it would not do business with manufacturers of anti-personnel mines.

"We shall not knowingly purchase the products of companies that sell or manufacture anti-personnel mines or their components," High Commissioner Sadako Ogata said.

BRAZZAVILLE - The World Health Organization reported an outbreak of haemorrhagic diarrhea which it said had killed some 100 people Equatorial Guinea.

JULY 7

BUJUMBURA - Grenades exploded and gunfire crackled through Bujumbura, the capital of Burundi, a day before an all-African peace-seeking mission was due to arrive in the city. It was not clear who was fighting who.

YAOUNDE - More than 100 people were reported missing after a Nigerian ferry on its way home capsized in a mangrove swamp in western Cameroon. There were 273 passengeres on board.

COTONOU - China disclosed limited financial aid (USD 3 million) to help strenghten Benin's armed forces.

JULY 9

BUJUMBURA - Forty-eight people were killed in ethnic clshes at the Cagizo market in the province of Muyinga, north-eastern Burundi, the official Burundi News Agency (ABP) reported on Tuesday.

JULY 10

LUSAKA - The Zambian government warned former president Kenneth Kaunda of possible arrest for inciting civil disobedience. Home Affairs Minister, Chitalu Sampa, said at a news briefing that the government would hold Kaunda responsibile for any public uprising.

JULY 12

LUSAKA - Zambia's foreign ministry disclosed it had evacuated families of diplomatic staff at its Consulate in Lubumbashi, capital of Zaire's southern Shaba region, in the wake of political disturbances in the area.

JULY 13

MASERU - Lesotho and South Africa decided to leave a long-standing border dispute to further negotiations, a joint communique issued in Maseru after discussions between visiting South African president Nelson Mandela and his host, Prime Minister Ntsu Mokhehle, said.

JULY 14

HARARE - Persistent drought had obliged Zimbabwe to double its power imports from neighbouring Zambia and Zaire to a total of 300 megawwats, the authorities in Harare said.

JULY 17

NAIROBI - The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) said it had over the last two days repatriated 557 Somalis who had volunteered to return home.

LUSAKA - The Zambian government said it had engaged security experts to trace former Meridien Bank BIAO Chief Executive Andrew Sardanis, believed to have led to the collapse of his international bank through fraud and other malpractises.

KAMPALA - Ugandan President Yoweri Museveni reshuffled his cabinet, promoting the Third Deputy Prime Minister, Eric Adriko, to Second Deputy Premier and Public Service Minister.

LUSAKA - A court in the Zambian capital, Lusaka, convicted President Frederick Chiluba's 19-year-old son, Castro and two others, for assaulting a woman at a night club in the city in April.

KINSHASA - Two journalists were sentenced to seven months in prison by a Zairean judge who found them guilty of defaming him and other court officials.

The verdict was pronounced by the Kinshasa-Matete Magistrates' court. The convited were the editor and the publisher of 'Le Point Zaire' newspaper, Belmonde Magloire and Nestor Mazangu.

JULY 18

ADDIS ABABA - United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, wound a five-nation visit to Africa.

MASERU - Prime Minister Ntsu Mokhele of Lesotho reshuffled his cabinet, sacking two senior ministers and hiring three others to replace them.

JULY 19

DAKAR - French Presidnent Jacques Chirac arrived in Rabat, Morocco, on a tour Frane's former Afrian colonies.

JULY 20

KHARTOUM - Former US President Jimmy Carter flew to the southern Sudanese town of Juba in another attempt to put together a ceasefire between government troops and rebels fighting for autonomy from Khartoum.

MAPUTO - Mozambican authorities expressed anger at South African plans to build a dam at Injaka on the Sabie river, despite being told this will worsen water shortages in Mozambique.

JULY 21

DAKAR - Rebels fighting for the separation of the southern Casamance region from the rest of Senegal wounded three government soldiers and an eight year old girl in a surprise attack against a military camp there.

ADDIS ABABA - The OAU Secretary General Salim Ahmed Salim joined world leaders and human rights movements in appealing to Nigeria's military leader for the release of recently convicted political prisoners.

JULY 24

KAMPALA - The third Presidential Forum on the Management of Science and Technology in Africa opened in Kampala, Uganda, with five Presidents expected to attend.

BUJUMBURA - Eleven people were killed and 15 others wounded when a group of unidentified persons threw hand grenades at a public bus along the airport road in Bujumbura, the capital of Burundi.

JULY 25

MAPUTO - Some 160 grave-diggers and other workers at Maputo's main cemetery called off a strike they had planned for fear of repression by the Mozambican police. They wanted increased pay and improved conditions of service.

JULY 26

HARARE - Zimbabwe's intelligence chief, Elleck Mashingaidze, was named as the source of a Financial Gazette story, which purported that President Robert Mugabe had married his former secretary, Grace Marufu, at a secret wedding at which a high court judge and a cabinet minister had officiated.

Financial Gazette editor, Trevor Ncube, facing criminal defamation charges along with his deputy, Simbarashe Makunike, and Publisher Elias Rusike, stunned a packed courtroom in Harare when he said that Makunike, who wrote the story, had told him that Mashingaidze was his source.

JULY 27

MAPUTO - It was reported Eduardo Arao, one of the five people sacked earlier in the week from the Secretariat of Mozambique's ruling FRELIMO party, had committed suicide in Maputo.

A statement issued by the FRELIMO Central Committee said Arao, the party's former secretary for administration and finance, killed himself with a firearm.

HARARE - Violence erupted at the University of Zimbabwe in Harare when some 20 students boycotting lectures attacked a group of riot police at the campus and burnt riot police helmets and shields.

NAIROBI - President Daniel arap Moi warned warring Somali Clans against using Kenya as a base to fight one another. Moi, who met representatives of 10 Somali factions at his Nairobi office, told them that those wishing to hold meetings in Nairobi should inform the government in advance.

JULY 28

DAKAR - Twenty-three Senegalese government soldiers, including an army officer, were reported missing in the southern region of Ziguinchor, 450 km from Dakar, the capital, following clashes with separatist guerillas.

JULY 30

ACCRA - Four people were killed when two factions clashed in a chieftaincy dispute at Diare in Ghana's northern region.
Summary of African Events in August 1995

AUGUST 1

LAGOS - In a further show of toughness, the military administrator of Lagos, Nigeria's business capital, Col. Olagunsoye Oyinlola, promised to execute more armed robbers by firing squad.

NEW YORK - Nigeria's Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi urged dialogue between the United States and Nigeria as a way of easing the current tension between them. "It's time for dialogue and cooperation (between the countries)," Ikimi told American editors and publishers.

KHARTOUM - A Sudanese Air Force plane crashed near a military base about 40 kilometres north-west of Khartoum, killing the pilot instantly.

AUGUST 2

LAGOS - Police in Lagos, Nigeria's business hub, reported they had shot dead 57 armed robbers in running gun battles in the past two month.

HARARE - An advance party of 80 Zimbabwean soldiers left Harare for Luanda as part of Zimbabwe's battalion-strong contingent to the United Nations Verification Mission (UNAVEM III) in Angola.

ENTEBBE - A Kenyan registered aircraft, operated by 'Speedbird Aviation Services of Uganda', crashed near Entebbe airport (Uganda) soon after take-off, killing all the six people on board.

AUGUST 3

VICTORIA FALLS - Angola's Home Affairs Minister Andre Pitra said his government remained suspicious of UNITA's commitment to the country's peace process, despite worldwide optimism.

NAIROBI - Thirteen secondary school students on their way to a music festival in Nairobi were killed and 27 others seriously injured in an accident on one of Kenya's 'death' highways.

LUSAKA - Edward Chisha, a former deputy minister in the Zambian president's office, was sentenced to 10 years in prison with hard labour for killing a lawyer in a bar brawl.

AUGUST 4

LUSAKA - Police released some 30 University of Zambia students arrested three days before for disturbing 'public peace'.

AUGUST 5

Arsonists burnt down 37 huts and stole catlle from villagers in Mugongomanga on the outskirts of Burundi's capital, Bujumbura.

AUGUST 6

BUJUMBURA - At least 30 people were killed by an unidentified group at Buganda in Burundi's north-eastern province of Cibitoke.

AUGUST 7

HARARE - The Zimbabwe government announced it had reduced the size of its army from 51,000 to 41,000 over the past 18 months.

MAPUTO - Foreign Minister Leonardo Simao denied Mozambican peasants would lose their land under following a deal under which white South Africans would be allowed to farm in the country.

AUGUST 10

LAGOS - Nigeria's military government said it was setting up a national human rights commission to address rights issues in the country. The NIgerian regime pledged its committment to human rights.

AUGUST 11

PRETORIA - Six former defence force chiefs and police commissioners under apartheid South African pledged their full support for the country's controversial Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

AUGUST 13

ACCRA - Thirteen people died on the spot and 34 others were seriously injured when two vehicles collided in an accident in Ghana's eastern region.

AUGUST 14

JOHANNESBURG - South Africa announced it planned to honour an agreement to store 15-million barrels of Iranian oil, despite American efforts to win allies in an embargo against the Gulf state.

AUGUST 16

HARARE - President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe told a group of Christian women it could become necessary to create an international group to oppose homosexuality and its supporters.

AUGUST 17

LUSAKA - The United States suspended aid to Sao Tome and Principe in the wake of a military coup on the Island nation off the coast of Gabon.

HARARE - Senior staffers on Zimbabwe's 'Financial Gazette' were convicted and fined for criminal defamation after the newspaper had carried a report claiming President Robert Mugabe had been married in a secret ceremony.

AUGUST 18

MAPUTO - The Gaza provincial government in southern Mozambique declared a state of emergency in eight districts due to severe drought. Reports said 128,000 people were severely affected, and Gaza's food deficit was at 134,000 tonnes of grain.
