LAGOS - Officials of the Nigerian customs service tried to unravel the mystery of how 800 million U.S. dollars in cash had reportedly found its way to the Lagos airport for export.

AUGUST 20

GUAYAQUIL - Ghana's Under-17 national team, the black starlets, produced dazzling form to beat Brazil 3-2 in Guayaquil, Ecuador, to win this category of the Junior World Cup for the second time.

AUGUST 21

JOHANNESBURG - South Africa said it would not bow to United States pressure regarding a new oil-marketing agreement with Iran. South Africa "will not reconsider the deal," a government spokesman said. "I do not understands why the United States should be so concerned about our little bit of business with Iran."

AUGUST 22

JOHANNESBURG - South African foreign minister Alfred Nzo denied his country had passed on nuclear secrets to Iran. Addressing a media briefing in Johannesburg, Nzo said dealings between the two countries fell within the scope of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

AUGUST 23

LUSAKA - Zambia's main opposition United National Independence Party (UNIP) warned government against what it called "harassment" of its leader Kenneth Kaunda -- the country's first president -- by the government of President Frederick Chiluba.

RABAT, Morocco - Moroccan authorities disclosed 230 people had died while 500 had gone missing following torrential rains in the tourist city of Marrakesh, 250 kilometres south of the capital.

BUJUMBURA - The President of Burundi, Maj. Pierre Buyoya, said his troubled country had reached a state of 'civl war'.

AUGUST 28

HARARE - Namibia and Zimbabwe agreed on joint military training as part of efforts to strengthen bilateral relations.

AUGUST 29

KAMPALA - The state-owned New Vision reported Sudanese army units and Ugandan rebels, led by a former minister under the dictator Idi Amin, had attacked government troops in Oraba, northern Uganda.

AUGUST 30

KHARTOUM - Sudan said it would release 18 more political prisoners, among them people acccused of an attempted coup in 1991 .

Summary of African Events During September 1995

SEPTEMBER 1

LUSAKA - The Zambian authorities announced Unita, the rebel movement from neighbouring Angola, has handed over 14 Zambians it had taken capitve.

TRIPOLI - The 1995 Kadhafi Prize for Human Rights was awarded to former presidents Ahmed Ben Bella of Algeria and Gusta Gomez of Portugal. The USD 250,000 prize was created in 1988 and first went to Nelson Mandela.

SEPTEMBER 4

ADDIS ABABA - The Eritrean government appealed for international action against what it called neighbouring Sudan's subversion and terrorism.

ADDIS ABABA - Foreign ministers of Egypt and Ethiopia agreed to try and arrest gunmen who had tried to kill Egypt's president Hosni Mubarak as he had arrived in the Ethiopian capital for an OAU summit in June.

SEPTEMBER 7

GABORONE, Botswana - The South African government refused to back down to demands for a 25 per cent salary increase from striking nurses at Soweto's sprawling Baragwanath and surrounding hospitals.

SEPTEMBER 8

LUSAKA - The Zambian government ruled out impeachment of President Frederick Chiluba for exposing the existence of security tunnels at State House in Lusaka. Chiluba claimed the tunnels had been used as torture chambers by the former regime led by Kenneth Kaunda.

NAIROBI - A committee of eight banks from Eastern and Southern Africa was created in Nairobi to tackle the rise in international bank fraud in the region.

SEPTEMBER 10

DAKAR - Some 290 Senegalese nationals who had been living in Burundi were repatriated from the country by their government.

SEPTEMBER 11

KHARTOUM - Several people were killed and many others injured in student riots in the Sudanese capital.

SEPTEMBER 12

KHARTOUM - The Sudanese government accused the banned Sudanese Communist Party of formenting the student riots that had hit Khartoum and neighbouring Omdurman the previous day.

ADDIS ABABA - The Organisation of African Unity told Sudan "to desist from engaging in activities of assisting, supporting and facilitating terrorist activities and from giving shelter and sanctuaries to terrorist elements."

LAGOS - The authorities disclosed 18 armed robbers had been executed in Nigeria's southeastern provincial town of Warri.

KHARTOUM - Sudan accused Ethiopia and Egypt of having conived to force the Organisation of African Unity (OAU) to condemn it for alleged involvement in an attempt to kill President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Addis Ababa in June.

SEPTEMBER 13

TRIPOLI - Libyan authorities postponed, until further notice, their planned expulsion of Palestinians from their territory.

SEPTEMBER 14

KHARTOUM - The official Sudanese News Agency reported the arrest of an undisclosed number of people in connection with riots that had rocked Khartoum and its environs.

ADDIS ABABA - Ethiopia disclosed it had expelled 500 illegal immigrants who had entered the country through unguarded sections of its borders. The Security, Immigration and Refugees Affairs Authority said the immigrants had "acquired" Ethiopian identity cards from "irresponsible local officials."

SEPTEMBER 15

Zambia postponed a visit by South African president Nelson Mandela to the country. No explanation was given.

SEPTEMBER 18

LAGOS - The Nigerian Union of Teachers (NUT) started a nationwide strike, despite government's announcement that it would meet part of the teachers' demands, the Union's secretary Gabriel Falade said in Lagos.

JOHANNESBURG - South African nurses gave their government 10 days to respond to their demands for a 33-per-cent wage increase and better working conditions.

KAMPALA - Workers in Uganda's government hospitals went on an indefinate strike for better pay.

SEPTEMBER 20

LUSAKA - Zambia's National Tender Board awarded Nikuv Computers of Isarel a USD 18 million contract to register voters for local government polls, and the 1996 Presidential and parliamentary elections amid wide protests from the opposition who said the company could help government rig the elections.

SEPTEMBER 21

COTONOU - Flooding in central and south-eastern Benin early in the week had left 19, government disclosed.

JOHANNESBURG - It was disclosed China would invest at least 60 million U.S. dollars to revitalise the Dikolong ferrochrome mine in South Africa.

SEPTEMBER 25

LAGOS - Nigeria' military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha, in a veiled response to mounting pleas on behalf of detained millionaire-politician Moshood Abiola and Nigerians convicted for an alleged coup plot, said the country's law would take its course.

SEPTEMBER 26

LUSAKA - Three children in Zambia's Copperbelt town of Chililabombwe were admitted to hospital with burns after their single 28-year-old mother set them on fire. She claimed she had been frustrated by her inability to provide for them.

SEPTEMBER 27

ADDIS ABABA - Former United States President Jimmy Carter appealed to Nigeria's Military ruler to show clemency and release that country's former leader, Olusegun Obasanjo. "I urge Abacha to release Obasanjo, one of the greatest leaders of Africa," Carter said.

SEPTEMBER 28

DAKAR - Fighting was reported in Moroni, capital of the Indian Ocean Island state of Comoros, where a group of white mercenaries tried to overthrow the government.

SEPTEMBER 29

DAKAR - Condemnation of the attempted coup in the Comoros by European mercenaries continued from leading African institutions and governments.

Summary of African Events in October 1995

OCTOBER 1

ABUJA, Nigeria - In a speech marking Nigeria's 35th independence day Military ruler Gen. Sani Abaha says he will handover power to an elected government in three years.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's former head of state, Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, listens with rapt attention as he is told on state television that he had knowledge of the failed coup attempt March 1994 in the West African state.

Looking haggard and bemused, Obasanjo who handed power to a civilian administration in 1979, appears visibly agitated as one of the alleged coup plotters, Col. Bello Fadile, tells the tribunal that he had held consultations with the statesman on the botched coup at his (Obasanjo) farm house in Otta, some 80 kilometres from Lagos.

The broadcast come seven months after the military government says it has uncovered the conspiracy and three months after the tribunal, headed by Brig.Gen. Patrick Aziza, which tried and convicted some of the suspects, ends its sitting.

OCTOBER 2

LAGOS - The executive director of the African American Newspaper Publisher Association, William Reed, urges the United States to lift sanctions on Nigeria and begin talks with the military government on restoring democracy to the West African country.

Speaking from the Nigerian capital Abuja he tells the Pan African News Agency in Lagos that the country's political problems are not "as bad as being portrayed by the foreign media."

Reed, one of a 19-member delegation on fact-finding mission to Nigeria, was speaking after military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha announced his three-year transition programme to civilian rule October 1.

HARARE - A five-day conference to examine the role of consultants in shaping development policies and programmes in Africa begins. The meeting is attended by 44 public and private sector consultants from 20 African countries and the United States. It aims at imparting practical skills to African consultants who can contribute to their professional development.

WASHINGTON D.C. - Britain and the United States, normally friendly to Nigeria, give a lukewarm response to the address by Gen. Sani Abacha guiding Nigeria back to democracy over the next three years.In a statement from Washington D.C., after Abacha announced his 36-month political transition and other major decisions, the United States says it is pleased that the convictions of alleged coup plotters have been commuted.

Britain welcomes elements of the Abacha speech with caution. The Foreign Office in London welcomes the clemency for the alleged coup plotters but "regrets the lack of commitment to an early handover to civilian democratic rule."

PRETORIA - South Africa condemns the second French nuclear test on the Fangataufa Atoll in the South Pacific.The censure comes in a statement from the Department of Foreign Affairs. It says the test is contradictory to the principles and objectives of the Nuclear non-proliferation treaty's review and extension conference.

It asks France "to reconsider" its testing policy, abandon plans for further tests and "join in a global moratorium."

LUSAKA - Zambian women's' non-governmental organisations joins the political opposition and the church in rejecting government's plan for parliament to adopt the country's draft constitution instead of the widely favoured assembly.

The organisations' Coordinating Committee chairwoman, Susan Jere, says in Lusaka that government's insistence that parliament ratify the constitution runs contrary to the wishes of the majority Zambians.

UNITED NATIONS - Kenyan Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation Minister Stephen Musyoka attacks what he calls a systematic campaign to denigrate African countries.

Addressing the United Nations General Assembly in New York Tuesday, he says such a destructive campaign is aimed at manipulating public opinion with a view to pitching people against their governments.

OCTOBER 3.

BAMAKO, Mali - Franc Zone Justice Ministers from 14 French-speaking African countries end their meeting in Bamako without reaching an agreement on the location of the Organisation for the Harmonisation of Business Law in Africa, known by the acronym, OHADA.

The council of ministers were expected to designate the host countries for OHADA's permanent secretariat, the common Court of Justice and Arbitration
and the regional law school.

But The ministers postpone the decision until their next meeting January 1996 in Ouagadougou.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwe says it has not sold any ivory since the 1989 trade ban and now has stockpiled 33,000 kilogrammes of the commodity valued at about 15 million zimdollars (about 8.52 million U.S. dollars).

Environment and Tourism Minister Chen Chimutengwende says the ban, under the Convention on International Trade In Endangered Species, has badly affected the operations of the cash-strapped Department of National Parks and Wildlife Management.

Zimbabwe has, for years, been pushing for special treatment so it could trade in ivory, arguing that it has a successful elephant conservation programme that has seen the national herd grow to unsustainable levels, hence the need for culling.

GENEVA - The United Nations High Commissioner For Refugees says it requires 41 million U.S. dollars to assist returnees and displaced people in war-torn Liberia. This is announced in Geneva during the launching of a fund-raising event by nine U.N. agencies under the Coordination of the Department of Humanitarian Affairs.

LAGOS, Nigeria - The Nigeria Police Force, waging an unrelenting war against rising violent crime, says 931 people including 123 of its men died in the last five years during robberies.

In one of its bulletins released today in Lagos the police says 7,538 cases of armed robbery were reported in the country between 1990 and 1994.Armed robbery, which surfaced with the end of Nigeria's 30-month civil war in 1970, is a national problem. The crime is punishable by death.

NEW YORK - A delegation of African American publishers just back from a fact-finding visit to Nigeria, say it found a country that is in sharp contrast to what had been portrayed in the general United States media.

The 19-man delegation, which was in Nigeria at the invitation of Foreign Minister Tom Ikimi, also describes the restriction on Nigerian officials by the U.S. government as "blatant racism."

PRAIA, Cape Verde - The African Commission On Human and People's Rights decides to appoint two special rapporteurs on women's rights and prisons in Africa, the commission's chairman, Isaac Nguema, announces in Praia.

OCTOBER 4

LUSAKA, Zambia - For the second day running, striking workers demanding higher pay paralyse operations on the Zambian side of the 1,850-kolometre Chinese-built railroad jointly owned by the governments of Tanzania and Zambia.

Zambian employees of the Tanzania-Zambia Railway Authority, TAZARA, demand a 150-per-cent pay increase across the board.

MAPUTO, Mozambique - The third anniversary of the 1992 Mozambican peace agreement, which ended he civil war, is overshadowed by the assault, battery and abduction of a Frelimo party official.

State-owned television claims that former RENAMO rebel leader Afonso Dhlakama ordered the detention of the FRELIMO secretary in the town of Gorongosa, Rui Franque. It claims that Dhlakama ordered the punishment because Franque had urged residents of the town, in the Central Solafa province, to stay away from Dhlakama's rally

OCTOBER , 5 1995

CAPE TOWN, South Africa - Outgoing Tanzanian President Ali Hassan Mwinyi arrives in South Africa on a three-day visit at the invitation of his counterpart Nelson Mandela. This is his last official visit before stepping down as Tanzania's second post-independence president after multiparty elections October 29.

PRAIA, Cape Verde - The African Commision on Human and Peoples' Rights meeting in Praia, Cape Verde, commends Tunisia for the progress it has made in upholding those rights. This is the consensus at the end of a lengthy debate, which started October 3, on the situation of human rights and basic freedom in the North African country.

COTONOU, Benin - The government of the West African state of Benin appeals for international donations of drugs, foodstuffs and clothes for flood victims in six of the country's districts.

The appeal is made by the minister in the President's Pffice, Guy Adjanohoun, in the presence of senior diplomats and representatives of international organisations.

Flooding of the Mono and Oueme rivers followed heavy rains in September. Twelve people died in the flooding which destroyed some 25,000 hectares of crops, killed 10,000 head of cattle and damaged 300 kilometres of roads, the interior ministry says. Some 165,000 people are affected by the flooding.

PORT LOUIS, Mauritius - The French government's foiling of the coup d'etat October 4 by foreign-led mercenaries in the Comoros is met with approval by some countries of the Indian Ocean sub-region, Mauritius' Planning Minister Prent Nababsing says.

The islands, grouped under the Indian Ocean Commission, comprise Comoros,
Madagascar, Mauritius, Reunion and Seychelles. .

The coup attempt was made September 28 by a score of mercenaries led by Frenchman Bob Denard. France has a defence pact with the Comoros.

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana President Jerry Rawlings tells the ambassadors of Benin, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, France and Togo that West African countries which have not played a role in the Liberia peace process need to get off the fence and become actively involved.

He says that a few of the 16-nations within the Economic Community of West African states had contributed money to maintaining its peacekeeping forces in Liberia.

Rawlings is the chairman of the community.

TEMA, Ghana - Ghana delivers its first test tube baby at the Pro-Vita Hospital in Tema. The delicate 70-minute operation was made by Dr Joe Mainoo, an obstetrician and gynaecologist.

OCTOBER 6

MAPUTO - Gangs of unemployed Mozambican youth rampage through the streets of Maputo, the capital, attacking vehicles and market stalls, to protest the rising cost of living.

Unhindered by police, the youngsters marched towards the centre of the city, from the informal Dumba-Nengue market to the road to the airport, spreading panic in their path.

OCTOBER 9

WASHINGTION D.C. - Sub-Sahara Africa needs to sustain economic qrowth at a minimum of 5 percent if it is to reduce poverty and compete effectively in the global market, the World Bank says in a regional brief.

This document is released ahead of the bank's 50th joint annual meeting with the International Monetary Fund,

OCTOBER 10. The bank says this minimun growth level must be met to offset the region's population expansion of 3 percent each year.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian police opens an inquiry into the assassination

OCTOBER 6 of Alfred Rewane, 79, a critic of the military regime in Abuja. Lagos State Police Spokesman Isaac Akinmoyede says the probe is being conducted by the Federal Investigations and Intelligence Bureau.

BAMAKO, Mali - Some 40 officials of consumer protection associations in 16 African states begin a meeting in Bamako, Mali to see how they can better serve the public. They consider guidelines on providing better information on the content of manufactured goods which may present health hazzards to the public.

OCTOBER 12

BANJUL, Gambia - Gambia's military rulers announce that the regime's spokesman, Capt. Ebou Jallow, had absconded with at least three million U.S. dollars of state funds. The announcement is made to the press at 1300 gmt by the office of the head of state, Capt. Yahya Jammeh.

It says the money was withdrawn from the the Central Bank of The Gambia

OCTOBER 4, without the knowledge of the Head of State or any other member of the Armed Forces Provicional Ruling Council.

KAMPALA, Uganda - Burundi has asked Uganda to extradite nine Burundian soldiers who allegedly master-minded the 1993 coup in which President Melchior Ndadaye was killed. The request is accompanied by warrants of arrest, Burundi Embassy and Ugandan Foreign Ministry officials say.

The officers sought include Majors Bernard Busokosa and Rene Rumbete. They allegedly took part in the July 3 coup attempt against Ndadaye, a week before he was sworn in as Burundi's president. Also wanted is Lt. Jean Paul Kamana who is said to have led the attack on Ndadaye's presidential palace and ordered his death.

The request was sent to Kampala September 18 after a meeting in July between President Yoweri Museveni and Burundi Prime Minister Antionne Nduwayo.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The first Africa and Middle East Conference of Parliamentarians on Population and Development opens.

NAIROBI, Kenya - Some 26 percent of all long distance truck drivers passing through Kenya are infected with the HIV virus believed to cause AIDS, a recent study shows.

Kenya's Daily Nation, a privately-owned Nairobi newspaper, cites a report in the East African Medical Journal as saying the drivers belonged to the "high risk" group. The study was conducted by five researchers from the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) and two others from the University of California in San Francisco, the United States.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa - South Africa's local government elections get the go ahead for November 1. The Senate gives its final approval to the local Government Transition Act Second Amendment Act.

The bill is approved by 57 votes to 18, with the opposition coming from the former ruling National Party, the right wing Freedom Front and the Zulu-based Inkatha freedom Party.

MAPUTO, Mozambique - The Mozambican parliament, the Assembly of the Republic, accepts to set up a nine-member ad-hoc committee to revise the country's national anthem.

The initiative comes from the deputies of the second major political party, Renamo, who have complained that the anthem and the Mozambican flag, are all the property of the ruling FRELIMO party and, therefore, are unrepresentative of the nation.

YAOUNDE, Cameroon - FIFA, the world soccer governing body, orders the reinstatement of the Cameroon football association executive dissolved June 23 by Minister of Youth and Sport Bipoum Woum.

FIFA tells the ministry that failure to restore the executive and its head Maher Daher by October 31 would lead to Cameroon's suspension from international soccer.

The minister had dissolved Daher's administration, accusing it of having stolen FIFA funds sent to the Cameroon Football Federation,to help it prepare for the 1994 World Cup in the United States.

OCTOBER 13

MAPUTO, Mozambique - Germany agrees to give Mozambique 62 million marks (about 43.4 million US dollars) to support labour intensive road construction projects. The grant will also support small and medium size private companies; and balance of payments in this, among the poorest of African countries.

Announcing this, the German Embassy says the grant followed negotiations September in Bonn.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi reaffirmes promises that he will not go back to war following the Lusaka peace accord which has led to relative peace in Angola.

Savimbi says this on his way to South Africa. But he returned to war after refusing to accept defeat in the 1992 elections won by President Jose Eduardo dos Santos' ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola.

BANJUL, Gambia - The military government of Capt. Yahya Jammeh denies accusations of killings and wanton arrests preferred against it by one of its officials, Capt. Ebou Jallow, who fled Gambia Ocober 7.

Banjul also rejects Jallow's resignation from the Armed Forces Provisional Ruling Council, saying he absconded with some three million U.S. dollars in public funds.

Jallow, who was the junta's spokesman, said October 12 he resigned from the government because of "murder and unwarranted arrests" perpetrated by colleagues in the council.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Ghana President Jerry Rawlings and three reknowned Nigerians win the first Zik Leadership Prize awards, government officials say in Lagos.

Rawlings is chosen winner in the political category of the prize, named after former Nigerian president Nmmamdi Azikiwe for his leadership and contribution to the independence and development of Nigeria.

Two eminent Nigerians, Akintola Williams and Alhaji Abdulaziz Ude, are declared winners in the business and professional categories.

The Award is designed to encourage the evolution of leadership among Africans on the continent and in the diaspora and also highlight Azikiwe's qualities as worth emulating.

OCTOBER 16

NEW YORK - Gambia's military government spokesman who fled to the United States October 7 denies absconding with three million U.S. dollars and vows to return home to bring justice and freedom to his country.

The official, Capt. Ebou Jallow, refuses to elaborate on his plans but says he will bring normalcy there by "all necessary means, but with Minimum cost to human lives."

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - The Organisation of African Unity appoints Justice Kamal Badri of Ethiopia to head the observer mission it plans to send to monitor the forthcoming multiparty elections in Tanzania.

Badri, who is president of the Ethiopian Supreme Court and Chairman of the National Electoral Commission, heads the team of election monitors from Egypt, Ethiopia, Ghana, Guinea, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zambia.

DAKAR, Senegal - In spite of the much touted "Education For All by the Year 2000", some 36 million Africans will never enter schools by that year, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation says.

However, Its Africa office in Dakar says that this figure should not scare but galvanise efforts to face up to the challenges ahead. This was contained in the agency's "Report on the State of Education in Africa" in 1995.

LAGOS, Nigeria - The secretary to the Nigerian government, Aminu Saleh, considered by many compatriots as the power behind military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha, is fired.

Saleh, who occupied the third highest position in the government when the present military administration came to power in November 1993, is replaced by another seasoned civil servant, Gidado Idris, lately director-general of the Ministry of Finance.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole appears in court on charges of plotting to assassinate President Robert Mugabe. Ndabaningi Sithole heads the Zimbabwe African National Union (Ndonga) which obtained two seats in the parliamentary

OCTOBER 17

GENEVA - Mozambican humanitarian Graca Machel is named the 1995 Nansen Medal winner. She gets the acclaim for her outstanding contributions to the welfare of refugee children, the United Nation High Commissioner for Refugees says.

The award is named after Norwegian diplomat and explorer Fridtjof Nansen, the first High Commissioner for Refugees under the League of Nations. The award was created to focus attention on refugees and to give new impetus to the need for international support for the uprooted.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - South Africa and Zimbabwe agree to establish a joint Water Commission which will oversee all matters so related.

The agreement is made at a closed door meeting between Zimbabwe's Lands and Water Resources minister, Kumbirai Kangai and South Africa's Minister of Water Affairs and Forestry, Kadar Asmal.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's Department of Immigration at the weekend round up 47 illegal immigrants.

Immigration spokesperson Catherine Poso says that the "aliens" picked up mainly on the Zambian Copperbelt include Gambian, Nigerian, Malawian, Senegalese, Tanzanian and Zairean nationals. Most of the Zaireans are taken to the border.

ACCRA, Ghana - Ghana says it will pay Mali the equivalent of 36,290 U.S. dollars by the end of November for 100 cattle under terms of an agreement signed today in Accra.

Mali gave the cattle in 1985 as part payment of a five-million pounds sterling loan from Accra to Bamako 24 years earlier. The refund became outstanding because Mali later paid the entire loan in cash after Ghana had already received the cattle.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's military ruler Gen. Sani Abcaha cancells a scheduled trip to Cartagena, Colombia, where he is to attend the 11th Summit conference of the Non-Aligned Movement.

Abacha also cancells another planned visit to New York to attend the special United Nations General Assembly session to be held next week in commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the world body.

No reason is given for the last-minute cancellation of the two engagements during which Abacha was expected to address the two bodies on the political situation in Nigeria and the three-year transition to civil rule programme he announced on October 1.

OCTOBER 18

LUSAKA, Zambia - Commercial activity in the Zambian capital, Lusaka, remains partialy paralysed following an earlier riot scare precipitated by the feared arrest of former President Kenneth Kaunda. The Zambian government says it intends to deport Kaunda on the grounds he is an alien.

Almost the entire city centre is jammed for about 30 minutes as scared members of the public panic and try to run away from riot police who keep vigil over the city in an army helicopter.

CARTAGENA, Colombia - The summit of the Non-Aligned Movement, a grouping of 113 mostly developing countries, begins in Cartagena, Colombia, with at least 48 heads of state and government attending.

The three-yearly summit is held to review the role of the organisation in view of changing global political trends following the end of the cold war. It also discusses social and economic issues as well as regional conflicts affecting developing countries.

MAPUTO - Deputies to Mozambique's parliament, the Assembly of The Republic, are shocked to learn that 18 out of the body's 99 employees have not received their wages for the past nine months.

Assembly Deputy President Abdul Carimo informes the legislature of this during a debate on the report submitted to it by its governing board, the Standing Commission, covering the last six months of the commission's activities.

NAIROBI, Kenya - At the advanced age of 80, John Muhu of Naivasha, in Kenya's Rift Valley Province, becames one of the country's oldest persons to be given a life sentence.

His bagful of crimes, read before a Naivasha court in eastern Kenya, includes murdering his father, two sons, a stranger and raping a 13-year old daughter.

OCTOBER 19

PRETORIA, South Africa - South Africa is to receive 700 million U.S dollars in foreign grants and technical cooperation agreements during the next four years.

International Development Cooperation Director in the Office for Reconstruction and Development, Shaheed Rajie, says that about 200 million U.S dollars out of this total is expected during the current financial year.

MONGU, Zambia - In a major turnaround, the Zambian government halts investigations relating to the citizenship of former President Kenneth Kaunda.

Speaking in Mongu, Western Zambia, Home Affairs minister Chitalu Sampa orders police to stop investigations against the country's first post-independence president, until further notice.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - A Cameroonian is shot dead and two others injured in two botched up counterfeit currency making deals in Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital.

State-owned Ethiopian News agency (ENA) reports that in the forgery deals, two Ethiopians had lost 140,000 Ethiopian birr (1 U.S. dollar = 6.30 birr) and 20,000 U.S dollars.

ADDIS ABABA - OAU Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim says he will send observers to monitor Cote D'Ivoire's October 22 presidential election. The observers, whose number he does not specify, include "diplomats, lawyers and eminent professors from member states and OAU officials."

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria has paid 350 million U.S. dollars to seven joint oil partners for jobs done in September, The Central Bank says. The payments are part of government's efforts to boost crude oil production from the current two million barrels per day to 2.5 million barrels per day.

OCTOBER 20

LUSAKA, Zambia - Former Zambian President Kenneth Kaunda files an injunction in the Lusaka high court asking it to restrain the Minister of Home Affairs and his Chief Immigration Officer from deporting him. Judge Peter Chitengi sets November 1 for an inter-parte hearing.

PARIS - The United Nations Scientific, Educational and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) and the UN Commissioner for Human Rights have signed an agreement to increase cooperation in the protection of the rights of people, UNESCO says.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zimbabwean opposition ZANU (Ndonga) leader Reverend Ndabaningi Sithole, in custody for seven days on allegations of plotting to assassinate President Robert Mugabe, is granted bail by the High Court in Harare.

The court, sitting in chambers, set bail at 100,000 Zimdollars (11,764 U.S. dollars) and orders Sithole to surrender as surety title deeds of his one million zimdollar (117,650 U.S. dollars) two-hectare plot in Waterfalls, Harare.

He is ordered to surrender his travel documents and stay at his plot for four weeks until November 18.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Nigerian-born English soccer star John Fashanu offers to help prepare the Zambian national soccer team for the African Cup of Nations Finals scheduled to take place in South Africa in Janaury 13, 1996.

Fashanu arrived in Lusaka October 19 saying he had come to see what he could do to assist the Zambian side.

In a related development, the Football Association of Zambia appoints Fashanu's Blue Orchid Company as management consultants to take charge of Zambia's soccer business in Europe.

ABIDJAN, Cote D'Ivoire - Partial results of Cote D'Ivoire's presidential election which begin today put the outgoing President Henri Konan Bedie far ahead of his rival from the Ivorian Labour Party, Francis Wodie. Figures released by the Interior Ministry show Bedie with 90 percent of the vote as against Wodie's 10 percent.

United Nations - The United Nations 50th General Assembly opens sounding alarm bells that it could be forced to shut down some of its operations unless member states clear arrears amounting to 3.4 billion U.S. dollars.

U.N. records show that at least 62 countries have not been paying their dues, among them the United States which owes one billion dollars, Russia 500 million dollars while 50 other countries, mostly from Africa owe the remainder of the arrears.

PRAIA, Cape Verde - Cholera claims 245 lives on the islands of Cape Verde since an outbreak was declared 11 months ago, the country's Ministry of Health says. Of the 797 cases recorded in October, 336 were recorded on the northern island of Sao Vicente.

OCTOBER 26

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Zambian government denies media claims that it planned to deport Labour Minister Newstead Zimba and several other prominent politicians to Malawi.

Zambia's Home Affairs Permanent Secretary Kalombo Mwansa and the State House Special Press Assistant Richard Sakala dismisses press speculation that the minister is on a government list of potential deportees.

OCTOBER 30

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania - Tanzania's National Electoral Commission cancels presidential and general elections held October 29 in Dar es Salaam after they are marred by logistical problems and reports of attempted rigging.

Commission Chairman Justice Lewis Makame, who announced the nullification, says that the 700,000 voters in the city will vote again next week on a date to be annouced.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - A 41-year-old man whose actions were described by a Harare regional magistrate as "animal-like and socially sickening" is sentenced to an effective 20 years in jail for raping his daughter, almost on a daily basis, between 1991 and October 1994.

In a blistering judgement before sentencing the man, regional magistrate Jacqueline Pratt says society should strongly deplore fathers who turned their own daughters into their wives.

UNITED NATIONS - Ghana, Guinea and Nigeria say they are willing to send additional troops to the ECOWAS peace monitoring group in Liberia, the United Nations reports.

In its latest report, the U.N. pledges to help raise the African peacekeeping troop strength from its 7,269 to 12,000. This would enable the force, known as ECOMOG, to carry out their duties under the Abuja Peace Accord reached August.

According to the report by Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali Nigeria, which has 6,000 soldiers in Liberia, will provide two additional battalions. Ghana and Guinea would provide one battalion each.

OCTOBER 31, 1995

PORT HARCOURT, Nigeria - Nigerian novelist and human rights campaigner Ken Saro-Wiwa is sentenced to death for the murder of four of his kinsmen in May. Saro-Wiwa, 54, is the winner of two international environment and literature awards.

Three other members of the Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People, or MOSOP, to which he belongs are also sentenced to die. A fifth accused was set free.

This brings to nine the number of MOSOP members condemned to death within two days. The first five were sentenced by a tribunal October 30.

Summary of African Events for November 1995

NOVEMBER 2

LUSAKA, Zambia - Bending to opposition demands, the Zambian government postpones local government elections originally set for 30 November to facilitate the updating of voters' registers.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The World Bank suspends balance-of-payments support to Zimbabwe until the country reaches an agreement on the pace and direction of its economic reforms with the IMF.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Vote-counting in South Africa's first multiparty local government elections in starts in earnest Thursday morning.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Lediem Mitee, one of the Ogoni leaders freed by the Nigerian tribunal which sentenced to death nine others for murder appeals to the military government to spare their lives.

NOVEMBER 3

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Three pedestrians are shot dead in Harare Friday by a policeman chasing two suspected car thieves. .

HARARE, Zimbabwe - A senior United Nations officer says Friday individual armed bandits were responsible for the sporadic cease-fire violations in Angola which is recovering from a bitter civil war.

DAKAR, Senegal - UNESCO Director General Federico Mayor promises to ask the International Telecommunications Union to examine possibilities of taking legal action to end the broadcasts of a pirate radio station fanning ethnic hatred in Burundi.

NOVEMBER 6

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina - Eight leaders arrive in Buenos Aires, Argentina, to attend the fifth group of 15 developing countries summit which started Sunday and ends Tuesday.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Southern Africa pledge to take a hard line against drug trafficking in sub-region.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) opens a sub-regional office for Southern and Eastern Africa in Harare as part of the organisation's restructuring and decentralisation programme.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - OAU Sceretary General Salim Ahmed Salim strongly condemns Sunday's assassination of the Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.

LIVINGSTONE, Zambia - Five people suspected of involvement in the ritual murder of six children appear in a magistrate's court in Livingstone, southern Zambia.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - OAU Secretary General Salim Ahmed Salim Monday urges the management of the Pan-African News Agency (PANA) to make its news cast available to as many member states as possible.

PARIS, France - UNESCO, the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organisation says it has scrapped some 871 posts in 10 years bringing its current staff strength to 2,188, according to the U.N agency's Director-General Federico Mayor.

NOVEMBER 7

HARARE, Zimbabwe - A regional draft protocol on combating illicit drug trafficking in the Southern African Development Community (SADC) region is adopted by senior SADC and European Union (EU) officials.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Heavy rains in the urban centre of Muyinga, in northeastern Burundi, on Sunday leave nine dead and 33 wounded and many fanmilies homeless.

NDJAMENA, Chad - Chadian president Idriss Deby leaves Ndjamena Tuesday morning for Libreville, Gabon for talks with President Omar Bongo on the proposed talks of Chad's political leaders.

PARIS, France - Liberia's Minister of Education Moses Bah in Paris appeals for international support for the ongoing peace process in his country. #BAMAKO, Mali - The International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) gives Mali a loan of 15 million dollars under an agreement signed in Bamako.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria's Obafemi Awolowo University, at Ile Ife in the west, is closed following student protests Monday over the reported mass failure in examinations.

ABIDJAN, Cote d'Ivoire - President Henri Konan Bedie of Cote D'Ivoire commends his country's opposition for finally accepting to participate in parliamentary elections on November 26 and the December 17 municipal polls.

NOVEMBER 8

LAGOS, Nigeria - The World soccer governing body, FIFA, says it is considering Nigeria to host the 1997 under-20 world soccer tournament, according to a statement by its president, Joao Havelange in Lagos.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - All security personnel protecting President Nelson Mandela, his two deputy presidents and Inkatha Freedom Party leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi are placed on maximum alert following assassination of Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa - The South African National Defence Force, for the first time, has a black majority.

ACCRA, Ghana - India's prime minister P.V. Narasimha Rao arrives in Accra on Wednesday on a two-day official visit. He is the first Indian leader to visit Ghana.

KHARTOUM, Sudan - Sudan Head of State Omar Al-Bashir declares a general mobilisation of his militia to deter what he says is an anticipated rebel attack in the country's east Equatoria State.

NOVEMBER 10

LAGOS, Nigeria - Convicted Nigerian writer and minority rights campaigner Kenule Saro-Wiwa is hanged together with eight of his Ogoni kinsmen, prison and security officials tell journalists.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand - The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) opens in Auckland's Aotea Conference Centre Friday morning with leaders underlining the need for the 52-member body to reaffirm the 1991 Harare (Zimbabwe) declaration that emphasised democratic governance.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - Mozambican Prime Minister Pascoal Mocumbi is in Johannesburg for a meeting with the leader of South Africa's far-right 'Freedom Front', Gen. Constand Viljoen, concerning an agreement under which South African farmers are to invest in Mozambique.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand - An overwhelming majority of leaders attending the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) condemn continued nuclear weapons testing and called for an immediate end to such programmes as well as elimination of nuclear weapons.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian villagers in the eastern Katete District are reported to be scavenging food in neighbouring Mozambique in because of shortages at home.

COTONOU, Benin - Algerian Islamic fundamentalists reportedly threaten to disrupt the 6th Francophone summit due to take place in Benin December 2 to 4 , police sources say without elaborating.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - A senior official of the Organisation of African Unity describes as timely, the establishment of the peacekeeping section of the Zimbabwe army.

ADDIS ABABA, Addis Ababa - The Organization of African Unity (OAU) says its 50 election observers are leave Saturady for Algeria to monitor the north Africa's multiparty polls.

NOVEMBER 13

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigeria recalls its envoys in the United States, South Africa and 15 European union member-countries in retaliation for the countries' recall of their own diplomats from Lagos.

LUSAKA, Zambia - The Nigerian high commission in Lusaka Monday defends last week's executions of prominent human rights activist Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight others, saying the sentence had been sanctioned by a legal court after the condemned men had been convicted for murder.

KADUNA, Nigeria - At least 30 people are burnt to death when a Nigeria Airways Boeing 737 crashed in the country's northern city of Kaduna.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - An OAU mission, led by William Eteki Mboumoua, former OAU secretary-general, is in the Comoros to help in efforts to defuse the current political crisis in the country and facilitate the process of democracy and national reconciliation.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - The South African and Zimbabwe governments fail to reach an agreement on the reinstatement of preferential tariffs for Zimbabwean exports of textiles and clothing to South Africa. #

NOVEMBER 14

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - A South Africa-Nigeria support group is formed amid growing calls for pressure against the Nigerian military government following the hanging of nine Ogoni rights campaigners.

DAKAR, Senegal - A mediation summit to find a durable solution to the crises in Burundi and Rwanda takes place in Cairo on November 27, PANA learns.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian Works and Housing Minister Abdulkarim Adisa urged citizens Tuesday to be united against what he call"unjust" international sanctions against the country

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa - The new Coca-Cola bottling group established in South Africa announces plans to spend at least 150 million dollars in Africa during the next two years.

UNITED NATIONS - Nigerian diplomats at the United Nations continue diplomatic moves to counter an United States-led campaign for UN sanctions against the West African country for Friday's execution of nine Ogoni activists for murder.

PARIS, France - The UNESCO General Conference in Paris "vigorously protests against the execution of the (Nigerian) writer Ken Saro-Wiwa and his eight fellow defendants"

NOVEMBER 15

ASABA, Nigeria (PANA) - Hundreds of Nigerians in Asaba in the mid-west stage a protest march against the suspension of their country from the Commonwealth.

COTONOU, Benin - A rocket fired Tuesday by unidentified persons punches a 30 centimetre-diametre hole through the walls of a conferene centre in Cotonou, Benin, venue of a summit for the world's French-speaking nations.

DAR ES SALAAM - Tanzania demands a public apology from the Sudanese government over recent allegations that troops from Dar es Salaam were assisting the southern rebel Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA).

NOVEMBER 16

COTONOU, Benin - A hitherto unknown armed group claims it launched Tuesday's mortar attack against the conference centre in Benin's capital, venue of the December 2 to 4 Francophone summit.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Nigerian military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha has describes the international condemnations and sanctions against his regime as "most unfortunate and uncalled for."

KUALA LUMPAR, Malaysia - Zimbabwe's state-owned Industrial Development Corporation (IDC) signs a Zimdollars 14.4 billion (USD 1.6 billion) joint venture agreement with a Malaysian company for the establishment of Zimbabwe's first industrial park, about 15 kilometres east of Harare.

NOVEMBER 17

ACCRA, Ghana - Former United States President Jimmy Carter arrives in Accra Friday on the first leg of an eight-nation African tour.

LONDON - A group of British businessmen in London forms an association by the name "Understanding Nigeria" with the aim of forging positive international image for the West African country.

It chairman, John Parker, says Friday that the group is"appalled by the unbalanced presentation of events in Nigeria."

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Burundian President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya starts an official visit in neighbouring Uganda

NOVEMBER 20

DAKAR, Senegal - The Organisation of African commends the way Algeria's
November 16 presidential elections were conducted.

MAPUTO, Mozambique - Mozambican police at the border with Swaziland shoot dead a Nigerian who fails to stop his car when flagged down, Radio Mozambique reports.

DAKAR, Senegal - Organization of African Unity Secretary General Salim Ahmed Salim calls for the employment of more women in African industry, in a statement to mark Africa Industrialization Day.on.

KIGALI, Rwanda - Still shattered by the sight of skulls of massacre victims in a Rwandan church, former U.S. President Jimmy Carter expresses hope that forthcoming talks in Cairo will bring lasting peace to the region. #

NOVEMBER 21

BUJUMBURA, Burundi - Former United States President Jimmy Carter leaves Bujumbura for Zaire without guarantees concerning the Burundi government's participation at a summit in Cairo, Egypt, to discuss an end to the ethnic conflicts in that country and in Rwanda.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Thousands of placard-carrying people take part Tuesday in a rally, which organisers say is in solidarity with the Nigerian government after its suspension from the 53-nation Commonwealth following the November 10 executions of nine Ogoni ethnic minority leaders.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Zambia's President Frederick Chiluba makes a brief stopover in Harare and holds talks with President Robert Mugabe to review decisions reached at the just-ended Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting in New Zealand.

COTONOU, Benin - A soldier is killed and several others arrested during the night as security forces closed in on those believed responsible for a recent rocket attack on the Cotonou conference centre, venue of the sixth Francophone summit to be held December 2 to 4.

PRETORIA, Soith Africa - South African authorities say a Southern African summit, to consider possible action against the Nigerian military after the recent hanging of nine minority activists, could be held soon.

NOVEMBER 22

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania - Tanzanian outgoing President Ali Hassan Mwinyi bids farewell Wednesday to his compatriots at a grand ceremony held in Dar Es Salaam a day before the installation of his successor, Benjamin William Mkapa, 57.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - Three men believed to be members of an international drug ring appear before a Harare magistrate to answer charges of smuggling canabis worth at least six million Zimbabwe dollars (667,000 U.S. dollars).

NOUAKCHOTT, Mauritania - Mauritania qualifies for the semi-finals of the Amilcar Cabral soccer tournament after beating Mali 3-1 in the third round match of Group A.

NOVEMBER 26

LIBREVILLE, Gabon - The European Union (EU) grants Gabon eight billion CFA francs (about 16 million US dollars) to finance rehabilitation of certain regional hospitals in the central African country.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambian civil society organisations, which have been agitating for a national constituent assembly to adopt the country's draft constitution, meet in Lusaka for a two-day conference to further press government to yield to their demands of having the document adopted by a Constituent Assembly.

BEITBRIDGE, Zimbabwe - Presidents Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and Nelson Mandela of South Africa calle for closer economic ties between their countries, saying they needed each other for economic advancement.

Officially commissioning the 50-million-Zimbabwe dollar (5.6 million U.S. dollars) Limpopo River Bridge, linking the two countries, they noted that their countries were the two largesttrading partners in Southern Africa.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Senegal's Foreign Minister Moustapha Niasse delivers a special message from President Abdou Diouf to Nigerian leader Sani Abacha, the foreign ministry said in Abuja.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania - Tanzanian opposition parliamentarians Friday obliged the newly elected Speaker, Pius Msekwa, to take three oaths over legal technicalities.

NOVEMBER 27

ACCRA, Ghana - United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali prepares to discuss with President Jerry Rawlings on a wide range of topics especially on progress in Liberia's transition from war to a peaceful democracy.

HARARE, Zimbabwe - An independent Zimbabwean politician, Margaret Dongo, wins the by-election in Harare South constituency, beating Vivian Mwashita, the candidate of President Robert Mugabe's ruling Zimbabwe African National Union (ZANU-PF).

MAASTRICHT, Netherlands - Several world statesmen Monday gathered in the southern Dutch city of Maastricht to review political and economic issues under the Global Coalition for Africa (GCA).

KHARTOUM, Sudan - A Khartoum daily announces that two men convicted for armed robbery in the western Sudanese province of Soderi and sentenced to death by hanging were executed on November 22.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - OAU secretary general Salim Ahmed Salim begins a three-day official visit to Italy, the continental body says in a statement.

MONROVIA, Liberia - Enviromental expertsin Monrovia try to unravel the mystery of an unexpected earth tremor that shook the Liberian capital last Friday, creating serious panic but no physical damage. #

NOVEMBER 28

KHARTOUM, Sudan (PANA) - The Sudanese government lifts its ban on food relief flights to the south where it is enagaged in a war with rebels of the Sudanese People's Liberation Army.

LAGOS, Nigeria - The number two in Nigeria's military government, Lt. Gen. Oladipo Diya, accuses South African President Nelson Mandela of constituting "a serious threat to African unity," through his unrelenting campaign for the isolation of the West African country.

LAGOS, Nigeria - Fuel queues, occasional sights in oil-rich Nigeria re-appear in Lagos despite assurances from the petroleum authorities that there is no shortage.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - Ethiopia's former military rulers deny charges of genocide and crimes against humanity which the state alleges they committed while in power.

NOVEMBER 29

ACCRA, Ghana - President Jerry Rawlings starts a two-week tour of China, Malaysia and Singapore.

COTONOU, Benin - Foreign ministers from French speaking countries start meeting to prepare an agenda for the sixth Francophone summit to be held from December 2 to 4 in Benin's economic capital.

TRIPOLI, Libya - Libya expresses displeasure at Mauritania's decision to open of diplomatic relations with Israel.

TRIPOLI, Libya - At least 18 million Egyptians elect 444 members of parliament amid opposition claims that President Hosni Mubarak's government was bent on rigging the polls.

ACCRA, Ghana - Boutros Boutros-Ghali, United Nations Secretary-General, urges the World body's affiliate agencies to eschew internal competition and rivalry and unite to tackle new challenges facing the world body.

LUSAKA, Lusaka - Zambia and Egypt announce plans to conclude agreements on a programme of cooperation in various fields including trade, industry, investment, transport and communications.

BADAGRY, Nigeria - Nigerian Customs Service officials impound a vehicle carrying some 10,000 rounds of ammunitions and pistols at Seme, near the country's border with Benin, the official News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) reports.

The Agency said the Peugeot 504 station wagon with Togolese registration number was impounded on entering Nigerian territory.

VIENNA, Austria - The Southern African Development Community (SADC) says that it will ask the Dutch government to exert pressure on the Anglo-Dutch oil giant Shell to suspend its business with the Nigerian military government.

LAGOS, Nigeria - A 50-member committee of Nigerian traditional rulers and opinion leaders is inaugurated in the capital, Abuja and given two days to submit a report to the miltiary government on how it should respond to anti-Nigeria actions by the intertnational community. #

NOVEMBER 30

COTONOU, Benin - United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghaliinaugurates at Ouidah the 'Gate of No-Return' through which thousands of West Africans passed before embarking on their trans-Atlantic route to slavery.

LOME, Togo - Togolese Prime Minister Edem Kodjo has carried out his first cabinet reshuffle since he was appointed in April 1994.

DAKAR, Senegal - Mauritanian refugees who have been living in Senegal since 1989 annaounce plans to petition the Francophone summit, starting in Cotonou Sunday, to exert pressure on Nouackchott to allow them to return home.

TRIPOLI, Libya - At least five people were killed and 60 others injured in election day violence in Egypt Wednesday, sources in the country said.

LUSAKA, Zambia - Zambia's main opposition, the United National Independence Party (UNIP) of former president Kenneth Kaunda, calls for an international commission of inquiry to probe President Frederick Chiluba's disputed citizenship.

LAGOS, Nigeria - A government circular announcing an imminent purge in Nigeria's bloated Federal Civil Service raises fears among workers as labour unions prepare to oppose the action.

PRETORIA, South Africa - A large number of Cuban doctors are to come to South Africa next year to alleviate the critical shortage of general practitioners in the country, the health ministry announces.

NAIROBI, Kenya - Three Kenyan pilots are charged with overloading aircraft and making incorrect take-off weight entries.

Summary of African Events During December 1995

DECEMBER 1

JOHANNESBURG - Almost two million South Africans are infected with the HIV virus that leads to AIDS, a dramatic increase from 5,000 in 1990, the country's health minister Nkosazana Zuma was reported as saying.

HARARE - Zimbabwean opposition politician Ndabaningi Sithole, accused of plotting to kill President Robert Mugabe, was remanded until February 17 when he appears before a Harare magistrate.

DECEMBER 5

JOHANNESBURG - United States Vice President Al Gore started an official visit to South Africa designed to boost economic and diplomatic ties between the two countries. ADDIS ABABA - Organisation of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim left Addis Ababa for a three-day visit to Nigeria to discuss the country's political problems. The visit came amidst growing international demands that Nigeria be returned to civilian rule before October 1998, the military proposed date for the transfer.

DAR ES SALAAM - Bank of Tanzania governor Idris Rashid urged a further restructuring of the National Bank of Commerce, the country's largest commercial bank, to save it from total collapse. He said the bank was broke and failure to restructure could lead to a collapse of the country's entire banking system.

DECEMBER 6

BUJUMBURA - At least 20 people were killed in ethnic clashes between Hutu militia and government forces in Bujumbura, independent sources said.

KIGALI - The Rwandan government expelled 38 humanitarian non governmental relief organisations, accusing them of interfering in the country's internal affairs and a lack of cooperation. DECEMBER 7

BENGUELA - A bomb-blast killed two quarreling passengers on a train travelling between the township of Catumbele and Negrao in southern Angola's Benguela province. The two were killed when one of them detonated a 'F-1' type grenade.

LAGOS - Nigeria's federal Accountant-General, Olusegun Olusemo, and nine others, appeared in court on a charge of trying to defraud the state of some USD 37.5 million.

DECEMBER 11

KHARTOUM - The Sudanese media reported government would deport an unspecified number of its 260,000 Ethiopian refugees for political activity threatening state security. The move was seen as retaliation for Ethiopia's earlier expulsion of Sudanese nationals. PRETORIA - Some Southern African Development Community (SADC) leaders met in Johannesburg for a one-day summit to work a response to the Nigerian regime's execution of nine minority rights activists, including the author Ken Saro-Wiwa.

DECEMBER 12

KINSHASA - Zaire's justice minister, Joseph N'Singa Udjuu, ordered the closure of all brothels in the country. He said in a circular the brothels had become a public nuisance in especially Kinshasa, the capital.

WINDHOEK - The second conference of "sister" parties in Southern Africa ended in the Namibian capital Tuesday with a communique urging more respect for former heads of state and other political leaders. The call was prompted by reports from the United National Independence Party of former Zambian president Kenneth Kaunda to the conference hosted by Namibia's ruling SWAPO.

DECEMBER 13

YAOUNDE - Cameroon's commission of inquiry into the crash of a Boeing 737 December 3 began as investigators continued to dig into the twisted metal of the jetliner in which 73 people died. LAGOS - Nigerian Military ruler Gen. Sani Abacha swore in a 13-member commission to supervise the country's transition to civilian rule within three years. TRIPOLI - Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko left Tripoli at the end of a three-day official working visit in Libya.

NIAMEY - Once bitter enemies, Niger government officials and rebel Tuaregs from the desert in the north began a fourth round of peace talks and on the disarmaent of the rebels.

DECEMBER 14

NAIROBI, Kenya (PANA) - The Sixth African Ministerial Conference on the Environment (AMCEN) began with a call for immediate action to tackle extreme poverty which it said was a major cause of environmental degradation.

LAGOS - Nigeria's military government gave the national soccer team, the Super Eagles, the go-ahead to defend the Africa Nations Cup in South Africa in January 1996, in spite strained diplomatic ties between the two countries.

DECEMBER 15

KIGALI - Sources disclosed a former head of Rwanda's intelligence service, Colonel Theonestre Lizinde, had fled into Zaire. The immediate cause of his action was not stated.

DECEMBER 18

ADDIS ABABA - Organisation of African Unity Secretary-General Salim Ahmed Salim urged that the continental body maintain its office in Burundi when its mandate ended on December 24. BUJUMBURA - Burundi's Tutsi dominated army killed 30 Hutu rebels in fighting in the Mugwu commune some 75 kilometres northwest of Bujumbura, state radio reported.

DECEMBER 19

LUSAKA - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba warned the outspoken privately-owned newspaper, The Post, that he could ban it if it continued suggesting he was of Zairean origin.

BULAWAYO - The 12-nation Southern African Development Community's regional Food Security Early Warning Unit predicted countries in the region are likely to receive above normal rains and good crop yields in 1996 because of a positive change in climatic conditions.

DECEMBER 20

MAPUTO - The local press reported Mozambique's labour minister, Guilherme Mavila, had denied accusations in the South African media that his government and corrupt ministry officials were stealing millions of South African rands designed to compensate families of Mozambicans crippled or killed in South African mines.

HARARE - Zimbabwe could soon displace Brazil as a major supplier of flue-cured tobacco to the Far East, Zimbabwe Tobacco Association (ZTA) president Peter Richards said.

ACCRA - United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) Director-General Jaques Diouf urged improved use of modern technology to improve food security on the continent.

LUSAKA - Zambian President Frederick Chiluba was relected president of his ruling Movement for Multiparty Democracy

DECEMBER 21

LUANDA - The Angola government released 64 Unita fighters as part of an ongoing peace process in the country.

DAR ES SALAAM - It was disclosed in the Tanzanian capital Kenya and Tanzania had agreed to a resumption of a passenger railway service between them. The service came to a halt 18 years ago at the dissolution of the East Africa Community comprising the two countries and Uganda.

DECEMBER 22

Nigeria raised preliminary objections about the jurisdiction of the Industrial Court of Justice in its dispute with neighbouring Cameroon on the oil-rich Bakassi Peninsula.

DECEMBER 24

The Sudanese government announced it would hold presidential and parliamentary elections in the first half of 1966. It said the elections would be open to all eligible nationals, irrespective of their political background.

DECEMBER 25

DURBAN - Ten people were killed Christmas Day as violence erupted again in South Africa's troubled KwaZulu-Natal province. This shooting, the third in the province in 10 days, broke out when a group of men went on a rampage in the Shobashobani area of KwaZulu-Natal.

KHARTOUM - A Khartoum court sentenced 15 young men to 40 lashes each and fined them 50,000 (about 80 US dollars) Sudanese pounds apiece for drinking and disturbing the order in a Khartoum suburb.

DECEMBER 27

ADDIS ABABA - OAU Secretary General, Salim Ahmed Salim, left for Eritrea for talks with the country's leadership on the country's dispute with Yemen over of the Hanish Islands in the Red Sea.

LAGOS - The oil company Chevron Nigeria Limited announced it had started construction of Nigeria's first liquefied natural gas floating storage and offloading (FSO) facility, one of the key components of a USD 569 million joint project with the Nigerian National Petroleum.

ABIDJAN - Fourteen people were killed when a bus hit a parked trailer 50 kilometers from Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire's business capital, police reported. Twelve of the victims were killed instantly while two others died at a hospital in Abidjan.

DECEMBER 28

LAGOS, Nigeria (PANA) - Nigeria's military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, under intense international pressure for democractisation, announced the creation of a 13-member body to reconcile citizens of the country wrecked by political crisis. The is headed by businessman and former information minister Alex Akinyele.

LAGOS - Nigeria Airways said it had suffered a loss of some 14 million naira (about 165,000 U.S dollars) as a result of the British aviation authorities decision, a week before, to block the airline's Lagos-London round trip on the grounds many illegal immigrants were expected on the trip.

TRIPOLI - Libya and Niger signed an agreement to enhance their cooperation in security matters.

DECEMBER 29

LUSAKA - Zambian election officials said they would not be able to sign up the targeted four million potential voters in the countrywide registration drive which they said had been adversely affected by logistical, administrative and weather problems.

ACCRA - Ghana's Vice President Kow Nkensen Arkaah told a news conference he had been assaulted by the Head of State Jerry John Rawlings at a cabinet session Thursday. "He gave me a terrible blow on the shoulder which sent me falling to the floor. He then attempted to pull me up by the shoulder in order to hit me further; he tore the shoulder of the jacket in the process," said Arkaah.

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large South Africa Club Ready for Ivorians


LENGTH: 920 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 1, 1995
by Lungile Madywabe

Johannesburg - They've had a long, hard season and several key members of their squad are weary after representing the national team, but Orlando Pirates can rise to the occasion against Ivory Coast's Asec Mimosa

Despite the national team's recent triumph in the Four Nations tournament, there is still a belief that South African football is stronger at club level than at national level.

Consider this: we were readmitted into world soccer in 1992 and the following year Jomo Cosmos and Kaizer Chiefs represented South Africa in both Confedaration of African Football continental competitions. Chiefs failed narrowly to reach the semi-finals of the Champions Cup when they went down to Zamalek of Egypt. Cosmos were booted out of the Cup Winners Cup (Mandela Cup) semi-finals by Africa Sports of Ivory Coast. But it was their dismal performance on the domestic scene which hampered their progress to the final -- they had to sacrifice reaching the finals and try to save themselves from being relegated. But it is history now that they were relegated at the end of that season. 

Sundowns, however, could not proceed further than the Champions Cup second round in 1994.

Tomorrow Orlando Pirates play Asec Mimosa of Ivory Coast in the finals of the Champions Cup. There are several similarities between the two teams. Both became league champions of their countries in 1994 after boardroom discussions. They both boast a large, fanatical following.

The major difference is that Pirates had been starved of championship honours for 19 years while their opponents have virtually monopolised the Ivory Coast league title. Champions again this year, they have won the title for the last six years. Asec boast 10 internationals while Pirates have six.

John Zaki, who played alongside Daniel Amokachi, Rashid Yekini and the current African footballer of the year Emmanuel Amunike in the 1994 World Cup in the United States, is one of the stars at the disposal of coach Zare Mamadou.

Pirates have lost only once away from home in this competition when they went down 2-1 in Gabon against Mbilinga.

Asec also boast a remarkable away record: they lost once to Ismailia of Egypt in the semi- finals. This tells more about the style of play of both these teams, and Mamadou sums it up well when he says: "We have not come here to defend but to try and win, and our away record says more about us. But we also know that Pirates have not lost a game at home."

Will they be the first to dent the Buccaneers' impeccable home record in the face of vociferous support from the Pirates fans? Mamadou, backed by Nigerian under 23 international midfielder Akeem Ogulande, said: "There are 22 players on the pitch and they are the people who influence the proceedings. Those in the stands can shout but they will remain where they are."

But they have their fears of the Pirates danger men: left back Edward Motale, the dazzling Brendon Silent and John Moeti.

Tsotetsi Phiri and Helman Mkhelele will be closely watched by the Ivorians. "They are quick on the ball and if you don't close them down they can be dangerous,"said Mamadou.

But Pirates have their own worries. Mkhelele, Moeti and Mark Fish all had a tough week representing the national team in the Four Nations matches and it is hoped they have not run out of energy after all the tough matches they have played this year.

Fish may not be match-fit following a knock he received on his knee during the Zimbabwe game. Pirates coach Joe Frickleton was a bit hesitant about who is available for the match, saying: "I will see how they respond to training."Pirates go into Saturday's game knowing very well that they will have to beat the Ivorians convincingly at home if they hope to lift the title at their first attempt.

But the Asec team will be hoping that their opponents, backed by a home crowd, are not at the full strength which saw them reach the finals.

Asec have failed four times before to reach the final and having reached the final after so many tries they feel that they are destined to be champions at last. "We have been victims of bad refereeing for many years now that we have finally made it we hope to win, but if we lose it's all in the game," said Mamadou.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
