Africa News


December, 1995


Comores and South Africa Political Turmoil Continues in Holiday Isles


LENGTH: 467 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995

Johannesburg - Although the Comoros Islands have reopened for South African holiday-makers in the wake of Bob Denard's abortive coup in October, the "Perfume Isles" are still being battered by other political storms.

Political leaders on Moheli Island, one of the largest in the Comoros complex, last weekend announced they no longer recognise two "governments" that are currently fighting to rule the archipelago in the wake of Denard's putsch.

The Indian Ocean Newsletter reports from Paris that an interim administration set up by Prime Minister Mohamed Caabi El Yachroutu after the coup is now being challenged by a "counter- administration" set up with Said Ali Mohamed as a rival prime minister. 

The Moheli islanders, disgruntled with the state of confusion, are reported to have called for a campaign of civil disobedience, chased the Moroni-appointed governor off the isle, and set up a citizens' committee to run their administration.

A petition has been circulated on neighbouring Anjouan Island calling for secession from the Comoros Islands and reunion with France as an overseas territory --- as is the case with Mayotte Island.

The petition is based on a popular perception that ruling elites on the island of Grande Comoros have imposed a form of political and economic hegemony over the archipelago.

Meanwhile, the capital Moroni continues to be torn by the two rival administrations, each claiming to be legal.

Government rivals "obeyed a call from local bigwigs to organise a political meeting on November 20 calling for the El Yachroutu government to resign. The meeting scheduled in the capital's main square was banned by the government," says the latest edition of the Indian Ocean Newsletter.

The volatile political climate has raised doubts about plans to hold a presidential election on the islands in January.

World Leisure Holidays, a tour company which operates hotels in the Comoros, was unavailable for comment on whether the latest developments on the islands would affect tourists.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


109 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


South Africa Mandela Retains Taiwan Ties


LENGTH: 1507 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995
by Gaye Davis

Johannesburg - President Nelson Mandela has cited a $10- million donation from the Republic of China on Taiwan for the African National Congress' general election campaign as one reason South Africa would not break ties with the island republic in favour of diplomatic relations with mainland China.

Mandela disclosed details of the R35-million grant while responding to questions after briefing political scientists last Tuesday on the pending trial of former defence minister Magnus Malan and 10 former colleagues.

The disclosure is certain to set a cat among the pigeons in diplomatic dovecotes. Cash-rich Taiwan has been intensively lobbying for the retention of diplomatic ties with South Africa and is pumping millions into the economy: this week it finalised an agreement to spend R141- million on a vocational training centre for demobilised SANDF soldiers. 

Big business, however, sees recognition of China --- with its 1,2-billion people and fast-growing economy --- as essential despite its atrocious human rights record. As China refuses to recognise Taiwan, this would mean South Africa having to downgrade its links with Taiwan and face possible economic consequences.

But the disclosure has also deepened concerns about South Africa's foreign policy-making, currently under heightened scrutiny after its failure in Nigeria.

Mandela told the gathering the money was given as "a donation and not a bribe" after he requested assistance and that the ANC would not repay a friend's favours by "stabbing them in the back".

Rumours that Mandela had secured the funds surfaced when he visited Taipei in July 1993. A joint statement by the ANC and the Taiwanese government at the time denied any such request had been made. This week the Taiwanese ambassador to South Africa, I-Cheng Loh, was still insisting no donation had been made.

But presidential spokesman Parks Mankahlana confirmed the grant, saying the amount was a "one-off" --- and added that the Taiwanese government was providing "assistance" to various sections of the ANC and was "fully sponsoring" an ANC Youth League bursary programme.

"There are reasons to be friends with Taiwan, but this aid would not influence our foreign policy decisions," Mankahlana said.

Democratic Party leader Tony Leon would not agree. He said this week he had learned while visiting Taiwan in December 1994 that Mandela's request for funds, made directly to Taiwanese president Lee Teng Hui, had been granted "within minutes".

"Our whole foreign policy is based on the electoral debts of the ANC," Leon said. "When the ANC is short of cash it runs off to the Gulf states or to Morocco for help. There is a porous wall between party and state in this regard.

"There is something wrong and imminently corruptible about governments donating funds to political parties. In our view, our foreign policy is largely available for hire.

"If you make a substantial donation to the ANC you get special foreign policy considerations --- whether or not these are in our country's best interests or in keeping with the international posture South Africa is trying to keep.

"It is flawed, short-sighted and should be corrected by legislation." Leon said if the issue was not addressed by Parliament's ethics committee --- currently focusing on the extent to which members should be required to disclose their financial interests --- the DP would consider bringing private members' legislation "on the question of foreign governments and political parties donating money to South African political parties".

Mankahlana said: "We are writing a new constitution and will look at all these questions. The situation is not helped by people jumping up and down making noises intended to score cheap political points."

Dr Sara Pienaar, national director of the Institute for International Affairs, said: "Quite obviously Taiwan was buying favours for the future --- and it does look from the Taiwanese point of view as if it has worked. It is not a very healthy phenomenon. Foreign governments should not be funding our political parties --- but circumstances last year were very peculiar."

The ANC had an election campaign to fight and its old friends were not in a position to help, Pienaar said. "But there should be a policy that political parties do not receive any funds from any foreign government and that if any grants are received, they should be made public."

Mandela would be able to wield "considerable influence" over any foreign policy matter, Pienaar said. "There is no doubt that important foreign policy decisions in this country are made by the president himself."

While Taiwan's past human rights record is not spotless, it has spent the past 10 years democratising. Mandela told the political scientists it had done nothing to deserve de- recognition: it was simply that China desired this. South Africa saw the issue as a domestic Chinese problem. It wanted to recognise both Chinas and had told the People's Republic of China so.

But the funding raises inevitable questions about the ANC's links with other countries. In its pre-election foreign policy manifesto, the organisation committed itself to "canonise human rights" in its foreign relations.

In May, after he had come under fire for twice visiting Indonesia --- internationally condemned and shunned by the ANC for years for its brutal occupation of East Timor --- Mandela revealed the ANC had received substantial donations from that country.

Strong rumours have been circulating about whether Moroccan funds for the ANC have anything to do with South Africa failing to carry out its promise of diplomatic recognition for Africa's last colony --- the Polisario-led Saharawi Republic, struggling for independence from Moroccan control. Questions have also been asked about whether South Africa's disastrous softly-softly approach towards Nigeria was not perhaps founded in financial backing the ANC received from previous rulers of the oil-rich country.

Foreign affairs ministry spokesman Pieter Swanepoel said any decision on the two Chinas would be made by Parliament. "It will be a political decision, up to the political parties to decide," he said. "Foreign Affairs will have to execute it."

ANC MP Raymond Suttner, chair of Parliament's Foreign Affairs Portfolio Committee, said he had no personal knowledge of any donations to the ANC. The question of recognising China was "under discussion in ANC ranks and has still to be decided by the collective leadership", he said.

Said Leon: "I'm not saying the Taiwanese have no case. But in my view the continued diplomatic recognition of the ROC is based not on the merits but the fact that they paid off the ANC. The DP had yet to formulate a position on the question of the two Chinas, he said.

ANC representative Ronnie Mamoepa this week failed to respond to a Mail & Guardian request that the ANC provide information about donations it had received from foreign governments. ANC secretary-general Cyril Ramaphosa, contacted for comment, said: "We have received donations from a number of countries, but I do not have the details at hand."


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

December, 1995


Somalia Supplies Airlifted to Mogadishu


LENGTH: 227 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 8, 1995
by APS Correspondent

Nairobi - The Lutheran World Federation (LWF) is funding nearly 30 flights which will airlift nearly 600 tonnes of virtually needed supplies into the Somali capital, Mogadishu, and the southern port city of Kisimayu. The flights started on November 5. 

This is the second time in six months that the LWF has come to the rescue of vulnerable children and mothers in Somalia "which is immensely appreciated by UNICEF-Somalia."

The vital supplies comprise food, health, education, sanitation and fuel. The whole operation is organised by the Nairobi office of United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF)-Somalia.

UNICEF-Somalia's Information Officer Ms Lynn Geldoff said the cost of the airlift operation by LWF would be nearly US$500,000 which is immensely appreciated by UNICEF-Somalia."

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


111 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria and South Africa Archbishop Tutu Demands Sanctions


LENGTH: 867 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 8, 1995
by APS Correspondent

London - Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu has called for sanctions against Nigeria in the wake of the November 10 execution of Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other activists from the Ogoni minority last month.

Speaking here on before attending the official memorial tribute in London to the writer and human rights campaigner and eight other Ogoni activists hanged by General Sani Abacha's military junta, Archbishop Tutu called for an oil embargo against Nigeria and for the accounts of the military rulers to be closed.

"Apartheid was brought down to its knees by the support for sanctions. Therefore we could call on the international community to continue that good work," declared Tutu, the Nobel Peace Prize winner. 

Tutu also gave support to an international boycott of Shell Oil Company, saying he believed that Shell should be encouraged to bring pressure on General Abacha's government by pulling out of gas projects there.

"But if they refused, then yes. I would myself be inclined to call for a boycott of Shell worldwide," Tutu said.

Tutu, who is also president of the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) and a close friend of South African President Nelson Mandela, said Mandela's initial "softly, softly" approach towards Nigeria was hardening, and warned; "He has got the bit between his teeth".

Tutu said he also hoped the British government would eventually impose sanctions, adding: "I hope that John Major (British Prime Minister) will take a moral stand."

Tutu was supported by former Anglican peace envoy and hostage in Lebanon Terry Waite, who said he had seen the effectiveness of sanctions in South Africa and insisted that ordinary people would be behind them.

Waite also spoke about the fate of Saro-Wiwa before he attended the tribute evening, saying; "I myself have lived under a death sentence and I know there are many people in Nigeria now who are living under that threat."

Saro-Wiwa's brother, Owen Wiwa, 39, who demonstrated last week outside Shell's London offices, also addressed the audience of 900 sympathisers who attended Sunday's memorial performance at the Theatre Royal in Haymarket, speaking of the "insensitivity" of Shell and the worsening conditions for the Ogoni people.

"My mother-in-law was arrested for wearing black to mourn her own son. Ken's death devastated our people and we are not allowed to mourn," Owen said.

Tutu's call came only a day before Mandela renewed his call for sanctions against Nigeria to be intensified during a meeting in Johannesburg with Commonwealth Secretary-General Chief Emeka Anyaoku, himself a Nigerian.

"The lack of response (to calls for Nigeria to restore democracy) means that we should intensify demands for the application of sanctions, especially oil sanctions, against Nigeria," Mandela said after talks with Anyaoku. Their meeting followed the November Commonwealth Heads of Government Summit in Auckland last month at which Nigeria was suspended from the world body following the executions.

The talks came ahead of the third meeting on December 20 and 21 of the Commonwealth's eight-nation sub- committee on Nigeria comprising eight foreign ministers, including South Africa's Alfred Nzo. The meeting would map out further action against Nigeria if it failed to embark on political and human rights reforms.

The talks also came as the European Union foreign ministers were agreeing to place a sports boycott on Nigeria and to withdraw all military attaches from the country in a bid to step up pressure on the regime over its human rights record.

The move, announced by German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel, followed last month's agreement to impose an embargo on arms sales to Nigeria and a ban on issuing of visas for members of the junta. They also decided to withdraw visas issued before last month's ban.

Officials said the sports boycott was principally aimed at persuading the world governing body, Federation of International Football Associations (FIFA), not to award Nigeria the 1996 World Youth Championships.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


112 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Ghana Christians and Muslims Clash in Kumasi


LENGTH: 507 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 8, 1995

Accra - At least eight people were injured in clashes between Muslims and Christians in Ghana's second city, police on the scene said on December 1.

The incident, which took place on November 29 in Kumasi, 200 kilometres northwest of the capital, Accra, was sparked off when Muslim youths destroyed speakers and other sound equipment used by Christian evangelists, the police said.

Despite warning shots fired by police, the clash escalated after Christians responded by destroying stalls owned by Muslim traders at the city's market and several people were injured when missiles were thrown by the two warring groups. 

"We are on full alert, but tension is still latent," a policeman reached by telephone in Kumasi said.

Tension between Muslims and Christians in Ghana has been running high this year, largely as a result of the zeal of those newly converted from one faith to the other.

However, it was the second time violent clashes have erupted between Muslims and Christians in Kumasi this year, the first having occurred on February 23, during which at least eight people were arrested.

The earlier clashes, which were reported in the February 28 edition of the government-owned Daily Graphic, had said that the violence broke out when Muslim radicals in the mainly Muslim community of Old Suame stormed a Methodist church.

According to the paper, about 50 people armed with sticks and stones had attacked the church and beat up members of the congregation, after alleging that a guest preacher had insulted the Muslim Holy Book, the Koran.

The attackers then went on to destroy musical instruments and electrical appliances in the church and threatened to burn down the building.

The attack had followed other religious clashes in the town of Wenchi, 310 kilometres northwest of Accra on the evening of February 7 in which several people were injured.

The February 7 clashes involved orthodox and reformist Muslims arguing about religious practices.

Ghana's population of some 15 million people comprises 50 per cent Christians, 35 per cent traditionalists, 10 per cent Muslims, while the remaining five per cent practise other beliefs.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


113 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Rwanda UN Troops Ordered To Leave


LENGTH: 1920 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 4, 1995

Nairobi - Rwanda has ordered UN peacekeeping troops stationed in the country to leave the central African country or face expulsion by the local population, Rwandan President Pasteur Bizimungu announced on November 27.

In an interview with the Ethiopian daily, Herald, during a stopover in the capital Addis Ababa en route to a five-nation international summit on the Rwandan refugee crisis and the ethnic strife threatening the Great Lakes region, which includes Rwanda, Burundi, Zaire and Uganda, Bizimungu said that UN troops and military observers who do not leave the country would be considered an "occupation force."

"The Rwandan government is perfectly capable of ensuring the country's internal security and safeguarding its sovereignty without an outside military presence," Bizimungu was quoted as saying.

In New York, a source said the UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros- Ghali was preparing to recommend a phased withdrawal of the last 2,000 peacekeepers from the central African country, following the request of the Rwandan government. UNAMIR's mandate is due to lapse on , and by the time of going to press officials had not asked for it to be renewed. 

UN sources say Boutros-Ghali will ask the Security Council to approve a phased pullout of the last remaining 2,000 peacekeepers in the force, which numbered 5,500 troops at one point. Some diplomats said, however, that some council members favoured keeping troops in the country-engulfed by the ethnic bloodbath between Hutus and Tutsis last year during which Hutu extremists killed between 500,000 and one million people, most of them Tutsis and moderate Hutus - so long as the massive refugee problem, among others, remained unresolved.

The secretariat studied in recent weeks whether a continued military presence in Rwanda might be negotiated with local authorities. The central government, however, made known on November 24, through Foreign Minister Anastase Gasana, that it wanted UNAMIR forces to leave. Western sources also fear that UNAMIR pullout will create difficulties for other agencies, notably those involved in monitoring human rights in the country.

The move by the Rwandan government to force out UN peacekeepers comes as an international war crimes tribunal began work on November 27 in the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha. Court clerk Andronico Adede said by telephone from Arusha, where the tribunal sits, that South African judge Navanethem Pillay had arrived and begun studying the first indictment.

It was prepared by tribunal's prosecutor, South African judge Richard Goldstone, who said the previous week he would announce on December 12 the names of those singled out in the first indictment, and that the first trial could begin up to eight weeks afterwards.

The tribunal was created by the UN Security Council in November 1994 to try people accused of war crimes during the ethnic bloodbath that engulfed Rwanda in 1994, following the shooting down on April 6 of a plane carrying Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana and Burundian President Cyprien Ntaryamira, both Hutus who died in the resulting crash.

Goldstone, said he signed "one indictment for a number of accused suspects," but the indictment must still be confirmed by a tribunal judge. The Rwandan government has drawn up a list of 463 genocide suspects.

The tribunal clerk Andronico Adede told a press conference held jointly with Goldstone that the tribunal would effectively begin work in Arusha on . The first of the tribunal judges will arrive in Arusha at the weekend.

Goldstone met Rwandan judicial authorities on November 24 after visiting the Zambian capital, Lusaka, to examine the case of 18 Rwandan genocide suspects being held there. The tribunal may yet charge six of them, whom he has asked the Zambians to hold. Belgium has arrested six suspected organisers of the massacre, Canada two and Switzerland one, and many more are being hunted in various countries.

In a separate development, former Rwandan premier Faustin Twagiramungu charged in a communique obtained late November in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, that the Rwandese Patriotic Front (RPF) army had "massacred more than 250,000 people" in a second wave of genocide.

Twagiramungu, a moderate Hutu who left the government in August, had earlier claimed in a Canadian newspaper that the Hutus died in "revenge killings" by the RFP and that in 16 months, it had "done worse than the assassinated president Juvenal Habyariamana did in 20 years of power. As for massacres of more than 250,000 people, we have irrefutable proof backing up our claims, and challenge anyone who claims the contrary to agree to an independent international inquiry to be launched into these crimes," said the former premier.

Calling on the international community to stop all aid "which supports the Rwandan government in its criminal work," Twagiramungu said the crimes committed in the Habyarimana regime, the massacres and genocide which he prepared, no matter how monstrous they were, can in no way justify or excuse those attributed to the RPF."

In the Kenyan capital, dozens of Rwandans were arrested in the last week of November and between 25 and 100 were still being held in police stations by November 28, an official of the main Hutu refugee organisation said.

@t least 3,000 Rwandans, mostly Hutus, fled their country to Kenya since rebels of a Tutsi-led front seized power after a bloody civil war last year, ousting a Hutu regime and troops and militias accused of genocide against minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus.

The Kenyan government said in a statement that 'although some bona fide refugees have conducted themselves well, it has now become quite clear that there are a number of foreigners who pose as 'refugees' with neither proper documentation nor being in recognised refugee camps."

The government installed in Kigali by the former rebels accuses Kenya of harbouring several leaders of the genocide. These are believed to include Habyarimana's widow and family, as well as Felicien Kabuga, the former financial backer of the Radio Milles Collines, the radio said to have urged Hutu extremists to exterminate Tutsis.

Kenyan opposition leader Kenneth Matiba told journalists on November 29 that Madame Habyarimana had left the country three weeks earlier for Zaire to check certain discussion her late husband held with authorities in Zaire, but she would return. Matiba, leader of the opposition Forum for the Restoration of Democracy Asili (Original - FORD-A) party, said he was taking care of the family of Habyarimana, a personal friend and would do so "for ever if needs arose".

The international community was currently also making frantic efforts to help find a solution to the long-standing ethnic conflict in the Great Lakes region of central Africa. In a five-nation summit convened in the Egyptian capital since November 28, by former US president Jimmy Carter, African leaders vowed to tackle the Rwandan refugee crisis on the ethnic strife threatening the Great Lakes region of Burundi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire.

"Everyone agrees that hundreds of thousands of refugees should come back home and to reconciliation with their neighbours," the former US president who is also chairman of the summit, said in his opening address.

"Cross-border raids should stop, smuggling arms to small groups should stop and committing genocides should stop. Reconciliation should prevail," Carter added.

The former US president expressed his hope of repeating with the African countries the success of the Egypt-Israeli Camp David accords which he presided over in 1979.

Rwandan President Pasteur Bizimungu recalled that it was "not the first time that Rwanda had a problem of refugees. It has existed since 1959 and has been an influence on neighbouring countries.

"In 1990 there were almost two million refugees outside the country, and my government is committed to helping all refugees to come back under equal conditions," despite the barring of some of the two million ethnic Hutu refugees living in Zaire and the UN High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) from attending the Cairo summit.

Among those present as mediators were South African Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu and former Tanzanian President Julius Nyerere.

Tutu told the summit that he had "never been so proud to be African as I am this time because the initiative for this meeting is an African initiative. The Heads of State have shown by their presence here their commitment to reach an African solution for African problems," Tutu who is the president of the Nairobi-based All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) said.

Zairean president Mobutu vowed to "work to make this conference a success for the world community watching us. My presence here shows that we are going to find solutions to all these problems<' Mobutu pledged.

Tanzania, which held general elections last month is represented at the summit by the outgoing State Minister for Defence Abdel Rahman Kinana.

More than a million Rwandans fled the small central African nation last year during an after the bloody civil war. Extremist Hutus are accused of the genocide and of causing unrest in exile and intimidating their mainly Hutu fellow-refugees into not returning to Rwanda.

The Zairean government has announced plans to make all Rwandans living in the Lake Goma border region return home by the end of the year, but Mobutu said in Cairo that he opposed the use of force.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


114 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Kenya Opposition Parties Launch Alliance


LENGTH: 280 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 4, 1995

Nairobi - Kenya's opposition Members of Parliament on November 30 launched a new initiative, The Opposition Alliance, whose main purpose is to field a single presidential contender to facePresident Daniel arap Moi in the next general elections in 1997.

The idea of an alliance has been discussed since the contentious multiparty elections of 1992 but has often beem met with varied disagreements from leaders of the main opposition parties in Kenya namely the Democratic Party (DP), Forum for the Restoration of Democracy-Kenya (FORD-K), FORD-Asili (Original) and other smaller ones. 

The announcement of the opposition alliance presents a reckoning force for President Moi's ruling Kenya African National Union (KANU) party.

In the 1992 presidential poll, Moi received 1,820,872 votes against a combined opposition total of 3,439,967 votes. KANU won a larger number of seats in parliament - 100 compared to 88 for the opposition. At least 12 MPs from the opposition later defected to KANU.

Underscoring, the imperative for unity during the launching of the alliance, MP James Orengo, the Vice Chairman of Ford-Kenya said the lessons of the 1992 debacle should have been learnt by now.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


115 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Sudan and South Africa Catholic Body Probing Arms Deal


LENGTH: 1054 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 4, 1995

The Hague - An international Catholic peace organisation here, has launched investigations into the alleged arms deal between the South African and Sudanese governments.

In a message to the New Sudan Council of Churches (NSCC), which serves churches in the liberated areas in southern Sudan, Mr. Jan Gruiters, Secretary for African Affairs of Pax Christi says, "our concern over the issue was as a result of a letter, written to us by the Justice and Peace department of the South African Catholic Bishops' Conference (SACBC)".

In their letter dated November 16, the Catholic bishops have expressed concern about alleged shipments of arms to conflict areas like Burundi, Rwanda and Sudan.

Mr. Gruiters, adds; "In its letter, the SACBC has referred to rumours indicating that arms were reaching these countries through third countries, possibly France and Seychelles." 

The communication between Pax Christi and the NSCC is aimed at gathering more information regarding the issue for the Catholic peace organisation to realise its investigation goal, says Gruiters in his message to NSCC.

In the message, Gruiters a renowned personality in matters concerning human rights, disarmaments and reconciliation through Pax Christi, quotes the South African Bishops saying; "In meetings with representatives of Armscor, the South African arms manufacturer stated that it cannot be expected to know if a purchasing country is not honouring the contract conditions, which would state that no South African arms may be sold to a third country."

Pax Christi, says it is concerned about the rapprochement between Sudan and South Africa as the move has political, commercial as well as military connotations.

Although the significance of this relationship should not be over- estimated the rapprochement between democratic South Africa and Sudan, notorious for its flagrant violation of human rights and on- going civil war is startling, observes Pax Christi. And adds; "This is particularly true for those Sudanese who hoped for firm South African support in their struggle for a just and lasting solution of the civil war or at least some empathy."

The Catholic peace movement also lamented its futile attempts to get information from South African embassies in both Nairobi and the Hague regarding the government's foreign policy guidelines.

Responding to Pax Christi, the NSCC in the statement signed by the organisation's Communication/Interpretation Coordinator Mr. Soforonio Efuk, states; "With this letter, we would therefore, like on behalf of the suffering population in Sudan, to draw President Mandela's attention to the consequences of South Africa's arms shipment and the presence of that country's mercenaries to the embattled Sudanese people.

"We are saddened and grieved about the rapprochement between South African companies and the hard-line Islamic government in Khartoum. This growing military co-operation is not only incompatible with South Africa's foreign policy but also contradictory to President Mandela's recent stand on Nigeria's human rights violations as well as his status as one of Africa's most respected leaders," added the NSCC statement.

But a spokesman at the South African High Commission in the Kenyan capital denied ever having been contacted by Pax Christi as the latter claims in its message to the NSCC. He told APS that matters regarding Sudan were handled by their embassy in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

And a spokesman for the Sudan Embassy in Nairobi denied his country's involvement in the arms deal with South Africa. "Those are calculated moves by international human rights bodies to damage the good name of Sudan on the national, regional and international levels," he told APS.

However, he said the only business deal he knew of between his country and South Africa was Sudan's purchasing of train coaches from South Africa.

Sources close to the French authorities claimed that in April 1994, the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) received sophisticated weaponry made in China, Israel and South Africa, including South African made ground-to-air missiles, Pax Christi said in the message to NSCC.

But it is not clear whether the South African made weapons were delivered recently and/or directly to the conflict parties in the Sudan. It is also difficult to present substantial evidence that countries like France and the Seychelles have either re-exported South African military goods or acted as transit ports, Pax Christi observes.

However, Armscor's position that it cannot be expected to know if a country is not honouring the sale conditions which would prohibit that South African arms are sold to a third party, is far from the accountability one may expect, notes the Catholic body.

According to sources within the NSCC, Gruiters, is scheduled to visit South Africa early next year regarding the alleged sale of arms by the South African government to the Islamic government in Khartoum.

While there, Gruiters is expected to confer with the South African authorities including President Nelson Mandela and church leaders, among them Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, the NSCC source told APS.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


116 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Malawi Women Call For Gender Sensitive Policy


LENGTH: 827 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 4, 1995

Mchinji, Malawi - Although Malawian women are standing against anything seen as an obstacle to their rights, they charge that police and judiciary are "not doing enough" to bring to book all those who harass women.

As numerous workshops, seminars and conferences on gender equality awareness continue at all levels of the society in Malawi with the aim of enlightening women about their rights , more women (85 per cent of whom are illiterate) are now coming out in the open to speak against women abuse, condemning police and judiciary for not doing enough to bring to book rapists and all those who harass women.

The Director of Public Prosecution, Kamudoni Nyasulu, however says the activists' concerns are misdirected because the judiciary is at the end of most cases that are brought before courts. The re- enforcement of the law against women abuse is generally inadequate. 

"In any case, even if courts may pass judgement in favour of a woman, relatives may reverse the court's decision by influencing the woman," Nyasulu contended.

But police say that one of the solutions to the fight against sexual offence and domestic violence is civic education. "Aggressive awareness campaigns is a must and there is need to establish rape crisis centres, incest, abuse and sexual offence support groups that will provide education, counselling and support for victims."

Latest statistics show that five in every 50 women are battered everyday in Malawi.

In this connection, police were quick to say that the majority of the women are economically dependent on the husband. It is this setting that allows the battered wives to bear their suffering in silence. The women who report incidents of beatings do so at the "heat of the moment' but withdraw later.

Not only are many women ignorant of the laws that protect them but it is also a widely held belief that if a woman reports on offence of domestic violence to police or goes to court, her action is interpreted to mean that she wants a divorce.

>From January to July 1995, 211 rape cases were reported throughout Malawi as compared to 87 during the same period in 1994. The low figures are attributed to under reporting. Consequently, to encourage more victims to report cases to police, plans are underway to build private interview rooms at all police stations that will promote confidentiality.

Meanwhile, representatives of the Women Activists' Groups here lobbying for the advocacy of gender sensitive policy have proposed a number of issues to the Malawi Government. These include changing the socio-economic and political structures in the country so that these should reflect gender balance, and legalising the elimination of sexual harassment by giving this form of abuse a statutory definition which does not currently exist.

Other concerns raised include imposing a statutory duty on employers to take steps to eliminate sexual harassment, and provision of civil remedy to victims.

Women working in shops, restaurants and small companies should be entitled to three months maternity leave to enable them take care of their babies, the activists' group proposed. They also called for the establishment of creches or day-care centres for breast-feeding mothers, at work places. Ideally, the centres will be situated where mother would leave their babies as they go about their duties in the offices and breast feed them when they take some time off.

"Changes at this level will have strategic benefits not only for women but for men as well in terms of the development process," argue the activists.

Much as the Malawi Constitution guarantees equality, there is lack of specific legislation to protect women on a particular issue. It remains to be seen therefore whether the women's fight for gender sensitivity will be maintained and achieve the goals set out.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


117 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


South Africa Archbishop Tutu To Head Truth Commission


LENGTH: 800 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 4, 1995

Pretoria - Archbishop Desmond Tutu was on November 29 appointed to head South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, a body being set up to probe human rights abuses during the apartheid era.

Tutu, the Anglican Archbishop of Cape Town and 1984 Nobel peace laureate, was appointed to the post by the Cabinet, said Jakes Gerwel, the director general of President Nelson Mandela's office. The cabinet also named the other 16 members of the commission, which will begin hearings at the beginning of 1996. 

The body, which Gerwel said would begin work immediately, will investigate all politically motivated crimes committed by members and allies of the former regime in defence of apartheid, as well as those committed by members of the liberation movements.

One of the commissions's three sub-committees will have the power to grant amnesty and indemnity from prosecution to the perpetrators of such acts in exchange for full disclosure of their crimes.

Another committee will give out reparations to the victims and families of those killed, injured, or who lost property during the racial struggle since 1948. Gerwel said the cabinet's decision last week on the appointments "marks an important stage in this historic process of coming to an understanding of our past.

"The process is aimed at reconciliation and reconstruction of this once deeply divided and conflict ridden society, now in pursuit of a future founded on the recognition of human rights, democracy and peaceful co-existence of all its citizens," Gerwel added.

The multiparty cabinet led by President Nelson Mandela's National African Congress (ANC) expressed the view that the commission's work was directed by the need for understanding but not for vengeance, the need for reparation but not for retaliation, Gerwel noted.

The appointments were made by Mandela in consultation with the Cabinet from a short list drawn up by an independent selection panel after interviews with 46 nominees. Gerwel said the cabinet discussions were held in a "spirit of consensus seeking and without acrimony."

This was despite the fact that the cabinet also comprised members of the former ruling National Party (NP) and the nationalist Inkatha Freedom Party (IFP), some of whose members are likely to appear in front of the commission.

Former liberal politician Alex Boraine, who is now the executive director of the non-governmental organisation, Justice in Transition, was appointed deputy chairman of the commission.

There appears to be only one overt right-winger on the commission, advocate Chris de Jager, a member of the statutory Volkstaat Council which is seeking an autonomous white state in South Africa. A former Member of Parliament of the NP who later became involved with white liberal politics, Wynand Malan, is also on the commission.

The other members include Mary Burton, former national president of the anti-apartheid women's movement, the Black Sash, and human rights lawyers Richard Lystr, Fifi Kamphephe, Dumisa Ntsebeza and Denzil Potjieter.

Also appointed were academic Wendy Orr, who mounted a successful campaign against the apartheid police to stop them assaulting prisoners, medical researcher Matule Ramashala and Faizel Randera, a doctor who investigated the suspected poisoning by the former government of church leader Frank Chikane in 1989.

Also in the team are Yasmin Sooka, national president of the World Conference on Religion and Peace, Hlengiwe Mkhize, national director of Mental Health and Substance Abuse, Glenda Wildschut, social worker who has counselled victims of political violence, Bongani Finca, the interim administrator of the black homeland of Ciskei after the military rule collapsed there in 1994, and Khoza Mgojo, Methodist cleric from KwaZulu-Natal.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


118 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Uganda Anglican Archbishop Censures Men


LENGTH: 494 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 4, 1995

Kampala - Church of Uganda Archbishop Livingstone Nkoyoyo has blamed Ugandan men for the rising cases of the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) scourge in this East African country.

Nkoyoyo who was speaking during a confirmation ceremony at Bukoto Church of Uganda in the capital Kampala on November 26, accused Ugandan men of behaving "like a vehicle which has bad alignment. It knocks in every direction." 

"You men are vulnerable to loose sex since you move in all directions
... Stop indulging in loose sex," the Anglican Archbishop said amid applause from the hundreds of women amongst men who attended the ceremony.

The manager of Uganda AIDS Control Programme (UACP) Dr. Elizabeth Madraa, says the HIV virus which often causes AIDS is spreading more rapidly amongst women in the country's rural areas. Statistics in Uganda from the AIDS Control programme show that of the 41,559 regular AIDS cases 19,638 (47.8 per cent) are men and 21,921 (52.7 per cent) are women.

Dr Madraa attributed the high incidence of AIDS infection among women in Uganda to wide spread rape, defilement and commercial sex, especially amongst the rural poor.

"Many times (Ugandan) women find themselves dependent on men financially. This reduces their bargaining power for protected sex. When a man says no to a condom the woman has no choice," she noted.

Dr. Madraa further said that most of the infected Ugandan women are married. She attributed this to culture in most parts of the country. "Women are expected to get married so that even if their husbands are unfaithful and demand unprotected sex the women who are more (in numbers) than men will agree than lose marital status and be stigmatised by society."

Dr. Madraa called for awareness campaigns to be concentrated amongst rural women and girls. She also appealed to non-governmental organisations operating in Uganda to increase their efforts in providing village women and girls with income generating projects.

"The underlying factor of women's lack of negotiating power and skills is that Ugandan women generally lack a sense of identity. They spend all their lives under the authority of men. From their fathers to their husbands.... this stems from dependency," she added.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


119 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria and South Africa Countries Quarrel Over Human Rights


LENGTH: 1067 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 4, 1995

Johannesburg - Africa's two most powerful nations, Nigeria and South Africa, are bracing for a major confrontation emanating form the execution by Nigeria's hardline military junta of nine Ogoni minority rights activists, including writer Ken Saro-Wiwa.

On November 26, South African President Nelson Mandela launched a scathing attack on Nigerian military strongman General Sani Abacha, describing his dictatorship as "barbaric, corrupt, irresponsible and arrogant."

In an interview published in Johannesburg's Sunday Independent newspaper, Mandela also revealed that he had warned South African officials of Anglo-Dutch Shell Oil company that action would be taken against them because of Shell's refusal to halt a gas project in Nigeria.

"Abacha is sitting on a volcano and I am going to explode it under him," Mandela told the newspaper. The South African President said the executions had hardened his stance against Abacha, whom he had, until then, been trying through diplomatic means to persuade to restore democracy to Nigeria. 

"I felt we were dealing with an insensitive, frightened dictator and in my view we should use the strongest methods to show our disgust and resentment of what he has done. What we are now proposing are short and sharp measures which will produce the results Nigerians and the world desire," Mandela said.

However, the President expressed disappointment at the lack of effective internal resistance against Nigeria's military rulers, saying the pace and outcome of international campaigns will depend on Nigerians themselves.

"It is of no use for Nigerian leaders to shout from abroad and not to ensure that the fires of resistance are burning inside Nigeria," he added.

Mandela has been lobbying world leaders, among them US President Bill Clinton and British Prime Minister John Major, to impose an oil embargo and other economic sanctions on Nigeria "to bring Abacha to his knees."

On November 20, Mandela asked Shell to shelve its Sterling pounds 2.5 billion (US dollars 3.9 billion) gas project in the oil-rich West African country, but received what an aide described as a "deeply disappointing" response.

Mandela said he had also taken a hard line with the Shell officials. "I told them that I expect them to suspend the project which they have launched in Nigeria ... as a mark of protest," and when they hesitated to do so, I warned them that we are going to take action against them in this country, because we can't allow people to think in terms of their gains when the very lives of human beings are involved," but did not elaborate on the action to be taken.

Mandela's angry interview against Nigeria's military regime followed similar criticism against him by Abacha in the Nigerian press three days earlier.

Public castigation of Mandela in Nigeria reached a peak on November 23 when Nigerian Head of State, General Sani Abacha, openly attacked the South African leader saying his long years in prison may have left him incapable of understanding the complexity of modern diplomacy."

"Possibly, it may not be his fault. Probably because.. of being incarcerated for 27 years, he cannot understand the complexity of modern diplomacy," General Abacha told a delegation of traditional Nigerian leaders from across the country, who went to the political capital Abuja to demonstrate their support.

Abacha said it was unfortunate that South Africa and Zimbabwe, two southern African countries which Nigeria had helped in their struggle for independence, were leading the lobby for sanctions against Lagos.

"I cannot understand, neither can I appreciate any reason why people like Mandela and (Zimbabwean President) Mugabe are behaving the way they did. These were the same people for whom we have made a lot of sacrifices in order to ensure freedom in their own countries," Abacha was quoted saying.

"I think there is a need for us to review our foreign policy in order to reconsider our priorities," he added in what was interpreted by analysts here as indicating that Nigeria might shift the focus away from Africa.

Until now, the Nigerian government has always insisted that Africa is at the centre of its foreign policy.

Observers said the present face-off seemed to be the culmination of mutual suspicion between the two countries since Mandela came to power last year after the dismantling of apartheid..

Top officials from both countries, Africa's most influential, have in the past year reiterated that the two nations were not in competition over leadership of the continent.

But Nigeria's national television reported a week earlier that South Africa's campaign for sanctions against Nigeria was aimed at facilitating Pretoria's entry into the UN Security Council as Africa's representative if and when the body was enlarged.

For Nigeria, Mandela's current posture may have been interpreted as a challenge to its traditional stand as the most powerful and influential nation on the African continent.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


120 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zimbabwe Bishops Warn Government On Health Budget


LENGTH: 547 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 4, 1995
by Goodson Machona

Harare - Zimbabwe's Catholic Bishops Conference (ZCBC) has warned it may reconsider partnership with the government at some hospitals following a drastic cut in the Ministry of Health budget.

The government announced late November that Zimbabwe dollars 1.37 billion (US dollars 148 million) allocated to the Ministry of Health in the financial year that began last July would be cut to about US dollars 110 million.

Health Minister Timothy Stamps says to work optimally, his ministry needs at least US dollars 200 million per annum. 
Dr. Stamps recently auctioned his cut hair sold to a German expatriate for about US dollars 40, to dramatise the need for funds to support efforts to stop the spread of the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).

The Health Minister said AIDS would kill some 100,000 Zimbabweans in
the next 18 months. In addition, the government has to deal with a host of other common diseases like malaria which afflicted 300,000 Zimbabweans last year, killing 290 of them.

The government is under pressure from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and other donors to reduce State spending but the Catholic Bishops questioned the priorities, saying cutting spending in health was counter productive and would hit the most vulnerable in society. "We question the priorities which the government has set itself in the current budget," they said.

The announcement of the cuts and the Bishops' letter coincide with the contradictory announcement that effective next July, President Robert Mugabe's annual salary package would rise by more than 100 per cent from Zimbabwe dollars 195,000 to 456,000 (approximately US dollars 21,000 to 50,000). There would be matching increases in salary for the two Vice Presidents, members of the Cabinet and Parliament.

The Catholic Bishops asserted that by targeting the public health budget, the government was effectively abandoning the rural poor Zimbabwe where serious drought in the past year had severely curtailed incomes in peasant holdings.

Earlier this year during the United Nations World Conference on Poverty in Copenhagen, Denmark, British aid agency, Oxfam, said many peasant mothers in Zimbabwe had abandoned ante-and post-natal clinics because they could not afford the meagre fees required of them in contributory health schemes recently introduced in Zimbabwe.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December, 1995


Rwanda Extension Of UN Presence Requested


LENGTH: 414 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 4, 1995

Cairo - Rwanda will request a three-month extension of the United Nations mandate in the troubled central African country, former US President Jimmy Carter and Rwandan President Pasteur Bizimungu said at a five-nation international summit here aimed at resolving the Rwandan refugee crisis and the ethnic strife threatening the Great Lakes region of central Africa.

Carter, whose peace centre is sponsoring the conference on Rwanda's
refugee crisis, told a press conference that he had asked the Rwandan government to request an extension and that President Bizimungu had agreed. 

Bizimungu confirmed that he would ask for the extension for the current mandate, which expires on .

The conference brought together leaders of Burundi, Rwanda, Uganda and Zaire, while Tanzania, which held its last leg of general elections last week, was represented by its minister of state for defence Abdel Rahaman Kinana.

On November 27, Bizimungu had ordered the UN peacekeeping troops stationed in Rwanda to leave or face expulsion by the local population, an order that had forced UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali start preparations to phase out the UN Military Assistance in Rwanda (UNAMIR) peacekeepers from the war-torn tiny central African nation.

Sources at the UN headquarters in New York said Boutros-Ghali was at the point of asking the UN Security Council to approve a phased pullout of the last remaining 2,000 peacekeepers in the force, which numbered 5,500 troops at their peak.

However, some diplomats at the UN Security Council favoured keeping the UN blue-helmets in Rwanda - engulfed by ethnic bloodbath between Hutus and Tutsis last year during which Hutu extremists killed between 500,000 million people, most of the Tutsis and moderate Hutus - as long as the massive refugee problem, among others, remained unresolved.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


122 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zaire Hopes For New Diplomatic Ties With Belgium


LENGTH: 480 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 4, 1995

Brussels - As francophone leaders gathered in Cotonou, Benin, at the weekend for their annual summit, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire hinted that he would use the occasion to seek renewal of diplomatic ties with former colonial power, Belgium.

He urged that Belgium and Zaire should put their differences behind
them and begin talks on restoring relations. President Mobutu told
Belgian television that the 47-nation francophone summit, which was
expected to begin in the Benin capital on December 2, could provide
an opportunity for him to meet Belgium Prime Minister Jean-Luc
Dehaene. 

In the last one and a half years, Mobutu's battered image has
recovered significantly following the outbreak of the Rwandan crisis
which sent more than 2 million refugees across the border, focusing
international attention on Zaire.

Belgium and a number of other Western countries severed diplomatic
ties three years ago following Mobutu's reluctance to speed up
democratic reforms, resulting in a series of violent riots and army
mutinies.

Analysts say Mobutu appears to be firmly in control of his chaotic
central African country thanks to his cooperation with the
international community over the Rwandan refugee crisis, and economic
reforms instituted by Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo.

Among other issues top on the summit's agenda would be how to deal
with the crisis sparked by the military regime of General Sani Abacha
in Nigeria following the execution of human rights campaigner, Ken
Saro-Wiwa and eight other minority Ogoni leaders.

The summit is also expected to discuss the peace process in Liberia,
where several francophone African countries are contributing troops
to the West African intervention force, ECOMOG, as well as the civil
war in neighbouring Sierra Leone. It would also review progress made
by the economies of francophone West Africa, following the
devaluation by 50 per cent of their common currency, the CFA franc
early 1994.

LANGUAGE: English

123 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Business Government Advised to Write Off Farmers' Debt


LENGTH: 600 words


 
The Post Of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 6, 1995
by Goodson Machona

Lusaka - Government has been advised to write off debts of small-scale farmers in drought affected areas to allow more farmers back into the credit worthy net, The Post has learnt.

A list of some 220,000 small-scale farmers eligible for debt relief due to
drought has been drawn up, according to a report by the technical committee
of economic ministers obtained by The Post. The report says the write-off would involve a maximum sum of K28.5 billion. 

According to the report, dated November 10, 1995, government should consider writing off the outstanding debts on an individual basis.

However, the report has warned against wholesale forgiveness as this would
send the wrong signals and lead to future wholesale defaulting.

"Obviously, the review of outstanding debts of small-scale farmers has to be undertaken carefully; wholesale forgiveness can not be considered as a
realistic option as this would send the wrong signals and lead to future
wholesale defaulting again."

"Timely action now will clear the way for these farmers to get access to the delivery of agricultural credit during the 1995/96 production season," the
report further reads. "The proposed debt write-off would have to be off set
against all debts outstanding from fertilizer loans as well as the
disbursement of marketing promissory note credit owed to government."

The report says the lending institutions that made the loans to the farmers
should be allowed a "corresponding debt write-off in the amounts owed to
them by drought-affected small-scale farmers."

The report further says the write-off would involve a maximum sum of K28.5
billion to be off-set against the current outstanding debt of the lending
institutions to government.

However, according to the report, the debt write-off will reduce the 'book
value' of money owed to government, but will have no direct negative
financial effect on government finances.

"These fertilizer loans, both in cash and in kind, originate from 1991/92,

1993/94 and 1994/95 and should be considered as 'bad debts"; neither the
individual small scale farmers nor the lending institutions will ever be
able to repay these," the report says.

The committee is made up of ministers and technical advisers from the
finance, commerce and agriculture ministries.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


124 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Business Drought Relief Food Demand Drops


LENGTH: 387 words


 
The Post Of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 5, 1995
by Goodson Machona

Lusaka - The demand for drought relief requirements has dropped by more than ten per cent, it has been learnt.

According to report by the technical committee of economic ministers
released yesterday said the 1995 showed that there had been a downward
adjustment from 85,700 to 77,300 metric tonnes of relief food. 

The report said the results were based on the assesment conducted by the
World Food Programme, the Programme Against Malnutrition and Care
International last month.

"Total pledges, including commodities already arrived, committed or being
finalised, equal 75, 705 metric tonnes or approximately 98 per cent of total
requirements," reads a brief.

However, the commitee, which has representatives from the commerce, finance
and agricultural ministries, expressed worry on the distribution of relief
maize.

"While the aggregate national requirements for food relief will be largely
met, much concerns remain regarding the actual distribution and targeting
mechanisms being used at provincial and district levels to reach effectively
the seriously affected population groups," the brief further reads.

The report has also expressed concern on the implementation of the
distribution methods.

It cited the programmes like the food-for-free, food-for-work and
cash-for-work projects; the food-for-sale activities which it said it could
have some effects on normal marketing operations.

Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Journalists' Trip To Zaire Won't Clear Image


LENGTH: 1094 words


 
The Post Of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 6, 1995
by John on Wednesday (Column)

There are moments, as a citizen, that I have felt hopeless and frustrated by the people we entrusted the government machinery to ensure and secure the
greatest happiness of the greatest majority of the people. Some of the
problems being experienced are simple and can be adequately addressed.

The frustration comes in primarily because one is convinced that there is a
better way of solving the problems, but there are no channels between
yourself and those in leadership to air such ideas. But such channels of
communications do not exist. There is hardly any unity between those in
power and the people. The people appear to have their own agenda which is
diametrically opposed to that of those in power. 

This feeling was reactivated in me when I heard on the news that State House has invited journalists from both government and owned media institutions to travel to Zaire to establish whether the reports published in this paper about the President's place of birth are true or not.

The more I think about this course the more I get enraged. Whoever has
dreamt the scheme is very dull and childish and need not to be associated
with the office of the President in whatever capacity.

The scheme reveals the calibre of the people surrounding Chiluba as
advisers. Admittedly, the allegations made about the Chiluba's origin are
serious and threaten the foundation of our system of government. But what is
objectionable is the method which has been devised to address the problem.
It spells a crisis among the people surrounding Chiluba they have run out of
ideas on how to rebut the allegations.

I believe there is a cheaper and most effective way to dispel these
allegations which many people have suggested. A lot of allegations have been
made against Chiluba and his traditional attitude has been to ignore them
and treat them as none issues. No doubt Chiluba cannot be expected to
respond to every allegations which are published in the media. But there are
some allegations such as those concerning his origins, which need to be
treated with the seriousness they deserve rather than attempt to cheapen
them.

These allegations will not just die away. We have elections next year and if Chiluba has intentions of contesting for the second term then he has to
settle this issue once and for all and in the most mature and responsible manner.

It is not enough for Chiluba to casually make reference to them at a
political rally or any other not so serious forum, or to let his ministers
or assistants to clear the mess for him. The issue at hand is bigger than
Richard Sakala or Sata or Sampa. Any statement by any person other than
Chiluba will not wash, because we have heard them before. The issue
threatens Chiluba's very existence as a person and secondly the Presidency.
It is unthinkable for any person to remain idle when his very person is
being questioned.

Everything about Chiluba has been disputed. His academic qualifications have been questioned, it is alleged that he used another person's certificate to get a job and that the real Frederick Chiluba exists. Controversy still
surrounds his father. Luka Chabala maintains that he is the father to Chiluba. Now it is place of birth being questioned.

On none of these issues has Chiluba cared to make any serious comment and
yet these are very serious allegations. Only an insane person can claim that
one is his son when this is not true. With the advancement of technology
this can easily be settled through DNA tests. It is an insult to one's
intellect and one's own being to allege that he used another person's
academic papers to get a job. It defies logic for one to remain silent in
the midst of all these allegations.

Chiluba is on record that he was born on the Copperbelt but people
conversant with the system at that time maintain that if the Chiluba's
version is true there should be some records to establish to support is
contention. as usual Chiluba has not risen to the challenge.

Some people have read the revelations in this paper in disbelief and
remained hoping that Chiluba will come out and say that what was written was
not true and regain our confidence and trust in him by giving us his side of
the story. But with equal disbelief we have watched this opportunity slip
away.

But to put together a team of journalists mostly from government media to
dispel the allegations made against Chiluba is insane and an abuse of
office. What is being questioned is not the office of the President but the
person occupying that office. Although the allegations made affect the
Presidency what is in issue is Chiluba as a person. This is a purely private
matter which Chiluba in his own private capacity must address. Government
resources or employees should not be employed in such a venture.

Chiluba should have come out in the open and declare that enough was enough
and put these allegations to an end by presenting his side of the story.
Otherwise the only logical conclusion is that there is no Chiluba's side of
the story.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

December, 1995


Zambia Human Rights Added To School Curricula


LENGTH: 267 words


 
The Post Of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 5, 1995
by Mabeni Sikalyabwanda

Lusaka - Information and broadcasting deputy minister Valentine Kayope said
yesterday the government is working on plans to introduce human rights and
gender subjects in school curricula.

Speaking when he officially opened a five-day Information and Education
Communication (IEC) workshop in Livingstone, Kayope said the time has come
for Zambian school children at both primary and secondary schools to learn
about human rights, gender, environment and health education. 

The deputy minister told the gathering of twelve non-governmental
organisations and Zambia Information Services that government is working
with the United States Agency for International Development on a project to
co-ordinate family planning matters in the country.

Speaking earlier, ZIS director Patrick Jabani said all organisations
currently working on family planning have agreed that for too long now they
have been pulling in opposite directions and that it is necessary to build a
consensus if family planning matters are to be dealt with effectively.

127 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia State House Sets Up Fact Finding Mission to Zaire


LENGTH: 1280 words


 
The Post Of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 5, 1995
by Staff Reporters

Lusaka - State House has organised a trip to Zaire for any journalist who wants to verify Post stories of last week reporting that President Chiluba was
born in Zaire.

State House presidential aide Richard Sakala said arrangements for the trip
had been left in the hands of the government-owned Zambia Information
Services (ZIS).

"The trip is to go and verify the Post stories about President Chiluba and
it is an open invitation to both local and international journalists. Each
organisation is, however, supposed to meet its own costs," Sakala said and
then referred everything to ZIS. 

He also emphasised that the invitation was especially for The Post since it
was the originator of the story.

The Post last week reported it had seen and obtained copies of birth records indicating Chiluba was born at Chibambo Mission Hospital in Zaire (then Belgian Congo). But after the visit by Post investigators, the Zairean
government took control of the hospital and changed its name.

ZIS phoned The Post to extend the invitation. However, they said nothing to
indicate the invitation was "especially" for The Post.

The Post has declined the invitation, saying that documentary evidence that
was in Zaire has by now probably been removed.

"What is needed now is not further denials of the story in such a manner but for the President to simply prove through documentary evidence that he was
born in Zambia," said Post managing editor Bright Mwape.

Several journalists, opposition parties and civic organisations also
objected to the trip and called on Chiluba to instead provide evidence he
was born in Zambia.

Zambia Union of Journalists (ZUJ) chairman Edwin Musaika described the trip
as ridiculous.

"When there was a Commonwealth summit in Auckland, (New Zealand) State House didn't see any need to take a delegation of reporters to go and cover the summit," said Musaika, a journalist at the Times of Zambia . "To them there was no need to cover the President.

"It could have been better to show journalists the birth place of Jesus
Christ. This is a waste of public funds, unless they are using MMD funds,"
Musaika said.

He also questioned the sense in taking along government journalists.

"In fact the whole thing is staged-managed. Suppose a state journalist comes across information that the President was born there. Is that journalist
going to write the story and for which paper?"

The United National Independence party (UNIP) called for the cancellation of the trip and also announced it has asked parliament to investigate the
matter as required by Article 37 of the Constitution.

UNIP acting president senior chief Inyabo Yeta said it was improper for the
executive to investigate itself or arrange such a conducted tour of Zaire.

"UNIP is aware that the media has thoroughly investigated this matter of Mr. Chiluba's identity. The evidence so far published suggests that there indeed may be serious questions pertaining to : the natural and legal identity of the incumbent President, some of his principle lieutenants, including senior cabinet ministers and others in positions of political power," chief Yeta said.

He also said the intended trip was an attempt to cover up any evidence that
may exist.

"We also believe that this administration's programme is aimed at
hoodwinking the Zambian public. It is diversionary and an attempt at
forestalling and preventing a genuine inquiry," he said.

He also said a select committee representing all political parties in
parliament be set up and be charged with the important task of investigating
Chiluba's identity.

Rodger Chongwe, president of the Liberal Progressive Front and prominent
human rights lawyer, said the trip "is not going to solve Mr. Chiluba's
problems."

He said Chiluba's parentage, place of birth and citizenship have all been
questioned and "the journalists are not going to resolve that problem for
him." He said it was quite clear from Chiluba's reaction last week that he
had already sent intelligence people to Zaire to destroy birth records and
other evidence, because he claimed The Post had offered a K300,000 bribe for
the information.

Chongwe, too, called for an independent inquiry by a commission appointed by the Commonwealth, which has the facilities to investigate issues of
parentage, birth place and citizenship.

"That is what Chiluba must do if he wants to gain credibility not only in
Zambia, but worldwide," he said.

"But Chiluba would not accept this because he knows the commission would
show otherwise."

"If he does not clear himself, he will not stand for the presidency."

Lucy Sichone, chairperson of the Zambia Civic Education Association, said
Chiluba is actually giving credibility to The Post's story by not coming out
with evidence he was born in Zambia.

"What is his problem," Sichone said. "Why can't he just tell us where he was born. We have now lost the dignity of that office. He is giving The Post
credibility because the visit has no dignity."


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


128 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Now FTJ Chiluba Breaks Silence Over His Origin


LENGTH: 960 words


 
The Post Of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 6, 1995
by Sipo Kapumba

Lusaka - President Chiluba for the first time in nine days went public on December 5 over allegations he was born in Zaire.

In reports broadcast on ZNBC television, he hinted the Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines (ZCCM) may today prove his claims that he was born in Wusakile
township in Kitwe.

The president said Wusakile was in existence by the time of his birth in
1943 and referred to an inquiry on the housing situation involving blacks in
the townships that took place about that time.

"There are even maps to show this and all this information is there. And it
is not coming from me. ZCCM has said it is there, so who is Aka to tell me
Wusakile was not there. (Mongu MP Akashambtwa Mbikusita Lewanika has said
Wusakile didn't even exist in 1943 when Chiluba claims he was born there.) 

"But that is a small issue. The truth will come out, that is why you have
traveled to prove the truth," Chiluba said.

State House yesterday transported journalists to Chibambo in Zaire to
disprove reports in The Post last week that Chiluba was born in Chibambo
Mission Hospital. The state led trip to Zaire includes a stopover in Kitwe
where journalists are expected to be presented with "birth records and
historical facts of Wusakile." Nkana division of ZCCM under which Wusakile
falls, is managed by Ernest Pilula, a relative of defence minister Ben
Mwila.

Only journalists from the government media traveled with State House to
Zaire; nearly all the independent media declined the invitation.

In reaction to Chiluba's comments, Lewanika has said the onus is on
President Chiluba to prove where he was born and not anyone else because of
the conflicting versions of his birth.

"He is the one who opened up the personalisation and questioning of other
Zambian's Zambia-nness which is a disservice to politics.

"The solution is to have one official verified and verifiable version of
where he was born, when he was born and who his parents were," Lewanika said
last night.

He also refuted Chiluba's claim that he (Lewanika) was born in 1953, saying
instead he was born in 1948 in Wusakile African Mine Workers' Hospital.
Lewanika, who has called upon Chiluba to produce his father's mine number as
proof he was born in Wusakile, said his own father's mine number was 781915.

"There is no miner's child who does not know his father's mine number. If he has forgotten he should ask someone in his family," he said.

Lewanika added that the age of the people demanding that Chiluba clear the
air about his nationality was irrelevant because he started the debate
himself.

The credibility of the Zaire trip has further been questioned by several
people after government quietly rushed Health Minister Michael Sata and Home
Affairs minister Chitalu Sampa to Zaire several days ahead of yesterday's
trip.

Meanwhile, an MMD member based in Monze, Michael Mundale, has said in
reaction to Chiluba's remarks on television that since Chiluba insisted that
people should have questioned his nationality before he became president,
equally, the only time anyone should have questioned UNIP president Kenneth
Kaunda's nationality was in 1964.

Opposition parties also continued to charge that the onus of proof is on
President Chiluba.

Zambia Democratic Congress (ZDC) Vice-President Kasuka Mutukwa said in
Lusaka yesterday that the president should not drag along other people to
help prove his case.

"If he (Chiluba) wants to clear his name in that way, he should do it
privately using his own funds. The trip to Zaire is unnecessary," he said.
"We would like to know which part of the budget was used to support the
trip."

National Party secretary for home affairs, Kennedy Samabi, said the trip to
Zaire was "stage managed" and would not yield anything new about the
Presi-dent's origin.

He said the probe needed to be conducted by a body of unquestionable
legitimacy and supported calls for an independent inquiry.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
