129 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Controversy Over Chiluba's Nationality


LENGTH: 1654 words


 
The Post Of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 5, 1995
by Milimo Moyo and Fidelis Mulenga

Lusaka - A Movement for Multi-party Democracy (MMD) official has accused President Frederick Chiluba of "buying votes" from the Eastern Province electorate in order to increase his chances of retaining the party's presidential seat at this month's MMD convention.

George Munuka, senior private secretary in the office of the party's
vice-president, Levy Mwanawasa, has also challenged Chiluba to come out in
the open about his true nationality.

Mwanawasa himself is seeking the party's presidency.

In an interview with The Post, Munuka said Chiluba has given
"millions of tax payers' money" to the Eastern Province MMD coordinator to
persuade cadres to cast their votes for him at the convention. 

"The President is always preaching about democracy and Christianity but what he is doing is shameful. He is actually using his powers as republican
President to block other candidates," Munuka said, adding that the people
themselves will decide who to vote for and should not be bought.

Munuka expressed fears that the MMD was tampering with the list of Eastern
Province delegates to the convention to ensure that only those whose
loyalties lay with Chiluba were registered for attendance.

"Right now, health deputy minister Katele Kalumba is out there registering
only those who expressed President Chiluba as their presidential choice.
Those who show signs of doubt in Chiluba are being ticked off," Munuka
claimed.

But presidential press aide Richard Sakala declined to comment.

"I cannot lower the dignity of the delegates to the convention by commenting on such a matter," he said in a telephone interview yesterday.

Munuka, who is a card-carrying member of the MMD, has also joined opposition parties in challenging Chiluba to establish his true nationality because Zambians are not prepared to vote for "a person whose background is not known".

"Many people believe the stories of Chiluba's Zairean parentage because he
himself has not told us the truth. He must tell us before the convention
because if he is re-elected at the convention, the MMD will have another
convention next year because of the presidential clause in the draft
constitution which demands a true Zambian for presidency," he said.

Meanwhile, a member of the National Executive Committee (NEC) of the National Party (NP) has called on President Frederick Chiluba to step down from State House because, as head and manager of Security Services, the investigations into his birth place would be biased.

Kahalu Kenete, who is NP provincial chairman on the Copperbelt, said in
Kitwe yesterday that Chiluba should step down on moral grounds because the
integrity of the nation was at stake following revelations that he was born
in Zaire.

"Once he steps down as Commander-In-Chief then the investigations can be
carried out fairly because at the moment, public respect for him is fast
wearing out because of the revelations."

"The onus is on the President himself to prove that he is a Zambian and not
a Zairean as alleged," he said. "Not one member of the ruling MMD or his family can prove that he is a Zambian except himself.

"MMD cadres should not waste time talking as if they are not patriotic to
Zambia and should leave the matter to the President,' he said and stressed
that he was speaking in his capacity as a concerned Zambian citizen.

He supported Zambian Democratic Congress (ZDC) president Dean Mung'omba's
calls that Chiluba should resign over the controversy surrounding his
nationality but that as custodians of the law, the Law Association of Zambia
(LAZ), the Judiciary Services and some key government ministries must tell
the nation the truth and what was right.

Kenete suggested that in carrying out the investigations, four ministries
should be involved.

The Ministry of Energy must establish or confirm the allegation that Zambia
was supplying electricity to Chibambo Mission where Chiluba is alleged to
have been born and who was paying the bills.

The Ministry of Health must also direct all on the Copperbelt to establish
which centre the President was born in because "certainly there must be some
record of some kind."

The Ministry of Education should also establish which schools the President
attended and to what grade, while the Ministry of Labour should provide
information and records of where Mr Chiluba worked and how he rose to his
current positions at State House.

Kenete further suggested that the Ministry of Local Government and Home
Affairs must establish and tell the nation when Musangu village was actually
set up on the Zambian soil.

"Was it a village at the time," he asked.

"These reports should be presented to parliament and together with comment
from LAZ, the judiciary service, a decision would be made by parliament.

"My appeal to all these bodies is that they should not consider this issue
on partisan lines because the integrity of the nation is at stake," he
added.

The United National Independence Party (UNIP) has joined the chorus calling for the resignation or impeachment of President Chiluba. The party said it would incite civil disobedience if needed to ensure that the President leaves office.

Senior chief Inyambo Yeta said allegations leveled against Chiluba over his
nationality are evidence that "he had assumed and continues to exercise
power fraudulently".

"The President cannot therefore continue to lead this country and should
immediately step down or be impeached," Inya- mbo said yesterday.

Yeta, who is also acting party President in the absence of Kenneth Kaunda,
further charged at a press conference at Freedom House yesterday that
failure of the President to resign or the failure of parliament to impeach
Chiluba would lead the country into chaos and anarchy.

"UNIP is going to ensure that the President either resigns or is impeached.
If these don't happen, we will organise all pressure groups, opposition
parties, NGOs and the church to hold mass protests against his leadership.
If we need to incite civil disobedience throu- ghout the country for him to
leave the presidency, then we will do so," he said.

He said Chiluba's leadership has led the country into a state of national
crisis.

He cited a long list of errors by Chiluba, including: the "revelation of
state secrets (tunnels) for the purpose of gaining political capital;
dishonest assurances to the public over Zambia Airways and Kabwe Mines;
false assurances to parliament and to the public over Meridien BIAO Bank's
financial soundness when the government knew that the bank was in fact going
under; credibility gap over the construction of Soweto Market by October
1994 and the government's insincerity over the Gabon disaster report etc."

Chief Yeta said these actions constitute "grave misdemeanors and crimes
against the constitution and oath of office of President.

"The President cannot therefore continue to lead this country and should
immediately step down or be impeached," Yeta charged.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


130 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Party Says Sacrifices Difficult To Justify


LENGTH: 854 words


 
The Post Of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 6, 1995
by Bob Sakahilu (Column)

Lusaka - When Zambia got independence the mood among leaders and the entire nation was more of euphoria.

The country had not only shaken itself of British rule but had enormous
mineral resources like copper, which enabled it look to the future with
confidence.

The government set about an ambitious programme to improve the economic and
social welfare of its people. The positive effects of this move were rapidly
felt and, by the end of the 60s and the beginning of the 70s the average
income and per capital of Zambians were among the highest in the world. 

The period also saw the nationalisation process, perhaps necessary at the
time as it facilitated many Zambians without capital to participate in the
directing of their national economic affairs.

When in the middle of the 70s, the price of copper from which Zambia even
today gets about 80 per cent of its export revenue began to fall on the
London Metal Exchange, a rapid economic decline set in. Coupled with the
sacrifices made by Kaunda on the struggle for independence in the
neighbouring countries, this saw the living standards decline even further
and in its wake followed an economic crisis.

Kaunda was compelled by those circumstances to approach the IMF which
recommended a series of strict policies in return for financial aid.

The measures included the withdrawal of subsidies on maize and increase in
price fuel. These unleashed a general outcry which led to strikes and demonstrations in 1983.

Kaunda later allowed multi-partyism which saw the MMD come to power in 1991. People had a lot of expectations from the new government which also assured the nation of solving the economic crisis in the country.

But four years in power, Zambians have been asking about what the MMD has
done for them and what has gone wrong with the initial impressive programme.

Economic experts agree that the policies introduced by the Chiluba regime
have not yielded much nor have they benefited the majority of the people
economically. In fact critics maintain that the MMD has deviated from its
original ideals, lost vision and, as a result there has been little economic
progress that has taken place since the ruling party came into power.

For example, the much talked about restructuring of the civil service has
not taken place while the government continues to spend colossal sums on the
defence budget and other insignificant government.

Lack of commitment in the privatisation of ZCCM, which could have brought
about fresh capital has had its own adverse effects.

The informal sector has not been supported financially in order to enable it create new employment opportunities.

On the social front, there has been a failure on the part of the government
to curb corruption, embezzlement, inefficiency, bribery at most government
levels. Delays in the diversification of the economy has made Zambia still dependent on copper, whose production levels have since drastically dwindled.

Efforts to encourage agriculture and tourism as a means to earn revenue for
this country have not been seriously exploited and the two industries remain
virtually dead.

Economically, Zambia is still on a drip feed. With the population now put at 9.7 million, chronic malnutrition, poverty , increased crime delinquency and other problems, the challenge of stopping scourges like corruption becomes
even greater.

Zambians have had to endure the consequences of the Structural Adjustment
Programme (SAP). Now the MMD government is finding it increasingly difficult to justify the sacrifices the Zambians have made in the hope that the economy would improve.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


131 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


United States and Africa Angolan President Asks U.S. Firms to Invest and Trade


LENGTH: 2427 words


 
Africa News Service
December 8, 1995

Washington, D.C. - Text of remarks by Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos at a dinner hosted by the US-Angola Chamber of Commerce and the Corporate Council on Africa

In a speech before the UN in 1963, President Kennedy said that: "Peace is a daily, a weekly, a monthly process, gradually changing opinions, slowly eroding old barriers, quietly building new structures. " I firmly believe that this quote is applicable when we consider the current situation in Angola and the future of my country. Peace has come to Angola.

My country is now engaged in an irreversible process of peace and political reconciliation. Two generations of young Angolans have gone to war, many to their death. 

The time has come to end war.

My Government and those in the opposition, specifically UNITA, recognized this reality one year ago when we signed the Lusaka Protocols. We recognized that the past three decades of war, especially the last three years, was destroying the infrastructure and social fabric of the country.

Over the past year we have moved toward the full implementation of the Lusaka Protocols. This has been a difficult process, but we have made significant progress over the past month.

I discussed the state-of-play and the future of Angola with President Clinton this morning at the White House.

He agreed that the process is moving forward as planned and urged all Angolans to ensure that peace holds, that national reconciliation becomes a reality and that the country moves to the next phase -- one of stabilizing and rebuilding Angola. I know that many of you here tonight are very interested in the Lusaka process.

In sum, the critical phase of demobilization has started. UNITA's forces are moving into demobilization camps.

At the same time, the Government has pulled its forces back from the demobilization areas and has placed the Rapid Intervention Police in barracks as called for in the Lusaka Protocols.

The UN has deployed over 6000 peacekeepers throughout Angola and soon more than 7000 peacekeepers will be in place to help ensure that the process is a success.

At the same time, my Government has announced that it will release all prisoners. We urge UNITA to do the same as soon as possible. Simultaneously and importantly, representatives of the Government and UNITA are holding talks in Luanda to resolve outstanding military and political issues.

I am confident that these talks will produce mutually satisfactory solutions on military integration and political reconciliation. On the latter, we are working with UNITA to initiate the political process at the provincial level. I want to emphasize that I am in regular contact with Dr. Savimbi.

We have met several times over the past year and now talk regularly on the telephone. We agree that the process is irreversible and we fully understand that the future of Angola is at stake.

We cannot return to war. Indeed, we must now focus on two key issues: 1. Ensuring peace

2. Rebuilding the country.

I recognize that without peace, Angola cannot be stabilized, we cannot implement economic and financial reform, we cannot rebuild the country and we cannot attract assistance and investment critical to rebuilding the country. In 1839, de Tocqueville recognized the importance of a strong economy in supporting democracy.

He stated that: "In democracies, nothing is more great or more brilliant than commerce. " The same is true today as we attempt to stabilize Angola's economy and attract trade and investment from the US.

We are working hard to establish and maintain a democracy in Angola.

At the same time, we know that we must do more to establish and expand a market economy -- a process that will take some time and involve tough decisions regarding reform.

Futher, the process will require foreign trade and investment. Angolans are looking to many of you in tonight's audience for advice and tangible action that will increase commerce between our two countries.

Angola recognizes the US as the world's economic leader in the post-Cold War era. US companies have been operating in Angola for almost four decades, largely in the petroleum sector. This participation has been mutually beneficial, but we want to expand oil production and investment in other areas of the economy. I want to take this opportunity to assure you that my Government will do its best to facilitate trade and investment. We have already initiated a process of removing any existing barriers to expanding trade. We know, however, that more needs to be done.

To that end, I want to stress several important points. Angola will adopt sound macro-economic policies that will stabilize and bolster the economy and promote trade and investment. We have initiated a three-pronged strategy to do so. Earlier this year, we launched the macro-economic reform program. It is designed to:

* reduce the budget deficit

* liberalize the economy

* privatize public enterprises

* adopt appropriate exchange rate policies, and

* reform the banking and finance sectors

We have made progress on ending subsidies on domestic fuel prices, authorizing the creation of private banks, privatizing some state-owned and operated enterprises, abolishing the state's hold on mineral rights, and approving over $105 million worth of foreign investment projects in construction, manufacturing, trade, and the hotel and fishing industries. I know that more needs to be done.

Finance Minister Tomas and Governor of the Central Bank Furtado are heading the team that will attempt to meet our goals.

In relation to the 1995 macro-economic strategy, we have also established the $212 million Consolidated Humanitarian Appeal. It is designed to provide emergency assistance, integrate and demobilize military forces, and support demining efforts. During the successful Donors Rountable Conference in Brussels three months ago the Government and the UN Development Program initiated the National Program for Community Rehabilitation and Reconciliation.

This is vital to consolidating and implementing the Lusaka Protocols.

It is a nation-wide strategy, with an emphasis on community development. Fortunately, donor response was outstanding. The international community pledged nearly $1 billion in assistance, with the US pledging $190 million over the next two years.

I want to take this opportunity to restate our gratitude for this generosity and support. But I want to keep the focus of my remarks tonight on the critical need for US trade and investment with Angola.

Assistance can help place Angolans back on their feet, but we must move expeditiously from aid to trade, to move from assistance to economic rehabilitation and development as quickly as possible. Angola must take advantage of peace and reconciliation to most effectively utilize its vast natural resources -- assets that have lay dormant because of war.

We also recognize the new reality of the post-Cold War era: the emphasize is on trade and investment, not security matters. I say to you, one of our top priorities is to broaden and deepen bilateral relations -- particularly through trade and investment and in critical sectors -- communications, agriculture, fisheries, transportation, construction, finance and industrial development. With that in mind, let me make several important points.

Angola is in the process, with the guidance and assistance of Chevron, of resolving any outstanding obligations with the Export Import Bank. We already have a working agreement with the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. The Government is working hard to finalize a new accord with the International Monetary Fund and will then restructure its foreign debt with the Paris Club.

During my visit, I met, respectively, with the heads of the IMF and World Bank to ensure that we are working in a coordinated and cooperative manner with them. It is my hope and intention that these moves will establish and maintain Angola's credibility with the international financial community -- particularly the US. Simultaneously, Angola has passed a new foreign investment law that facilitates investment by providing the necessary guarantees to investors.

In addition, we permit private commercial banking. The 1994 foreign investment law permits foreign investors to transfer dividends, profits and proceeds abroad.

The liberalization of foreign exchange rates should expedite the repatriation of capital by improving access to foreign exchange. These concrete examples of reform demonstrate our desire to attract US trade and investment. I have stressed many of these same points in my talks at the White House, with leaders of Congress and others. During those talks, we discussed a number of initiatives that mesh well with the aforementioned steps that my Government has or is taking.

These initiatives included: cooperation with the Trade and Development Agency, additional support from ExImBank, a top-level trade mission in 1996, opening a AID office in Angola, specific education programs, democracy building, self-help programs, additional demining assistance, reciprocal liberalization of visa requirements and cultural exchanges.

Out talks produced tangible results and a basis on which to build. More broadly, I want to close by reiterating my Government's unqualified commitment to the following four goals: 1. Ensuring the success of the peace process.

2. Working with all US entities to rebuild Angola. 3. Improving bilateral relations.

4. Promoting economic, financial, and trade and investment ties with the US.

In accomplishing these goals, Angola needs your counsel and support. As we enter an era of peace and reconstruction in Angola, I know that I can count on you.

In that regard, the doors of the Angolan Government -- its Embassy in Washington, led by my close colleague and friend Ambassador Ndalu, and our ministries in Luanda -- are open to you.

In considering the situation in Angola, the future and the goals of my visit to the US, it strikes me that Angola has been at war for most of my adult life. For much of that time, relations between Washington and Luanda have been strained. I believe that the causes of those strains have largely passed.

The process of improving relations began on May 19, 1993 when the US extended official diplomatic relations to Angola. Today, President Clinton and I agreed that other problems that bedeviled the relationship have also passed. Most importantly, the war has ended and it is time to look ahead. In doing so, I want to provide you with my personal commitment to making sure that peace and democracy take hold and grow in Angola.

The same holds true for my commitment to broadening and deepening economic and financial ties. There are significant opportunities for US companies in Angola.

We want to work with you now to take advantage of them. Thank you very much for the opportunity to address this distinguished gathering this evening, an audience that includes many long-time friends and, I hope, new friends of Angola. It has been four years since my last visit to Washington. I am confident that this visit has been a success and I am certain that we will not have to wait another four years to meet again.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December, 1995


Arts The Magic Flute in an African Setting


LENGTH: 547 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995
by Coenraad Visser

Johannesburg - First KwaZulu-Natal gave us a Zulu Macbeth. Now, with equally striking effect, it gives us Mozart's The Magic Flute in an African setting. This production is the fledgling Opera Africa's debut. It is entirely fitting that it should transfer from the Playhouse in Durban to the Roodepoort stage, where so many enterprising productions showed the way for our grander opera companies. 

The Magic Flute is director Themi Venturas' first opera production. It was an inspired thought to set Mozart's mystical work in Africa, complete with the Queen of the Night as a sangoma (rather ironically sung by the only white face in a lead role amid an all- black cast). He is helped, too, by Patti Slavin's minimalist but arrestingly evocative sets.

A pity, then, that Venturas' production is so static, often in the worst operatic traditions of the past. And he still has to learn to pay attention to what happens in the score, and to the words sung. When Tamino recoils in horror of the snake at his feet, that is where the snake should be; not behind his back some metres away. There were far too many silly moments like this.

But what glorious voices to work with. Raphael Vilakazi is a characterful Papageno, completely at home on stage and in magnificent voice. Thokozani Mkhize is a winning Pamina, not as tenderly affecting as is the tradition, but fresh and youthful. Ruth Smith copes well with the Queen of the Night's ridiculously difficult coloratura. What she lacks in vocal ease she makes up in presence. As the three ladies, Bongi Simelane, Nozipho Mfayela and Bongiwe Khumalo are a constant delight, their voices blending beautifully.

Bongani Tembe fares better as Tamino than in the recent Italian season. But one's impression still remains of a small, bland voice which is overprojected. Mike Mkhize lacks the resonant lower register required of Sarastro, but it is surely merely a question of time before these notes appear.

The only real disappointment of the evening is the shocking playing of the Pro Musica Orchestra. The players mastered the overture nicely enough, but then lost all interest and concentration. Conductor Weiss Doubell, too, was strangely erratic, often abruptly changing tempi in mid-phrase, to the noticeable horror of the singers on stage.

This extraordinary production should be seen. After all, it may be a first glimpse of an exciting future for opera in this country.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December, 1995


Arts and Aids Cinema: Toe-tapping Aids Musical


LENGTH: 507 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995
by Justin Pearce

Johannesburg - The unique charms of Zero Patience can be gleaned from a quick run through of this film's musical numbers: a bluesy solo sung by a blonde, beehived HIV virus; a Victorian scientist, who has discovered the secret of eternal youth, delivering an ode to enlightenment values, called Let's All Be Empiricists; a chorus of stuffed jungle animals coming to life in their museum display case and protesting at being stigmatised as the first carriers of the immuno-deficiency virus.

In fact, the particular marriage of form and content -- a toe-tapping musical on the subject of Aids -- says a lot about this film's brand of irreverence. How it manages this without being completely tasteless is by focusing on the social malaise that surrounded the arrival of Aids in North America -- "an epidemic of blame", as one character calls it -- and turning the myths on their heads. At the time, much of the hysteria around Aids concerned a gay air steward, dubbed "Patient Zero", who was blamed for bringing the epidemic across the Atlantic. In the film, "Patient Zero" is reincarnated to challenge his accusers. 

The devices which Canadian director John Grayson uses in his cinematic expose provide much of the film's fascination -- the boldness of its execution leaves you breathless, the lurid colours and catchy tunes echoed by the in-your-face innovation of the plot. The 19th-century scientist finds himself a perfect niche as a perpetrator of Aids hysteria in modern Canada, implying that the old truisms about Victorian morality apply equally well to the late 20th century -- and suggesting what Victorian scientists might have got up to given the benefits of contemporary technology.

And yet the film is no circus, with an unlikely love story and a subplot concerning the travails of a schoolteacher with HIV bringing the metaphorical shennanigans down to earth.

Zero Patience is unashamedly activist filmmaking, which adds to its immediacy, but also means it doesn't travel well in space or time. Here in Africa, where no one has tried blaming Aids on an individual, the film's process of debunking carries less of a punch than it surely did in Canada. But Aids in Africa is no less cocooned in myths, even if they are different. Zero Patience is invigorating as a movie that knocks down sacred cows, and it does so without establishing any new idols of its own.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


134 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Arts and Aids New Exhibits Explores 'Living with Aids'


LENGTH: 1120 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995
by Hazel Friedman

Johannesburg - How can an illness be photographed when its symptoms -- until the final agonising stages -- are largely invisible? How can the struggle of those afflicted with this disease be adequately documented without resorting to sensationalism or stereotype? These are some of the questions confronted by award-winning South African photographer Gideon Mendel in Positive Lives: Responses to HIV -- an exhibition recording the impact of Aids on ordinary lives.

A member of the London-based Network group of photographers who curated the show, Mendel played a pivotal role in bringing it to this country. He is also the only South African photographer represented in an exhibition which -- through a series of vignettes photographed in different contexts -- reveals the impact of Aids on everyday lives.

Most visitors to the Johannesburg Art Gallery -- attendance figures at this venue have been appalling, compared to Cape Town's National Gallery, where the exhibition was first shown -- will be familiar with the background to the show. But many are probably unaware of the challenges involved in documenting the pandemic: the process of establishing trusting, confidential relationships with subjects, and the imperative of subsuming the photographic ego beneath honest, non- judgmental documentation. 

Although the term "documentary" carries with it the expectation of objectivity, the latter task is impossible to achieve, particularly when the subject is an illness shrouded in myth and fear. Yet, overall, the exhibition has succeeded in playing down the sentiment and focusing on the subject. And this is particularly the case with Mendel's work, which links the experiences of two countries -- England and South Africa -- provoking a reassessment of the prejudices surrounding the big disease with a small name.

Both essays produced by Mendel -- the first photographed in London hospital wards, the second taken in a predominantly rural context -- serve as quiet monuments to the courage of those who allowed themselves to be made visible.

"I included the South African component in the exhibition as a bridge of sorts," says Mendel, "because I wanted to form a thematic link between Aids in varying contexts. I felt it was important to articulate the different ways in which the disease affects different communities.

Mendel's London narrative is pictorially more successful than his South African project -- predictably, because it taps into the emotionally-charged aspects of the disease within a more contained, concentrated environment. Yet the photographs are far more than exercises in lump-in-throat documentation. They are testaments to intimate, loving and surprisingly comfortable (given Mendel's presence) moments between Aids patients and their loved ones. But, as empathetic as these works are, as Mendel admits, they cannot depict the process involved in gaining the consent of families who have learned to acknowledge the disease but not the sexual preference of their children; nor the dilemma of families and lovers torn between the desire to preserve epitaphs to the dead and the need to erase them.

"In situations like this, you are not dealing simply with the wishes of the patient but of those who are left behind with their grief. They are often filled with conflicting motions, and the photographer is inevitably caught between respecting their privacy and the need to educate the public. In situations like this, the photographer cannot completely escape the role of intruder and voyeur."

Mendel describes the South African project as "extremely tough -- probably the most difficult photographic assignment I've ever undertaken -- but incredibly fulfilling. It is definitely the beginning of an ongoing journey."

Words like "access" and "education" pepper his recollections. "The need for both," he explains, "has resulted in the transformation of Positive Lives into a mobile exhibition which will be taken to townships and rural communities around the country. By looking at these images and reading the stories of suffering and courage, hopefully people will be able to understand the disease in a new, demystified light."

Mendel's photographic trajectory took him through the South African hinterland, documenting workshops on Aids prevention attended by traditional healers and interacting with Aids fieldworkers who had transformed their affliction into an opportunty for educating their communities and eradicating the stigma of Aids.

Although a picture is supposed to paint a thousand words, or so the clich_ goes, an exhibition of this nature is inevitably dependent for clarity on written contextualisation. Although Mendel attempts, as far as possible, to let the photographs speak for themselves, the fact that they cannot do so without an accompanying text does not demean the potency of the images. For in their ordinariness and, in parts, seeming lack of specificity, they challenge the notion that Aids only touches certain faces.

Through the eyes of a baby who has never felt the touch of a naked hand, the actions of an HIV-positive fieldworker who preaches the gospel of the condom, and the expression of a domestic worker abandoned by her loved ones, Mendel effectively communicates the banality and ubiquitousness of an illness that is blind to colour, class or sexual preference -- a disease that has imposed a death sentence through the most primal and life-affirming of all acts.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


135 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


South Africa Constitution Writing Fans Gender Debate


LENGTH: 1320 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995
by Etienne Mureinik

Johannesburg - Is the Constitution good for women? Both the interim Constitution and the final one now being written are constitutions to undo apartheid and its legacy.

The ideal of equality is therefore a central constitutional value, and it is widely agreed that the Bill of Rights should entrench that ideal strongly.

One consequence of that agreement is an equality guarantee that outlaws both sex and gender discrimination by name.

But the apparent consensus about gender equality is often superficial. Beneath the surface, there are serious tensions between gender equality and traditions followed in many South African communities. 

Much of the debate has concentrated on the friction between gender equality and traditions in African customary law, such as polygyny, lobola, and male-only traditional leadership.

But there is as much friction between gender equality and important rules of religious systems, such as the Jewish law of divorce, the Muslim rules of inheritance, and the Catholic men-only priesthood. Why, then, is there so much more focus on African customary law?

Not, surely, because religion and custom are profoundly different. Many of the religious rules antagonistic to gender equality derive their force as much from tradition as from faith. And some rules of customary law may be as sacrosanct to their adherents, and carry as much spiritual meaning, as many religious rules.

The better explanation for the difference is that customary law has been put under the constitutional spotlight by its own champions. It is because traditional leaders have demanded that customary law be recognised and reinforced by the Constitution that the question attracts attention.

When you demand that the Constitution lend its authority to a system of law, you immediately raise the question of how compatible that system is with the Constitution -- including its guarantee of equality.

Religious communities such as Catholics and Jews have avoided that issue by keeping their distance from the Constitution. But the traditional leaders have invited scrutiny of their practices by seeking constitutional endorsement.

So although custom may be receiving more attention in the constitution-making process than religion, both kinds of traditional rules, religious and customary, raise the same essential question: whether the ideal of equality affects all law universally, or is subject to exceptions.

Some argue that gender equality is a western secular idea, and that to impose it on non- western or religious traditions is cultural imperialism.

In fact the difference between western secular law and the now-controversial traditions is largely a question of timing and degree. A century or so ago, the antipathy of western secular law towards gender equality was as marked as that of much current customary and religious law.

What is more, the power of the idea of gender equality comes not from external imposition, but from the internal logic of any system of law which aspires to do justice. Western secular law found that to achieve the kind of justice it wanted, it had to start taking the ideal of equality between men seriously.

Once it started doing that, it became difficult to explain why it was not also treating men and women equally. And then gender discriminatory rules started crumbling. Western secular law has been going through this process for a long time, and has made much progress towards gender equality.

That internal logic has the same force in religious and customary law. To achieve justice, those legal systems also need to take the idea of equality seriously, and religious or customary communities which have suffered discrimination feel that need especially keenly. But progress towards gender equality in those systems has been slower because they change more slowly.

Religious law changes more slowly just because it is thought to have divine authority. And the capacity of customary law to change has been impaired by colonial and apartheid interventions. The result is an urgent need to compress a process that has taken decades in western secular law into a very short period.

How effectively does the Constitution assist that process?

When the interim Constitution was being written at Kempton Park, the debate focused on a demand by traditional leaders for a clause explicitly exempting African customary law from the guarantee of equality.

That demand inspired women from several political parties to unite in a cross-party coalition which defeated the clause. But having spent itself on that effort, the women's coalition lacked the energy to deal with other features of the interim Constitution which still have the potential to undermine their victory.

One such feature is a serious ambiguity about how much of customary law is covered by the interim Bill of Rights, and its guarantee of equality.

It is clear that the Bill's coverage includes written customary law, for instance customs codified into regulations made under a statute. But it is less clear that the coverage includes unwritten customary law -- pure custom handed down by word of mouth.

The working draft of the final Constitution published recently clears up this ambiguity, making it clear that the coverage of the Bill of Rights is plenary.

The draft deals effectively also with the religious dimension of this issue.

The freedom-of-religion clause in the interim Constitution now in force contains a sub- clause insulating legislation recognising systems of religious personal and family law from challenge under the constitutional guarantee of equality. However, the drafters of the final Constitution have (in both senses of the word) emasculated that sub-clause by deploying an ingenious drafting device.

It is now becoming clear that equality is a sovereign value, prevailing over any system of traditional law enjoying constitutional reinforcement. The effect will be to energise the process of reviewing traditional systems of law for compatibility with gender equality.

Etienne Mureinik is a professor of law at Wits University


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


136 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Business 'A Day in the Life of Cyberspace' Planned for February


LENGTH: 787 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995
by Annicia Reddiar

Johannesburg - On February 8 1996, more than 100 professional photojournalists from around the world will be working on a 24-hour project to find the pictures that tell the story of how the Internet has changed people's lives.

This is Rick Smolan's new 24-hour project. But it's nothing like the usual projects with which his name is synonymous -- images of specific places or happenings photographed over a 24-hour period and published in book form. This time, it's for instantaneous release on the Internet and, instead of a specific place, the images will cover the globe. 

In a single day, Smolan's multimedia company Against All Odds Productions (which Fortune magazine calls "one of America's 25 coolest technology companies"), will put up a World Wide Web site and co-ordinate the digital transmission of photographs which show how cyberspace is changing people's lives. Called 24 Hours in Cyberspace, Smolan believes it will put a human face on the digital revolution.

Smolan is better known for his Day in the Life book series, photographic books which present and express a specific 24 hours in a country or culture. For example, his book Passage to Vietnam covers the day the United States trade embargo was lifted. But 24 Hours in Cyberspace is a first of its kind for him, as well as the 'Net. It will be the largest online event ever produced, and will be about people's experiences with this technology, visually and interactively.

Anyone with access to the Internet will be asked to send in their story of how the information superhighway has affected their life, and some of these stories will go up on the site together with the pictures. And the more bizarre the tales, the better, like the story of the Wall Street lawyer who answers legal questions of non-profit organisations at 3am for free, and the blind America On Line forum hostess, who has used the 'Net to make friends around the world.

Smolan believes that this takes his 24-hour photographic projects into a new dimension. "We have spent the past 12 years travelling around the world, documenting different cultures," he says, "We were in China during the Tiananmen Square uprising, the Soviet Union at the birth of glasnost and in Vietnam last year as the trade embargo was lifted. For us, cyberspace is another culture and place to visit, but this time around, because of the nature of the new medium itself, people can actively take part in the project, and respond with their own point of view."

A group of editors, designers and programmers will set up the Web site on Febuary 8 as soon as the picture and story transmissions come through to the project's headquarters in San Francisco, updating it throughout the day. Cyberspace will be the featured event at the opening of the Internet 1996 World Exhibition.

On March 15, a permanent World Wide Web site will be set up with in-depth stories, photo essays and commentaries. And, towards the end of next year, a 24 Hours in Cyberspace book, CD-ROM, television documentary, and a weekly news issue will be released.

A large group of companies are behind the project. Eastman Kodak Company, Sun Microsystems Inc, and Adobe Systems Inc have underwritten Cyberspace. Applied Graphics Technology, Illustra Information Technologies, NetObjects, CE Software and Now Software will provide the extra technical support. And Clement Mok designs will design the 24 Hours in Cyberspace web site.

A provisional web site with 24 Hours in Cyberspace details can be found at www.cyber.24.com/ and another site will soon be put up at http://www.Cyber24.com which will serve as an info site on the project.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


137 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Business South African Gold Giant Goes International


LENGTH: 1547 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995
by Karen Harverson

Johannesburg - Gencor's transformation from an unwieldy conglomerate with a myriad of unrelated interests into an international mining group, focused on mining and metals, has been accomplished with aplomb.

Through the foresight of Derek Keys, appointed chairman in 1980, whose plans were carried out by successor Brian Gilbertson, the group has become the world's leading producer of ferrochrome, one of the largest platinum producers, the biggest exporter of steamcoal, a major gold producer and a leading source of titanium minerals.

Gencor's revamped headquarters in Hollard Street are a worthy emblem of an organisation whose star is rising and which boasts a reputation as one of the world's premier mining houses.

The high-tech, marble, glass and perspex building, completed in mid-95, is a far cry from the poorly lit, cramped quarters -- reminiscent of the civil service -- which greeted visitors in the not too distant past. 

Now the place is suffused with light, pouring into the centre of an atrium as if to epitomise the enlightened route taken by Gencor.

But do its new image and business direction extend to its internal policies? Has the company, long regarded as an Afrikaaner powerhouse and the most conservative of all mining houses in South Africa, embraced the external changes in the country within its internal workings?

Judging by the number of senior black managers and women appointed at both head office and its subsidiaries, it still has some way to go. Only 4,5 percent of upper middle management are black, while a mere two percent make up top management.

An affirmative action policy is in place which focuses on advancing employees through training programmes plus looking at the recruitment of black candidates externally.

"We are trying to create accelerated career paths for people who have the potential but have for various reasons been overlooked," says general manager (corporate strategy) Mike Roussos.

He adds that there is a lot of opportunity for high-potential black candidates to advance as the new dynamic and entrepreneurial Gencor puts less emphasis on seniority and long service and becomes more achievement-focused.

But the pool of black employees suitable for advanced training and that of external candidates with mining experience is fairly small.

Gencor is decentralised into operating companies Samancor, Ingwe, Implats, Gengold, Alusaf and Billiton with each responsible for its own human resource development.

"We do have a system in place to track people with potential within the group as a whole, to expose them to different opportunities, and keep abreast of their progress," says Roussos.

But Gencor's harshest critic -- the labour movement -- scoffs at the group's affirmative action policy. "There is no real transformation in relation to people," says National Union of Mineworkers assistant general secretary Gwede Mantashe.

While acknowledging the group's progress, he says despite efforts to appoint black managers, the jobs are without real authority. He adds that the attitude of head office may have changed dramatically but at mine level there is no change -- "the old guard is still in place."

So how soon before blacks reach executive status. Apart from the controversial inclusion of Mantashe on Samancor's board, no firm targets and time frames have been set to promote black managers or recruit outside candidates on to the executive board.

"It's been a long debate," says Roussos. "While some believe it is important to get a few black people on to board level as soon as possible even if it is not representative of things happening lower down, others feel it is more important to give employees more say in influencing decisions through participatory structures."

He believes that many support the idea of giving a black candidate, already at senior level in the company, the opportunity to advance into an executive position "by growing through the system" rather than just recruiting someone from outside.

Group manager Sam Mkhabela agrees that a programme that will lead to a capable black person on the board of directors is a good idea, "but at the same time -- I don't see such a programme in place with specific targets being set at present".

Eric Ratshikhopha, one of two black top-level senior managers at Gencor believes targets must be set -- "if only to measure one's progress".

Other managers feel Gencor does not disclose enough information to them as individuals. "You just work -- you don't know if what you're doing will lead to better things." While Gencor's emphasis on training programmes to equip blacks with the necessary skills is praised, some criticise the programmes as "delaying tactics" to avoid placing blacks in positions.

Ingwe marketing manager Sipho Nkosi believes the setting of targets is vital but at the end of the day Gencor must work. "If in 10 years' time, Gilbertson is better than another candidate -- black or white -- he must remain chairman."

Another perspective is that most suitable black candidates outside the organisation may be serving on a number of boards already and thus couldn't commit to Gencor 100 percent.

Humphrey Oliphant, the other top-level senior manager, agrees the organisation should look internally for a suitable candidate, but if not available, "there's nothing wrong with Oshopping outside' for one". Resentment only occurs when people in the company are disregarded in terms of career pathing, which doesn't happen in Gencor.

Ratshikhopha says despite his 14-year climb through the ranks of the organisation, it will not take other blacks that long to reach his position.

"Judging by Gencor's statements and actions, one tends to believe that being black is not an obstacle to succeeding."

Oliphant says Gencor has undergone changes both at head office and at the operational level, particularly in companies like Samancor and Ingwe.

He describes Gencor's affirmative action policy as liberal but says while it aims to equip black personnel with skills, it fails to address the problems of white personnel who are in positions for which they are under- skilled.

He describes Gilbertson as a "mover and a shaker" who puts pressure on people to define their roles. "There's a fresh wind blowing through Gencor -- people are constantly moved between head office and operations so there's no dead wood lying around ... or unassailable comfort zones."

One of the few black women managers, Manoko Nchwe of Samancor, says transformation began with Keys' commitment to include all stakeholders in the decision-making of the group. "There's been a fundamental change in terms of how people relate to one another within the organisation and how issues which impact on the quality of life of employees are dealt with."

At Samancor, Nchwe says, the company has switched from total management control to participatory forums.

On Gencor culture, Ntche believes change is slow but is happening. "Meetings are held in English but do lapse into Afrikaans which many blacks can't understand but there has been an attempt to open up. For there to be a culture change, there has to be sensitivity to the other people's interests."

Ntche says it's quite exciting to see an essentially Afrikaaner affirmative action group moving to become an integrated South African company.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


138 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Science Mandela Administration Sychronizes Data Watches and Computers


LENGTH: 627 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995
by Leon Perlman

Johannesburg - Following the move to electronic on-line communication with the masses, pioneered by the Constitutional Assembly, the Ministry of Post and Telecommunications, African National Congress MPs and the Constitutional Court, the offices of the president and deputy presidents have also become neophyte technophiles. A paperless office system is being implemented along with use of unique Windows-compatible Timex data watches.

The two offices have standardised on PC-based applications for tasks ranging from word- processing, database management, scheduling of appointments to electronic mail (e-mail) connectivity between departments. The executive had previously been using outdated mainframe-based software, including an antiquated Wang word-processor. A new e-mail system is being used extensively. 

According to John Foonk, director of administration of Deputy President FW de Klerk's office, there was an urgent need to move to a paperless office: "It's more effective. Managers now use the e-mail system to disseminate management decisions to personnel and invite feedback later."

The system has proved its worth in circumstances where directors, in Cape Town for the parliamentary system, want to communicate with the staff located in Pretoria. An external electronic "post office" has been installed to allow the separate -- but equal -- data networks of the offices of Nelson Mandela and De Klerk to communicate electronically via e-mail.

De Klerk's office is also using a state-of- the-art wrist watch as a portable diary. The Dick Tracy-like Timex Data link watches keep track of appointments, tasks and telephone numbers. There are also a number of alarms and anniversary storage facilities. De Klerk's private secretary, his head of the office, and two other staff members all have the watches.

The information is created using Microsoft's Schedule+ Personal Information Manager and sent via a PC screen to the watch without the need for any physical connection.

The watch has a special optical eye which picks up various line configurations generated on the PC screen, a process analogous to a bar code reader in a supermarket checkout. Users simply hold the watch up to the screen and hit the transmit button on the PC. The data is then transmitted to the watch.

"The technology fits our needs perfectly. Both Deputy President De Klerk and Mrs de Klerk's diaries are managed via Schedule+ and the watch," says Foonk.

Instead of printing out appointment schedules or keeping a physical diary, the scheduling information is simply "downloaded" to the watch.

Asked why De Klerk himself does not use the watch, Foonk revealed that the deputy president cannot.

"He's good at all other things, but he's not technically minded," he said.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


139 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Business Foreign investment in South Africa Keeps Rising


LENGTH: 720 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995
by Simon Segal

Johannesburg - Evidence is mounting that foreign investment in South Africa is picking up and could well be higher than popular perception has it. Information services group BusinessMap SA, the only known source to be developing a database that monitors foreign investment, calculates that since the elections last April some R8,5- billion has been committed by foreign firms in investment money.

Of this, R6-billion has been committed this year, indicating the trend. 

These monies are only committed and thus their final numbers will change. They are committed over a period of a few years. The figures are thus not fully comprehensive, based only on press reports, but they are nevertheless an indicator of a trend.

The numbers, notes BusinessMap, are almost certainly an underestimate as many deals are announced where figures are undisclosed.

The largest investments are from Malaysian group Landmark Berhad (who have announced an investment of R500- to R700 million), Nestl_ (R600 million over three years) and Samsung (R600 million over five years).

BusinessMap's trend is borne out by the Washington-based investment monitoring group Investor Responsibility Research Centre (IRRC) which reports "a surge of US business activity in South Africa since January".

Some five new US firms per month are opening offices or placing employees in South Africa. This is the highest rate since US firms began to return to South Africa in 1991 after years of disinvestment. In that year there were 104 US firms involved in South Africa, compared to 280 at its peak in 1985.

There are now a total 235 US firms with equity ties or employees in SouthAfrica.

Since July, 12 US firms have invested or committed to invest over $200 million in South Africa. These include household brands such as McDonald's ($5,5 million), Nike and Levi Strauss ($9 million).

"Not only are US companies establishing operations in South Africa at a record rate, but they are also banking that popular consumer goods and services, such as Big Mac and Levi's, will have strong marketability in South Africa," states the report.

IRRC director Meg Voorhes cites four factors behind this trend -- economic growth, the strong response to major US brands, government pledges to reduce tariffs and global competition.

Despite this improving trend, foreign investment is still small relative to the size of the economy (not even two percent of the gross domestic product). It is not yet being converted into the type of large-scale, long- term investments that will substantially expand the economy's productive capacity that creates jobs and wealth.

Most firms setting up in South Africa are still largely confining their involvement to setting up branch offices. Some have assumed direct control of distributorship. Others have entered through non-equity ties such as licensing and distribution agreements.

Still by far the largest foreign monies invested in South Africa are in short-term portfolio flows. In the first 11 months of this year a net R4,5-billion was bought (purchases were R22-billion and sales were R17,5-billion) on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, compared to R185 million last year.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December, 1995


South Africa Apartheid-Era Civil Servants Weigh Heavy on the Budget


LENGTH: 667 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995
by Lynda Loxton

Johannesburg - Nearly two years after South Africa's April elections, many government departments are still struggling to rid themselves of the detritus of apartheid and emerge as sleek and efficient operations.

The process, unfortunately, is costing South African taxpayers millions of rands either in redundancy packages or in keeping on staff from the former homelands who have no work to do but do not want to move to other areas.

In fact, Public Service and Administration Minister Zola Skweyiya told a press conference last week that the government is sometimes hard put to say exactly how many civil servants South Africa has on its payroll. 

These issues were discussed during a two-day hearing by the parliamentary public service and administration committee and highlights the testing task that awaits the newly- appointed presidential commission of inquiry into the rationalisation of the public service.

Home Affairs Director General Piet Colyn told the committee that it had, for example, been difficult to amalgamate officials from the former Transkei into one national home affairs department.

"We need 49 people in Umtata but we have nearly 300 ... people come to work and are frustrated because there is no work for them and this leads to dissatisfaction and strikes," Colyn said.

But for housing, family and other reasons, most of these employees refused to accept transfers to other parts of the country unless they were offered substantially improved salary packages, which was out of the question as far as the Public Service Commission (PSC) was concerned.

The solution was to offer redundancy packages, which were not cheap either.

Trade and Industry Director of Administration Emma Ramaema told the committee that 90 percent of the staff that had been inherited from the former homelands "we do not have much use for", because their skills did not match those that were needed.

The committee heard similar tales from other government departments as well as bitter complaints about the Public Service Commission's "inflexibility" about offering competitive salary packages for professionals.

As a result, they did not have professionals in key areas, which was affecting their efficiency and efforts to radically restructure their operations to meet the needs of the new South Africa.

"It has become a priority for the PSC to be transformed as an institution," committee chairwoman Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka said.

It had to be more flexible both in terms of salaries for professionals and in terms of the paper qualifications required for certain posts.

Housing Director General Billy Cobbett was outspoken on the latter. He said the apartheid system had kept many people out of formal education, but many had notched up years of experience in areas such as housing and would be an asset to government. The PSC, however, had other ideas.

Mlambo-Ngcuka said her committee was considering the experiences of countries such as the Philippines, New Zealand and Namibia in restructuring their civil services.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December, 1995


South Africa Cabinet Minister Buthelezi Was Nearly Arrested With General


LENGTH: 920 words


 
Mail and Guardian (Johannesburg)
December 8, 1995

Johannesburg - Home Affairs Minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi came close to being arrested and charged with the KwaMakhutha murders, according to sources involved in the investigation.

Buthelezi's name appears several times in the documents that describe events leading to the formation of the Caprivi 200, the hit-squad unit whose members allegedly massacred 13 civilians in 1987.

Most important is a meeting that took place on November 25 1985 between General Tienie Groenewald, then chief director of military intelligence, and the Inkatha leader. The indictment says Buthelezi, fearing plans by African National Congress supporters to "eliminate him and neutralise Inkatha", asked Groenewald to provide him with protection, information and a military capacity. 

The indictment contains an excerpt from a 1984 speech made by Buthelezi in the KwaZulu Legislative Assembly which says: "We must prepare ourselves to hit back with devastating force at those who destroy our property and kill us."

It adds that Groenewald presented Buthelezi's requests to Malan and reccommended the South African Defence Force should train "a defensive unit of 50-100 men and an offensive unit of 10-20 men (on a covert basis) for Buthelezi and Inkatha".

An extraordinary State Security Council meeting was called the next day where "Ministers (Chris) Heunis and (Louis) Le Grange were mandated to assist Buthelezi in creating a security force for KwaZulu".

The indictment says the State Security Council had initial reservations about the paramilitary offensive unit "and it was then resolved that that aspect be investigated at the highest political level and be cleared with Buthelezi".

During a further round of discussions with Groenewald, on February 12 1986, Buthelezi requested the SADF to provide him with a "contra-mobilisation capability", an "offensive capability (or defensive element)" and an "intelligence capability".

The state's indictment alleges that in April 1986 Malan asked his chief of staff intelligence, Vice-Admiral Andries Putter, to "sell" the covert aspect of the plan to Buthelezi. If this was successful, implementation of the scheme would proceed in collaboration with Buthelezi's aide, MZ Khumalo. Putter's job was to "explain to Buthelezi that the minister of defence (Malan) had sent him because it was (Malan's) wish to implement the plan for a paramilitary force without delay."

A top-secret document attached to the indictment says: "Offensive element: the task of this group is to set up a small group of well-trained troops for Inkatha that can be used offensively against the ANC, UDF (United Democratic Front) and related organisations. Further this group can be used as a personal bodyguard unit for the Chief Minister (Buthelezi) in his capacity as President of Inkatha when the SAP is not able to protect him".

The Mail & Guardian has additional information -- supplied in an affidavit made by a defector from the Caprivi 200 group who is not on the witness list -- that describes in detail how the group was trained by SADF special forces officers in offensive warfare techniques.

The informant, who cannot be named because he fears for his life, explains the group received further training at a farm near Pretoria after returning to South Africa from the Caprivi Strip.

"The day for us to leave Pretoria came. We left in a removals truck. We were escorted by a small car with four whites (in it). It was doing surveillance. We were taken back to Nhlungwane (a camp in KwaZulu-Natal). Dr Buthelezi came to meet us. He was accompanied by Brigadier Mathe and Zakhele Khumalo, his assistant in Inkatha. He received us. An ox was slaughtered."

This affidavit adds that Caprivi fighter Vela Mchunu was involved in the murder of union shop stewards at Mpophomeni near Howick (see accompanying story). After this killing "he (Mchunu) went to hide at Ulundi and was received by Zakhele Khumalo, Chief Buthelezi's assistant who is in charge of Inkatha offices".

Sources close to the investigation say there was a real possibility that Buthelezi would be charged because of the information contained in the secret document. However, because the investigative team wanted to build a watertight case -- and because technical details were missing -- it was decided to leave him off the charge sheet.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

December, 1995


Zambia Apathy Slows Start of Voter Registration


LENGTH: 427 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 15, 1995
by Reuben Phiri and Mabeni Sikalyabwanda

Lusaka - Observers of the voters registration exercise are disappointed at the apathy exhibited by people in the last three days throughout the country. Rob Black, the Zambia programme director for the National Democratic Institute (NDI) for International Affairs in the United States, said the apathy was an indication that the exercise lacked publicity.

"It was disheartening to see registration officials prepared to proceed with the exercise while the government was failing to assist. "For democracy to be nurtured people should be made aware of the power to vote , which without proper government publicity, robs the nation of good governance," Black said in Livingstone yesterday. 

Black, who is head of NDI, an American based NGO which is supporting the exercise, said voting should be encouraged and that the government has a critical role to ensure that this was attained. He was in Livingstone with the Zambia Independent Monitoring Team (ZIMT) president Alfred Zulu.

Black criticised the elections office for under paying the registration workers, saying the money they are being offered is too little for the sacrifice the people involved are making. In Lusaka the exercise will resume today after the pay and allowance dispute had been resolved. The pay was increased from K500 a day to K2,500 a day.

And National Party member of parliament for Senanga Inonge Mbikusita- Lewanika yesterday said the registration of voters should be suspended until national registration cards are issued to all people who have attained the age of eighteen and those who have lost them. Lewanika charged in a statement yesterday the "government was aware that many persons, particularly in rural areas, had not been able to obtain NRC's.

"Zambians want to exercise their right to vote, therefore issuing of NRC's is a pre-requisite to the registration of voters," she said. "The current planned mockery of registration of voters should be stopped."

Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Column: Race for Ruling Party VP Heats Up


LENGTH: 760 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 15, 1995
by Carolyn Mwanza

Lusaka - The most interesting battle in the forthcoming MMD elections for members of the National Executive Committee at the MMD Convention will be for the post of Vice-President.

This is not because the outcome of the election will give an indication as who will lead the party after President Chiluba or if Chiluba gets disqualified as a result of the serious questions being raised about his origin. But rather, the result will betray the party's folly in succumbing to ethnic pressures which has led to block voting based on regional tribal lines. 

As a result of that shortsightedness, the party is most likely to end up with a vice-president without an identifiable personal following, with neither material nor financial resources to offer the party, highly detested and suspected by his ministerial colleagues, stubborn and only willing to play with others on his rules.That candidate is Republican Vice-President Brigadier General Godfrey Miyanda.

The political scenario that has evolved in the MMD as a result of tribal balancing and block voting has relegated the vice-presidency post as it is now dependent on, and will be determined by, whoever gets elected as secretary-general of the party.

Of the four candidates who have publicly declared their intentions to contest the secretary-general post, Newstead Zimba is most unlikely to win, as it will be unacceptable to all to have the presidency and the second most powerful post in the party in the hands of trade union people. King Cobra Michael Sata also doesn't stand a chance. His uncharacteristic silence in recent weeks does not mean that his roguish and mischievous activities are at world behind the scenes. It is unlikely that the party will allow two people from the same Bemba speaking tribal grouping to dominate it.

Therefore, the post of secretary-general is most likely to be taken by Southern Province, either Vernon Mwaanga or Frederick Hapunda could best be elected. Hapunda, as matters stand now, appears to have an edge because Southern Province can trade him with other provinces in line with the block voting arrangements.

Therefore, Luminzu Shima-ponda will not stand a chance to win the vice-presidency as the party, conscious of tribal balancing, will not accept having the secretary-general and vice-president from the same region or tribal grouping.

Miyanda could therefore become party vice-president by default. It is possible that certain influencial people in the party realise this possibility and are most uncomfortable with the prospect. When B.Y. Mwila recently accused Miyanda of being short on integrity, it was more out of fear of the man whom he saw, with nothing to offer, occupying a more presitigious position in the party. It was certainly not intended to block the ascendancy of Miyanda as no proof of that shortage of integrity was given, it was a cry of a frustrated man who realises that his wealth and influence in the party cannot alter certain realities.

Of the other vice-presidential candidate, Christon Tembo, his chances against Miyanda are minimal. Both are Easterners and the East cannot trade any candidate because it has nothing to offer the party in view of the strong UNIP influence in the area.

Miyanda's chances against Tembo arise from the fact that Miyanda elicits certain emotions in people which make them feel he could have a sobering influence on the excesses of his ministerial collegues, and for that, he could beat Tembo hands down.

In this whole scenario, I hope I can be proved wrong.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


144 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Business Measures to Boost Zambian Stock Issues and Safeguard Deposits


LENGTH: 1054 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 15, 1995
by Sipo Kapumba

Lusaka - A Lusaka stock broker has advised the government to liaise closely with pension fund mangers each time new shares are being floated to the public to avoid under subscription of such shares.

Nduba Namoonde, general manager of Finance Securities Limited of Lusaka, said this yesterday in reaction to The Post's revelation on Wednesday that only 60 per cent of the Rothmans of Pall Mall shares which were offered to the public had been bought.

He said pension funds like the Zambia National Provident Fund, Mukuba Pension Scheme and the Civil Service Pension Fund have a lot of money which they could invest in shares but are unable to do so sometimes due to short notice.

"The floatation should be planned in such a way that fund managers are given enough time to refer issues of their participation to their respective boards for approval," he said. 

Sources have attributed the under subscription of the Rothmans of Pall Mall shares, which were offered on November 6, to non-participation of pension funds in the offer. That is partly attributed to the recent turmoil in the banking sector which saw the collapse of Africa Commercial, Commerce Bank and Cooperative banks.

Namoonde said another reason the Rothmans shares did not do very well was that most people were disappointed with the fall in Chilanga Cement shares from K65 when they were issued in May to K58 at present.

He remarked that the under subscription of the Rothmans shares means that there will be less of a demand once they are listed on the exchange, possibly today if all goes according to plan.

The Rothmans offer closed on December 4 and a total of 30,238,848 shares were on sale to the public. They represented 18.75 per cent of the total shares and they were held by the Zambia Industrial and Mining Corporation on behalf of the government.

Lusaka Stock Exchange general manager Charles Mate said in an interview on Monday that the drop in Chilanga shares was due to a slump in the economy which resulted in little demand for cement in the building industry. However, he said in the long run investment in stocks had proved to be a better hedge against inflation because the returns generally out performed other options.

Meanwhile, a group of indigenous banks and financial institutions has proposed the creation of a deposit protection scheme to safeguard customers' money in the event of bank problems.

The scheme will be financed by the banks, who have tentatively agreed to contribute one per cent of their total monthly deposits to the fund which could be used to pay depositors in the event that any of them closed. Included in the group are Chase Trust, First Alliance, Credit Africa, First Merchant, Manifold, Prudence and Safe Deposit banks while the financial institutions are Unifinance and Union Leasing.

Safe Deposit Bank managing director Ramaswamy Chan-drasekhar said in an interview yesterday that the fund was meant to restore public confidence in local banks which had been shaken by the collapse of Meridien BIAO, Africa Commercial, Commerce and Cooperative banks in the last few months. He said that in addition to the scheme, the banks intend to work out a mechanism to reduce the period of clearing local cheques to one day from the current four.

Another objective of the group, which is simply called a "coordinating committee," is to promote exchange of information which should reduce the possibility of multiple-borrowing embezzlement and fraud.

Chandrasekhar said the government could play a leading role in restoring confidence in local banks by continuing to maintain deposits with local banks instead of withdrawing just because others had failed. He also called for stricter banking supervision coupled with timely action to prevent banks from collapsing.

Credit Africa Bank managing director Ben Muntanga, who is chairman of the group, said local banks have "special needs" which they need to address themselves."Amongst ourselves we could arrange to have cheques cleared fast to improve our service to customers and in the process get a better market share," he said.

He said that unlike the large multi-national banks whose customers are mainly multi-national companies and big corporations, local banks serve mostly small depositors and emerging local companies whose needs are quite peculiar.

Muntanga said the group would not be a rival to the bankers association but would complement it. Bank of Zambia spokesman Kabinga Pande said BOZ was aware of the group's formation, adding that the members must have had a good reason to form it. And commenting on the depositors' insurance scheme which BOZ is working out, he said it is a long process which requires consultation and detailed study before recommendations are tabled to the government.

BOZ governor Jacob Mwanza told a group of journalists last week that the central bank was working out the scheme but did not indicate when it would be in operation.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English
