Africa News


December, 1995


South Africa Mandela On Foreign Relations And Support For ANC


LENGTH: 440 words


 
Africa News Service
December 12, 1995

Johannesburg - Statement Issued by the Office of President
Nelson Mandela.

The President's Office has noted that speculation continues in
the media regarding South Africa's foreign relations and how these
are impacted upon by financial assistance that may have been
received by the ANC. 

In particular, reference has been made to the President's and
the government's approach to the People's Republic of China and
Taiwan, Morocco and the Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic, the
situation in Nigeria, as well as Indonesia and East Timor.

The President wishes to reiterate that South Africa's foreign
policy is based on the government's assessment of our country's
interests and our principled stance on issues of human rights, demoprocess of setting up formal relations with any country is undertaken within the context of these considerations, and in
cracy, development and equitable relations among all states. The
consultation with all interested parties.

In his capacity as leader of the ANC, President Mandela has
indeed raised funds to ensure that this organisation discharges its
functions, a process which has made it possible for South Africa to
undergo the transition that we have achieved. Such funds, and other
forms of support, have been acquired from virtually all countries
that the President has visited or interacted with - including the
countries which are alleged in media reports to have been
disadvantaged in comparison with others on account of some pecuniary
considerations.

We hope that the media will handle these matters with
circumspection, and ensure, at least, that clarification is sought
with relevant government structures, before such serious allegations
are made.

LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


166 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Business U.S.-Backed Black Investment Firm Gets Joburg Listing


LENGTH: 520 words


 
Africa News Service
December 15, 1995
by Reed Kramer

Durham, NC - When shares of Umbono Investment Corporation began trading Friday on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange (JSE), the Durham-based Sloan Financial Group chalked up another breakthrough in Africa.

Umbono is the first company to be listed in the new JSE "financial
redevelopment" sector, which was established to support President Nelson Mandela's economic recovery effort, known as the Reconstruction and Development Program. Two years ago, Sloan established the first black-owned investment management firm in South Africa, New Africa Advisers. Earlier this year Sloan and the Maryland-based Calvert Group launched the Calvert New Africa Fund, the first open-ended mutual fund with a portfolio devoted to Africa. Calvert New Africa is the principal founding investor in Umbono, along with several other Calvert funds. 

The Sloan Financial Group, was founded in 1991 by Maceo K. Sloan, who also chairs New Africa Advisers, a Sloan subsidiary headed by Justin F. Beckett.

With an initial offering of just over 5 million shares, priced at 10 Rand each, Umbono will have a market value of about 51 million Rand, or $14 million. The firm, whose name means "vision" in Zulu, one of South Africa's principal languages, will concentrate on unlisted and closely-held companies in six industries, including consumer products, health care, non-capital intensive manufacturing, tourism, telecommunications and services.

"By investing in firms with black shareholders and in the fastest-growing sector of the economy, the black consumer market, Umbono will promote the reconstruction and development program while also exploiting enormous investment opportunities," said Charles Allison, Umbono managing director.

Allison, who has worked for Merrill Lynch, James D. Wolfenson Inc. and J. P. Morgan, moved to South Africa in late 1993 to direct the New Africa Advisers office. Andrew Mari, a Zimbabwean-born finance professional who has also been working for New Africa Advisers, is the other member of the Umbono management.

Umbono hopes to expand by 100 million Rand over the next twelve months and to obtain an minimum compounded return of 25 percent. "Once we show that these returns are achievable, we expect to raise at least half of our finds from local institutions," Allison said.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


167 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Donors Tie Aid to Good Governance


LENGTH: 680 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 19, 1995
by Chilombo Mwondela

London - The government has to achieve tangible prog- ress on the governance agenda and maintain the economic reform programme for Zambia to be granted the much needed US $300 million balance of payments support. These are the donor demands, according to a World Bank report of December15. World Bank director for southern Africa, Kathreen Marshall, said in an interview prior to a press conference that Zambia's external financing needs have been "particularly demanding in the past four years". At the press conference in London discussing the recent Consultative Group(CG) meeting for Zambia which ended in Bournemouth, UK, last Friday, Marshall said many donors were concerned about what she described as "political and governance issues" and she hoped the government would maintain the economic reforms all through the elections next year. According to Marshall, the CG meeting extensively reviewed Zambia's macro-economy. The Bank also looked at ways of alleviating poverty and "a full range of governance issues in the light of the forthcoming elections" including the financing prospects for Zambia. The total financing needs of Zambia for 1996 were estimated at about US $750 million, assuming no new rescheduling takes place. But Zambia has already pushed in a request for debt rescheduling at the Paris Club meeting to take place in February 1996. The aid partners gave indications of over US$300 million in project and commodity support, but the rest of the funding was unclear on the remaining gap. Donors did not commit themselves on balance of payments support. "We have pledges of about US$335 million for balance of payments support but I must say that these are unconfirmed figures and we'll only know for sure at the Paris Club meeting. Altogether, we could have about $635 million combining project and commodity funds and balance of payments support but this again depends on the Paris Club," finance minister Ronald Penza said at the conference. Kathreen Marshall confirmed that the figures may change after the Paris Club meeting depending on the results of the meeting and the performance of the copper industry. However, the external aid partners emphasised the link between good governance, economic growth and improving the welfare of the Zambian people. World Bank officials said many donors were concerned about governance issues and urged the government to continue building an open and transparent system of government. In response, the Zambian delegation said it would maintain the move towards democratic change, including constitutional changes based on consensus. "We continue to practise the democracy we have implemented in the past four years. We liberalised the economy and because of this, we have managed to reduce our initial debt of about $7.2 billion to $6.3 billion. We have had very poor copper production over the last four years and this has not helped in closing the debt gap," Penza said. The meeting was attended by delegations from Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Japan, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden, the United Kingdom, the United States, the African Development Bank, the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa, the European Commission, the European Investment Bank, the Food and Agriculture Fund for Agricultural Development, the International Monetary Fund, the Saudi Fund for Development, the United Nations Children's Fund, the United Nations Development Programme and the World Food Programme.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Soccer: Zambia Wins Southern Africa Tourney


LENGTH: 440 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 18, 1995
by Reuben Tonga

Lusaka - Zambia edged South Africa 1-0 to retain the Confederation of Southern Africa Football Association (Cosafa) championship yesterday in Maseru, Lesotho. A 47th minute goal by Zanaco's Kelvin Kaindu was all Zambia needed to wrapup a week long competition that attracted eight countries.

It was a blow for the South Africans who were hoping for another win after their impressive run in the Africa club champion in which Orlando Pirates beat Asec of Ivory Coast on Saturday and the goalless draw between their senior squad and three time World Cup champions Germany. 

"Zambia missed a lot of scoring chances in the first half, I think we could have won by more than four goals, we really missed chances but thank God, we have won," said FIFA referee Kassie Kalande in an interview from Maseru.

Kaindu's efforts were rewarded after combining well with Shy Kumwenda and Davy Musole to tear apart the Bafana Bafana defence. In the third and fourth play-offs, hosts Lesotho beat Swaziland 3-1 in a game which was played as a curtain-raiser to the Zambia-South Africa final.

Zambia finished the tournament as the team with the highest number of goals, scoring 18 and letting in only one in the 1-1 draw against South Africa in a group B tie.

Meanwhile, the future of the competition has been thrown into disarray after two participating countries threatened to pull out.

The two, Mozambique and Namibia, accused tournament organisers of conniving with referees to rob them of victory. An angry Mozambican official said his country would have nothing to do with the competition in future. The Namibians also threatened to pull out because of alleged poor refereeing .

Mozambique's protest eminated from their 2-2 draw against Botswana. Leading 2-1 after 90 minutes the Lesotho referee surprisingly added 20 minutes of injury time. It was during this time that Botswana forced a last-gasp equaliser.

LANGUAGE: English

Africa News


December, 1995


Zambia Paris Club Donors Pledge $850m


LENGTH: 440 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 18, 1995
by Anthony Mukwita

Lusaka - Zambia's donors have given the country US $100 million more than finance minister Ronald Penza 'begged' for. In an interview yesterday at his Lusaka's Ibex Hill home, Penza said Zambia who initially asked for $750 million from Consultative Group Meeting, the Paris Club, will now get $850 million.

"This is a financial commitment by the donors for the financial year beginning 1996 until we go for another meeting next year,"a cigar puffing Penza said. "The only reason the donor community allowed us to over-subscribe is because we have lived up to their expectations, otherwise we would not have been treated this well." 

The money which will be given to Zambia according to Penza "includes debt relief and project relief together with commodity assistance which the donors have already agreed upon".

Penza also disclosed that the donor community expressed reservations at the manner in which the MMD government was going about with the adoption of the the constitution. "The donor community would rather see a more broad based method of adopting the constitution based on consensus and not power," he said.

He also revealed that the donor community would also love to see the government leave the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) to be autonomous in a bid to exercise good governance.

The Penza interview was from time to time disturbed by paramilitary police officers whom the minister had called in to throw out the Post reporter. "You had misrepresented facts when you recently reported that I was almost crying in parliament when I was asked about banks,"

Penza complained. "I am not happy with your paper's constant use of my picture whenever you run stories on Musa Siame and Africa Commercial Bank." Penza also disclosed that this is the first time Zambia is being allowed to IMF loans in eight years since the Kaunda era.

Africa News


December, 1995


Science, Medicine, and Technology Zambia British Ornithologist Still Missing


LENGTH: 520 words


 
The Post of Zambia (Lusaka)
December 18, 1995
by Kunda Mwila

Lusaka - British ornithologist Dylan Aspinwall is still missing and there has been no clue of his whereabouts for more than a month.

Both the police and family friends are considering increasing the reward for any one with information leading to the finding of Aspinwall from K1 million to K2 million.

"I hope and pray that the efforts of the Zambia Police and Aspinwall's friends will prove successful," said Paul Russell, a close friend of the missing person. 

But Force spokesperson Bartholomew Jere expressed worries on the disappearance of Aspinwall: "I am not trying to say he is dead but this is a third week since police and the man's family friends launched intensive investigations and searching but we have not obtained any information leading to the finding of Aspinwall so far."

Aspinwall, 53, a Lusaka resident for more than 30 years, went missing from his Chamba Valley home on November 8 when he left his 80-year-old mother to visit a shop.

He never returned and his Toyota Hilux vehicle he was driving was recovered in Rufunsa a week later. His mother has since returned to England.

According to Russell, who is also Anti-Corruption Commission director for human resource development, Aspinwall was expected home at lunchtime that day but he never returned.

Aspinwall is the current chairman for the Zambian Ornithological Society and was for many years a well known teacher at Munali Secondary School and school inspector before he resigned to concentrate on ornithology.

"Mr Aspinwall is a well known and respected man both locally and internationally because of his ornithological prowess. Prior to his disappearance, Aspinwall was working on a major ornithological atlas of Zambia," Russell said.

"I have received many calls from his former students and friends from all over the country expressing concern for Mr Aspinwall's safety," he added.

A former student, Emmanuel Katongo, said he was shocked to learn about Aspinwall's disappearance.

"He was a very good teacher of English and an entertaining man," Katongo said in an interview on Wednesday. And many teachers at Munali who worked closely with Aspinwall have expressed deep concern on his disappearance.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


171 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


AIDS Conference in Kampla


LENGTH: 920 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995

KAMPALA - Uganda last week hosted the ninth International conference on AIDS and STD in Africa.

The December 10-14 Conference in Kampala, the country's capital, was attended by about 3,000 government scientists and non-governmental organisations from over 100 countries who in one way or another are dealing with the Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndromes (AIDS).

In a statement ahead of the conference, the chairman of Uganda AIDS Commission Bishop Misaeri Kawuma of the (Anglican) Church of Uganda said the East African country had been chosen to host the big event because of its openness towards AIDS.

Bishop Kawuma said Ugandans, at least about 10 per cent of whom are believed to be infected with the HIV virus which causes AIDS, have suffered severely since the first HIV cases were discovered in the southwestern district of Rakai in the early 80s. 

"The greatest impact of AIDS is felt at the family and individual level... The big difference between AIDS and other epidemics is that AIDS affects the most productive groups who are responsible for support and care of others such as children, the elderly and extended family members especially in Africa."

Apart from Uganda, Africa, said to have some 10 million HIV victims was expected to benefit from the conference because the world meeting, whose theme was "AIDS-Hopes and Challenges" was expected to recommend an African AIDS policy.

"Appropriate research for intervention must be developed quickly... It is my hope that the conference will come out with... solutions for prevention of AIDS," Bishop Kawuma said in his statement before the conference began.

Addressing conference participants later, the chairman of Uganda AIDS Commission Bishop Misaeri Kawuma recommended sexual abstinence as the most viable way of fighting the deadly HIV virus.

He told delegates attending the Ninth International Conference on AIDS in Africa here; "AIDS is like the flood in Noah's days and unless people jump onto the ark, they will die... the ark is abstinence."

Shortly before the Kampala conference began, World Health Organisation Director for Africa, Dr. Ebrahim Samba singled out the Church in Africa as being responsible for the ineffectiveness of the global body's condom strategy against AIDS on the continent.

"They (religious leaders) believe that condoms will create promiscuity, but we must be realistic and accept human weakness exists, " Dr. Samba said.

But the head of the Catholic Community in this East African country Cardinal Emmanuel Wamala says the WHO condom strategy is unacceptable.

"It is like saying since murder and robbery are human weaknesses we should accept them," Cardinal Wamala said in an interview shortly before the AIDS conference began.

"Condoms are for loose people so by supplying them to our (Christians we are creating more AIDS", Cardinal Wamala, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Uganda cautioned.

The world AIDS conference, the first of its kind in Africa was expected to discuss several aspects of social behaviour on the continent whose generally conservative culture does not permit openness on sex and other social behavioral issues.

In his opening and welcome address on December 10, Uganda President Yoweri Museveni called on the industrialised nations to involve African scientists on an equal basis in their search for an AIDS cure.

The World Health Organisation Director Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima praised Uganda for starting what he called "the first National AIDS programme in Africa.

WHO officials say despite interventions like condoms, the AIDS scourge has not shown signs of abetting. A senior United Nations official told a press conference here that the global body has put aside US dollars 120 million for its worldwide AIDS programme.

Mrs. Sally Collar, said during the press conference that 60 per cent of the money will go towards AIDS programmes in African countries like Uganda which have pragmatic AIDS policies.

The UN official said United Nations International AIDS which starts its operations next January will coordinate a multi- sectoral AIDS approach in Africa.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


172 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Science, Medicine and Technology Attack Of Deadly Ebola Confirmed In Refugee


LENGTH: 587 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995

GOZON (IVORY COAST) - At least one Liberian refugee admitted to hospital in this Ivorian border village has been confirmed as having the deadly ebola virus while four other suspected cases are being studied.

The Geneva-based World Health Organisation (WHO ) said 25-year-old Jasper Choa crossed into Ivory Coast at the end of November to seek medical treatment and was diagnosed to have the virus following laboratory tests. The tests were done from his blood sample at the Institut Pasteur in Paris. He said he had left a sick friend in his home village of Plibo, Maryland County. 
Amid fears that the disease could spread like wild fires, the WHO hurriedly sent a team of medical experts into Liberia, where five years of civil war has made many remote areas virtually inaccessible. The area is controlled by Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia (NPFL), who granted the team permission.

A woman who lived in the same house as the confirmed case has been taken to Gozon and is being treated for similar symptoms. Reports say blood samples from two other suspected cases are being studied at Institut Pasteur in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, and results were expected by the time of going to press. All those affected lived in the same house.

The virus kills by causing massive bleeding. Early this year, an outbreak of ebola in the Zairean town of Kikwit claimed 244 lives.
Ebola has no known cure. WHO spokesman, Richard LeClair, is quoted as saying the Liberian outbreak appeared not to be as dangerous as Zaire's epidemic. He told reporters in Geneva: "Up to now we have had no deaths. The original case is recovering."

He added: "In this case, what we have found is that it does not seem as dangerous as the Kikwit epidemic because there is not as much haemorrhaging... It may not be the same type." A third man thought to have been contaminated is also being sought and medical experts hope to return to Liberia to check on the suspected cases. Last year, in Ivory Coast, a Swiss technician was reported to have contracted the disease but later recovered.

Meanwhile, in Liberia, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) intervention force, ECOMOG, was expected to begin deploying in rural areas under the control of warring factions on December 14, with or without money needed for logistics. Reports from Monrovia say the decision was made in the interest of peace for Liberia following delay in releasing funding for disarmament pledged by donors last October.

The troops deployment would include Maryland County, in the southeast, despite reports of an outbreak of ebola there. A ministry of Health team which flew into the area immediately the news broke quoted local people as saying about 20 people have died of diseases in the area in the last one month but there was no evidence to trace the deaths to ebola.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


173 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Angola Catholic Media Set To Return


LENGTH: 814 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995

LISBON - The Roman Catholic Church in Angola is preparing to relaunch a radio station, and possibly a newspaper, 20 years after independence from Portugal, the bishop of Lubango said here December 12.

Monseigneur Manuel Franklin da Costa, who is visiting Portugal, said Radio Ecclesia would resume broadcasts from January, starting in the Luanda city area, with coverage to extend across the war-ravaged nation from March.

"It is very important that Radio Ecclesia go on the air and provide news with total impartiality... to help Angolans draw their own conclusions on what is happening in the country," he said.

Before 1975, when Angola was still a Portuguese colony, the radio used to operate 24 hours a day. 

The bishop also said that another fixture of colonial times, the Apostolado newspaper, may reappear next March. However it would be a monthly and not daily as before, he said.

"We are now rebuilding everything that was destroyed in the war," he said, referring to the civil war between the People's Liberation Movement of Angola (MPLA) and the national Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA).

"We hope to be able to do this because it is important for the Angolan people," Bishop Da Costa said. The bishop's announcement came amid fears that the ceasefire between Angola's warring factions was collapsing and that it would call the United Nations- brokered peace into question.

A UN report released in New York on December 11 said that the "repeated failure by both sides to honour their undertakings has cast doubt on the reality of that commitment" to the Lusaka peace accords signed by UNITA rebel leader Jonas Savimbi and President Jose Eduardo dos Santos more than a year ago.

"The government and UNITA must demonstrate through concrete action that they are indeed committed to peace and that they are ready to correct these negative factors. I urgently appeal to them to do so," UN Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said.

The UN Verification Mission (UNAVEM III) in Angola has designated 8,000 peacekeepers to make sure the truce is respected and that both UNITA and government troops lay down their weapons and merge into one national army.

Boutros-Ghali said he was pleased that the slow process of cantonment and demobilisation of the country's soldiers as called for in the accord, had "at last begun."

But he said several important tasks that should have been dealt with in the early stages of the peace process - release of prisoners, exchange of military information and the resolution of the issue of mercenaries - have not yet started.

"It is also unacceptable that violations of the ceasefire and military preparations, including mine-laying, still persist, a full year after the signing of the Lusaka Protocol," the UN chief said.

"Human rights abuses and restrictions on the free circulation of the population also continue. This unsatisfactory state of affairs is aggravated by recent propaganda attacks against the United Nations and threats to the safety and security of international personnel in Angola," Boutros-Ghali said.

New clashes between UNITA and the government troops over the weekend have raised fears that the truce could fall apart.

On December 10, following artillery attacks blamed on UNITA rebels on towns in the east, government officials warned there could be a "bloodbath" if the United Nations did not do something.

The two sides are clearly still vying for control over the mineralrich northern and eastern regions.

But so far, both have backed off from any large-scale military operations of the sort that marked the civil war, one of Africa's bloodiest, which erupted after Angola won independence from Portugal in 1975.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


174 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Sudan Group Proposes Peace Radio


LENGTH: 547 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995

KHARTOUM - The Horn of Africa Policy Group (HAPG), a forum of Canadian Churches and non-governmental organisations (NGOs) involved in policy initiatives for countries in the Horn, has called for the institution of certain measures to help the peace process in Sudan.

The forum which was convened as a working group earlier this year by the Inter-Church Coalition on Africa (ICCA), an affiliate of the Canadian Council of Churches proposes among other measures that pressure should be brought to bear on the different parties in the Sudan to ensure that peace, justice and human rights become a reality in that troubled country.

Following consultations with churches, business, labour, women's and political groups of Sudanese both within and outside Sudan, the HAPG also calls for the implementation of an international broadcast news mechanism that will beam radio news on a weekly basis into all of Sudan (not just the Christian South). 

The broadcast would give news about the course of the war, the cost of waging war and emphasize peace initiatives in Sudan. "Objective information puts pressure on leadership groups and provides hope for all peoples in Sudan working for a peaceful future."

The HAPG also challenges the Government of Sudan as well as the two leading guerrilla movements fighting in the south- the Sudan Peoples Liberation Army (SPLA) and the Southern Sudan Independence Movement (SSIM) to live up to their rhetoric on democracy and autonomy for non-military institutions in their areas of control.

Furthermore HAPG advocates fool proof observance by all countries of the European Union's Arms Embargo on Sudan. The group seeks to have this embargo extended to police, security and intelligence equipment and cooperation.

Since the HAPG rekindled the peace initiatives, the war in the South has reflared, with the SPLA reported in stronger military position in areas south of Juba and west of Torit, the latter town once their stronghold and headquarters.

A Ugandan correspondent Emmy Allio who has toured the war front with the SPLA says the guerrillas are hampered by lack of a bridge to cross Kit River, 60 kilometres south of Juba. The original permanent bridge was blown up by retreating Sudan government troops early November.

Allio who reports for Uganda's government-owned New Vision daily, witnessed hundreds of SPLA combatants sitting in their trenches south of Kit. "Several tanks pieces of artillery missiles mounted on motor vehicles and other support guns were strategically placed in tree shades," reports Allio.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


175 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Burundi Hutu Official And Son Murdered In Bujumbura


LENGTH: 1680 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995

BUJUMBURA - The Hutu head of Burundi's Welfare Institute and his four-year-old son were killed instantly when unknown assailants tossed a grenade inside their car over the weekend, climaxing the orgy of violence that has left more than 30 people dead in one week.

A Tutsi friend of Juvenal Manirambona, a former parliamentarian who had just been appointed to the post two weeks earlier, and who was also in the car, died of wounds soon after the attack on December 10.

In a communique published in Germany, the pro-Hutu organization "Burundi Buro" blamed "members of the Tutsi death squad, "without failure," for the attack.

On December 8, two people were reported killed and another injured in a similar grenade attack at a hospital clinic after a week of ethnic unrest which ended in a huge rally for peace.

Although none has claimed responsibility for the grenade attack, suspicion also centered on Tutsi extremists active in Bujumbura. 

Police said 26 people, 26 militia members and an old woman - had died in clashes earlier last week in the east of the capital, but diplomatic sources said the real death toll could be higher. Witnesses said hundreds of Hutu extremists, whom police said had come from Zaire had been involved in fighting.

Political or ethnic killings are common in Burundi, where the civil war pitting the Hutu majority against the Tutsi minority has claimed thousands of lives since the start of the year, according to the international aid group Medicins Sans Frontieres (MSF) - Doctors Without Borders.

On December 8, between 1,000 and 4,000 women, according to various sources, demonstrated in Bujumbura in a rally for peace and against violence.

The mayhem started on December 6 with heavy fighting in the mountains overlooking Bujumbura between the Tutsi-dominated security forces and Hutu militias which the gendarmerie said left some 20 people dead.

The gendarmerie said they slipped over the border from Zaire, where thousands of Burundian Hutus are living as refugees, travelling via Bihanga, 20 kilometres north of the capital.

Their targets had been the houses of Tutsis and moderate Hutus in the eastern suburb of Mutanga, the city's most luxurious neighbouring, where many government ministers and parliamentarians live, and the southern quarter of Kanyosah, the gendarmerie said.

Rumours had circulated on December 6 of a possible coup d'etat, with clashes around the residence of Hutu President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, who was in Paris, but these were discounted the following day as calm returned to the capital.

The 1993 assassination of president Melchior Ndadaye in a failed military putsch sparked fighting in which some 50,000 Burundians died, and continuous ethnic clashes and massacres since then have raised fears that Burundi will slide into full-scale civil war similar to that in neighbouring Rwanda last year, during which Hutu extremists killed between 500,000 and one million men, women and children before being defeated by a Tutsi rebel army made up mostly of men who had been living in neighbouring Uganda.

Hutus make up 85 per cent of Burundi's population -- the same percentage as in pre-war Rwanda -- but the armed forces, who have chased most Hutus out of Bujumbura, are almost exclusively Tutsi and are virtually independent.

Thousands of Hutus have fled the country, but Hutu militiamen carry out frequent attacks in the capital, withdrawing afterwards to the surrounding mountains.

An attack on a bus on December 6 in the northern suburb of Cibitoke by uniformed men was reported to have left eight people dead.

Meanwhile, the United States claimed on December 8 that 430 people, 90 per cent of them women and children, were massacred near Bujumbura on November 14, and urged the need to promote reconciliation in Burundi to end the ethnic violence.

State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said the massacre took place at Basarara, near the Burundi capital. At the same time, MSF also claimed on December 11 that some 40,000 people have been killed in ethnic unrest so far this year, 40 per cent of them women and children.

For every one person wounded in the violence, 10 are killed, most of them civilians, MSF spokesman Lucas Van den Broek told a news conference in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi.

"Over the past few weeks the situation has become even more critical. Violence is spiralling and the lack of interest from the international community is no longer acceptable," he added.

ARUSHA DECEMBER 19 - The Rwanda War Crimes Tribunal charged eight people with genocide on December 12, issuing its first indictments relating to last year's ethnic bloodbath that left between 500,000 and one million people dead, but did not name any of the suspects.

The clerk of the international tribunal, Dr. Andronico Adede of Kenya, said the indictments concerned massacres at four sites in Rwanda's southwestern Kibuye area between April and June 1994 during a bitter civil war.

"The indictments allege that this conspiracy (caused) literally the death of tens of thousands of men, women and children," most of them minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus, Adede said.

Five suspects were charged with genocide and crimes against humanity, while all eight were charged with conspiring to commit genocide. Other indictments were expected to follow shortly against suspects held in Belgium and Zambia, the head of the UN-appointed tribunal, South African judge Richard Goldstone said.

"Other key developments will follow shortly," he declared, and said that he is working on the basis of about 400 suspects, but stressed that their names were not drawn from lists of "criminals" some observers have attributed to the post-war regime.

"I intend to make an application on January 10 seeking the deferral of investigations involving four suspects currently being held by the Belgian authorities," he added.

Goldstone also said his office would begin mass grave exhumations in January in connection with the initial indictment. The chief prosecutor had stated last month that he would reveal the names of those charged on December 12, but after consultations, Navanethem Pillay, one of the six trial judges, ordered that identities should not be revealed until further notice. The South African judge said the tribunal did not want to make it easier for suspects to evade arrest.

Three lawyers attending the proceeding - a Belgian, an Ivorian and a Kenyan -- to represent exiled Rwandan Hutu refugees, said that to name those indicted would be tantamount to launching a political trial. Hundreds of potential suspects are sheltering among the refugees, many of them in Zaire, as well as among the refugee community in Kenya.

The tribunal was created by the UN Security Council in November 1994 and set up operations in Tanzania to try those charged with involvement in the ethnic carnage. Goldstone said a date for trials depended on the cooperation of the countries concerned, but the trial of suspects already in detention could begin between six and eight weeks after indictment.

Much of the genocide has been blamed on Rwandan Hutu extremists accused of embarking on revenge killings after the death of Hutu president Juvenal Habyarimana when his plane was shot down on April 6, 1994, also killing president Cyprien Ntaryamira of neighbouring Burundi.

The civil war ended in July 1994 when the Tutsi-dominated Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF) seized power in Kigali. More than two million Hutus -- about a quarter of the pre-war population -- fled to neighbouring countries and have refused to go home for fear of reprisals.

Troops of the RPF have also been accused of human rights violations, even of large-scale massacres, that according to some Rwandans are continuing. The charges, which have not been independently verified, have been denied by the Rwandan government.

The tribunal's mandate is restricted to crimes committed between January 1 and December 31, 1994.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


176 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Rwanda AID Agencies Expelled As Dispute With UN Continues


LENGTH: 827 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995

KIGALI - Rwanda is expelling 38 Non-Governmental Organisations (NGOs) because they have "failed in their mission," the country's Rehabilitation Ministry announced December 6.

Several key French organisations, including the Medecins sans Frontieres (MSF) medical aid agency, and Aide Internationale Contre la Faim (AICF)/International Aid Agency against Hunger) were on the list of groups ordered to quit the country.

The ministry said the NGOs had displayed a "lack of experience" and failed "to adapt to the criteria necessary for an intervention in Rwanda," and further accused some of the agencies of "not obeying the rules" set by the Rwandan authorities. 

And 18 other NGOs have been told to "provisionally suspend" their activities while their cases were being examined, leaving another 102 accredited bodies to continue their activities normally, the ministry added.

Among the more serious cases, the ministry specified, some agencies had "abandoned children in orphanages" or "sold food intended as humanitarian aid on the open market."

Rwanda is still in the process of recovery from a genocidal civil war which left between 500,000 and one million people dead in a three- month period last year.

The Kigali regime, dominated by former rebels of the Rwandan Patriotic Front (RPF), has recently increased its criticism of France for its support of the former Hutu regime of Juvenal Habyarimana and also voiced increasing hostility to French policies in the region.

However, the Rehabilitation Ministry said its decision had not been motivated by political considerations.

The expulsions come amid an eruption of a major dispute between the Rwandan government and the United Nations over the role of UN peacekeepers in the tiny war-torn central African nation.

On December 9, the Rwandan government threatened to terminate the mandate of the UN peacekeeping force operating in the country if the UN Security Council refuses to reduce its troop strength and insists on maintaining the strength of the force above 1,400 men, the government-owned Rwanda Radio said.

The mandate of the UN Assistance Mission in Rwanda (UNAMIR) - which was due to end at midnight on December 8, was saved in last-minute discussions at the UN Security Council in New York.

An extension until December 12 brought diplomats at the UN another few days to work out how many UN peacekeepers should remain. UN planners believe that the organisation cannot maintain an effective force below a minimum of 1,400 men from its more than 2,000 peacekeepers currently serving in Rwanda.

The Tutsi-dominated government has an uneasy relationship with UN peacekeepers in the country since they watched powerlessly as more than 500,000 Tutsis and moderate Hutus were massacred by extremists from the Hutu majority during the 1994 civil war. The war ended with the Tutsi-led Rwandan Patriotic Front seizing power in July last year.

Diplomats at the UN in New York will be hoping to reach a compromise on a revised mandate with the government before the new deadline ends on December 19.

In another development, Rwanda's former intelligence chief has accused his home government of slaughtering more than 300,000 Hutus in the last civil war. "I accuse the RPF of crimes of genocide against the ethnic Hutu population, and of ethnic cleansing and I am calling for an urgent inquiry," Sixbert Musangamfura said in a statement released in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi.

Former Prime Minister Faustin Twagiramungu made a similar accusation last month, but both were denied by Rwandan President Pasteur Bizimungu.

Musangamfura, like the former premier, had worked with the new government up to last August.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


177 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Egypt President Appoints Christians To Parliament


LENGTH: 640 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995

Cairo - Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak named six Coptic Christians to Egypt's new parliament on December 11 after their community failed to win a seat in general elections, the official Middle East News Agency (MENA) said.

Following the two-round legislative vote for 444 seats completed on December 6, Mubarak appointed 10 more deputies to the People's Assembly. His ruling party won 416 seats in an election plagued by violence and charges of fraud. Only 14 opposition members took seats, while the remaining 14 were taken by independents. 

The president's appointments were all pro-government figures, including three women, two of them Coptic Christians and the other a Muslim. Five other women won contested seats in the election, bringing the total in the new parliament to eight, two less than the outgoing body.

The president traditionally uses his appointments to give seats to women and Christians, who rarely win in the general elections. Some 25 Christians ran in the latest polls but none won seats. Coptic Patriarch Pope Shenuda III criticised the ruling National Democratic Party for not entering a single Christian candidate in the race. Officially, Christians make up around 10 per cent of the country's 50 million-plus population.

Opposition and human rights groups accused the government of massive fraud during the vote and have called for fresh elections under international supervision.

On December 10, Egypt's top administrative court postponed until December 18 a ruling on whether to cancel vote results in almost a quarter of seats won in the newly-elected parliament because of alleged fraud. More than 100 appeals were lodged against the results of two rounds of elections held on November 29 and December 6, citing vote rigging.

Opposition parties and human rights groups had called for the dissolution of parliament and the holding of new elections, saying the government used vote rigging to bar them from the assembly. But legal sources said the court was likely to pass judgement that only parliament itself has the right to rule on the legality of its elections.

The Centre for Human Rights Legal Aid (CHRLA) also condemned in its report widespread fraud by police and the state during the two rounds of voting, saying it meant "the destruction of the democratic system".Opposition and rights groups have called for a new election, blaming fraud for the crushing victory of the NDP.

The CHRLA called the NDP majority "illogical", saying the results "reflect the government's refusal of the principle of peaceful disagreement with it and of the people's right to remove the standing government. The group also called for a new law giving the supreme court the right to decide appeals against elections, since legal scholars now generally put that right in the hands of parliament itself.

"A parliament which has such a sweeping majority of the ruling party cannot be expected to decide on the legitimacy of its members in an independent and impartial way," the CHRLA said.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


178 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Nigeria Anglican Leaer Asks Abacha To Step Down


LENGTH: 1000 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995

LAGOS - The head of the Anglican Church in Nigeria on December 11 called on the country's military ruler General Sani Abacha to step down and hand over power to the jailed opposition leader Chief Moshood Abiola.

The call from Rev. Joseph Abiodun Adetiloye was made in response to a statement in which military ruler Abacha reportedly said that neither the Nigerian people nor external pressure could force his government out of power.

"Power belongs to God alone. He gives it out and takes it back at His pleasure," reminded Adetiloye. 

In a highly critical letter published here by the independent Guardian newspaper, the cleric urged Abacha's regime to abandon its three-year transition programme towards democracy and install Chief Abiola in power instead.

Abiola, a Muslim millionaire businessman, is presumed to have won a presidential election held on June 12, 1993, and later annulled by the military and is currently being detained on charges of treason.

Adetiloye said that if the regime was "anxious....not to be disgraced out of office, it must forget its three-year transition programme."

Last October 1, General Abacha announced a transition programme that is scheduled to culminate in the military handing over power to an elected president on October 1, 1998.

All lovers of peace in Nigeria should urge Western powers for a "Camp David" or "Lancaster House type" conference which should lead to the withdrawal of the military and installation of a national government, headed by Chief Abiola, without further delay.

The Camp David Accord, signed in 1978, was the prelude to the peace accord between Israel and Egypt while conferences at Lancaster House in London led to the independence of Nigeria in 1960, Kenya in 1963 and that of Zimbabwe in 1980. All the steps Abacha has taken so far, are "like those of the captain of a sinking ship. These panicky measures impress no one, but himself," Adetiloye added. The Anglican church head, a prominent and respected religious leader in the country, has in the past year written several letters to the military authorities urging them to quit power and install Chief Abiola.

Adetiloye's outbursts against the Nigerian military came as human rights and minority groups in Nigeria declared Sunday, December 10, the United Nations Human Rights Day, a day of mourning for Ken Saro-Wiwa and his eight executed companions.The Organisation for the Protection of the Niger Delta from Environmental and Allied Degradation (OPNEAD) said that the struggle for which Saro-Wiwa, a writer, and his colleagues were executed on November 10 in Port Harcourt, capital of the southern Rivers State, would continue.

In a statement received here on December 10, the OPNEAD said that it had lined up a week-long programme, beginning December 10 with a 'stay-at-home' action by all peace-loving people of the Niger Delta area to mourn those executed.

Ken Saro-Wiwa was the president of the Movement for the Survival of Ogoni People (MOSOP), a body fighting against marginalisation of the oil-rich Ogoni community and destruction of its eco-system by foreign oil companies, particularly Shell.
A peaceful demonstration was scheduled for December 11 in all the major cities in the Niger Delta area, while on December 16, a ceremony to mark the "mock suspension" of oil exploration and exploitation in the area would be organised in Bonny, one of the main cities in Rivers State, according to the text.

The organisation also called for "urgent" imposition of an oil embargo on Nigeria in protest against the executions, which triggered a flurry of local and international condemnations and sanctions.

The Southern Minorities Movement, a body which claims to represent minorities in five oil-producing states of Nigeria, also set aside December 10 as a day of mourning by indigenous people of these states for Saro-Wiwa and his companions.

The Committee for the Defence of Human Rights (CDHR), in a statement, urged Nigerians to use World Human Rights Day to "rededicate ourselves for the struggle for the termination of military rule at all cost" following the military's "unprecedented violations" of the economic, social, political and cultural rights of Nigerians.

The statement signed by the body's secretary-general, Jiti Ogunye, urged the UN to use its December 11 session on Nigeria to enjoin its member-nations to impose oil, arms, trade and sports embargoes on this West African country and visa restriction on all military officers and their relations.

Following the executions, the Commonwealth suspended Nigeria from its fold while the United States and European Union clamped arms embargoes on Nigeria.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English

179 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Ethiopia No Trees For Christmas Among Ethiopian Christians


LENGTH: 840 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995

Addis Ababa - As Santa Claus rides in a reindeer through the snow in a one horse open sleigh to deliver dainties in the night and slip them under the mistletoe in the North, some parts of Africa will fell trees by the numbers and adorn them with snow-balls and small lights. Everyone will know it is Christmas. The Christmas tree tradition has over the years become an integral part of the end-of-year decoration euphoria in many parts of the world. But in Ethiopia, where 90 per cent of the population is Christian and is affiliated mainly to the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, conservation of trees particularly at this time of the year is an important issue. 

At a time when Ethiopia's Transitional Government is completely pre-occupied with putting up political structures towards a favourable Federal State, environment and development issues are shelved for a later time.

It is with the aim of filling this gap that Lem, a Non-Governmental Organisation has prioritised working on environmental resource conservation. Lem facilitates discussions among 350 high school clubs and 250 peasant farmers' associations, and acts as partners with these groups.

"We realised in our operations as a network that an important entry-point to community outreach is the Ethiopian Orthodox Church," says Asseged Bezabih a Programme Coordinator with Lem. Ethiopia records centuries of the Christian tradition. Monasteries and churches, 30,000 of them in all, have promoted the protection of trees mainly through strict adherence to planting of dense woods around the Church throughout the years. The practice has been a combination of Christian beliefs and elements of traditional African cultures.

Traditionally, the Ethiopian Orthodox Church holds to an uncompromising belief that a church or monastery must be heavily surrounded by trees. All churches must also have graveyards to bury members and these are used for purposes of conservation of nature.

In many cases, the Church easily acquires permission from the Government to extend its own acreage owing to respect and fear of God and priesthood. Lem has assisted in expanding the wooded areas by having the priests ask for government support for more land and thus extension of forests.

According to Mr. Bezabih, this practice favours conservation of species of trees and brush that would have long ago gone extinct. It is attributed to the priests who have played a great role in ensuring trees' preservation.

"No one is allowed to touch trees surrounding a church or a monastery." Says Mr. Bezabih. He adds that forests have been preserved as a result of a belief that the angel of the Church resides there and are therefore sacred. This belief parallels the sacred groves depicted in many African traditional cultures. Trees are thus revered and at this time of the year, priests remind Ethiopians through the media not to cut them for Christmas because it is not a biblically-oriented practice. "Nowhere in the Bible does it say that to remember the birth of Jesus Christ, one must have decorated trees in the Church or in the home," says Rahel, also a member of Lem.

The activities of Lem in this regard are an important step to the on-going disappearance of world's forests. According to data provided by a United Nations environmental statistician, Thomas Mpofu during a workshop in Harare Zimbabwe recently, forests are disappearing at an alarming rate of between 14 million and 20 million hectares a year.

The greatest losses that account for up to 62 per cent are taking place in dryland south of the Sahara, as well as in East and South- East Africa. At least 60,000 of the approximately 265,000 plant species in the world are in danger of extinction. Through involvement in church activities, Lem disseminates environment and development related information to members, an activity that is sanctioned by the priesthood. During church meetings, issues of importance to the members are raised and these have become useful fora for discussion of environmental concerns. The 4,000-member network spreads out all over Ethiopia and is planning an outreach programme for the non-Christian community.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


180 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large A Meetign With An Indigenous African Church


LENGTH: 1360 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995
by John Wafula

Nairobi - The African Church of the Holy Spirit (ACOHS) is a church with a difference. Not only does time cease to exist when the motto of the church, the "Spirit and the Bible", grips adherents but the day's agenda also joins the list of dispensable appendages.

And with heel-long white flowing robes, white turbans which often conceal waist-long dreadlocks, and symbolic red crosses on their robes, African Church of the Holy Spirit faithful are a sight to behold for any first time visitor.

The Church has more surprises in store. Its prayer sessions sometimes last upto three hours, with the congregation liberally talking in tongues, singing hilariously and dancing energetically "for the Lord". "One does not need to go to a disco after our evening prayer meetings," joked Gilbert Lijina, 28. 

Lijina, a primary school teacher in western Kenya where the ACOHS has its headquarters at Lugala, some 450 kilometers north-western of Nairobi has been a member of the church from childhood. "I can't remember when I joined the church. But I must have been very young, my mother brought me," he says.

Like most other adherents when "the spirit and Bible" motto is upon the church, Lijina abandons himself to the care of the Holy Spirit, talking in tongues, sometimes leaping high up in the air and often falling down and rolling on the ground. "I have never known this to hurt anyone," he told this writer.

He conceded he felt very calm afterwards. "A strange calmness like I were living in a different world. You can't understand until you allow the Holy Spirit to take control of your life," he said.

Lijina is quite sure that the Holy Spirit guides him on a daily basis. "I always feel the presence of God and the guiding hand of the Holy Spirit in whatever I do," he said. So does Enock Kanjie Mayo, 55. Mayo, a father of six who hails from Cheptuyiet, Nandi district in Kenya's Rift Valley Province said he joined ACOHS in 1965. He put it very clear that, "I will never leave this church." Why? "Because it is a compass for my life. Without it I would not know how to live, I would not even care to live," he told APS.

Kanjie admits that he often encounters problems from people who do not understand his devotion to guidance by the Holy Spirit. "My elder brother makes cruel jokes about me always. He often refers to me as a mad man and pointing to my turban greets me; Goodmorning old woman."

Is Kanjie bitter with his brother? " Not at all. He does not know what he says, he does not what he is living for and so I always forgive him," explained Kanjie philosophically.
The only time Kanjie has been to hospital since he joined the ACOHS 30 years ago was when he was forcibly dragged there by the police in 1970 after some machine he was working on almost severed his thumb. "But I ran away after only two days." And showing a well healed thumb for all to see he adds, "through prayer, the thumb healed very fast."

Perhaps where the Africa Church of the Holy Spirit locks horns with its critics is on its stand on medical treatment. Founders of the ACOHS openly disapproved of hospital visits. However, today the church is of a different opinion. Said High Priest Hezekiah Timothy Shitsimi; "In earlier days members were not allowed by the Holy Spirit to go to hospital but relied on faith in the Lord to cure any disease. Today, members weaker in faith are allowed to seek medical care."

High Priest Shitsimi, a father of five sons and grandfather to 15, says he has never been to hospital for treatment since he joined the church some 44 years ago. "Not that I have not been ill all these years, all I do when I become sick is entrust my sickness to God through prayer," he told this writer. The church has a group of elders who pray for people and lay hands on them in such difficult circumstances as during illness.

High Priest Shitsimi, like his church, is a most striking personality. He wears a well kept beard and says he has not shaved his hair since 1951. With his flowing white and red gown carrying his ramrod straight bearing and cross-shaped staff, Shitsimi bears an uneasy resemblance to prophets of the Old Testament. Yet his church is sharply both old and modern. Its spacious building at the Lugala Headquarters in Western Kenya measures upto other modern churches the world over. Yet it has no pews save a few seats reserved for the leadership of the church. The pulpit is out of bounds for the laity and parallel lines running across the length of the church clearly divide male adherents from their female counterparts.

Worshippers leave their shoes outside the church because "the church is a holy place. The Holy Spirit showed founders ways of worship, different from the established Friends Church, (Quakers)" said High Priest Shitsimi. This apparently includes an allowance of 30 minutes or so for people to report their revelations after prayer sessions.

African Church of the Holy Spirit has a membership of 500,000 followers spread across the three East African countries of Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania. One of the earliest African Independent Churches, ACOHS broke away from the Quakers in 1927 and has since kept growing.

To outsiders ACOHS has a number of other surprises. There is no baptism by water, only by acceptance and the Holy Spirit. Rings and elaborate (expensive) gowns are no requirements for the solemnizing of weddings for example.

Speaking of wedding rings, Shitsimi described the bands as "things of this world. They do not bind a marriage. A willing bride, a willing bridegroom and God's hand are all it takes to sustain a living marriage."

Yet the church is as forward-looking and gender sensitive as any other modern church. Shitsimi is very hopeful that sponsors will be found to help educate ACOHS's clergy. The church, with assistance from the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK) is training two ladies in Bachelor of Divinity courses at the St. Paul's United Theological College in Nairobi. Locally, the ACOHS is a member of the NCCK and on the global level a member of the Geneva-based World Council of Churches (WCC).

Rev. Pastor John Akhura, who obtained his Bachelor of Divinity degree from the St. Paul's College insisted that ACOHS "is as progressive as any other church today." Referring to ACOHS as "a charismatic church that recognises the Holy Spirit, he noted that the church, like any other, is changing with the times. "However, like any other reputable church, we are trying very hard to keep our tradition too. Every church must have a tradition, an identity. When a church looses identity it becomes secular and has nothing original to offer its people," concluded Rev. Akhura.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


181 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Africa-at-Large Media: The Story About Ordinary Africa


LENGTH: 1067 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995
by APS Correspondent

Nairobi - One of the biggest problems with Western media reporting on Africa is the stereotyping of Africa as a continent of misery, Aids, perennial hunger and famines, military and parasitic governments.

In a practical approach to the problem of negative attitudes about Africa in the West, the Inter-Church coalition on Africa (ICCA), an affiliate of the Canadian Council of Churches has been working to sentitise American and Canadian editors, NGOs, church workers and others on how to avoid stereotyping Africa and thus improve the image of a continent that is dynamic but badly misrepresented in the West.

They have published a pamphlet guideline entitled Imaging Africa-A guideline for Fair and Just Representation on Africa, which is clear and concise on what should be done to overcome the problem.

Two Nairobi-based church organisations, All Africa Press Service, and the All Africa Conference of Churches (AACC) were associated with the production of these guidelines. The Southern Africa Research and Documentation Centre (SARDC) was also consulted in the formation. 

The pamphlet underscores that much of the news and information that Canadians and Americans receive about African countries today, consists of written and visual images of people who are hungry; people who are poor; people who are victims of injustice war, or violence or who are devastated by natural calamities like the Ebola virus.

But in a refreshing observation, the ICCA asserts: "Yet Africa in all its multi-national multi-cultural, multi-ethnic and multi- religious diversity, is so much more than this very limited portrayal suggests."

Conceding that suffering is part of the reality of African countries as indeed the rest of the world, the ICCA says this is not the total picture.

"To isolate and sensationalise the more violent and chaotic aspects of the events in African countries, as is often done, is to demean the dignity, self worth and resourcefullness of the people who live there."

There are numerous positive human qualities and traits that deserve to be affirmed. Stereotyping Africa assumes many forms. The inter-church coalition group has listed four most common errors that it would like corrected. Categorizing Africa as the homogenous continent, the group notes that People often speak about Africa as a single country and as if its people were of a single race and culture. Far from it. "The African continent is home to 53 countries each of which is diverse in terms of ethnicity, culture and religion. Every major racial grouping on earth is represented in Africa," says the ICCA.

nder coups and calamities, the ICCA says much of what is reported revolves around coups and calamities. The many success stories - dictators ousted through democratic means, ethnic conflicts resolved through peaceful indigenous mediation, local efforts to overcome poverty, for example - are more often than not ignored or down played.

Turning to the assumption of inferiority, the coalition group notes that one common message implicit in many news reports in various forms of advertising is that Africans are inferior to people in the West, and dependent on Western handouts. Sadly this assumption is found even in well meaning attempts by charitable organisations to raise funds for their relief and development work in Africa. "Emotionally charged images of starving children may help raise money but often they obscure the underlying causes of hunger and poverty and foster patronising stereotype of Africans as helplessly dependent on Western aid and support."

The ICCA believes emergency relief is important. However the group is of the opinion that the prime target of Western largesse "should be exposing and addressing the root causes of, rather than seeking temporary solutions to problems that require long term care and attention to heal."

Further, the church-coalition group describes the "Primitive African" as the common tendency in Western documentary news and popular cultural expression to portray African life as primitive. It says this tendency thrives today "and results in Africans being seen as barbarians or naive children frozen in pre-modern conditions." The effect of this approach is to demean African cultural traditions "which are no less valid than the traditions of people of European or other heritage."

ICCA says no simple formula exists to guarantee the fair and just representation of African people and events. Some of the guidelines are here summarised; Coverage of African events needs to be broadened and increased; One third of the world's population is in Africa; There are usually extenuating circumstances underlying the outbreak of wars and famines in Africa. It is not all due to "tribal rivalries" and may infact have their roots in colonialism and global policies of northern countries; News media should balance reporting on Africa because there are many success stories to be found; News media should make better use of African sources of news and information and seek an African interpretation of African events.

For NGOs that rely on images of hungry and poor Africans to raise funds, it is important to explore alternate fund raising appeals that affirm and preserve the dignity of Africans.


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.


182 of 216 DOCUMENTS


Africa News


December, 1995


Tanzania Celebrating An African Christmas


LENGTH: 1120 words


 
All Africa Press Service
December 19, 1995
by Sam Gonza

Nairobi - Throughout Africa south of the Sahara, the desert strip that separates the predominantly Muslim North from the largely Christian South, Christmas is a delightful period of celebration with colour dance, song, meals and prayer. Even in war ravaged Southern Sudan where people do with incredibly meagre resources, many Christians start to prepare for Christmas several weeks in advance.

Besides bringing hope to people in Africa, like a rejuvenation before the New Year, the Christmas season is also the best example of inculturated Gospel in action, says Father Joseph Healey, 58, a Maryknoll Missioner from Detroit, Michigan, who first came to Africa in the late fifties. Well versed in African traditions and the way African culture relates to the Gospel, he is the author of the metaphorically titled The Fifth Gospel a compiled narrative on how God continues to reveal Himself in the local environment in Africa. 

Through his study of African traditions, cultural practices, proverbs, oral literature and song, Fr. Healey has become convinced that inculturating the Gospel - rendering the Good News of Jesus Christ in an African idiom - is the best way forward in evangelising the continent in the millennium and beyond.
The Pope himself, during his tour of Africa last September, called Africa the continent of the future. He made a strong plea to African Bishops to pursue the challenge of inculturating the Gospel with vigour. "Jesus Christ Himself is an African..."

Healey asserts again: "The way people in Africa take their local symbols and songs and incorporate them into the Christmas liturgy and celebration is just wonderful." He tells the story of his own experiences among the Kuria ethnic group of Musoma Diocese in northwestern Tanzania, a story he has incorporated in his forthcoming book, "I Pointed Out the Stars."

In your imagination, travel to Kiagata Parish in Musoma Diocese. Three days before Christmas, an African Christmas Hut (the traditional Christmas Crib in the form of a small African Hut) is prepared in the sanctuary of the church. Within this small African Hut, figurines of tall shepherds with their cows and sheep portray a pastoral scene that is close to the hearts of the rural farming community in Kiagata. Bright red, green and yellow African cloths hang from the ceiling. Long cords hold rows of pictures and cards (much as in the West). On Christmas eve afternoon, the carved figures of Mary and Joseph are placed in the open hut, "tired" after their long journey from Nazareth.

The Christmas liturgy begins at 9 p.m. (Christmas eve). The priest reads the Gospel of Luke in Swahili (the principal lingua franca in East Africa). "She gave birth to her first born son and wrapped him in bands of cloth and laid him in a manger, because there was no place for him in the inn." The priest stops.
In a small procession with candles, an altar boy reverently carries the carved figure of the infant Jesus and places him in the manger. There is no electricity in the church, but the flickering candles dramatically highlight the manger scene.

Then a wave of singing clapping and drumming reverberates through the church. From the back of the church, a group of men and women of the Kuria tribe rhythmically dance forward to the beat of shakers and drums. Healey says the song they sing "We Come to the Home of the Child" is their traditional song, which they have always sung from time immemorial to welcome a new born baby in the village. As they dance in front of the African Christmas Hut the women and girls trill with joy. A sea of trilling and joyful excitement sweeps through the whole church.

After the singing and dancing, the priest finishes reading the Gospel and they all sing a popular Swahili version of the Christmas song. "The Lord Jesus Christ Has Been Born. It is Certain." A Christmas pageant play can be performed after the second reading, after the Gospel, or after the night Eucharist itself.

There is a Swahili saying Children are a blessing. Healey explains that children are a new life, a great value in African society. "A mother giving birth is a joyful community event. There is an African custom of visiting the newborn infant in his or her home. Visitors bring gifts of money, flour, soap and eggs. As a religious parallel, Christians visit the African Christmas Hut in Church and leave a small donation to honour the Christ Child."
In Mathew's Gospel, the Maggi offer the Christ Child gold, frankincense and myrrh which are symbols of wealth and divine worship in the Middle East culture. But what symbols would African people choose?

A catechist of the Logir ethnic group in Torit Diocese of southern Sudan says the gifts would be a goat which is a symbol of royalty and wealth, a spear which is a symbol of defence and healing and a small flexible stick which is the symbol of power. The Ganda people of Uganda would give the Christ Child a drum which is the symbol of kingship and authority, a spear which is the symbol of defence and protection and a bark cloth (a coarse deep brown fabric crafted traditionally from the bark of certain trees) which is a symbol of royal investiture.
The Kuria people would give a goat for the mother, flour for food and ghee (from milk) to shine up the baby. Observes Healey: "In African tradition it is very important to give a special gift to the mother of Jesus."


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 1996


LANGUAGE: English


Copyright 1995 AllAfrica, Inc.

December, 1995


Tunisia World Bank Aides Sees Good Progress on Privatization


LENGTH: 186 words


 
Tunisian Press Agency
December 19, 1995

Tunis - In an interview published on December 16th, 1995 by French-language daily "La Presse", Daniel Ritchie, World Bank director for the Maghreb region, spoke optimistically of Tunisia's chances for successful privatization.

Mr. Ritchie said that "there is a good chance that the private sector in Tunisia will be able to play its assigned role," for example insuring better performance in the banking sector.

Tunisia is fully capable of adjusting to the creation of a free-trade zone with Europe in 12 years, added Mr. Ritchie, who noted that only 8 to 10% of Tunisia's workforce will need retraining, a figure which is insignificant in comparison with that of other countries.

Business General Electric To Build Tunisian Power Plant


LENGTH: 187 words


 
Tunisian Press Agency
December 19, 1995

Tunis - A contract for construction of a new power station in Bir M'Chergua, near the city of Zaghouan (south of Tunis) has been concluded between Tunisia's national electricity and gas company (STEG) and the U.S. company General Electric International Inc. (GEII), it was announced in Tunis on December 15. 

The contract was signed by STEG's chairman and managing director Moncef Ben Abdallah, and by Mr James Fitzgibbons, GEII's director for Africa and the Middle East.

The Bir M'Chergua power station will cost some 80 million dollars and generate 240 megawatt (MW) production capacity. The two new 120-MW gas turbines will raise STEG's installed capacity to 1810 MW.

United States and Africa U.S. Official Visits Tunis for Top Level Talks


LENGTH: 320 words


 
Tunisian Press Agency
December 19, 1995

Tunis - President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali received on Thursday, December 14, U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for Middle Eastern Affairs Robert Pelletreau, Jr.,

The senior US diplomat described his meeting with the Tunisian president as "especially productive and fruitful." He added that the meeting had provided an occasion to examine bilateral relations, developments in the region, and the Middle East peace process. Mr. Pelletreau added that the "excellent" relations between Tunisia and the United States are based on "strong common interests " as well as on "trust, cooperation and common purpose." "We are continuously working to consolidate the relations of friendship and cooperation between the two countries in all fields," he said.

Speaking at a press conference at the end of his two-day visit, Mr. Pelletreau declared that, "the Tunisia of today is strong, stable and economically healthy," and added that Tunisian-U.S. relations had "matured and become more complex and multi-faceted." He expressed satisfaction at Tunisia's support for the Peace Process and the agreement on Bosnia, and his country's appreciation for Tunisia's "policies of economic liberalization, political enlargement and respect for human rights and the rule of law at home".

Mr. Pelletreau stressed that U.S. fully intends to promote trade exchange and investment between the two countries.

Tunisia Child Vaccination Reaches Most Under Fives


LENGTH: 146 words


 
Tunisian Press Agency
December 19, 1995

Tunis - President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali was briefed on Tuesday, December 12, by Dr. Hedi M'henni, minister of public health, on the results of the national poliomyelitis vaccination campaign. Targeting children under the age of 5, the campaign reached nearly two million children.

Since 1979, Tunisia has pursued a national vaccination program aimed at eliminating tuberculosis, diphtheria, tetanus, whooping cough, poliomyelitis, measles, and more recently hepatitis B. The vaccination rate among children under the age of 5 is between 90 and 96 percent.
